PROCTEXT.PARA: Madam SPEAKER (Hon. Joan Child) took the chair at 10 a.m., and read prayers.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Hunt The Hon R.J.D.

TALK.START.PARA: —I move:

SPEECH.PARA: That so much of the Standing Orders be suspended as would prevent the Deputy Leader of the National Party of Australia moving forthwith a motion to disallow the amendment to the Export Control (Orders) Regulations as contained in Order 1986 No. 2, made under the Export Control Act 1982 which vests discretion (a) in the Secretary of the Department or his nominee not to provide inspection services to designated primary export industries and (b) in the Minister to direct the Secretary of the Department to make a particular decision.

I have moved this motion to enable the Parliament to debate a motion to disallow an attempt by the Minister for Primary Industry (Mr Kerin) and the Government to run away from their responsibilities in the face of union standover tactics affecting the Australian meat industry. Mudginberri is a watershed for union power in Australia. This union-dominated Government is doing everything in its power to ensure that the Australian Council of Trade Unions is entrenched on the treasury benches of this country.

It is an outrage that the Minister should seek to give himself a discretion, instead of an obligation, to satisfy the Australian Government's constitutional export powers and the responsibilities for export authority. It is a constitutional responsibility. The export powers in the Constitution are quite clear. Yet the Minister seeks to give himself a discretion, rather than an obligation, to uphold the constitutional and legislative responsibility of his portfolio. Every member of the Parliament should be aware of the dereliction of duty and the attempt to transfer the Government's authority and power to unions which are prepared to use blackmail to achieve their objectives.

Four critical issues are at stake. The first is the capacity of a government to provide essential services which it must, by law, provide. The second is the capacity of a government to act independently of the commands and power of the ACTU. The third is the freedom of the individual Australian worker to negotiate his own conditions of employment outside the direct involvement of the unions. The fourth is the freedom of Australian industries to conduct their business free of government and trade union domination. Few actions taken by this Government have exposed the weak underbelly of the Hawke Labor Government more than this action has. Few actions that this Government has taken have demonstrated more the extent to which the Government has been dominated by the trade union movement since it came to office. It has virtually entrenched the ACTU and the Australasian Meat Industry Employees Union on the treasury benches of this country.

The Minister is derelict in carrying out his duty. The Federal Court of Australia and the High Court of Australia have indicated that the Minister had an obligation to provide Commonwealth meat inspectors at Mudginberri and that he did not exercise that obligation or duty. As a result of the Biloela debacle last month the Minister is seeking approval by this Parliament to the giving to him of a discretion rather than for him to have the obligation to carry out a constitutional and legal responsibility. I do not think there has ever been a regulation or piece of legislation before this Parliament that has exposed more the gutlessness of this Government when it comes to exercising its responsibility in government.

We all know what happened at Mudginberri when Mr Pendarvis, perhaps one of the most courageous employers in this country-a courageous and fair employer-was prepared to negotiate with his employees an arrangement that was condoned by the Australian Conciliation and Arbitration Commission to provide to those employees twice the amount of money, as a result of that agreement, that they could have earned under an award.

TALK.START.PARA: —How many jobs were lost?

—There were no jobs lost. There were productivity gains. Then, of course, what happened? As soon as the dispute started, the Commonwealth meat inspectors were moved to Jabiru and then a picket was set up by the Australasian Meat Industry Employees Union and was left in place for months. No Commonwealth export inspection service was available on the spot to carry out the legal obligation of the Government, the export inspection service and the Minister. The Minister having been derelict in his duty and the Government having been derelict in its duty, we are now witnessing an attempt to remove the obligation from the Minister by regulation.

SPEECH.PARA: In the 17 years I have been in this Parliament I have not seen a worse attempt by a Government to remove from a Minister his legal obligation to carry out export powers and export responsibilities that are vested in the Government and the Commonwealth of Australia by the Constitution. I think it is an outrage. However the Government might try to paint the picture, there is not the slightest doubt-

TALK.START.PARA: —By way of assisting the House, I indicate that no opportunity was taken to let the Minister know that this motion was going to be moved, but we now have some knowledge of this matter and the Government will agree to the suspension of Standing Orders, so that the honourable member for Gwydir can proceed with his motion.
—Is the motion seconded?

INTERJECT.SPEAKER: Mr N.A. Brown

TALK.START.PARA: —I second the motion.

INTERJECT.PARA: Question resolved in the affirmative with an absolute majority.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Hunt The Hon R.J.D.

TALK.START.PARA: —I move:

SPEECH.PARA: That the amendment to the Export Control (Orders) Regulations as contained in Order 1986 No. 2, made under the Export Control Act 1982, be disallowed.

The events at Mudginberri are a watershed for the trade union movement in Australia. I ask honourable members to listen very carefully to the reasons why the amendment to the Export Control (Orders) Regulations should be disallowed. I believe that there is and there must be an obligation-the Opposition firmly adheres to that belief-to carry out export inspection duties in accordance with constitutional and legal requirements. At a time when Australia is facing the worst balance of trade figures on record one would have thought that the Government would have done everything in its power to facilitate the movement of goods from abattoirs, farms, mines and factories at the most expeditious rate.

But this did not happen at Mudginberri. The Government and the unions have consistently ignored the fact that in this case the workers at Mudginberri entered into a negotiation with the owners of the Mudginberri abattoir which enabled those workers to earn twice as much as they would have earned under the award. That agreement was reached and given the approval of the Australian Conciliation and Arbitration Commission. Notwithstanding that situation, the Australasian Meat Industry Employees Union, because it was not involved in those negotiations, decided to sabotage the agreement. It did so by setting up a picket line defying the Commonwealth Government, the Minister for Primary Industry (Mr Kerin) and the Commonwealth Export Inspection Service in the provision of Commonwealth meat inspectors. They knew that unless Commonwealth meat inspectors were on site, there was no way that Mr Pendarvis would probably have the opportunity to export his goods. This has cost this proprietor millions of dollars. No doubt the union adopted this tactic in order to forestall any attempt by any other employer to enter into agreements outside the control, the supervision and the conduct of the union movement.

It is an outrage. It indicates the extent to which this country has fallen under union power and domination. No wonder this country is in the mess that it is. No wonder we have a national debt hitting $70 billion. No wonder we have a balance of trade deficit that will probably be $14 billion this year. It is an outrageous state of affairs that the Government should have attempted to walk away from its responsibility to provide Commonwealth meat inspection officers should there be an industrial dispute at an abattoir. Day by day, we are seeing this sort of thing happening in other ways in other places.

I think that it needs recording in this Parliament that Jay Pendarvis is one of the most courageous employers that this country has produced. He had the courage to offer his workers a productivity-based wages incentives scheme which has boosted enormously the output of his abattoir and, as I said earlier, had doubled his employee's earnings. A lesser man might have caved in to the meat employees union, but not Jay Pendarvis. His vindication came on 19 December when Mr Justice Bowen, Mr Justice Evatt, and Mr Justice Pincus of the Federal Court of Australia found that the director of this Government's export inspection service had not a discretion but an obligation to provide inspectors at the Mudginberri works. Of course, there was an appeal to the High Court of Australia which was dismissed or thrown out or not heard because the judges could not see any reason why it should be heard on 21 February this year.

The courts have highlighted the clear lawful requirements upon the Minister for PrimaryIndustry. He must provide export inspections as sought by abattoirs. What greater outrage could there have been in the light of the clear rule of law and a crystal clear court ruling for the Commonwealth Export Inspection Service to have once again failed in its responsibilities at Biloela last month. The hard heads of the Australian Council of Trade Unions have panicked at the thought that their grip on the Australian wage fixation system is not watertight. They have delivered their orders. They have pressured the meat works. They have attempted to ensure that there is never another Mudginberri case.

TALK.START.PARA: —There will be 1,000 more.

—But there will be other cases as time goes on. The events at Mudginberri will be repeated. The ACTU power brokers are on notice that Australians have had a gutful of their standover tactics. It is the riding orders of the ACTU that have led to the presentation of these Export Control (Orders) Regulations before the Parliament at present. There has been no fanfare or explanation to the Parliament. More than five weeks ago, the Minister did foreshadow that the rules would probably change but he never attempted, and nor has he done so right now, to justify the changes.
—How could he justify that?

—He could not. He was wise enough to realise that. I hope that this is not the Minister's doing. I imagine that the Minister has been so pliable in Cabinet on so many occasions that he has been stood over by those people who have only one loyalty, and that is loyalty to the union movement.

SPEECH.PARA: These regulations are nothing more than an attempt to change the rules now that the Minister has lost the umpire's decision. He wants an out to avoid the chance of a full-blown confrontation between the law of this nation and the constitutional responsibility that he bears and the union leaders who consider themselves above the law. The Opposition is determined that the Minister will not get his cop out. Today must be the day when he stops running and stands to face his responsibilities and the responsibilities of his portfolio. The Parliament must not allow itself to crumble in the face of this ACTU attack.

The Minister says that ministerial discretion is necessary to protect what he calls the national interest. On 6 February, I publicly suggested that he define what he means by public interest. I have not seen such a reply. It is nonsense to compare export inspection services with the activities of Australia Post, the railways or shipping and to claim that, because Acts covering those bodies contain ministerial discretion, the Minister should also have that discretion in relation to the EIS. The withdrawal of these services in the course of a dispute does not force the business that they serve to shut its doors immediately. But, unless there is an export inspection service available during a dispute on the floor of an abattoir, the meat that has been killed and the meat that is stored runs the risk of going bad. The Biloela exercise was a case in point. Over $100,000 worth of meat needed to be boned out following a dispute with the workers in the abattoir. But for the two days that that dispute occurred not one Commonwealth meat inspector was prepared to cross the picket line, nor do I believe that the Minister gave any instructions that they should do so. It is an outrage that this sort of thing is going on. The withdrawal of these services during a dispute can cost an abattoir and a meat processor hundreds of thousands, if not millions, of dollars. This is one of the biggest issues and one of the biggest responsibilities for the Commonwealth meat inspection service.

The Minister suggests by this regulation that it is logical for abattoirs to be compelled to receive the service but for him to have the power to withdraw that service. Let us face it: The industry meets 50 per cent of the cost of this service. It is not a service that is simply provided by the taxpayers or the Government. The industry has a right to expect the Minister and the Government to live up to their obligations. It has every right to protest when the Minister seeks to give himself a discretion in providing a service for which the industry pays 50 per cent.

These regulations throw the Federal Government out of step with State laws. Recently a meeting of Victorian farmers was surprised to learn from the Victorian Minister that he had powers of discretion under the Abattoir and Meat Inspection Act of 1973. Pressed on the matter, his office conceded that it was not sure. The Act itself spells out the truth: The Director-General shall provide inspection services for every meat establishment licensed under the Act. The actions of the Hawke Government in trying to give itself a cop-out clause in the wake of Mudginberri cannot be excused. Every Australian has the right to ask: Who governs this nation; who is pulling the strings? Only yesterday we learned that, as I said earlier, the trade deficit is collapsing and is now running at a figure in excess of $14 billion this year. No sector of the Australian economy is more important to this nation and the standard of living of the Australian people than the export industries, and therefore there are good reasons why certain laws should be enforced to ensure that services such as those we are discussing are provided.

I do not think that any incident in Australian industrial history has highlighted the seriousness of entrenched union power more than the Mudginberri abattoir incident. As I said, this action exposed the weak underbelly of the Hawke Labor Government. It is a union dominated Government. It is bound to the Australian Council of Trade Unions by the accord. The unions are running Australia. This legislation is probably the first legislation to prove that point. The Government does not have to go further than these orders to realise that it is under union control and domination. That is a frightening thought, and it should be a frightening thought for every Australian. So this Parliament must throw out these regulations. I have every confidence that they will be defeated and thrown out by the Senate because I understand that Opposition and Australian Democrat senators are horrified and shocked that the Government should have taken this action. It is incredible that the Government should have been so naive as to expose its underbelly, expose its intentions, and run away from its obligations that have been in law for some considerable time.

I return to the constitutional requirement of this Government. Its constitutional requirement is very strong in the area of export powers because the fathers of the Constitution were well aware that Australia would depend substantially upon its export earning income, yet we are seeing a Minister and a government derelict in duty, running away from responsibility because they do not want to face the picket lines or the unions. The Minister does not want to have to stand up to a handful of people in the sun outside an abattoir or to provide a service for which the industry is paying 50 per cent of the cost. It is an outrageous situation and I am surprised that the Minister would have allowed himself to be the victim of an attempt by his Government to make him nothing more than a pawn of the ACTU.

TALK.START.PARA: —Is the motion seconded?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Brown The Hon N.A.

TALK.START.PARA: —I second this motion to disallow the Export Control (Orders) Regulations introduced by the Government, and I do so because this House simply must disallow these regulations. If it does not disallow the regulations it is throwing up the white flag to excessive union power and control of this country by the trade union movement, as well as control by the trade unions of the export industries of this country. If these regulations are not disallowed by this House the trade union movement will have unlimited power to decide whether inspectors go in to inspect meat or any other agricultural produce, or fish, produced within this country before it can be exported. The regulations are the last crooked act by this crooked Government in a very sorry story indeed and the Government should be ashamed of itself for having the audacity to promote them. Before the regulations are defeated in the Senate, the Government should have the good sense to withdraw them.

SPEECH.PARA: This matter goes back some months. It must be seen as an essential part of the whole Mudginberri matter. From day one the Government has set itself against the great achievements at the Mudginberri abattoir and the great significance that those achievements symbolise. One would think that the Government, which should be concerned about encouraging industry and the export trade, would be pleased about the achievements at Mudginberri. One would think that the Government would look, as the Opposition does, at the facts of Mudginberri and say: `We should not set our face against them. We should encourage them. We should encourage exactly what has happened at Mudginberri'.

What has happened at Mudginberri? In the first place some men have been able to keep their jobs. Secondly, an abattoir has been able to remain open. Thirdly, productivity had increased. Fourthly, at long last we have been able to get some more export trade in this industry. We on this side of the House and, I venture to say, the Australian people say that these are great achievements of which we should be proud and we should be encouraging them. But has the Government endorsed what has happened at Mudginberri? Of course it has not; it has set its face against it. We had the discreditable spectacle of the Minister for Employment and Industrial Relations (Mr Willis) saying a few months ago that this was a piddling matter; that it was a piddling dispute when men were stopped from working and pickets were put up outside the abattoir.

What did the Minister's union masters, Mr Crean and the Australian Council of Trade Unions, say about it? Mr Crean said: `What you have at Mudginberri is the so-called rights of individuals'. We on this side of the House believe that individuals have rights; they have the right to negotiate with their employer; they have the right to fight to save their jobs; they have the right to negotiate with their employer to get a fair reward for their labours. We on this side of the House and the Australian people at large believe that what happened at Mudginberri is a great example of what can be achieved when free people get together and make decisions about important matters concerning their lives. However, the Government has said no to that. The Government has said: `We cannot allow what happened at Mudginberri to continue'. Why has the Government set its face against what has happened at Mudginberri? There must be some explanation. The only explanation which has any basis of fact is that the Government's union masters have told it that it must kill what happened at Mudginberri, otherwise union power in this country will be at an end.

Once again we have seen this Government, from the very beginning of the Mudginberri matter and through every stage of its development, giving in and sending the white flag up the flagpole to the trade union movement, which it believes should control what happens in this country. Apparently it now believes that the union movement should control what decisions are made by the Government. That is a discreditable act of which the Government should be ashamed.

We say that these regulations are discreditable and should be repealed. We say that they have come about because they are simply one more step in he Government's capitulation to the Australasian Meat Industry Employees Union in the whole Mudginberri matter. Furthermore, what has happened? How is is that the regulations have been brought into the Parliament? What has happened is that the Government took this dispute to the Federal Court of Australia. In effect, it said to the Federal Court: `We do not think that we should be obliged to provide an export service when the union stands in our way and says that we should not'. The Government lost its case in the Federal Court. It then went to the High Court of Australia and put the same argument to try to repeal the decision of the Federal Court. What happened there? The Government lost for the second time. Having lost in the Federal Court, the Government then lost in the High Court. But the Government was not prepared to accept the decisions of the highest courts in the land. It would not accept the decisions of the highest courts in the land for the simple reason that the union would not accept them.

The Government by these regulations is trying to reverse the decisions of the two highest courts in this land in the most discreditable manner and for the most discreditable reason. The only reason that the Government has been motivated to introduce these regulations is to expand union power and to give to the Australasian Meat Industry Employees Union the power to override decisions which the Government should make on providing export inspection services. That by itself, without any more, should encourage this House to disallow these regulations because they are simply an attempt to reverse decisions of the High Court and of the Federal Court.

But it goes further than that; indeed, it is even worse. What are the powers which the Minister wants to give to himself? What are the powers that he will use to create his rathole so that he can escape from his real obligations to provide an inspection service? Let us listen to the quaint language that the Government uses by which it means: `We will capitulate and give all power in this matter to the Meat Industry Employees Union'. The regulations state that when someone applies for an inspector to go along to the abattoir, for example, the Secretary of the Department has to consider a number of things. One of the things he must consider is this:
Such other considerations consistent with good management practices as he-
the Secretary-
thinks fit including the welfare and safety of authorised officers.

That is the Government's polite way of saying that the Secretary has to have regard to what the union wants and, if the union does not want an inspection service provided because it might set the union back in its activities at Mudginberri-the union might be prevented from its campaign against free people getting jobs at Mudginberri-the union has to have the last word and the inspection service will not be provided. So when the Government says that the Secretary has to have regard to good management practices all that it means is that the Secretary has to have regard to what the union wants. That is not the way the Australian people want this country governed. The Australian people, through an Act passed in this Parliament, have given power to the Minister which he should exercise in the national interest. He is not prepared to exercise that power unless the union agrees with him. He will give way, like the craven backboneless Minister that he is, as soon as the union says boo to him. He has no responsibility or right to hold the office that he does. No confidence is left in him as far as the exporters of this country are concerned and he should resign.

Secondly, the regulations go on and give to the Minister-this is very important-the power to tell the Secretary of the Department what decision he should come to. It is not simply left to the Secretary to find out what the union movement wants about this thing. The Minister has the power to control the Secretary of his own Department. I ask honourable members to listen to the shameful language in the regulations that this Government is promoting. The regulations state:

Where the Minister considers that it is desirable, taking into account the national interest, that a decision which may be made by the Secretary under orders is made in a particular manner then the Minister may direct the Secretary to make that decision.

In other words, under these regulations, the Minister is giving himself power to tell the Secretary of his own Department what he should do and power to make a most discreditable decision, namely, a decision that export services should not be provided to meat exporters. How the Government can hold its head up when it is putting up that backboneless sort of proposal I do not know.

This is something which should give us very great concern because the Minister has already shown, through his conduct of his Department, that he has no control over the employees of his department. Meat inspectors are public servants. They should do what they are paid to do. They should do what they are told to do by the law. The Deputy Leader of the National Party (Mr Hunt) has made it perfectly plain that an Act passed by this Parliament states that the inspection service shall be provided. It must be provided for very good reasons so that the standard of our meat can be kept up to high standards and so that exporters can achieve what they are in business to achieve, namely, the export of meat and other products. But the Minister has shown that he has no control over those inspectors. He stood by like the craven, backboneless individual that he is when the meat inspectors refused to cross a picket line. He was not concerned whether they got paid for doing their work or not. He was not concerned about meat rotting at the abattoir because it could not be certified. He was not concerned about the men's jobs that were at stake. He was not concerned about the export trade. He was not concerned whether the abattoir company went bankrupt or not. He was concerned about one thing and one thing only-the poor trade union which had set its face against men keeping their jobs and getting paid what they thought they were worth for their jobs.

When the Minister writes with his wicked hand into these regulations that he is to have regard to the national interest, I put it to the House that the whole history of the Mudginberri matter makes it perfectly plain that he has not the faintest idea what the national interest means. He knows what the union interest is. He knows that as a member of a government that is controlled by the trade union movement he must do what it tells him. That is what he means by the national interest-the union interest. We say finally, because these arguments are clear for all to see, that if the Government had its wits about it, it would admit at this stage that these regulations should not be proceeded with. It should have the wit to see that they will be defeated in the Senate. If the Minister does not want another embarrassment for this crumbling Government, he would be well advised to pull these regulations out now.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Kerin The Hon J.C.

TALK.START.PARA: —The raving display by the Deputy Leader of the Opposition (Mr N.A. Brown) says a lot more about himself and his attitude to the ordinary men and women of Australia than it does about the issue before the House. He hates, as the Liberal Party hates, people who work for a living. That is what this is all about. It is all about an attack on wage earners. He needs to encourage his own right wing fanatics in the Liberal Party because John Howard is down to 13 per cent-that is what it this is all about.

SPEECH.PARA: Let us look at realities. It is a simple change in administrative law in accord with legislative provisions in many other areas of Commonwealth legislation where national interest grounds supersede discretionary powers in legislation. In the Federal Court decision which overturned the decision by Justice Neaves on this matter, the invitation was there for the Commonwealth Government to take this action and get it into accord with other provisions in other legislation. There were implications in that judgment for a lot of other areas of Commonwealth legislation. There was a desire by the Cabinet to put this into accord with other parts of legislation.

The other matter we took into account was that if we followed the Federal Court decision to the letter and did not accept the invitation implicit in the judgment, we would be opening up the meat industry to additional cost. It is nonsense to say that the Australasian Meat Industry Employees Union was consulted in this, as it is nonsense to say that the Meat Inspectors Association was consulted. Let us look at other areas of legislation where we have the same provisions. There is the Building Industry Act 1985, the Telecommunications Act 1975, the Postal Services Act 1975, the Australian Tourist Commission Act 1967, the Australian Shipping Commission Act 1956, the Australian National Railways Commission Act 1983, the Wool Industry Act 1972, the Wheat Marketing Act 1979, the Snowy Mountains Engineering Corporation Amendment Act 1985, and the Aboriginal Development Commission Act 1980. The legislation in all these Acts is exactly the same as we are putting in here.

What this motion is all about is not this legislation; it is all about the fact that Opposition members need to appeal to their own hard core, because they want to return to the politics of confrontation with the trade union movement-and where did that get them? What they are opposed to is orderly industrial relations. They are so opposed to the accord. What has the accord done? It has reduced real unit labour costs by 11 per cent. It has put the profit share up. It has increased investment. It has increased jobs by 608,000. Opposition members cannot live with that. They got 250,000 extra people on the dole line in one year. That is what they cannot hack. That is the problem. They want industrial disputation and confrontation. They do not want consultation. They do not want the accord, which was between the Government, business and the Australian Council of Trade Unions. They cannot handle the fact that business goes along with the accord, either.

What did Opposition members do when they were in government? They let it rip. They abandoned centralised wage fixation in 1981-82. What happened? Wage rates went through the roof-a 14 per cent to 17 per cent increase. What happened to farm costs? They rose by 12 per cent. They are now down to an increase of 7 per cent a year. Opposition members talk about trade, but what did they do? They ran an over-valued exchange rate to try to fight inflation. They hit the farmers and the exporters. And they talk about trade!

I am not going to re-argue the Mudginberri issue and all the politics that went on with that, but the national interest thing that we were taking into account was very much on the balance of trade. We had an isolated abattoir in the Northern Territory that had three meat inspectors and 20 meat employee unionists employed there. Because the National Farmers Federation dealt into a dispute between the Australasian Meat Industry Employees Union and Jay Pendarvis, this became a national dispute, because the NFF wanted to break down centralised wage fixation. But from the Government's point of view, when we were trying to fill the Canadian quota, when the brucellosis and tuberculosis eradication campaign in the remote areas required abattoirs to be open, and when we had a major lamb promotion with Japan, we took the national interest decision that it was nonsense, in this case, for a government to deliberately enlarge an industrial dispute. That was the decision we took.

TALK.START.PARA: —It was a wrong decision, and you know it.

—It was not the wrong decision in terms of the national interest that was involved at the time. The union was in an unsupportable situation at law in terms of clause 33 of the McKenzie judgment. But that clause attacked, completely and fundamentally, the raison d'etre of the trade union movement, and that is why the ACTU put on an official picket. We had to deal with that reality. The Government was asked to take actions which would have expanded the strike. We are normally enjoined to limit strikes, not expand them. It suited Opposition members politically to expand it-but we did not take that decision, because of the national interest, the balance of trade, and the interests of the meat industry and the beef cattle industry.

SPEECH.PARA: Because an official picket was put on, because the interest of the cattle industry was that trade continue, we did not think that 23 people in a dispute in a remote area should imperil the cattle industry, the sheep industry, our balance of trade, and the jobs of another 30,000 or 40,000 people in the meat industry. But it suited Opposition members because they are against centralised wage fixation and against the trade union movement, and they are against the accord because they cannot wear the success that is coming from it. That is what this motion is all about. It is not about a small change to regulations to bring this part of legislation into accord with other areas of legislation in this Parliament. This is what the motion is really all about.

I shall just give some brief background to this matter so that we may have a few facts here to overcome some of the ideology of the opposite side-because that is what it is all about. On 19 December a Full Bench of the Federal Court of Australia found, on appeal, that the Department had no discretion under the export meat orders to provide inspection staff when required to do so. When Cabinet considered this matter in July 1985 it had before it advice of the Attorney-General's Department that there was a qualified duty to provide inspection staff. It was considered that the virtual certainty of widespread industrial action with significant financial implications to the meat industry was reasonable justification for not supplying inspection staff and that this provided a qualification to the orders. The Court, in a decision by Mr Justice Neaves, supported this view. Now, on appeal, the Full Bench has rejected it as a basis for not supplying staff.

We required the staff to go in four times. They refused because of an official Australian Council of Trade Unions picket. We took a decision not to expand the strike. That was a political decision-the only political decision.

TALK.START.PARA: —It shows where the real power lies, doesn't it?

—No, it does not at all. That is absolute nonsense. One deals with industrial reality. What did the blokes opposite do, when they were in power, about the Builders Labourers Federation? They should tell us about all the Public Service strikes they had when they were in government. I think the Leader of the National Party of Australia (Mr Sinclair) was Minister for Communications when there were strikes in Telecom Australia and Australia Post. He should tell me about all of them. Did he march workers across picket lines? Was he able to get them to work when they went on strike? He had to deal with industrial reality. What did he do about it? What did the previous Government ever do about strikes? It did not even have the guts to take on the BLF. Which government has had the guts to do that? What did the previous Government do about the BLF? It caved in. Honourable members opposite should not tell us nonsense about their having any guts in the area of industrial relations. At the end of the day they, too, had to accept industrial reality.

SPEECH.PARA: What have we done? We have provided the Department with a discretion to take the efficiency of operations and the safety of staff into consideration in deciding whether to provide inspection services. That is in accord with law right across the board in this place. We also have provided the Department with a discretion, to be exercised at the appropriate level, to take the interests of the industry into consideration in deciding whether to provide inspection services and enable the Minister to give a direction as to how the Department should exercise the discretion where Ministers consider that national interest considerations are involved. Honourable members opposite will focus on that because it is a two-edged sword. It does not put me, as Minister, or officials in the difficult situation we were in with regard to Mudginberri, where there was only a qualified obligation and where, if a decision were taken in the national interest, one did not quite know where one stood. This measure gives the Minister more powers. If honourable members opposite cannot work that out, they really do not understand administrative law.

Why did we go for a discretion? First, the word `impossible' was not defined by the Federal Court. If the Court's finding was read literally it meant that we had to provide inspection services unless it was impossible to do so. The word `impossible' was undefined. If that is taken literally it means that we will have to impose many additional costs on the industry. The normal day to day running of the Export Inspection Service means that many requests are made when cattle are not available and some discretion has to be exercised by the Service. If the Service has to have a great pool of additional people, so that at all times anyone can make a demand on the Service, it will cost it at least $2.5m extra a year. Taken literally, the Full Bench decision meant that neither the Government nor the Department had any real say in the provision of services. This would have added a cost to the Export Inspection Service of some $2.5m per annum, not to mention the cost of ongoing industrial disruption.

The Inspection Service is faced with quite a few local industrial disputes and rather than force the issue and spread the dispute, it relies more on negotiation and conciliation. This often holds back service while this is going on. Departmental officials should have a say in the provision of staff where efficiency of operations or staff safety are involved and the Government needs to have its policies, be they of an industrial or other nature, taken into account and, where appropriate, to issue directions when decisions involve political considerations. While this might put the Minister up front, it gets away from the criticism of the courts and the media that officials should not take political decisions. I think it is only correct that there should be provision for government involvement where the decision is political rather than administrative. Ministerial direction is preferred to review or reconsideration as it enables the Minister to become involved before the problem arises. An official does not have to actually take a decision and then have an aggrieved party ask for a review before the Minister can formally become involved.

This motion today is a stunt. This regulation merely puts this part of the law in accord with many other areas of Commonwealth law and is virtually at the invitation of a Federal Court of Australia ruling. The two motivations were to get that accordance with other law so that discretion can be applied and to cut down costs to the meat industry. I move:
That the question be now put.
Question resolved in the affirmative.
Original question put:
That the motion (Mr Hunt's) be agreed to.

DIVISION.RESULT.PARA: Question so resolved in the negative.

PROCTEXT.PARA: Debate resumed from 19 February, on motion by Mr Hurford:
That the Bill be now read a second time.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Cadman Mr A.G.

TALK.START.PARA: —Any change to the Australian Citizenship Act immediately arouses interest in the Parliament and within the community. The community is concerned about changes in citizenship which deal with the character, identity and political and legal status of all Australians. The Government in the amendments which it has proposed continues the practices which have been used by it to bring about alterations to the nature of Australian citizenship. The Government brings a range of proposals before this Parliament without consultation with the wider Australian community, immigrants or the Opposition. As with its handling of the Australian Bill of Rights Bill, the Government wrongly believes that it has been given a mandate to change the character of Australian citizenship. It will make those changes regardless of community or public opinion.

SPEECH.PARA: The Opposition rejects the techniques of socialist authoritarianism. The attitude of the Minister for Immigration and Ethnic Affairs (Mr Hurford) reflects the prospect of a new trilogy-a lack of consistency, a lack of clarity and a lack of consultation. What does the Government propose in the Australian Citizenship Amendment Bill? It attempts to address four main areas: Firstly, the claims of residency based on children who were born in Australia; secondly, the situation of Australians in Israel who have lost their citizenship; thirdly, the oath and affirmation of allegiance and, finally, a number of administrative changes to the Act.

The Bill seeks to remove automatic citizenship for children born in Australia of visitors, temporary entrants and prohibited non-citizens, thus closing the loophole which has allowed infants to sponsor their own parents. Also the Government considers the situation of stateless individuals. The Bill will allow appeals to the Administrative Appeals Tribunal where citizenship is denied or not granted by reason of an administrative error. The Bill proposes a number of technical amendments by replacing sexist language and the waiver of fees. The legislation meets most of the aims. The Opposition supports these proposals with the exception of clause 7 relating to those people who have inadvertently lost their citizenship. That clause requires additional clarification. I understand that the Minister has amendments. We also have amendments to that clause and also to clause 11 in relation to the oath and affirmation. For some time there has been a considerable cost, and much concern has been expressed, regarding the automatic granting of citizenship to children born in Australia. There are instances of pregnant women coming from overseas, having their child in Australia and of that child then sponsoring the parent as a permanent resident. Temporary entrants, visitors or prohibited non-citizens have been sponsored by infant children. In addition, many complicated and expensive court cases have followed where parents have not accepted the Minister's ruling regarding their claim for permanent residency. The Government's proposed amendment will close this back-door avenue of entry to those people, particularly prohibited non- citizens, who would not normally meet the requirements for Australian immigration.

The investigations of the House of Representatives Standing Committee on Expenditure resulted in a recommendation for an alteration to this aspect of Australian citizenship law which has been in effect since 1948. The Committee confirmed that parents who were illegal immigrants would acquire residential status and resist deportation on the grounds that the child who had automatically gained Australian citizenship, needed the parents' constant attention. This is another instance in which those who have no real claim on Australia might receive considerable benefit ahead of those seeking immigrant entry through proper channels. The House will remember the shocking facts exposed by the Expenditure Committee which revealed that up to 25 per cent of illegal immigrants receive health care, social welfare, unemployment benefits or legal aid, the cost of which could amount to over $52m a year. Still nothing has been done to curb the outrageous waste of public money on those who have no rights or recognition within Australia.

The Human Rights Commission has also expressed its concern about automatic child citizenship. The Commission concluded that better supervision by the Department of Immigration and Ethnic Affairs would remove or substantially reduce these problems. The Human Rights Commission seemed to have more compassion for illegal immigrants than commitment to the best interests of Australians. The Human Rights Commission has used the issue to propagate its vested interests. Indeed, this Commission is the stalking horse of the proposed Bill of Rights. Its record is another reason for the Opposition's being strongly opposed to the Bill of Rights.

Clause 7 of the Bill arises from the amendments to the Australian Citizenship Act which in 1984 gave the Minister the power to restore Australian citizenship lost inadvertently. These amendments caused some Australians to lose their citizenship. Up to 2,000 citizens living in Israel at that date as permanent residents lost their Australian citizenship. Under Israeli law of return every person of Jewish descent is automatically conferred with Israeli citizenship on arrival as a permanent resident unless those people realise that they need to reject the offer of citizenship within three months. The principle intention of Australians going to reside in Israel is not to acquire Israeli citizenship, nor to deny their Australian citizenship. They had either no knowledge or received poor advice on the implications of the law of return.

The Bill before the House allows former citizens to make a statement to the Minister and there is a consequential ministerial discretion to reinstate citizenship. The Government's proposals are not entirely satisfactory. The Opposition does not believe that permanent residency within three years is required. That was an unconscious action which deprived Australians of their nationality and their distress and sense of alienation has been completely justified. All that is necessary is a statement of their intention to ultimately reside in Australia. The Bill also contains an inconsistency. The statement to be furnished to the Minister is based upon the person having suffered significant hardship or detriment. On the other hand, the Minister's discretion is exercised on the basis that the person suffered hardship or detriment of an economic nature. We will explore those factors when the House is at the Committee stage and comes to the point of debating the details of each clause. We will move amendments to clarify this clause.

The oath or the affirmation of allegiance which is taken by a person at the citizenship ceremony is significantly changed by this Bill. The Government proposes that no person will renounce allegiance to the sovereign of any other state, nor will a person be required to state his or her name when taking the oath or affirmation. The Minister has said that the renunciation of allegiance is ambiguous and unnecessary. The Minister contends that some candidates for citizenship think that they are not merely renouncing formal ties with their former country but also renouncing their cultural heritage and traditions. The Minister is confused and incorrect in these assumptions.

Renunciation is a positive step in recognition of the legal requirements and the individualism and status of the Australian identity. Allegiance is acquired through birthright, naturalisation and a feeling and declaration of identity. The principle is clear: Whilst any person should retain his own private, cultural and individual character, there is a higher and stronger national character-a public identity in which allegiance to one's chosen country is paramount. Such an allegiance implies both the benefits and the responsibilities of national duty. Australia is not alone in these things, in requiring a renunciation. I refer the House to a number of countries of similar background and status that also require renunciation. Italy, Malta, Yugoslavia, West Germany, the United States of America, Cyprus and even the Union of Soviet Socialist Republics require renunciation either on the oath or on application for citizenship in their law. In one form or another, that renunciation is required.

The report of October 1982 commissioned by a previous Minister, Mr Macphee, entitled `National Consultations on Multiculturalism and Citizenship' stated that there was less unanimity in proposals, compared with other proposals, about what should be substituted as the object of allegiance. The report noted that the discussion on renunciation in the oath tended to lack clarity. The views were wide ranging. Some suggested that a renunciation was not legally binding while on the other hand it stated:
It was thought highly repugnant that a person granted Australian citizenship should retain allegiance to another country or power.

The general conclusion was that `it is probable that clearer wording would resolve some of the apparent disagreement'. The report declared that Australian citizenship should be clearly Australian in character. What could be more Australian than to be an individual beholden to no one except one's own country. The Minister has chosen to reject this conclusion. It is one of the most indefinite conclusions reached by that consultative process. In fact, that process finally found that there were alternative wordings, and alternative wordings were proposed that were acceptable to all as an option for the Government to take up. Yet the Government and the Minister have chosen in this area to move ahead of the recommendations of that consultation and to follow the proposal of the Human Rights Commission, which he and I both condemn. Yet he chooses to pick up one of that Commission's more weird recommendations despite recommendations in the `National Consultations on Multiculturalism and Citizenship' report.

I am surprised by this process. I would have thought that in this process the concept of bipartisanship would have entered into the whole affray. That committee was divided and unsure of itself in the consultations. This House is now divided, and it has been every time that citizenship changes have been brought out, particularly with regard to the oath, by this Government. It has all occurred because there has been no consultation. I am sure that over a period an acceptable form of words for the oath, based on the suggestions in that report, could have been achieved. But that is not the case.

Even in some countries which allow dual nationality such as Switzerland an applicant is required to refrain from any act which may acknowledge former citizenship, and renunciation is demanded. If the Minister is using this amendment to send out a signal that Australia is moving towards dual citizenship, it is a poor and inappropriate method by which to begin that discussion. What do we have? Such important changes demand consultation with all interested groups. To my knowledge there has been no consultation other than those in 1982. Those consultations were inconclusive and suggested changes to retain renunciation. The Minister has not consulted widely, nor has he opened debate on this question to wider public scrutiny or the accountability that he has to the public at large.

We understand the continuing private bonds that some of our citizens feel for their country of origin. That needs to be said. Even though these traditions and external pressures on our citizens may be significant to those people, as a nation we cannot diminish our national identity by accommodating a wide variety of individual and sometimes conflicting obligations. The Opposition believes that a renunciation of other allegiance in the oath and affirmation does not deny a person's private cultural heritage. However, it is a most important step towards recognising one's Australian identity as the foremost ideal for the individual. From the early pioneers to the most recent arrivals, migrants have brought with them skills, investment and knowledge to contribute to this country. Consequently, the opportunities for employment and development at all levels have widened. Families have been nurtured and businesses have grown.

Age and length of residence are major factors in the decision which is made to become an Australian citizen. The personal, social and financial investments made over a period influence the probability or lack of probability of a return to country of former residence. In 1983 the `Australian Values Study' found that 86 per cent of the population was proud of its country. Regardless of country of origin, commitment to Australia is alive and well. The study also found that the two largest migrant groups were even more committed to Australia than the average Australian. Those groups to which I referred are the southern Europeans and the British, 96 per cent of whom were proud of our nation. The southern Europeans, in particular, figured highly in their commitment to this country. In spite of these facts-this commitment and enthusiasm by people for a sense of nationalism and a regard for their country-the Minister wants to devalue the allegiance.

All Australians share common values. This runs across political parties and background. The importance of our families, concern for our homes, individual freedom and liberty are values which unify Australia and provide a sense of purpose for individual endeavour. They enrich our own culture and improve and extend our social and political identity. Such contributions can never be too highly regarded.

However, what has the present Government done? The Minister for Immigration and Ethnic Affairs has established his national immigration policy by a series of Press releases. Departmental officers are concerned and demoralised by the effects of imprecise policy, backed up by interminable review processes and procrastination in resolving thousands of immigration cases. We know that the Minister-I say this in a friendly sense-would like to be Treasurer. However, let us get down to the matters of the great Department of Immigration and Ethnic Affairs-

TALK.START.PARA: —I am the world's best assistant Treasurer.

—The Minister would be an improvement on the chap who is there now. I would like to see him do the job. It is possible for a person who has been refused permanent residency to undergo an internal review by the Department, as well as by the Immigration Review Panel. The total process will take three months for the internal review and another 12 months for the Immigration Review Panel-a total of 15 months. If litigation ensues, that person may well have been here for three or four years before a final decision is made. Perhaps the Minister is more concerned with creating activity that achievement.

SPEECH.PARA: The new system of overseas assessment introduced last May has exacerbated delays and has placed an incredible burden on overseas officers of the Department of Immigration and Ethnic Affairs. In most posts there is a delay of four to six months before a person can be interviewed and a further delay of two to three months following the interview, in the most urgent cases, before people know the result of their applications. Usually the total period ranges from five months to one year. I draw the attention of the Minister again to the urgent requirement of nurses to be brought to Australia and my prediction some months ago that it would be May before any substantial number were here. We are at the middle of March and my prediction is coming closer every day.

This process has been interfered with by the Human Rights Commission, legal aid authorities and State governments. They have exacerbated the problem. That is why I said at the beginning of my speech that the Government has a problem not just in this area but in many other areas. It has a problem with its current trilogy and it is raising a new trilogy-a trilogy of lack of consistency, lack of clarity and lack of consultation. The Government has turned its new trilogy and that trilogy's philosophy on to the Australian Citizenship Act.

How does the new trilogy apply to the legislation before the House? I believe that the Government has downgraded its appreciation of an individual's decision to become an Australian citizen. The ceremony that a person goes through to become an Australian citizen should be, and is in every instance I am aware of, dignified and personal. It should be an occasion on which the Australian Government, the Parliament and our people can signify their warmest regard for the new citizen and his pride in his new nation. The certificate presented on these occasions should be a physical testament to this high regard. It should be personal, individually signed and recognise the local authority involved. Its design should artistically befit the importance of our history, our achievements and our pride in them. At present the certificate can be best described as a shabby second rate document, computerised and depersonalised. It is a disgrace that such a demeaning document is used when a person takes one of the most significant steps that an individual can ever take-to give up his nationality and accept that of another country. People do not make that decision lightly. We should not treat their decision with contempt. The Opposition, on coming to government, will scrap the present printout and replace it with a personal and aesthetic document. In fact, we will take all the stocks of these documents left in departments and have a bonfire. I invite the honourable member for Calwell (Dr Theophanous) to come along and share in the bonfire when we get rid of these terrible documents that do not really depict the pride that we all have in people making the decision to become Australian citizens. I know that he shares my views, and I know that he will be at that bonfire.

Furthermore, the Government's proposal to delete the requirement for a person to state his name in the oath or affirmation merely decreases the personal value of his pledge. The oath cannot be applied to anyone else but the individual making that commitment. The practices of local authorities vary tremendously and though the Minister dismisses this requirement as being confusing, that is not necessarily the case. It depends on the competence of the local officers conducting the citizenship ceremony and it depends on the practices and traditions of local authorities themselves, many of which clearly require an individual to state his name in the oath without being joined by others in making that commitment, so each person has an individualised, personalised commitment to make. A solemn oath or pledge demands a legal and personal identification with the commitment being undertaken. Indeterminate commitments lack compulsion and complete acceptance of the serious concept which follows. Therefore the Opposition is opposed to the removal of an individual's name when he is making a pledge or affirmation or taking the oath.

We reject the depersonalisation of this process. It is not good enough to say that it is confusing. Where is the basis for saying that? It is a statement made on some ad hoc basis at an Australian Labor Party Caucus meeting where some guy had a bright idea and said: `I was at a citizenship ceremony last week and it was a shambles because everybody got mixed up when it came time to say his name'. Why does not that Federal member-or whoever has problems of that type-exercise his proper responsibility as a Federal member and give some guidance to the local authorities as to how best they should conduct those ceremonies. It is a dignified process and we do have a responsibility. We as members go to these ceremonies and I believe that most local authorities with which I have had contact-it does not matter whether they are in the country or the city or are controlled by the Liberal Party, the Labor Party or the National Party; whether or not they are controlled by political parties is irrelevant-will accept the guidance of Federal members if there is confusion over the dignified administration of the oath. If the Minister pursues the claim of confusion I will offer him a whole series of suggestions, such as issuing written certificates before the ceremony and there being an opportunity for the shire or town clerk to explain to those involved precisely the processes to be gone through and what is required of them.

Let us pay more attention to this matter rather than giving it the flick-pass, which is what is happening in this legislation. The Minister for Sport, Recreation and Tourism (Mr John Brown), who is at the table with the Minister for Immigration and Ethnic Affairs, knows what I mean by `the flick-pass'. The Opposition believes that the character and quality of the individual come together to make that individual a member of a particular nation-Australia. The political status and allegiance of that person is primarily Australian. The underlying individual freedom of our society allows a person to hold his private and individual interests and endeavours, regardless of whether he was born in Australia or Malta, Italy, New Zealand or Greece. That is the freedom individuals have in our nation. Thus individual differences of heritage and tradition contribute first at the family level and then at the community level, ultimately to the development of our society. But rising above that is a public declaration of citizenship which is so highly valued, whether it is bestowed at birth or bestowed at a ceremony. As the American philosopher Libby de Brandeis said in 1915:
The difference between a nation and a nationality is clear. Likeness between members is the essence of a nationality, but the members of a nation may be very different.

It is the differences which add diversity and variety to our lifestyle but it is the essence of national identity which is the cohesive force to forge the nation. Nationality is a miracle of political independence. It is an independence enshrined in citizenship. Our national ideals have always sought reward for hard work and enterprise. All of us have contributed to this nation in one way or another and to these ideals, whether in our work place by hard work or by our own enterprise. Australians are justifiably proud of their country. We do not believe that any attempt at making it less significant for a new citizen to realise his rights, privileges and responsibilities as an Australian can be tolerated. John Stuart Mill said:
The desire to be under the same government and desire that it should be government by themselves or a portion or themselves exclusively.
We can all identify publicly with this desire but maintain our contribution, individual character and heritage no matter what our origin.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Theophanous Dr A.C.

TALK.START.PARA: —The whole question of Australian citizenship has been debated in this House before. In fact it was the Labor Government which, in its first term, brought in the first series of extensive amendments to the Australian Citizenship Act in order to modernise it, to make it relevant to modern times. We should remember that fact and we should focus on the important issues concerned with citizenship. Some of the remarks of the shadow Minister for Immigration and Ethnic Affairs, the honourable member for Mitchell (Mr Cadman)-I know he is well intentioned-were based on insufficient knowledge, in my view, of the desires of people, especially those taking the oath and affirmation at citizenship ceremonies. He did not seem to address himself to some of the more crucial aspects of the Australian Citizenship Amendment Bill in the way one might have expected.

SPEECH.PARA: Let me begin by saying something about citizenship in general and the meaning of citizenship. As the shadow Minister mentioned, citizenship bestows certain obligations on those who acquire it. However, it also bestows certain basic and fundamental rights. While no one wants to detract from the obligations involved one should also equally emphasise the rights which people formally receive as a consequence of becoming Australian citizens. I use the word `formally' in that context because there is no doubt that often there are groups and individuals in the community who attempt to treat persons who have come here as migrants and who have received Australian citizenship, through citizenship ceremonies, as though they are not full-blooded Australians and as though they are not full citizens of this country. We should not underestimate the extent to which bigotry continues in a variety of forms in this nation. Let me say in this context that there are still forms of discrimination against citizens who have become Australian citizens through migrating to this country. I refer, in particular, to some of the migrant groups who have recently arrived in this country.

They may go through the process of acquiring formal citizenship and they are given full rights under the law but they must still get those rights recognised in the social context of this nation, especially by certain groups and individuals.

In recent times some talk has been directed towards an attack on multiculturalism and on the multicultural nature of this nation. It is encouraging the very groups and individuals who do not consider it adequate that a person who has received citizenship has full Australian rights. Such talk is simply bringing up the old pseudo-racist, or even blatantly racist, background as the basis for attacking multiculturalism. In a nation such as ours, which is based substantially on immigration, the issues of multiculturalism and the full meaning of citizenship are intertwined and fundamental. We are a nation of migrants. A huge proportion of our population is made up of people who were not born here. They have become Australian citizens. If we do not recognise the concept of multiculturalism and what it entails in terms of the right to participate in the community in the fullest sense, the right to be able to practise a diversity of cultures and, more importantly, the right to allow those cultures to contribute towards the creation of the evolving Australian culture, citizenship will remain merely a formal ceremony and not a real and substantial right for many people.

In this context it is interesting that the Opposition talked about how glorious it was to achieve Australian citizenship and indeed it is. However, let me emphasise that it is members of the Opposition, and specially members of the National Party of Australia, who are constantly attacking the Human Rights Commission.

TALK.START.PARA: —Hear, hear!

—Let me point out to the honourable member opposite some of the important roles of the Human Rights Commission in relation to the matter I have been talking about. I have been talking about the need to make citizenship something that gives people full rights and if that need is to be met we have to end discrimination. Where there is discrimination it is necessary for people to have channels through which they can complain and make their grievances known.
—Members of Parliament.

—In that instance the Human Rights Commission has a very important role to play. Honourable members opposite who are very quick to denounce the Human Rights Commission are not fair dinkum in their pursuit of equal rights for all persons no matter what their cultural background. The fact of the matter is that the Human Rights Commission has played an important role. It is a nonsense for honourable members Opposite to say that it is sufficient for members of Parliament to take up all cases of discrimination. If the honourable member opposite has had as many cases of discrimination brought to his attention as have been brought to mine, he would be spending all his time examining and inquiring into those cases. So we need a body such as this Commission and we need to direct ourselves to the matter of discrimination in relation to the rights of people who have become Australian citizens through naturalisation.

SPEECH.PARA: Let me now address some of the other concerns I have about the Bill. We have heard from the honourable member for Mitchell that the Opposition takes objection to the fact that the clause renouncing all other allegiance will be taken out of the oath or affirmation. The facts of the matter are these: First of all, many nations have no such clauses in statements relating to citizenship. Secondly, many people in ethnic communities and many people who come here as migrants are confused about the actual meaning of that statement. Many of them do not consider that by making such a statement they are renouncing their cultural heritage, that they are renouncing their ties with the country in which they were born, that they are renouncing certain rights and in some cases even their property rights which they may still retain in their country of birth, for example. Because of the confusion that has been created in people's minds we are saying that this clause ought to be taken out of the legislation. It is interesting that the conservatives are saying: `We have to keep this clause in'. Of course; this is a knee-jerk reaction which has the false concept that somehow they are more patriotic and more loyal to Australia than everyone else. This is absolute rubbish. If they were more patriotic they might put forward some more sensible ideas about what we ought to be doing at the present time in relation to the problems of the nation instead of squabbling amongst themselves about a large number of issues, not knowing which direction they are going.

Member nations of the Commonwealth are in a peculiar position, especially those which have the Queen as their Head of State, for example, British citizens. On the one hand they are supposed to renounce the British Crown and on the other hand they are supposed to embrace it. What an absurd situation in which to put people! No wonder people coming from Europe and Asia who have these cultural concerns, and even people from the British Isles, will be totally confused about this clause. Obviously this is just a furphy. There is no substance to the Opposition's claims in relation to taking out this clause.

It has been said that we ought to do more to strengthen the meaning of citizenship ceremonies and to strengthen the meaning of taking out Australian citizenship. I agree entirely with that. We can do more in those areas. As the shadow Minister said, Federal members in particular electorates can do more in co-operation with their councils and other groups. I am sure that any suggestions that are put up about how we might give the ceremonies more significance and meaning will be taken on board by the Minister for Immigration and Ethnic Affairs (Mr Hurford) who is an extremely reasonable man in these matters. There is no point in honourable members opposite getting up and saying that we need to put more meaning into this ceremony without making concrete suggestions as to what we ought to be doing. We certainly want to ensure that the ceremony-the act of citizenship-becomes a very important act, which it is for most migrants who have gone through that process, such as myself. It is a very significant and symbolic thing. No one is wanting to take away from that process at all. So any concrete suggestions about improving the meaningfulness of the ceremonies and so on will be taken on board.

I address myself now to the oath and affirmation issues and wish to say something about the question of children, which was hardly referred to by the shadow Minister. The problem that has arisen is that some persons have been trying to get round the immigration laws by deliberately setting out to have children while they are in Australia as visitors or sometimes even as illegal immigrants. In that situation they have blatantly tried to get around the law. Under the present provisions if a child is born in Australia and the parents are Australian citizens or permanent residents there is no problem at all; and we are not changing that situation in any way. But there have been a few isolated cases where people have tried to get round the law by having children while they are in Australia as visitors or illegal immigrants. In those instances they have claimed that the child is an Australian citizen and they have used that as the basis for making a very substantial claim to stay in Australia. Rather than exacerbate the confusion that has been created in this area the Government has decided to legislate. I am pleased that the Opposition also supports this measure.

I reiterate that no person or persons, no couples who are Australian citizens or permanent residents awaiting citizenship-no person in either category-will be affected. Their children will automatically be Australian citizens. We are talking now only of illegal immigrants and those who come to Australia as visitors who are seeking to get around the law in this way. It might be asked: Why not be totally flexible about this and allow the children to be classified as Australian citizens? As the honourable member for Perth (Dr Charlesworth) said earlier this is a queue jumping problem. We do have a problem. Every year one million people apply to come to Australia. We have to have some rules and regulations as to how we process those people. Therefore, we have to recognise that there are people who come to Australia who sometimes would not even meet the criteria even if they took their place in the queue. We have to have criteria when the demand is so high and when the possibility of intake is limited. The Minister has already made his view known that he intends to extend the immigration program so that this limited capacity will be increased. But we obviously cannot take one million in a year, so we have to have procedures and we have to have some system of fairness within the rules and, therefore, we have to discourage queue jumping. That does not mean that, in certain exceptional cases, we should not be able to convert people who are on visitors visas to permanent residents. Of course we should in certain cases. But we cannot allow a situation where queue jumping becomes the rule because that would obviously undermine the whole immigration program. That is the justification for the clauses relating to the exclusion of children who are non-residents and non-Australian.

The other factor that has been mentioned is a very important factor and I am surprised that more was not said about it by the Opposition. I refer to the situation where people go overseas and, for some reason or another, lose their Australian citizenship because they acquire the citizenship of another nation. Even though they had Australian citizenship they lose it because they acquire the citizenship of another nation. Under certain circumstances they will be able to apply, when they return to Australia, for the resumption of their Australian citizenship. This is a very substantial concession which will get rid of certain problems, especially for some communities in this country, such as the Jewish community, which has had problems where people have gone to Israel for a period and have lost their Australian citizenship and, on coming back to Australia, they find that they are in all kinds of difficulties.

TALK.START.PARA: —They do not have to come back to Australia to reacquire their citizenship.

—That is true, but they have to express their intention of coming back. This legislation will make the rules much more flexible in relation to the resumption of people's citizenship. I point out that this will apply not only to Jewish people but also to a large number of people in ethnic groups who go back to their countries and acquire the citizenship of those countries. In these cases part of the acquisition of that citizenship is the renunciation of Australian citizenship. I believe that these are very progressive amendments that will assist people-after all, we are increasingly in a more international environment-and I commend the Minister for introducing them.

SPEECH.PARA: Let me conclude with the comments I made when I began. Australian citizenship is a great privilege. We recognise that. It does bestow certain formal rights. What we as a Parliament have to do is to try to ensure that those rights become embedded in the community as a whole; that they become real rights in the community; that discrimination is ended and the multiculturalism, the diversity of cultural viewpoints and the toleration of differences becomes the norm in this country. Once we do that citizenship will acquire its full meaning.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Sullivan Mrs K.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —One could never doubt the sincerity of the honourable member for Calwell (Dr Theophanous) in speaking on this subject. However, one has to doubt the wisdom of some of the things that he chooses to talk about and has talked about this morning. At the beginning of his speech he made reference to the fact that a Labor government brought in the Bill which made substantial revisions of the Australian Citizenship Act 1948. He said that it should never be forgotten that a Labor government made our Citizenship Act relevant to modern times. I remind the honourable member for Calwell that a Liberal government initiated the review of specified points of the act which were later followed through by a Labor government. It was a former Minister for Immigration and Ethnic Affairs, the honourable member for Goldstein (Mr Macphee), who in a statement to the Parliament on 6 May 1982 detailed the areas the Fraser Government wished to review. Following that statement, to which I shall refer later in my speech, a large scale process of national consultation on multiculturalism and citizenship was initiated, which resulted in a report being presented to this Parliament in October 1982. That report has been referred to both in the second reading speech of the Minister for Immigration and Ethnic Affairs (Mr Hurford) and in other speeches since, and I shall be referring to it also in my speech. I shall also refer to one other parliamentary debate and set of speeches.

SPEECH.PARA: One of the reasons I was particularly sorry to hear the honourable member for Calwell take that line on the Australian Citizenship Act is that it was the exclusive line of the Government in debate on the Act when it was substantially amended in 1984. The then Minister for Immigration and Ethnic Affairs, who did more to destroy bipartisanship on this important subject than anybody else in this country, made great play in his reply to the second reading debate of the fact that the Opposition had not referred in detail to substantial areas of change. Opposition members did not refer to them in detail because they agreed with them, and those changes were as a result of the actions of a Liberal Minister for Immigration and Ethnic Affairs.
