It is not surprising that the debate, which was constrained in time, concentrated on those areas of difference. I might say that, in the Senate when that was pointed out early in the debate in the Senate, Government senators chose not to follow their Minister's line in that sort of attack on the Opposition. I reiterate that I regret the fact that the honourable member for Calwell has seen fit to repeat it here today.

The subject of immigration and ethnic affairs, which includes the subject of citizenship of this nation, is one area of government which calls for a high degree of bipartisanship, together with such areas as foreign affairs and defence. I shall have more to say later in my speech on bipartisanship. However, I say at this stage that bipartisanship is not silent acquiescence in anything a government does. It is something a government extends to an Opposition and to which an Opposition responds in like spirit. It is a pity that that attitude has been lacking for the entire time of the Hawke Government, in contrast to the actions of previous governments, and certainly the Fraser Government.

The areas I shall speak about mainly relate to the acquisition of citizenship and to the oath. The reason I confine myself to those two points is that I substantially agree with what the Australian Citizenship Amendment Bill is doing in other areas. The Government is proposing to change the law so that children born in this country to illegal immigrants or illegal residents do not automatically acquire citizenship. Reference has been made in this debate to the Human Rights Commission's reports on this subject. There have been two such reports which were referred to in the Minister's second reading speech. In those reports the Commission pointed out that by taking action to deport illegal immigrants who had children who were Australian citizens by virtue of being born here, the human rights of the children were being violated. However, the Commission did not recommend that the parents should be allowed to stay; their rights were not being violated. It did indeed recommend that the law should be changed along the lines suggested. However, this is not the only change that was possible.

I wish to refer to the speech that was made on 6 May 1982 by the former Minister for Immigration and Ethnic Affairs, the then honourable member for Balaclava. In that statement he supported the `Proposals for Change' to the Australian Citizenship Act which he incorporated in Hansard later in the debate. The then Minister said:

If we value citizenship we should ensure that the laws and procedures which govern it strike a fair and sensible balance between the rights and the freedoms of individuals and the importance of ensuring that the status of being an Australian citizen is not open to abuse. In the present Act--
that is, the Act we are now amending, but he was referring at that time to the unamended Act-

the only persons born in Australia who do not automatically acquire Australian citizenship are the children born to foreign diplomats and those born to enemy aliens occupying Australian territory in time of war. This means that a child born to a tourist who is making a visit of a few days to Australia is automatically an Australian citizen for life even though that child may leave Australia immediately and have no further contact with this country. Equally, illegal immigrants who bear children while in Australia automatically acquire Australian citizenship for those children. There have been tragic cases over recent years where such children have been exploited by their parents to circumvent the normal provision of Australia's immigration Legislation and policy. In other cases the acquisition of Australian citizenship by children in this way is sometimes an inconvenience or embarrassment when they return to another country. But whether such citizenship is wanted or not, its acquisition should not be the result of an accident of timing or the consequence of a contrivance to circumvent Australia's immigration arrangements. Rather, it should reflect a personal commitment or a significant attachment to Australia consistent with Australia's interests and laws.

In view of these considerations it would be logical to confine the acquisition of citizenship by birth to children who are born in Australia to Australian citizens or legal permanent residents. A child born in Australia with neither parent in one or other of these categories would thus not have Australian citizenship.
With that we agree. However, the then Minister continued:

That approach, however logical, contains both humanitarian and administrative difficulties. It would mean that some children could be rendered stateless. Australia, both as a humane society and as a party to the International Convention on the Reduction of Statelessness, could not condone any approach that would lead to such an outcome. Also the practical administrative difficulties of such an approach would be that evidence of birth in Australia would no longer be satisfactory proof of one's being an Australian citizen. Further documentation showing the Citizenship or resident status of one's parents would be necessary and this would impose an unreasonable burden on those Australians who for a variety of reasons are called upon from time to time to provide evidence of their citizenship.
I shall refer to that point briefly in a few moments. It is an important point which is ignored by the Bill before us and ignored by the Minister's second reading speech. The then Minister continued:

There is a compromise which would eliminate most of the anomalies while avoiding inconvenience to the Australian population at large. This would be to require that where a child was born in Australia to parents, neither of whom was an Australian citizen or legal permanent resident, Australian citizenship would be lost if the child left Australia within five years of birth and did not return to Australia for a total of 12 months in the five-year period following that departure. In this way children who are born in Australia to parents who subsequently secure permanent resident status and remain in this country, would be deemed to have been citizens from birth. At the same time, we would avoid automatically bestowing Australian citizenship on the significant number of children whose families have no plan to continue residence in this country and, in many cases, no wish to see Australian citizenship thrust upon their children simply because of an accident of birth.

I am sorry that the present Minister has chosen to ignore that suggestion of the former Minister for Immigration and Ethnic Affairs. There are people with children born here who return home, who then come back quite legally, subsequently become permanent residents, and maybe even citizens, whose children will be put into an ambiguous or difficult position under this amendment. It is not an insuperable problem, but if that humane suggestion of the Fraser Government Minister for Immigration had been followed it would have been a better amendment.

In relation to reports which have been made on the subject, as the Minister said in his second reading speech, the Human Rights Commission recommended a change along the lines of this amendment. It put in a qualification that the children should not be rendered stateless. However, the Commission was not at all helpful on the other problems raised by the former Minister in his statement on the subject. For example, the Human Rights Commission August 1982 Report on the Australian Citizenship Act 1948 contained no comment on this aspect of the proposed amendment. It ignored that subject, as it did in subsequent reports on the subject of deportation of children born to aliens in this country. The report of the National Consultations on Multiculturalism and Citizenship had this to say on the proposal relating to a child of a temporary resident or prohibited immigrant:

This proposal was not the subject of close examination. One speaker expressed the view that citizenship by birth should be inviolable, but no-one addressed the reasons for the proposed amendment or suggested other means of resolving the problems it sought to overcome. One speaker, identified as a temporary resident of Australia, argued that, if the proposed amendment was introduced, the temporary resident parents of the child should be permitted to remain in Australia for the five years necessary for the child to have its citizenship confirmed.

Of course, if the person were permitted to remain as a resident for five years, it is highly likely that he or she would be well into train of getting his permanent residency approved. That argument reveals that having a child born in Australia is a device that temporary residents and illegal immigrants have used, and it is not a line that should be pursued. The report was otherwise quite unhelpful on the subject.

However, there was a report called `Who Calls Australia Home?' by the House of Representatives Standing Committee on Expenditure, tabled in the Parliament in November 1985, which also addressed this subject. I shall not give the full quotation, but part of it states:
The Committee is aware that such a change to legislation-
that is, a change along the lines being proposed in this Bill-

would impose considerable administrative difficulties under the system presently operating whereby births are registered by State Registrars. These bureaucratic impediments would appear to have been overcome in other parts of the world.

The Committee then went on to recommend the type of amendment that we are looking at. However, it did at least recognise that there are certain difficulties that flow from this amendment, and specifically in relation to how such a child's birth is to be registered. It should be remembered that the former Government's Minister for Immigration pointed out that it is possible for a tourist, who has absolutely no intention of remaining in Australia, to have a child while here. There ought to be some form of registration of the birth. This Minister totally ignores that. These amendments ignore that. I hope that by the end of the second reading debate, the Minister can say something fairly useful on the matter, otherwise, these amendments will lead to some confusion.

TALK.START.PARA: —He is not even here.
—Yes, I am aware of that, and I hope that he or someone answerable to him is taking notice of this.
—It is compulsory listening.

—The Minister at the table says that it is compulsory listening. I am sure that it is for someone. On the subject of the oath, I would agree with our shadow Minister for Immigration and Ethnic Affairs, the honourable member for Mitchell (Mr Cadman), and what he said. In the first place, in relation to the statement of names-some comments have been made on that-the Minister said in his second reading speech that it is unnecessary for people to state their name while taking the oath or affirmation of allegiance `because the candidates have already been identified and will be identified again when called to receive their certificates'. He went on to say:

SPEECH.PARA: . . . in many cases the requirement creates confusion and this confusion often detracts from the ceremony and distracts candidates' attention from the more important declaration of allegiance and commitment to obey the law.

I have three local authorities in the electorate of Moncrieff, and there would be a large number of members of this House who would have at least that number of local authorities, and probably many more. Each one of them, the Beaudesert Shire Council, the Albert Shire Council and the Gold Coast City Council, have different citizenship ceremonies, and each has its merits. But at most that I have attended, candidates are not identified prior to taking the oath or affirmation. The Minister says that it is unnecessary to state a name because the candidates have already been identified. They might have been identified by a piece of paper, such as a birth certificate or something, but they are not identified in connection with that actual oath or affirmation, which is the critical act necessary for the taking of citizenship. As I have said, I have seen those three local authorities in my electorate handle this matter in different ways. I have also attended Brisbane City Council ceremonies, which tend to be very large. At no time has the statement of candidates names in any way detracted from the ceremony, which can be of a variable quality anyway, depending on the local authority. If there is some confusion in the candidate's mind or someone's mind, that is the responsibility of the authority, or the responsibility of the Federal member when attending to point out to the authority that perhaps the ceremony could be done in another way; the member could make a helpful suggestion. If there is confusion, the local authority would certainly be aware of it and be looking for ways to improve its ceremony to overcome it. I incline towards keeping in the statement of the name because that makes the oath or affirmation personal to the person taking it. It is not an indirect or impersonal form of words; it becomes personal to people when they state their names.

So far as the matter of renouncing other allegiance is concerned, the former Minister for Immigration and Ethnic Affairs certainly clarified the position when making the statement to which I have earlier referred. He said:

Any change of wording to the oath and affirmation is likely to lead to debate. One option would be a rephrasing giving primary emphasis to the responsibilities of the new citizenship to Australia while clarifying that allegiance to a foreign state or sovereign is only being renounced, and not allegiance to cultural heritage.
The Human Rights Commission, in its report on the subject, said:

The Commission noted the Minister's announcement that the wording of the oath will be changed to stress that persons are not renouncing all cultural ties with their former country. Depending on its precise formulation, this could substantially meet the points made by the Commission.

Those points, which I do not have time to read out, refer to the effect of renunciation and the fear that migrants have that they are being required to renounce their cultural heritage. At no stage has that been suggested. In fact, it was our intention in government, and we support it in opposition, that that should not be the form of renunciation. However, we still consider it important that because the significance, indeed, the gravity, of the oath or affirmation of allegiance, the critical act of consciously changing one's citizenship, the renunciation of allegiance to another power is important, and, indeed, could be very important under some circumstances.

The Minister said in his second reading speech that the National Consultations in 1982 and the Human Rights Commission recommended either the clarification of the phrase or its deletion. In fact, they recommend deletion only if a wording cannot be found that clarifies the effect of renumeration. It was not an either/or situation. The report arising out of the National Consultations had this to say:

Discussion on the element of renunciation in the Oath tended to be lacking in clarity . . . it was thought highly repugnant that a person granted Australian citizenship should retain allegiance to another nation or power. This concern appeared to focus on national affiliations and obligations in time of war, whereas opposition to the renunciation seemed, in the main, directed to the denial of cultural heritage or a psychological attachment to a former homeland. It is probable that a clearer wording would resolve some of the apparent disagreement.

This brings me to my final point, because my time is nearly up. This is the point made by the honourable member for Mitchell. It is a great pity that the Minister has apparently, off the top of his head, come up with this particular revised wording of the affirmation or oath. No one ever suggested in all these reports that the person's name should be taken out. There were suggestions of modification in relation to renouncing allegiance. The Opposition does not support this suggested rewording. If the Minister had consulted more widely he could have achieved bipartisanship on the subject.

TALK.START.PARA: —Order! The honourable member's time has expired.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Charlesworth Dr R.I.

TALK.START.PARA: —I must say that when I first heard the second reading speech of the Minister for Immigration and Ethnic Affairs (Mr Hurford) with regard to the Australian Citizenship Amendment Bill 1986, it seemed to me that it was a very common-sense measure. Indeed, I suppose I should not be surprised that the Opposition is attempting to make this into a controversial matter. As usual, honourable members opposite are concerned about consultation, and they complain that there has not been any. I think that just points out more than anything else the lack of contact they have with the ethnic communities in this country, because I am aware that this is not seen as controversial by ethnic communities. I am aware of the record of honourable members opposite with respect to consultation. I remember very well attending a meeting in Perth at which the honourable member for Petrie (Mr Hodges) officiated when he was the Minister in charge of the immigration portfolio. Consultation is important. However, eventually someone has to make decisions with respect to these matters. This Bill is a very commonsense way of going about closing some of the loopholes and solving some of the problems that exist in this area.

SPEECH.PARA: The purpose of the Bill is to amend the Australian Citizenship Act 1948. It further builds on initiatives this Government has taken to encourage those who have come to this country to take up citizenship. Measures include the decrease in the qualification time for citizenship, changes to the English language requirements and the removal of certain discriminations which previously existed. The amendments contained in the Bill are not complex or controversial. That would be the case certainly in my electorate which contains a very high percentage of migrants.

Principally, the Bill amends the Australian Citizenship Act 1948 to exclude children born to visitors, temporary residents and prohibited non-citizens from automatic acquisition of Australian citizenship by birth. We are all aware-it has been mentioned in this debate today-of recent decisions by the Human Rights Commission, media attention and High Court of Australia appeals which, in effect, have assisted attempts of illegal immigrants to stay in this country because of the present provision. It is a loophole which has allowed people to jump the queue, so to speak. It is only fair that this loophole should be closed. I believe that the Minister for Immigration and Ethnic Affairs (Mr Hurford) has taken responsible action in doing so. Fecundity in Australia should not be a determinant of whether people stay in this country. When more than a million people apply through correct channels every year to enter this country, others should not be able to slip past the queue.

Honourable members are contacted in their offices on a weekly basis by constituents with respect to change of status claims. We hear elaborate stories of hardship. We are constantly beset with cases which involve, perhaps, bogus marriages. That is an aspect of the present situation which requires attention. I am sure many of us are aware that Ronald Biggs avoided extradition from Brazil by fathering a child there. We do not want that sort of a complication to become commonplace with respect to our citizenship laws. It is not appropriate for illegal immigrants to be able to stay in this country by using the provisions of the Citizenship Act.

Other provisions in the legislation concern the resumption of Australian citizenship by those who have lost or forfeited it. Sometimes this comes about as a result of economic necessity on the part of those who are living in other countries. On other occasions it is caused by compulsion, or without those who are implicated recognising the consequences. Within my electorate there is a large Jewish community. The provisions with respect to travel in Israel have caused its members difficulties. It will now be possible, thanks to legislation, for those people to be able to reaffirm their commitment to Australia, thereby avoiding the difficulties which previously have beset them.

We hear of all sorts of incredible cases with respect to those who have lost citizenship. I remember a case within my electorate of a person who had lived in Australia for 18 years, had had four Australian passports since he left the country, found out that he did not have Australian citizenship and had great difficulty in obtaining that citizenship. I think that common sense prevailed in that case. I hope that it prevails with respect to this legislation.

The final and, it seems, the most controversial aspect of this legislation which has stirred up loathing on the other side of the House is the oath or affirmation of allegiance. It appears that honourable members opposite wish to wrap themselves in the flag. With sanctimonious bleatings of nationalism, they complain about some minor changes to the citizenship ceremony which I believe from my experience are quite necessary. Certainly I know that at the city council citizenship ceremonies which I attend-those of the Perth City Council, the Stirling City Council and the Bayswater City Council-there is identification of those who are to take their place as new citizens before the ceremony begins. It seems that there could be no more personal affirmation by those who are taking part in the ceremony than for them to use the word `I' before they take their oaths of allegiance. Subsequent to the ceremony's completion they are again identified by name and their certificates are handed to them. I do not believe that it is necessary to continue the confusing present practice whereby people taking part in the ceremony are asked to supply their names. There is often confusion and the momentum of the oath is lost. The change seems to me to be very simple and worthwhile and to detract not at all from the present procedure.

The renunciation of one's previous allegiance seems to be a cause of great concern on the other side of the House. I think it is necessary to reiterate the point made by the honourable member for Calwell (Dr Theophanous), who mentioned that one minute we ask British subjects from the United Kingdom to renounce the Queen and, in the next few seconds, we ask them to announce their allegiance to the Queen. That is confusing and unnecessary. The suggestion has come from the other side of the House that, because some countries apply the renunciation provision, we should also do so. However, equally, many countries do not apply it. The United Kingdom, Canada and New Zealand are examples of countries where renunciation is not required. It seems to me that we have a great deal in common with those nations. Therefore, to suggest that we should follow a particular path because other countries do so seems to me to be quite absurd.

There is a concern that, by asking people to renounce their previous allegiance, we are asking them to renounce their cultural heritage. That is not the case. It is not applied. We can avoid that confusion by doing as suggested in this legislation and not requiring the renunciation of previous allegiances. In some countries such renunciation is not even accepted when it applies. For instance, on returning to Greece, a Greek citizen who has become an Australian citizen can be drafted into the army and the renunciation of his Greek citizenship is not accepted in Greece. That is another example of the absurdity of the argument which has been put forward by those on the other side of the House. Again, many countries allow more than one citizenship.

If this legislation is accepted by this place it will involve a more flexible approach. I believe that it goes to the intention of the Act. This legislation tidies up the anomalies that exist and removes a great deal of the confusion that new citizens find with respect to the citizenship ceremony. In my view, the legislation makes a lot of sense. I commend the Bill to the House.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Slipper Mr P.N.

TALK.START.PARA: —Like other members, I am very pleased with the very large degree of bipartisanship we find in this place and in our nation generally relating to citizenship and many other immigration matters. I am pleased that most honourable members, certainly all honourable members on our side of the House, have pointed out this fact. It is unfortunate that the honourable member for Calwell (Dr Theophanous) saw fit to introduce a contrary note in his speech. No doubt he will be judged for that.

SPEECH.PARA: There are a number of objectives of the Australian Citizenship Amendment Bill 1986. There is a provision whereby inadvertent loss of citizenship by virtue of the 1984 amendments to the principal Act is redressed. There is also a removal of automatic citizenship for children born in Australia by granting citizenship only to those with one parent who is a permanent resident or citizen of this country. There are the very controversial changes to the oath or affirmation. As one would expect in an humanitarian society, there is a provision to ensure that abandoned children do not become stateless. Certain administrative errors are redressed and I suppose in keeping with current attitudes we find that the alleged sexist language of bygone days is removed.

It was interesting to hear in this debate some mention of the Human Rights Commission and its reports on various immigration matters. I suppose with the shocking record of the Human Rights Commission in so many fields where it endeavours to subvert the values which we hold so dear, one ought to treat the reports of the Human Rights Commission with some suspicion. Indeed, I believe that the people of Australia will treat reports of that Commission with suspicion. It is a body which should be abolished forthwith upon the Opposition's return to office. Notwithstanding that, the Commission has drawn to the attention of the Government and the people of Australia the predicament and plight of certain children born here to prohibited non-citizens who have been deported along with their parents. I believe that the Government's approach to this aspect in the Bill should be commended because most countries in the world do not treat citizenship in a cavalier manner and I do not believe that the people of Australia should either.

Many people have endeavoured to subvert the intention of the Immigration Act. Couples have come here on holidays with the wives being very close to giving birth. When the children are born they obtain Australian citizenship for life. I do not think that it is the intention of the Government, the National Party of Australia or the Liberal Party of Australia that these sorts of subterfuges should be accepted and that these sorts of situations should be permitted to continue. Therefore we applaud the Amendments in the Bill in relation to this area.

Like other members on this side, including the shadow Minister, I express my concern at the changes in the wording of the oath and affirmation of allegiance. I was, however, very pleased to find that the oath or affirmation of allegiance to Her Majesty, Queen Elizabeth II, Queen of Australia, is to remain because with the avowed republican tendencies of many people on the other side of the House-

TALK.START.PARA: —All of them.

—Perhaps all of them, as the honourable member for Groom quite correctly points out. In view of that fact, I thought we may have seen in a Bill the deletion of the oath or affirmation of allegiance to Her Majesty. The Australian Labor Party has in its platform that Australia should become a republic and it is interesting to note that current opinion polls show that the people of Australia support the position of the National Party and the Liberal Party, which is that the Queen should remain the Queen of Australia. We are proud to have her as our Head of State and I have no doubt that the monarchy will continue forever.
—Hear, hear!
—I thank the shadow Minister for his support on this matter.

SPEECH.PARA: The shadow Minister pointed out earlier the devaluing of the act of taking Australian citizenship which occurs when the new citizen does not have to state his or her name in the actual citizenship ceremony. While members on the Labor side have expressed the opinion that people are adequately identified without actually having to state their name in the citizenship ceremony, mistakes could be made. I have been to some very large citizenship ceremonies and I have seen up to 70 or 80 people become Australian citizens at the one ceremony. While they have to stand up at times when their name is mentioned it may be, because of the large numbers, that the person does not have to state his or her name when taking the act of citizenship and the person might be mistaken in some way, with the result that the citizenship ceremony does not apply to that person.

I draw to the attention of the House the situation of the Pine Rivers Shire Council which is a very large local authority partly in my electorate of Fisher. It has monthly citizenship ceremonies and the Shire invites me, as the member for Fisher, and my colleague the honourable member for Petrie (Mr Hodges), to attend and witness the citizenship ceremonies and to say a few words-on behalf of the Commonwealth Parliament-to the people who are taking this momentous step forward. I commend the Shire and indeed all other local authorities in my electorate of Fisher because they make the act of taking Australian citizenship very meaningful and fulfilling.

After the formal Pine River Shire Council citizenship ceremony, when the Shire Chairman administers the oath or affirmation, there is a practice of handing a small tree to each new citizen. The people come forward one by one to receive this tree. Hopefully they take it home and plant it and as they watch that tree grow it will remind them of the very important step taken when they became Australian citizens. It is of great concern that the Government has not considered or consulted with migrant groups and ethnic communities on the new form of the oath and affirmation of allegiance--

TALK.START.PARA: —All Australians.

—Indeed, or all Australians, as the shadow Minister quite correctly points out. If there is to be a substantial element of bipartisanship in this matter, the onus is on the Government to make sure that the people of Australia are happy with the changes which are being introduced. As was pointed out by another member on this side, there has been no suggestion by any member, not even by the Human Rights Commission-that hopeless group-that there should be the deletion of the name of the person taking the actual oath or affirmation of allegiance. I think that the Government should reconsider this. I hope that the Senate will amend this Bill to make sure that the Government is not successful in sneaking this change through behind the backs of the people of Australia.

SPEECH.PARA: I emphasise that we in the National Party and the Liberal Party reject absolutely the statement that the honourable member for Perth (Dr Charlesworth) made when he claimed that we were taking a controversial approach on these matters. We are not taking a controversial approach at all. We are, however, quite prepared to stand up in this place and, indeed, we make no apology for doing so, to state where we disagree with the Government's attitude or approach. I think that the Australian public is quite happy for us to do that. In fact, it is our duty to point out where the Government is going wrong. The honourable member for Perth also claimed that we wrap ourselves in the flag. After seeing that pathetic piece-I do not know what one should call it-that pathetic new Australian alternative flag brought out by Ausflag yesterday, we do not apologise for wrapping ourselves in the flag.

TALK.START.PARA: —Order! The Bill is relevant to citizenship, not the Ausflag.
—It is part of it. Fair go.
—Mr Deputy Speaker, thank you very much for your guidance.
—Did the honour- able member for Groom reflect on the Chair?
—I withdraw what I said if you thought I reflected on the Chair.

—As always, Mr Deputy Speaker, I appreciate your guidance. However, I would like to point out that the flag reflects or results in national pride, and national pride is one of the characteristics of our new citizens. I was only commenting on the remark made by the honourable member for Perth who pointed out that we wrap ourselves in the flag. We make no apology for doing so because we support the Australian flag 100 per cent. People agree with us and that is the message that is coming back to me, indeed, as it is also to all members on this side of the House. I congratulate the Minister for Immigration and Ethnic Affairs (Mr Hurford)-it is a pity that he is not in the House-on the manner in which he deals with immigration queries. While the Minister and I have many political differences, I have found that the Minister always administers his portfolio and the matters I raise for his consideration with a caring compassion which is a real credit to him. I hope that with the continuing large numbers of immigration queries which I get on a regular basis, I will continue to receive the same caring consideration.

SPEECH.PARA: Much has been said about this Bill. The shadow Minister has pointed out in a very effective way the approach of the Opposition parties. I endorse what he said. Along with all other members of the National Party, I welcome the broad thrust of this Bill subject, of course, to the matters we have highlighted. I hope that the Government will grab this golden opportunity to reconsider those matters with which we disagree so that once again there can be a genuine continuation of the bipartisanship which we have in this area.
(Quorum formed)

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Blanchard Mr C.A.

TALK.START.PARA: —I support the Australian Citizenship Amendment Bill 1986, which was introduced by the Minister for Immigration and Ethnic Affairs (Mr Hurford). Of course, he is a successor to a number of Ministers in holding that portfolio, all of whom have served the portfolio with distinction, but none more so than the late Arthur Calwell, the very first Minister for Immigration, who can be described as the architect of post-war migration to this country. It is interesting to note that Arthur Calwell's maternal grandfather was an illegal immigrant, having jumped ship in Melbourne in 1847. Obviously the social and economic conditions in this country in 1945 were vastly different, because of the impact of the Second World War, from those existing today.

SPEECH.PARA: No other country has done as much for its migrants in the post-war era as Australia. The credit for this lies in the policies on both sides of the chamber. I give credit to those opposite who have tried to pursue a bipartisan policy. This Bill has four principal purposes. The first is to exclude children born in Australia to visitors, temporary entrants and prohibited non-citizens from automatically acquiring Australian citizenship. The second is to amend the oath and affirmation of allegiance to remove the following requirements of persons taking such oaths or affirmation: The requirement to announce one's name and the requirement to renounce all other allegiances. The third purpose is to allow resumption of citizenship for persons who lost it under section 17 of the Australian Citizenship Act at any time subject to a continuing commitment to Australia. The fourth part will effect other minor and formal amendments to the Act to remove sexist language and anomalies and to make the legislation more specific.

At present section 10 of the Act provides that persons born in Australia, other than children born of diplomats, consular officials and enemy aliens, automatically become Australian citizens. Clause 4 of the Bill has the effect of amending section 10 so that a person born in Australia after the amendment comes into effect will be an Australian citizen only if at the time of birth at least one of the parents is either an Australian citizen or a permanent resident. The obvious effect of that change is that children of visitors, temporary entrants and prohibited non-citizens will no longer automatically acquire Australian citizenship simply because they were born in Australia.

A number of speakers on both sides of the House have pointed out that this principle has resulted in queue jumping in terms of migration to Australia. However, such persons born in Australia can acquire Australian citizenship if they can prove that they have been ordinary residents for 10 years from the date of birth. A recent survey showed that Australia was one of only seven countries where children born in the country automatically acquire citizenship even though the parents are only temporary residents. Apart from Australia, the countries are the United States of Australia, New Zealand, Argentina, Fiji, Malaysia and Canada. The important point is that the majority of countries, including the United Kingdom, do not allow automatic citizenship on those grounds.

A factor which cannot be overlooked is that for some temporary residents the birth of a child has been grounds for seeking permanent residency for themselves as parents of the child. We must bear in mind-this has been mentioned by other speakers-that about one million inquiries are received each year by the Department of Immigration and Ethnic Affairs which express interest in migration to Australia. Our migrant intake is only 80,000 migrants each year. This means that many people wishing to come to Australia will be disappointed. They will not have the opportunity of attaining that desire. Hence, if people gain permanent residency on the basis of the birth of a child in Australia, some families or individuals who wish to immigrate, or are on a waiting list to come under the family reunion scheme, have to wait longer. This is unfair on those who have been accepted for migration to Australia and have gone through the legitimate process to secure their acceptance.

The extent of the problem-and it is serious-can be gauged by the fact that the number of persons seeking a change of status on the basis of having an Australian-born child has increased considerably in recent years.

Pre-1982-83, there was an average of 3,000 such applications. In that year, 1982-83, the number rose to 5,025 persons and subsequently rose in the following year to 7,422 persons. Whilst I have no later figures, I understand from the Department that the number of such applications still remains high. Obviously, if applications for change of status are successful, such persons can apply for the grant of citizenship in the normal manner. Whilst I sympathise with those here on a temporary visa to see relatives and who, if a child is born to the visitors during the stay, would like to remain, I have more sympathy for those waiting patiently overseas in a long queue to come to Australia, having been accepted for migration.

I am very pleased to learn that there is a fair degree of bipartisanship on this issue. The Human Rights Commission, in its reports 10 and 15 recommended that the Act be amended to ensure that children born in Australia of temporary residents or prohibited non-citizens should not acquire citizenship by birth provided that as a result they do not become stateless. The important point to make is that that should apply only provided that such children do not become stateless. This matter has been attended to by amendment to section 23d. The effect of this amendment will be that a person born in Australia, neither of whose parents is an Australian citizen or a permanent resident, will be registered as an Australian citizen subject to that person not being a citizen of any country and is not and has never been entitled to acquire the citizenship of a foreign country. This is a humane provision which I am sure is welcomed on both sides of the House. I am very pleased that it has been inserted in this Bill.

The second purpose of this Bill is to amend the oath and affirmation of allegiance to remove the requirements to announce one's name and to renounce all other allegiance. As a Federal member, like all other members I try to attend as many citizenship ceremonies as I can in my electorate. Some of those ceremonies are quite large. The honourable member for Fisher (Mr Slipper) mentioned that he attends large ones at which there are 70 people. In the city of Wanneroo, there are ceremonies which attract over 200 people and nearly 300 people on occasions. All of those people take either the oath or the affirmation. Because of the numbers of people participating in ceremonies in that city, they are brought before the mayor in groups of up to 40 persons. Of course, as is the usual procedure, they are asked to repeat the oath or affirmation. One can imagine the cacophony that occurs when 40 persons individually say their names. The removal of the requirement for a person to announce his or her name is to be commended.

For many years there has been a debate in ethnic communities about the need to renounce all other allegiances. Some of the arguments were outlined, as the honourable member for Moncrieff (Mrs Sullivan) mentioned earlier, in the report on `National Consultations on Multiculturalism and Citizenship', published in August 1982 by the Department of Immigration and Ethnic Affairs. On page 24 of that report, there is reference to this area. There is no doubt that there has been confusion in the area. I will read out some of the relevant points from that report:

Discussion on the element of renunciation in the Oath tended to be lacking in clarity. One speaker argued against any form of renunciation as smacking of moralism. Others noted that such a renunciation was not legally binding; nevertheless, though it was a deterrent to some honest people, it failed as a restraint on unscrupulous people who would swear to anything.
