DEBATE.SUB1.TITLE: Australian Submarine Construction Site-Nuclear Disarmament-South Australia: 150th Anniversary-Hawke Government-Australian Video Industry-Australian Rural Industry-New South Wales Tertiary Education-Australian Council of Trade Unions: Proposed Superannuation Scheme-Catholic Commission for Justice and Peace

PROCTEXT.PARA: Question proposed:
That grievances be noted.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Reith Mr P.K.

TALK.START.PARA: —The proposal to build Australia's next generation of submarines in Australia at a cost of $2.5 billion is of great significance to Australian industry and to Australia as a whole. Although most States are lobbying for the project it is clear that Victoria, with its strong industrial base, is the leading contender. Unfortunately, the Victorian Government is also leading in the pork barrel stakes. This is one project that must transcend pork barrel politics.

SPEECH.PARA: In Victoria there are now two potential submarine construction sites under consideration by the two competing consortia, due in large part to the efforts of Mr Robin Cooper, MP, the considerable efforts of the Hastings Shire, including the Shire President, Councillor Sue Wilding, and the very efficient Shire Secretary, Mr Bill Featherston and myself. One site is Corio, near Geelong-and I am very pleased to see the local member in the chamber-and the other is Western Port, which is a better site than the State Government's preferred option of Corio Bay.

When the concept of building submarines was first raised publicly by Mr Cooper, the MLA for Mornington and shadow Minister for Local Government and Public Works, we were told that the Victorian Government had decided to promote Corio as the best potential construction site in Victoria. We would have expected, and did expect, that the Government would have investigated all potential sites in Victoria before making a final decision to support Corio. We did, however, Mr Deputy Speaker, do our homework. Under the Freedom of Information Act we have been able to prove that the Victorian Government gave no consideration whatsoever to any other potential site in Victoria. It has consistently pushed only Corio Bay for the construction site. By this blatant, blinkered, parochial, pork barrel attitude, it may in fact have blown any chance of obtaining the construction site for Victoria. It is putting all its eggs in one basket without considering any other industrial ports in the State. No reports were called for, nor was consideration given to Western Port-all in the face of the Government's responsibility to all Victorians, not just Australian Labor Party members in the Geelong area, to ensure that the best possible sites in Victoria were promoted to increase Victoria's chances of obtaining the pro- ject. The Victorian Government, in a letter from the relevant Minister, dated 29 January 1986 said:

Until and unless the tender firms show a definite interest in pursuing and evaluating further the new Western Port sites, the Government is not prepared to make any commitment in relation to support for the Western Port alternative to Corio.

This is a blinkered attitude which is not prepared to evaluate objectively all available ports and promote them with equal vigour to the tender firms. As an aside, I note that on the Victorian Government's own criteria Western Port qualifies for its support as both consortia have shown a definite interest in Western Port and, I might add, to the embarrassment of the State Government.

Mr Deputy Speaker, I am not going to stand here today and knock the Corio site, as first and foremost I believe that there are sufficient economic reasons to justify the project coming to Victoria. However, on any independent point by point assessment of Corio Bay versus Western Port it is clear that Western Port wins hands down. That is the basis upon which I raise the issue of pork barrelling, which is the one factor which could lose this project for Western Port. Let me state clearly: The submarine project is a national one and should be judged on national criteria and not whether the particular State or local member is a Liberal or a Labor member. The honourable member for Dunkley (Mr Chynoweth), after attacking Mr Cooper and me publicly for actively promoting Western Port, has claimed that he has been quietly working in the background promoting Western Port. It is not for me to doubt his interests but he and I, as local members of parliament, and others in the area, should work together in a sense of co-operation. I encourage the honourable member not to knock this campaign but to join in and publicly help promote our area's claims.

As was said recently by the Leader of the National Party of Australia (Mr Sinclair), the Australian submarine project has to be located in an area where it can be successfully and economically constructed for the benefit of all Australians. Western Port is one of the few sites in Australia that meets those requirements. It is one of Australia's finest deep water ports, located south-east of Melbourne, lying partly within the Melbourne metropolitan area. Western Port provides a natural deep water anchorage and access channel to the open sea. Access to the proposed construction site at Crib Point is not restricted by either the draught of the vessels or the tides and is certainly not restricted by the possibility of bad weather, which occasionally has closed Port Phillip Bay. Furthermore, sufficient area of deep and relatively sheltered water exists to allow proper sea trials, including preliminary test runs and submergence trials to take place close to base in Western Port Bay itself.

There are several Western Port sites, either privately-owned or State-owned, available for the project with the prime one having ample space, good soil and ready access to deep water. Local heavy industry is already established in the Hastings area. In particular, and of importance to a shipbuilding project, is the existence of Broken Hill Proprietary Co. Ltd's coated products steel plant-formerly Lysaghts-which is one of the most modern rolling mills in the world. It is capable of rolling steel plate up to 1.5 inches thick. We would assume that, unless the Government's eventual choice of site for the building is either Whyalla or Newcastle, the steel plate used would undoubtedly come from the BHP plant and that would have cost advantages to the project.

In addition to that plant, there are a number of other local facilities, including HMAS Cerberus. Whilst civilians would be involved in the construction project, I believe that the proximity of naval resources and personnel would facilitate the project. Western Port also has the Esso refractionation plant. In addition, a number of engineering works provide immediate back-up resources to these major industrial plants.

In the greater Melbourne-Port Phillip Bay area, the majority of supporting heavy and light industry is concentrated in the Dandenong and Clayton areas and hence is readily accessible from a site on Western Port Bay. It is understood that one of the attractions of the Corio Bay site is the financial incentive that the State Government is prepared to offer the successful tenderer to undertake the works at Corio Bay. I now call on the Victorian Government to state unequivocally that the same financial incentives already available to Corio will be offered to the tenderers if they decide that Western Port is the preferred site in Victoria. Another of Western Port's characteristics and attractions is the fact that the centres of Frankston and Dandenong have ample supplies of labour and first class management services available.

Mr Deputy Speaker, I do not believe in pork barrel politics but I do believe in the people in the State of Victoria and particularly the people in my electorate of Flinders, especially those who are unemployed. The Mornington Peninsula with 6,967 persons unemployed as at June 1985 ranks as the third highest unemployment area in Australia, exceeded only by Bondi with 8,972 and Cabramatta with 7,851 persons registered for unemployment benefit. Whilst clearly absolute numbers of unemployment are not necessarily a major consideration, when all other things are equal I believe that they are a factor which becomes worthy of consideration. I am not talking about jobs for the Labor Party boys here, such as trade commission posts in Canada, but jobs for the ordinary unemployed people whereby they can contribute to their own well-being and the advancement and security of our nation.

The Prime Minister (Mr Hawke) recently hit an all-time high in the pork barrelling stakes in Western Australia over the fertiliser bounty issue. That was so blatant that even Blind Freddie could see he was attempting to buy the rural vote. I wonder whether the submarine construction project is going to receive similar treatment from this Prime Minister, or whether he will genuinely consider the national interests before his own or that of his Labor colleagues. Western Port is an eminently suitable site from a location, engineering, infrastructure, administrative and work force supply point of view. Accordingly, I believe it should be selected as the site for the construction of Australia's next generation of submarines.

All I ask for is for a fair go for Western Port Bay. I ask that the State Government give an assurance that it will offer the same financial package as it is offering to Corio to whatever site is selected. I ask the Federal Government to ensure that, when it makes the final decision in 12 to 18 months, instead of applying affirmative action to the demands of the pork barrelling Victorian State Government, it holds fast to the principle that the site be chosen on its merits.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Milton Mr P.

TALK.START.PARA: —In the International Year of Peace it is important for all those people who are dedicated to peace and disarmament, and particularly to nuclear disarmament, to speak out. It is for this reason that I am speaking in the grievance debate today although I have no doubt that my motives for speaking will be misrepresented by some members of the Opposition and the conservative forces they represent.

SPEECH.PARA: In January of this year, the Soviet leader, Mikhail Gorbachev, proposed a step by step program leading to the diminution of nuclear weapons by the end of the century. In the first stage, within the next five to eight years, the Union of Soviet Socialist Republics and the United States of America would reduce by one-half those nuclear arms which can reach each other's territory and of the remaining delivery vehicles each side would retain no more than 6,000 warheads. In the second stage, to start no later than 1990 and to last for five to seven years, the other nuclear powers would begin to engage in nuclear disarmament by freezing all their nuclear arms and to withdraw them from the territories of other countries. During this period Russia and America would carry out reductions agreed upon during the first stage and also carry out further measures designed to eliminate their medium range nuclear weapons and freeze their tactical nuclear systems. Following the completion by the USSR and America of the 50 per cent reduction in their relevant arms at the second stage, all nuclear powers would eliminate their tactical nuclear arms, namely those weapons having a range or radius of action of up to 1,000 kilometres. At the same time, the Soviet-American accord on the prohibition of space strike weapons will become multilateral with the mandatory participation of the major industrial powers.

Together with all these initiatives by the two super-powers, all the nuclear powers would stop their nuclear weapons tests. The Soviet leader also proposed a ban on the development of non-nuclear weapons based on new technology involving a destructive capacity close to that of nuclear weapons or other weapons of mass destruction. A final stage, beginning no later than 1995, would see the elimination of all remaining nuclear weapons by the end of 1999. The year 2000 will be celebrated by drawing up a universal accord banning nuclear weapons for ever.

The Soviet leader emphasised that the nuclear weapons elimination program was dependent upon Russia and America mutually renouncing the development, testing and development of small strike weapons. It must also be borne in mind that this radical program was proposed by the USSR despite the rejection by America of the extension by the Soviet Union of its nuclear test moratorium.

President Reagan's initial response to the proposed nuclear weapons elimination program was quite warm until his military advisers got to him. There is no doubt that President Reagan's support for the strategic defence initiative-better known as the Star Wars program-will continue to provide a major stumbling block to any real progress in arms reductions. Mr Gorbachev has said that the development of a space based missile defence system by the United States could lead to strategic chaos and a new uncontrollable round in the arms race. Serious questions must be asked about the reasons behind President Reagan's support for Star Wars. Almost certainly, his advisers are supporting the views of the military and industrial business leaders that Star Wars is necessary. Major corporations like General Dynamics, General Electric and Westinghouse stand to gain very profitable contracts from the Star Wars weapons development programs. So much is at stake that the same companies are prepared to take out full page advertisements in newspapers in order to frighten the American public about the Russian threat and to gain taxpayers' support for these highly profitable weapons systems. No one should forget that it was President Eisenhower who warned the American people of the potential power of the military-industrial complex in his farewell speech of 17 January 1961. He said:

In the councils of Government, we must guard against the acquisition of unwarranted influence, whether sought or unsought, by the military-industrial complex. The potential for the destructive use of misplaced power exists and will persist . . . Only an alert and knowledgeable citizenry can compel the proper meshing of the huge industrial and military machine of defense with our peaceful methods and goals, so that security and liberty may prosper together.

So said President Eisenhower, and in today's climate his warning is even more relevant than it was when it was first made. President Reagan's fiscal budget for 1987 is expected to propose an increase in Defense Department spending by nearly 40 per cent over five years while cutting back spending in the areas of housing, education, health and transport.

If the Soviet Union is ahead of America in strategic defence initiatives as some American military advisers claim, then one thing is certain and that is that it is aware of the huge and accelerating costs involved in developing such a program. In the visits I have made to both America and Russia it was very clear that the peoples of both countries want peace. Moreover, the Soviet people suffered the terrible loss of life and desecration of property which total war can bring. Their calls for peace are borne out of the frightening experiences of invasion and occupation which, mercifully, people living in the United States, have never had to face. More importantly though, the Soviet people are demanding a substantial improvement in their standard of living. The Soviet leadership cannot provide more consumer goods for their people while at the same time meeting the astronomical costs of the military expenditure necessary to provide Star Wars fighting capability. It should be obvious to any person with a grain of common sense that it is because of these pressures that the Soviet leadership is calling for arms reductions. They just cannot afford to match the prodigious military spending program proposed by President Reagan.

Nor, indeed, can the American people afford such a program although big business will always be willing to prosper at the expense of the poor. Budget documents show that the American Defense Department outlays will be $258.4 billion in the 1986 fiscal year, rising to $356.6 billion in 1991. It is interesting to compare these figures with the $250 billion each year that it is estimated that United States companies will earn from their commercial activities in the developing countries of the Third World. The overall effect is that the Third World countries are virtually paying for the defence budget of the United States.

In 1986, the International Year of Peace, it is time for the people of the world to speak out against this massive military overspending. On social economic grounds alone we need this money to combat economic backwardness, hunger and disease throughout the world. The human race is at a crucial stage of its development. The advances we are making in technological fields and space exploration and the ability we now have to split the atom and the creation of weapons of mass destruction do not sit comfortably with a Stone Age mentality. To believe that military superiority comes with a bigger stick or a heavier stone should have died with the citizens of Hiroshima and Nagasaki. All peoples of the world need to recognise this fact and act accordingly. The peace proposals put forward by the Soviet Union must be seen as progressive in the light of the nuclear age and should be supported by all the countries of the world.

Before I conclude my remarks, Mr Deputy Speaker, it is important to make some comment about the United States bases in Australia as they can be used for both defensive and offensive purposes. When considering the future of the United States bases it must be remembered that our Government has stated-it was announced by the Minister for Foreign Affairs (Mr Hayden) in August 1984 and reaffirmed by the Minister for Resources and Energy (Senator Gareth Evans) in February 1986-that it would re-evaluate these installations if it was found that they could be used for a nuclear first strike. I understand that the North West Cape joint defence facility now falls into the nuclear first strike category. The United States Defense Secretary, Mr Weinberger, recently told the United States Senate that it was official naval strategy to attack Soviet nuclear-carrying submarines at the outset of a nuclear conflict and in certain circumstances even in a conventional war. The North West Cape facility can be used for such purposes and it is disturbing that the Parliament is not sufficiently informed on these matters. It is vital, in my view, that the Australian public should be more informed about the operations of these bases. The bases are constantly being upgraded and improved and yet the Government does not appear, on the face of it, to wish to seek out the information about the constant upgrading of the capacity of the bases and their purpose. Members of the United States Congress are given an annual update of information on the United States bases in Australia which amounts to several hundreds of pages of information. Why are we members of the House of Representatives, who represent the people of Australia, not given such information? For the sake of world peace it is essential that there is less secrecy about all military organisations. I cannot understand why successive Australian governments refuse to provide information about American bases in this country which is readily available in the United States.

In this respect I have noticed on today's Notice Paper a series of questions to the Minister for Defence (Mr Beazley) on the operations of the joint Australia-United States defence facilities. I would like to congratulate the honourable member for Hughes (Mr Tickner) for his initiative in putting these vital questions to the Minister. I take this opportunity to urge the Minister to provide frank answers to the questions that the honourable member has put to him as there are quite a number of members on this side of the House who are becoming increasingly frustrated at the fact that we have to seek information about the joint defence facilities from sources in the United States.

TALK.START.PARA: —Order! The honourable member's time has expired.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Andrew Mr J.N.

TALK.START.PARA: —I rise in this grievance debate because the year 1986 is, in fact, the year in which South Australia celebrates its sesquicentenary. It is 150 years since the charting of the coast of South Australia by Matthew Flinders and the subsequent pioneering of the River Murray by Charles Sturt and Captain Barker who was determined to set up the free State of South Australia under principles and theories espoused by the man after whom my seat is named, Edward Gibbon Wakefield. it was determined that South Australia would, indeed, be a different State-that South Australia would, unlike its eastern State counterparts, be settled as a free State without convict labour. Some have observed that South Australia decided that they could do very well simply by breeding their own.

SPEECH.PARA: Into this free State there came people of German extraction and Polish extraction, who were fleeing from oppression and who were coming to a State that offered them the opportunity to settle and espouse the things in which they believed. It was not easy either 150 years ago in South Australia or almost 200 years ago at Sydney Cove to be a new settler. Fire, flood and drought beleaguered these people just as all new settlers have faced this sort of dilemma and all pioneers have had to face difficult odds. The facts are that in spite of the uncertain climate, in spite of the well-intentioned land clearance that in some cases resulted in soil erosion, our forefathers forged a community, the financial difficulties of which were largely solved by the discovery of copper at Burra in my electorate. I think it is worth noting that things do not change, in that it was, in fact, the then world demand for copper that made it possible for South Australia to be financially viable and it was the subsequent fall in the world price that threw the State into difficulty.

The point that I want to make in this grievance debate is that in spite of the prejudices and bigotry that these early settlers brought with them, they were so obsessed with enterprise and purpose, and they so believed in the future of the new colony, that they were successful. We, the people of South Australia and the people of this nation, look back on an inheritance which is little more than the length of two lifetimes but which has seen this nation change from a place that was unknown on the face of the earth, and a place that supported a few nomadic tribes, into a nation that now has one of the highest standards of living in the world. It is self-sufficient in food and clothing. It offers its citizens a stable community life. It has inherited a tradition of equality before the law, in which all constituents have the rare privilege of the right to change their democratically elected government. We, as South Australians and Australians, enjoy freedoms known only to a minority of people on the globe-freedom of speech, freedom of association, freedom of religion, freedom to travel where we choose, and freedom to change occupations as we choose. And all of this achieved in the span of little more than two lifetimes.

So my contention in this grievance debate is that our celebrations for South Australia's Jubilee 150 and in preparation for Australia's Bicentenary, ought to be marked by two sentiments: Pride and gratitude. I fear that in Australia in 1986 these two sentiments are sadly lacking. I find instead that there is a pervading sense of apprehension, cynicism, and uncertainty about the Australian community. Whether we are celebrating Jubilee 150 in South Australia or the bicentenary of our nation, we seem to be sadly without a vision and without a sense of purpose.

Nowhere is this more clearly expressed than in the opinions of our young people, and that is simply astonishing. Australia's young people are endowed by world standards with unlimited opportunity. But from the surveys they quite obviously lack confidence in the nation we govern for them and intend to pass on to them. I quote the opening paragraphs of an article in the Age of 7 February:
Sixty per cent of young people in a survey for the Youth Affairs Council of Australia have agreed with the proposition that `the future is so uncertain, it is best to live from day to day'.

The executive director of the Council, Mr Michael Clohesy, said this was basically the pragmatic response of a generation which was uncertain about the future and the institutions which were meant to safeguard it.

I fear that the young people of Australia are obsessed with destruction and my contention in March 1986 is that in a society such as ours, in a nation such as ours, which is by world standards both wealthy and just, we find people who are as cynical and divided as ever they have been. The irony, I put it to this chamber, is that this division has emerged under the leadership of a man and a government who were elected on a platform of consensus and on a platform of drawing Australia together. It is regrettable that both the Prime Minister (Mr Hawke) and his Government have been much more divisive than they intended simply because it is in the nature of the man to be divisive as is more than adequately illustrated in the book by Blanche d'Alpuget in a quote from Paul Munro. Paul Munro, commenting about the Prime Minister, said:

And it was a bluff. But it was a bluff made possible by his aggression. You see, he dropped it suddenly, unexpectedly and with extraordinary aggression-shouting something like, `If you don't settle we'll bloody-well withdrew the local officers' claims!'-and was the aggression that carried, people responded to his anger and were unable to think rationally. After a couple of minutes the Administration buckled and said, `All right, we'll deal with the territorial allowances'.

It is sad that this chamber, which should be the very chamber of the most elevated debate in the land, the chamber to which the people of Australia look for direction, the chamber from which the people of Australia gather a sense of purpose, has become a chamber of scorn and derision. I found it sobering to discover, and I am indebted to the honourable member for Fadden (Mr Jull) for these figures, that it is now apparently believed that little more than 9,200 Australians regularly listen to Question Time-the most listened to time in the House-compared with almost 50,000 in the days of the Whitlam Administration. What ought to be in this chamber debate that determines the future of the nation has been largely reduced to an exercise of rubber stamping and this Government, which has so proudly lauded before Australia a Bill of Rights, continues to refuse and deny its members a fundamental human right-the right to cross the floor and vote as one's conscience dictates. This nation, under this Government, flounders and is seeking direction when in its Jubilee 150 in the case of South Australia, and bicentennial in the case of Australia, it ought in fact to be a nation both purposeful and united.
Even the symbol of our nationhood, even our flag, is under attack. This morning, Mr Scruby of the Ausflag association was interviewed on the Wendy Wicks show. Wendy Wicks commented to him:
And the Prime Minister doesn't seem to be particularly keen to change the flag. He went so far as to say in Parliament yesterday that he had no intention of doing so.
That, one would have thought, would be reassuring to a nation but what did Mr Scruby reply? He said:
Oh, give that a bit of time. I've got a letter that might say the opposite.

How can we expect the nation to have confidence in a government that is as uncertain and politically pragmatic as this? We have in fact on both sides of the House made the mistake of leading the Australian people to believe that we had here some sort of wisdom that could solve their problems. We, in fact, have made the mistake on both sides, but particularly on the side of the Government, of promising the poor a new deal when after three years we have the honourable member for Calwell (Dr Theophanous) and the Minister for Social Security (Mr Howe) saying that the poor are as badly off as ever. We promised the majority middle class of Australia relief from the tax burden but they continue to be burdened by taxes.

TALK.START.PARA: — Order! The honourable member's time has expired.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Wright Mr K.W.

TALK.START.PARA: —I enter this grievance debate to raise a matter which for the last two years has caused hardship and trauma and significant financial loss to hundreds of Australian consumers. I refer to the rip-offs and the rorts that have occurred in the video sales and rental industry, particularly in the States of Victoria, Queensland and Western Australia. These video victims have come from all walks of life but the vast majority have been the low income battler families who could least afford to get trapped in these schemes that have cost them between $3,000 and $5,000 apiece. It is a sad fact that most of these schemes would not have got off the ground had it not been for the role played by some of the most reputable finance companies in our nation, these companies that have backed these video promoters.

SPEECH.PARA: I want to refer particularly to Custom Credit-`the good sports with money'. The relationship between Custom Credit and these video firms is a black mark on the credit industry. The management of Custom Credit should hang its head in shame for the hardship that it has been party to and that it has caused by the indiscriminate backing of these rip-off rogues in the video industry. I do not believe Custom Credit should have ever supported these different firms, because it saw in other States that these types of video companies were failing. Despite the fact that it witnessed the failure of these video companies in other States it continued to support them. For instance, a company called Electronic Sales and Rentals went into liquidation in Victoria in April 1985, but in Queensland in May and June of 1985 Custom Credit was still backing a firm known as Electronic Sales and Rentals with its credit arrangements through promissory notes.

The background is that throughout 1983, 1984 and 1985 a number of video sales and rental firms came on the scene-Video Vision, Electronic Sales and Rentals, Statewide Video Sales and Rental, Video Sam and Dollar Video, just to name a few. They heavily advertised on radio and television and in the newspapers, and sometimes they were able to use prominent media personalities in their advertisements. Their spiel was simple: Rent or buy a video in your home tonight. Thousands of people throughout the nation called up the various firms and asked them to come to their homes. The prospective customer would ring and a representative would appear at the door virtually within the hour. The pressure was, however, not on the customer to rent but to buy. On paper the deals sounded great. In fact, they sounded really good if people paid in cash because of the additional bits and pieces that they got.

One contract that I have here is for a Toshiba video machine. Purchasers received two movies, three blank tapes, 300 movie exchanges, that in themselves were worth probably $1,000 to $1,500, and an agreement to get 75 per cent discount on all future exchanges or swaps-all this, including the video machine, for $1,981. But it was a different story for those who decided to purchase on the monthly payment plan. That $1,981 suddenly blew out to $3,264. Another contract I have here for $2,900 blew out to $5,000. The payments varied from $60 a month to $115 a month. The interest rates varied from 16 per cent flat to 18 per cent flat. For those honourable members who do not have a calculator with them, that is 31 per cent or 33 per cent. I have nothing against finance companies being involved in consumer transactions but I am totally opposed to those that are using sneak tactics. They use all sorts of tactics to cover up their involvements.

Only one of more than 200 victims in Queensland knew that Custom Credit was behind the finance arrangements of Video Vision or Electronic Sales and Rentals. Not one of the consumers was told that he had signed promissory notes. Not one was told of the consequences of signing a promissory note as against entering a hire purchase contract. Not one was advised of his rights under the door to door sales Act. Not one was told of the interest rate applicable. And very few were given the opportunity to work out what the final cost would be. We all understand the pressure when people have a sales person sitting with them in the lounge-room saying how great the deal is, throwing figures before them. Many of the contracts were not even completed. They were simply set down as 48 payments at so much a month and the consumers who said they would like to pay cash were discouraged from doing so.

There were no credit checks by Custom Credit. Instead, Custom Credit relied on the decisions of the various video firms. So actually it let them act as its agents. Even after the companies failed, Custom Credit refused to reduce the interest component for those who wanted to pay out their debt. So those who suddenly realised they were up for in some cases $2,000 extra, went along and said `Look, I want to pay it out', but Custom Credit said: `No'.

In Queensland, Custom Credit is refusing to negotiate with the Caxton Street Legal Service and other consumer groups. Compare this with Victoria where Mr Spyker, the Minister for Consumer Affairs, intervened and the finance companies renegotiated the account. The consumers there have to pay only for the video hardware. An allowance or a deduction has been given for the 300 video swaps or exchanges that were supposed to be available but were not. I suggest that Custom Credit is fast losing its reputation as `good sports with money' and I would call upon John Newcombe to cut his ties with Custom Credit and its advertising campaign until these problems have been resolved. I also call on the National Bank to intervene because the reputation of the National Bank can be affected-I intend to make sure it is-if it does not do something about it.

I compare the role played by the Custom Credit group and other finance groups with that of the ANZ Bank and the failure of the aerobic and health fitness centres which I raised in this House some months ago. There are similarities between ANZ and Custom Credit's involvement. People were not told of the interest rates. In the case of the aerobics group, people were not aware of bankcard commitments. With the videos, people did not know of the promissory note commitments. The ANZ, because of public pressure and because of speeches made here and the threat of the Federal Government to act, was forced to back off retrieving the debts. An amount of something like $3m has been forgone by the ANZ banks for thousands-something like 15,000 people-caught up in the aerobics rip-offs.

I now call on the Custom Credit group and the National Bank to follow suit. These contracts should be renegotiated. The people should have to pay at the very least only for the video hardware. The promissory notes should be replaced by hire purchase agreements. I also believe that the interest component should we waived. Finance companies and banks should not be profiteering and profiting from the demise of these firms and they should not be getting benefit out of the resulting financial hardship of consumers. These cases back up the need for this Federal Government's move to bring in the linked credit provider legislation that has been introduced by the Federal Labor Government and is before the Senate. It demonstrates the need also for a higher minded approach by banks and finance companies in the market-place, to end the immorality that has existed, that has been shown by ANZ and by Custom Credit and many other finance groups.

In the few moments I have left in which to speak I want to comment on the announcement by the National Party State Cabinet in Queensland and by the Premier that they are issuing writs on the Leader of the Opposition, Nev Warburton, on the Deputy Leader, Tom Burns, on the shadow Minister, Bob Gibbs, on Keith De Lacy, the member for Cairns, on Peter Beattie, the Australian Labor Party State Secretary and on the Australian Broadcasting Corporation. I have been informed that this decision to issue these writs was originally made at a Cabinet meeting in Babinda in North Queensland. The people of Queensland are going to pay for this exercise. They are going to pay the legal costs. Regardless of what costs Bjelke-Petersen should bear, it will be the people of Queensland paying from the public purse. I believe it is a misuse of public funds. It is a desperate attempt to stop public comment about corruption in that State. It is a desperate attempt to stop the Opposition talking about the situation that exists there. It is a desperate attempt to hide the misuse of funds in the State of Queensland. I would urge the Attorney-General (Mr Lionel Bowen) and the Treasurer (Mr Keating) of this nation to consider the legal and financial ramifications of this move by Bjelke-Petersen and his Cabinet cronies. The Queensland Government has salted away hundreds of millions of dollars and it should be remembered just what put away and what it is now using the money for when the State and Commonwealth financial arrangements are under discussion later this year. I question the legal right of the National Party to use State funds to pursue legal quarrels.

TALK.START.PARA: —They are trying to gag debate there.

—Of course they are trying to gag debate. They are trying to stop discussion about the corruption and the activities of the National Party Government in Queensland and it is another reason for the people of Queensland to remove the National Party from the treasury bench of Queensland. It is not the first time it has happened. It happened against John Sinclair on the Fraser Island issue. John Sinclair took on the Premier and he used public funds, State funds, to fight him. When he lost his first case, he appealed again using State funds and took him to the Supreme Court.

SPEECH.PARA: I suggest that the people of Queensland ought to look beyond this activity, this action, this strategy and this tactic and look at the fact that Queensland has the highest number of bankruptcies in the nation; that Queensland has the highest unemployment in the nation and that it has the lowest income per capita in the nation; and that we spend in Queensland the lowest amount of money on education, health and welfare. They ought to realise that this move is only to cover up the corruption and the rorts that have been pulled by the National Party Government in the State of Queensland.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Conquest Mr B.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —Mr Deputy Speaker, if your ears have cleared after that bullhorn of a speech we just had from the honourable member for Capricornia (Mr Wright), which, of course, we understand is a lot of noise and out of tune, we can go on with the grievance debate.

SPEECH.PARA: Australia's standard of living, which was once around the highest in the world, has for some years been falling and poverty is on the increase because our exports are suffering and greatly affecting our economic performance. The agricultural and mining industries contribute greatly to the economy through exports and downturns are mirrored elsewhere in the nation. There is a crisis in rural Australia. Admittedly, within commodity groups effects differ markedly, as can happen in other sections of the industry. Whilst average farm income does not apply equally to all producers, it is, nonetheless, an indicator that in relative terms, things down on the farm are not well.
Unfortunately, few urban dwellers understand the importance of mining and agriculture to their economic well-being. Professor Geoffrey Blainey, a noted historian, had this to say about mining:
A democracy which does not understand the economics of its main export industry is likely, in good faith, to make occasional decisions of crippling stupidity.

This could, of course, be applied equally to agriculture. I believe that while the Federal Government cannot manipulate world markets, it has made decisions of crippling stupidity which have been to the detriment of the rural sector by adding to the cost squeeze, removing concessions, and increasing or imposing new taxes. On behalf of the agricultural industry, I call on this Government to start encouraging agriculture instead of exploiting it as though it will survive regardless of how it is treated.

Knowing there was a crisis in existence, this Government imposed unreasonable new taxes. For those who are prepared to take a risk and invest in productive ventures, we have seen a capital gains tax proposed. We have seen the quarantining of farm losses. What an example of woolly-headed thinking that was. I doubt that it will catch the smart money and this money will most surely move into those sectors where this impost in not in effect. It will certainly hurt the genuine farmer, perhaps one with a working wife who is also supplementing income off farm to keep the enterprise going, or even the young farmer attempting to become established. Because conditions in the rural areas do not compare favourably with suburbia, it has been standard practice for mining companies and rural producers to provide low cost housing and other incentives to attract the work force. To turn around and tax this benefit seriously prejudices the tenure of employment of many, especially those employed in agriculture. It is clear that farm job opportunities will diminish at a time when rural unemployment is already well above the national average.

The removal of immediate deductibility for water conservation or the conveying of water has presented enormous problems to horticulturalists in my electorate of Hinkler. The T-tape trickle system is the most commonly used irrigation tubing because of its comparatively cheaper cost against the more permanent system because of crop rotation that is used in that area. It has a disadvantage though in that its life cycle is only 12 months. I am sure that honourable members can appreciate the need for 100 per cent tax deductibility in the year of expenditure rather than by instalment over three years. The timing of payments of provisional tax each quarter would also seem to run counter to the seasonality of farm income as opposed to the relatively steady nature of income in most other industries. I believe that it is essential that this Government follows the National and Liberal parties in giving a clear-cut statement of support for our rural producers and that it desist in its ambiguous, uncertain, equivocating and almost bumbling attitude towards it. I wait with interest, but with dubious hope, for the 15 April aid package which has been promised.

We have a big spending Government in power, one which has increased spending by some $20 billion in three years. Despite warnings from within its ranks and from without, it relied heavily on the petrol pump to be its tax collector to finance a substantial amount of its pipe dreams.
The Treasurer, when in opposition and shadow Minister for minerals and resources, said in a Press statement in October 1979:
The great petrol rip-off must be curbed. Only Labor will stop this pernicious tax by stealth.
A year later he said:
Mr Fraser refuses to pass up the option to go on squeezing Australian motorists irrespective of any continued fall in international oil prices.
Five and a half years later we have the same honourable member, now Treasurer, saying:

After consideration of all options open to it, the Government has decided that part of the revenue lost as a result of the reduction in IPP is to be offset by increases in excise payable on petroleum products.
If there is one thing hypocrites hate it is hypocrisy. Somerset Maugham said:
Hypocrisy cannot, like adultery, or gluttony, be practised at spare moments; it is a whole-time job.

Certainly it must be, for the Treasurer, a cause of some concern that for every $1 borrowed 93c is paying interest on existing and old debts. A solution to our economic woes is to address our balance of trade by decreasing our imports and/or increasing our exports. The J-curve is not operating as predicted. We have been troughing around in the J. To repeat one of the Treasurer's quaint descriptive terms, to `claw' ourselves back out of the red, perhaps our exporters should be encouraged and not penalised. It has become painfully obvious to farmers over the years that muscle prevails over talk. This line of thinking has precipitated a rural revolt. The Queensland cane train and the farmers rally at the tax summit are now seen as legitimate weapons against an uncaring government. At the Bureau of Agricultural Economics National Agricultural Outlook Conference this year the Minister for Primary Industry (Mr Kerin) said of the dairy industry:

In a couple of months, Pat Rowley learnt what I came to know over the previous two years and what the bureaucrats have known since about 1935-you'll never get the States and the State dairy industries to agree. You can only ever come close.

For a while we were under the impression that the Minister and the Victorian Premier obtained agreement for the Australian Dairy Industry Conference plan on the eve of the Victorian State election. In a Press release on 1 March 1985, the Minister lauded Mr Cain by saying that agreement on the central elements of the ADIC plan had been reached by the Victorian Premier's intervention. After all that politically inspired propaganda was disseminated this Government's Primary Industry Minister reneged on that agreement.

The Australian dollar has been propped up by this Government through an oppressive monetary policy, sending interest rates soaring and struggling primary producers and others to the brink. This Government's monetary policy has hurt the farmer and many others. This Government's so-called tax reform has hurt the farmer and this Government's actions ranging from the emasculation of the income equalisation deposits scheme to the virtual elimination of the petroleum products freight subsidy scheme have all hurt the farmer. May 1985 saw an 8c a litre increase for fuel for many farmers and they will not forget it.
At the BAE Conference the Minister said of sugar growers:
. . . agreement on only the innocuous in the interests of the status quo is all you can get with the sugar industry where some people believe policies formulated in 1915 are sacrosanct.

Growers apparently have to agree to deregulation of the industry before the Minister will honour his price support promises which he gave back in 1983. It is a pity the labour market was not viewed in a similar light by this Government.

The chief reason for the delay in reaching any agreement on price support for the sugar industry is this Government's near psychopathic hatred of Queensland, which was illustrated by the former speaker, the honourable member for Capricornia, who certainly gets worked up when it comes to speaking on matters of Queensland. If woolly-headed academics or socialists on the other side of the chamber should see a deadly taipan and an angry farmer, I would warn them not to take their eye off the farmer.

I am proud to represent the electorate of Hinkler in which there are many rural people and many urban dwellers whose prosperity is directly linked to land. I will spare no effort to reverse the flow of resources away from our mining and agricultural sectors to the cities where this faction-ridden government has its base. It should heed what Edward Gibbon wrote in his Decline and Fall of the Roman Empire: `All taxes must, at last, fall upon agriculture'.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Grace Mr E.L.

TALK.START.PARA: —I would like today to address my remarks to the proposition that my colleagues and I from the western suburbs feel is justified, and that is the establishment of a new university for Sydney's western suburbs. Over the last few months there has been a groundswell of support for the establishment of a new university. I would like to point out to the House that if we miss the boat on this issue-that is, the establishment of a university in the west-it will be a long time before anything ever will be done about it. The people of the western suburbs will have once again missed the opportunity to have the facilities made available to them that are available to the rest of Sydney.

SPEECH.PARA: My colleagues and I welcomed the release of the Parry report-the `Report of the Ministerial Committee to Review the Structure of Higher Education in Western Sydney'. It is a positive step in the right direction. At least we have the ball rolling. The people of the western suburbs and the south-western suburbs are unfairly disadvantaged when it comes to higher education, and in particular university education. Sure, there may not be a great retention rate in these two regions compared with that of, say, the inner suburbs, the North Shore or the eastern suburbs. Those three regions all have university campuses within close proximity and a vast transport network available to them. This is something that is not available to the western and south-western students, or should I say even potential students.

Education has become over the last 30 years a very powerful tool. Higher education in general and universities in particular remain socially elite institutions. Those from the high socio-economic background have been over-represented for many years while those from the low socio-economic background have remained under-represented. It provides a stepping stone for those to move up the social ladder.

There are a number of salient points in favour of the establishment of a multi-campus university in south-west Sydney. Let us look for a moment at the large demographic region of Sydney's west and south-west. Travelling time to, say, Macquarie University in indeed long. The cost incurred is also large. If someone living in my electorate of Fowler, say, in Endensor Park, was going to university, the timetable would be to leave home about 7.30 a.m. and, travelling by train and bus, eventually arrive at Macquarie University at 9.37 a.m. for a 10.30 a.m. lecture. If we take into account travelling back in the evening, that is four hours travel each way, at a very conservative cost of around $25 per week. I would say that the same applies to constituents of my colleagues in adjoining electorates. As I previously pointed out, those with the high socio-economic background that may be lucky enough to have a car while those in my electorate of low socio-economic background may have to go to the expense of a car and hire purchase and therefore work part time, which affects their education.

I now turn to the very heart of the debate. Those who have opposed the establishment of a new university I feel are not completely knowledgeable about why we feel there is a great need for a university in the west. There is no way that some students who attend colleges of advanced education and who study for, say, a Bachelor of Education at the Macarthur Institute of Higher Education will gain the same level of accreditation and the same recognition as someone who attends Sydney University. Mr Deputy Speaker, I seek leave to incorporate in Hansard some figures that are a comparison between the different course data and the level of marks required for entry.

TALK.START.PARA: —I thank the House. Mr Deputy Speaker, as you can see the aggregate marks required to study at CAEs are lower than those required by someone who wishes to study at a university. I am fully aware and grateful to this Government for the way in which it has increased funding for CAEs in the west and south-western region of Sydney, but this will be only a short term solution to the problem; the problem being the lack of student places available, especially in the western suburbs.

SPEECH.PARA: As we approach the year 2000, the west and south-west regions will have a population in the magnitude of 2 million. This will mean that this region will be larger than the total population of some States of Australia. There will be a definite need for more educational facilities in the pre-school and primary and secondary school areas and, of course, a new university if the Government wishes to keep to its commitment of allowing young, or for that matter, middle-aged Australians the opportunity for advancement.

A further point that needs to be made is that a new university is formed via a split campus system. But two very important points need to be kept in mind. First, we must choose very carefully where the new campus is to be placed. To this effect we must look to where the growth is now occurring and in what areas in future years growth will occur. We would be defeating ourselves if we placed the campus where growth has petered out and the only change that was occurring was the natural turnover of the population. Do we place a new campus in areas that will hopefully, at the beginning of its establishment, draw students who are not in Sydney's western region and then, after its establishment, draw on the population that it was meant to service in the first place? I think not. Secondly, the need for easy access to campuses by transport-rail or bus-is extremely important in relation to where the campus should be sited. I have already pointed out the time and cost involved in travelling. It puts further pressure on the student which, at a time of transition to adulthood, is totally unwarranted.

I turn briefly to the Parry report. As I have already stated, my colleagues and I welcome the report but I feel there are a few very important points that the report has failed to address. Throughout my speech I have used the term western Sydney and south-western Sydney, the latter not having been included in the report. As the member for Fowler, which is in Sydney's south-western region, it troubles me that the south-western region is to suffer the humiliation of not being included as an area from where a new university would draw its population.

In this report the area of Baulkham Hills has been included. The areas of Liverpool, Milperra, Fairfield and Campbelltown were not included and why those areas were not included leaves me somewhat bewildered. Figures provided show that Macquarie University had enrolled twice the number of students for 1985 from Baulkham Hills shire enrolled by the Nepean CAE. Macquarie University, Sydney University and the New South Wales Institute of Technology combined enrolled more than three times the number of students from the Baulkham Hills shire enrolled by the Nepean CAE and the Hawkesbury CAE together.

Mr Deputy Speaker, as my time in which to speak draws to an end I reiterate that I would like to see a multi-campus university in Sydney's west and south-western region. The upgrading of Nepean and Macarthur CAEs is just the beginning. We will continue to fight to have a university placed in the regions mentioned for the betterment of all the people whom my colleagues and I represent.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Rocher Mr A.C.

TALK.START.PARA: —Surely the Commonwealth and State governments have enough problems with unfunded and underfunded superannuation schemes for public servants and academics without saddling consumers and taxpayers with another, even bigger, superannuation burden. Let there be no doubt that this is what this country faces under this Australian Council of Trade Unions dominated government. Somewhere down the track the outcome of the backroom deal between the socialist conspirators in the Australian Labor Party and the ACTU will become a burden on taxpayers. There should be little, if any, doubt that the considerable sums to be collected will be nowhere near sufficient to meet anything more than the most meagre retirement benefits, even if the vast funds to be controlled by the unions, are administered and invested wisely. Equally, there should be absolutely no doubt that the sleazy superannuation deal between the ACTU and the Hawke Government is more about the acquisition of even greater political power for the ACTU than about superannuation benefits for working men and women. This will be achieved at the expense of none other than Australian consumers; that is, all Australians in the first instance and ultimately a combination of consumers and taxpayers. Everyone should be aware and remember that the cost of the superannuation conspiracy will find its way into the prices of all goods and services that we as Australians will be buying, including the necessities of life. The scheme to be rammed down the throat of the Australian Conciliation and Arbitration Commission will impost heavily on our present generation and even more heavily on future generations.

SPEECH.PARA: What is to be the basis of, the catalyst for, if you like, this impost? It is to be a so-called productivity increase of 3 per cent. One fascinating aspect of the productivity saga will be whether this is to be another example of the rubber stamp role to which the Arbitration Commission has been accustomed so far under this Government. This deal was stitched together solely between the ACTU and the Government. No representative of business, big or small, was consulted. Nor was any farmer or representative farmer organisation consulted. Nor was any attempt made to consider the views of individual employees or independent contractors. The Government and the ACTU are both insisting that productivity increases should be given in the form of employer funded superannuation `equivalent to a wage increase of 3 per cent'. The proposal provides for progressive implementation over a two-year period commencing 1 July 1986. However, we all know that major industries, such as the transport and building industries, have largely acquiesced, rendering that two-year period less relevant than it might otherwise seem.

The argument to be mounted by the ACTU to justify its claim that productivity has increased at all, let alone by 3 per cent, will be very interesting indeed. The 3 per cent being bandied about has all the hallmarks of a guesstimate and not a very good one at that. Let me assure the House that it is no more than a stab in the dark. Estimates made during 1985 by the Confederation of Australian Industry and the Melbourne based Labour Research Centre, provide classic examples of the difficulties in measuring productivity growth. In July last year the CAI's industrial review argued that productivity actually fell between March 1983 and March 1985 by 0.4 of one per cent. On the other hand, a couple of months ago Melbourne's Labour Research Centre provided figures based on original data prepared by Dr Owen Covick of Flinders University that purport to show that productivity has risen by 10.5 per cent. There we have it; that is the range. Depending on what methodology is adopted for measuring national output, hours worked and what time periods are chosen, one can come up with a figure for productivity movements per mean hour over the past two years ranging from minus 0.9 per cent to plus 10.5 per cent. What is worse, a study undertaken by Noble Lowndes Australia Ltd on behalf of the Metal Trades Industry Association has raised very serious questions about the whole issue. The study claims that there is a `considerable lack of understanding of the complexities and implications' of the superannuation guidelines and raises serious doubts about existing costings.

Of additional interest is the question of just what this 3 per cent will provide. Frankly, the figure has absolutely no validity in superannuation terms. Noble Lowndes estimates that the cost of a reasonable benefit at age 65 would be between 10.5 and 12.7 per cent of payroll-far removed, far in excess, of the 3 per cent starting point claim. This calculation is based on what is needed for a male aged 42, with imputed salary growth of 8 per cent and an investment yield on funds invested of 9 per cent, to receive a reasonable benefit of some 50 per cent of final earnings payable from age 65.

Let it be clear, lest it be misunderstood, that I remain committed to encouragement of superannuation schemes which allow for self-provision for retirement. Indeed the Liberal and National parties in coalition government extended the concessions available for personal superannuation schemes. That is not what we are talking about. Self-provision and encouragement for it should not be confused with this issue because there are a number of key points of concern about the operation of the proposed scheme itself as distinct from the power politics which are its genesis.

The operating standards so far released specify that interest credited to employee contributions be reasonable having regard to earnings and administrative costs of the fund. But what does reasonable mean in a situation, for example, where the assets of the fund consist of a portfolio of individual investments or units in a pooled fund operated by an insurance company or professional investment manager? The investment return may well fluctuate greatly from year to year and could be made up of capital growth, interest and dividends. What will be done about employees who leave a fund after only a short period of service? If their benefits are preserved for periods that could exceed 30 years, this will greatly add to fund administration costs and become and administrative nightmare. Where the 3 per cent is paid into a defined benefits scheme, what certification procedure will be implemented to ensure that the benefits granted conform to the requirements of any award? Similar question marks hang over non-award stuff. Will part of their benefit have to be vested and preserved. The list goes on and on and I commend the study to which I have referred.

Will competition, for example, for members be allowed between those under this proposed scheme and those in the private funds? Will the same operating standards be applied to this scheme as those applied to the private funds? How will interest additions to contributions be calculated? Is the safety net to the taxpayer subsidised? Overseas experience provides an important warning. Governments are always keen to transfer the burden of such schemes to future generations yet one of the main rationales of such schemes is supposedly to reduce the call on government resources at a later date. That will not happen in this case. Remember Medicare and the gold-plated assurance that a one per cent levy on personal incomes would cover the extra cost of it.

What is probable, what is most likely, is that funds compulsorily acquired ostensibly for the future welfare of working men and women will be merely the tool by which the ACTU advances its aims of corporate socialism, at the same time further enhancing the power and privilege of a few union leaders. Even though the Commission's deliberations have been pre-empted by an unprecedented ACTU propaganda campaign, openly supported by the Hawke Government, the Commission has a unique opportunity to weigh the arguments to be put before it and insist that the ACTU prove its productivity cum universal superannuation case is proven beyond all reasonable doubt.

TALK.START.PARA: —Order! The honourable member's time has expired.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Hollis Mr C.

TALK.START.PARA: —I rise in this grievance debate to defend the 1985 statement of the Catholic Commission for Justice and Peace entitled `Working for a Just Peace'. In fact, I wish to do more than defend the Commission; I wish to congratulate it and the majority of Catholic Bishops of Australia who have supported it for having the courage to publish a forthright statement which raises many important questions.

SPEECH.PARA: From the time of the statement's publication last August it has been surrounded by controversy, a controversy which continues to this very day. This, of course, is simply an indication of just how important and timely are the questions raised by the Commission. I must, however, admit to being somewhat surprised that the controversy has been so heated and hysterical. My first impression on reading `Working for a Just Peace' was that its overall approach was quite mild. The statement makes no outlandish claims, rather it seeks to raise much the same questions that have been raised in many other circles, both within Australia and beyond, including the Catholic hierarchies of the United States of America, Germany and France. What the statement does is present a calm and logically argued case based on the teachings of the Bible and the social teachings of the Catholic Church for Australians to have a hard look at the arms race and our part in it. In particular, it suggests that Australians need to look at the details of the alliance between Australia and the United States, not to repudiate or weaken it, but to examine it in the light of our national commitment to work for nuclear disarmament.

There is, of course, another reason for examining the alliance. We have on our shores a number of American bases and we are visited by American warships and warplanes. Quite rightly, the Commission asks the same questions that many other Australians are asking, namely: Does the very presence of these bases, ships and planes make us a prime nuclear target should war ever break out between the United States and the Soviet Union? There is perhaps no more important question facing our nation and to avoid asking it is to retire into cloud cuckoo land.

Why then has `Working for a Just Peace' provoked such a hostile and hysterical reaction? I would suggest that this reaction is due in no small way to the fact that from the viewpoint of the Bible and the Catholic Church's social teaching, `Working for a Just Peace' is such a logical and developed application of these teaching that it simply cannot be attacked on these grounds and, indeed, it has not been. For these reasons its opponents, who lack the intellectual honesty and plain guts to face up to the highly necessary questions raised by the statement, are forced to fall back on their usual tactics of name calling, distortions and half truths. For example, they say that the statement calls for unilateral disarmament and then attack it accordingly, when, in fact, what the Commission calls for is progressive bilateral disarmament.

Being unable to attack the statement directly, its critics, for the most part, are intent on shifting their attack to the hip pocket question of the funding connection between Australian Catholic Relief, Project Compassion, that is the Church's Lent and appeal funding, and the Catholic Commission for Justice and Peace. I see in today's Australian that even an Opposition senator has now joined the fray. Even here, the critics of `Working for a Just Peace' find themselves on very uneasy ground in order to attack the long standing practice of Australian Catholic Relief in Project Compassion funding for the Commission. They are forced to ignore recent social teachings of the Catholic Church and its Popes including John Paul II, Paul VI and Pope John XXIII, all of whom have constantly reiterated the theme: If you want peace then work for justice.

We live in a world where we are faced with a scandal that far more is spent on waging war than on waging peace. It is a world, too, in which far more is spent on the propaganda of lies, distortions and half truths, all aimed at creating a climate of international tension and fear, than is spent on searching for ways to build up international understanding and harmony. The people who suffer most are the poor, especially the poor of the Third World countries. This is what the arms race comes down to: It costs as much to arm and train one soldier as it does to educate 80 children. It costs as much to build one bomber as it does to wipe out smallpox over a 10-year period. It costs as much to build one submarine equipped with nuclear missiles as it does to build half a million modest homes. For every 100,000 people in the world, there are 556 soldiers but only 85 doctors. Just 20 per cent of what the world presently spends on arms expenditure would be sufficient to abolish world hunger by the year 2000. The developing countries of the world each year spend 20 times as much on military purposes as they provide in economic aid to the Third World. Thus, in 1982 the world spent $500 billion on the arms race and only $25 billion on economic aid. Finally, world military expenditure has doubled between 1960 and 1983 to the extent that in the latter year, $800 billion was spent on waging war. The Catholic Commission for Justice and Peace questions the morality of spending-

TALK.START.PARA: —Order! It being 2 p.m., in accordance with Standing Order 106, as amended for this session, the debate is interrupted and I put the question:

INTERJECT.SPEAKER: Madam SPEAKER

TALK.START.PARA: —On Tuesday, I informed the House that, as respondents to the relevant industrial award, the Presiding Officers and the Public Service Board had lodged with the Australian Conciliation and Arbitration Commission formal notification of an industrial dispute within the Commonwealth Parliamentary Refreshment Rooms. The matter was listed for hearing this morning before Mr Commissioner Caesar. At the conclusion of the hearing, Mr Commissioner Caesar issued a statement and order as follows:

INTERJECT.PARA: On the basis of the undertakings given to me by Mr Banks and Mr Barry of the FLAIEU that they would take all necessary steps to have industrial action cease I order the parties to this dispute into conference, the subject matter of that conference to embrace all matters of concern to the members of the FLAIEU. The conference to be held as a matter of urgency and a report on the progress of the conference to be made to me at an appropriate time.
I request the Union to accept the responsibility of notifying me when such a report would be appropriate and in any event before any further industrial action is taken in pursuance of their claims.

I have been advised that, at a subsequent meeting of catering staff who are members of the Federated Liquor and Allied Industries Employees Union, it was resolved to lift all bans in line with the order given by the Commission.

TALKER.NAME: Mr SINCLAIR
TALKER.ROLE: Leader of the National Party of Australia)

TALK.START.PARA: —Madam Speaker, might you table in the House any final settlement agreed on or any final decision taken by the Commissioner in this matter? Obviously all honourable members are affected by the disruption that has occurred in the parliamentary dining room and it would be an advantage to members of this place to know of any resolution that might follow the determination of the Commissioner concerned in the matter.
—I thank the Leader of the National Party. I will take his request on board.

—I advise the House that the Prime Minister (Mr Hawke) and the Special Minister of State (Mr Young) will not be present during Question Time today. They are in Adelaide for the official farewell to Her Majesty the Queen at the conclusion of the royal visit to Australia.

—My question is directed to the Treasurer. As unemployment has now gone up by 40,000, or by 16,000 seasonally adjusted, to 8 per cent, does the Treasurer still stand by his claim made on the Sunday television program on 2 March that unemployment will not rise again, or does he now admit that this promise has already been broken and that he now agrees with the Minister for Employment and Industrial Relations that unemployment will increase this year? As employment has now dropped by 7,000, will the Australian Labor Party now withdraw its misleading advertisement on employment before the thieving magpie becomes the lying magpie?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Keating The Hon P.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —I thought that the Deputy Leader of the Opposition said at his Press conference that we cannot take any notice of one month's figures. If that is the case, what is the point of his question? The fact is that employment this financial year has grown by 195,000 jobs, which is already 15,000 ahead of the Budget forecast for the year. It is absolutely absurd for the Opposition to raise the issue in these terms when what we are seeing is a small reduction in February following a very large January employment figure of 60,000. The fact is that the participation rate is now higher than it has been for eight or nine years, maybe longer. At present it is at 61.6 per cent, which means that it is about one per cent higher than the participation rate at this time last year. That implies that about 120,000 instances of hidden unemployment have been dealt with by employment growth. In other words, while we are seeing the measured rate climb from 7.8 to 8 per cent-it has been hovering in that range for some time-the fact is that in the face of very strong employment growth we have been reducing hidden unemployment. I would have thought that the Opposition was as much interested in hidden unemployment as registered unemployment. In any upswing of an economy out of a recession there is always a higher participation rate. We on this side of the House are pleased that many thousands of people who were not registered as unemployed have found jobs.

ANSWER.PARA: The fact of the matter is that the Government has had just on 9 per cent employment growth in its three years in office. That 600,000 jobs contrasts with the quarter of a million jobs lost in the last year of the coalition Government. I find it amusing that the Leader of the Opposition has run around lately saying that in their first four years they created so many thousand jobs but he forgets to say that in the last year they blew it all out the door by putting 250,000 or 300,000 people out of work. If it were not sad, it would be comical. The principal commitment this Government gave during the campaign in 1983 and on taking office in that year was to deal with the disastrous rise in unemployment. Not only have we checked it; we have brought it down from 10.3 per cent to 8 per cent. We have given 600,000 jobs to Australians; we have clawed 600,000 families out of the tyranny of poverty, through our policies, and we can lay claim to having honoured absolutely both the spirit and the letter of the 1983 campaign promise of creating 500,000 jobs within our first three years. We have exceeded that 500,000 jobs by at least 100,000. I would have thought that members of the coalition, looking at their dismal record of failure, could at least think for one moment about the cast of policy on this side of the House and it might just enter their minds that may be they have the wrong cast of policy and that the party on this side of the House is the only one of the major parties that is capable of running the country.

TALK.START.PARA: —My question, to the Minister for Communications, concerns many people in my electorate and in other electorates. Is the Minister aware of the recent disturbing growth in unsolicited telephone selling? Is he also aware that in certain instances such telephone selling is associated with fraudulent marketing schemes? Can the Minister advise the House as to whether the recommendations of the Law Reform Commission on this matter have been adopted and, finally, is the Minister able to take any other action to deal with difficulties associated with telephone selling?

—I am aware of the problem adverted to by the honourable member for Stirling. Unfortunately the powers of the Australian Telecommunications Commission in relation to this matter are limited. The recommendations of the Law Reform Commission are currently under examination.

—I refer the Treasurer to Senator Walsh's statement yesterday that the trilogy only commits the Government to not increasing tax as a proportion of gross domestic product during the term of this Parliament; that is, over a three-year period. Does the Treasurer recall that pages 59 and 382 of Budget Paper No. 1, which he himself circulated, make it unequivocally clear that the trilogy also commits the Government to not increasing tax revenue as a proportion of GDP in 1985-86? Why has the Government broken yet another promise by junking this part of the trilogy in order to collect even more tax in the current financial year?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Keating The Hon P.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Government is breaking no promise and is making no adjustment to its policy. What the Government said in the course of the 1984 election campaign was that there had been no semblance of any decency in fiscal policy under the coalition Government. It indicates that the progress the Government had made would be continued over the life of the current Parliament and that tax receipts, as a proportion of gross domestic product, would not rise over the 1984-85 base. I reaffirm the statement in the Budget Papers which the Leader of the Opposition talked about. Of course it is correct. In 1985-86 the Government has budgeted for a receipts figure which will be within the trilogy ceiling.
—You budgeted for it.

—We budgeted for it. There are other influences on the economy including the depreciation of the exchange rate which has listed the Australian dollar price of oil over the year. This will mean that receipts from the higher volumes and higher prices of oil will be up.

ANSWER.PARA: However, it has yet to be determined what GDP will be or whether the trilogy ceiling will be breached. Even if it is breached the Government will not be aware of it with any precision until at least well into the next financial year, in which case we will adjust receipts in the course of the Parliament so that receipts will be no higher than the 1984-85 base-QED.

TALK.START.PARA: —Is the Minister for Health aware of claims made by the Australian Medical Association in Western Australia that West Australians suffer a disadvantage under Medicare when compared with other Australians? Will the Minister inform the House of the true situation?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Blewett The Hon N.

TALK.START.PARA: —I am aware of the newspaper report. I must point out, although probably most honourable members are aware, that the medical benefits schedule of fees is different in each State, and that is based on historical factors that have been in operation over the last 15 years. However, generally, patients in those States which have lower schedules of fees face lower charges from their doctors. For instance, Medicare refunds in New South Wales are higher only because the fees charged in New South Wales are correspondingly higher. This means that patients in New South Wales who are charged the schedule fee, even after their refund from Medicare, are somewhat more out of pocket than those in Western Australia.

ANSWER.PARA: As I have said, the fee schedule is based on historical grounds. It started in 1970 when it was agreed between the Government and the medical profession that the fees would be based on the most common fee in each State. A State by State survey was done of doctors' billing procedures and the common fee was based on the average for each individual State.
