Western Australian fees were lower than those of some other States, particularly New South Wales and Victoria, and that was because doctors in Western Australia charged less than doctors in those States. For most of the next 15 years the Australian Medical Association always opposed the notion of uniform fees and supported the continuation of this historic difference between the States.

Recently, the AMA has changed its policy. It has decided that there should now be a move towards uniformity across all States. The Government has indicated to the AMA that it agrees with this in principle but it believes that there should be a gradual move within the Medicare budget. For instance, the AMA is arguing that all fees should move up to the higher New South Wales standard. This would cost the taxpayer another $100m a year and it is the Government's view that it would be irresponsible simply to make that jump. The AMA is quite aware of the Government's position and its preparedness to negotiate a uniform fee within the overall Medicare budget. However, simply to accept an increase right across the board to bring all fees up to the New South Wales standard would disadvantage consumers and taxpayers who have to pay the bill.

TALK.START.PARA: —My question is addressed to the Treasurer. On Tuesday he told us that the current account deficit in 1985-86, as a percentage of gross domestic product, would be in the order of 5 per cent, implying a massive improvement in the next four months. I also remind him that yesterday Senator Button told the Senate that the Government did not expect any major improvement in the current account deficit this month, next month or the month after. I remind the Treasurer that yesterday the Prime Minister told us that `evidence is starting to emerge of the turnaround we have been looking for, for some time now'. I ask the Treasurer: Apart from increased unemployment, what is the Government expecting today?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Keating The Hon P.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —Yesterday's figures show some clear J effect in the current account figures--

—It is always nice to have the so-called free marketeers show the agnosticism about the free market and free market forces. We have had a 30 per cent price change on the exchange rate but the free marketeers say that that will make no difference to the pattern of imports and exports and investment decisions. That is a very novel position for a so-called free enterprise party to hold. I am sure that a lot of people in Australian business are trying to weigh up some of the Opposition's crazy views in this respect.

ANSWER.PARA: The figures released yesterday revealed a number of extraneous factors. About $73m related to a 767 aircraft which is part of a re-equipment program and about $260m related to oil export revenues which fell sharply. However, import costs had not, at that stage, had time to fall and be reflected in the figures. About $100m represented seasonal factors. The underlying trend in imports was significantly down and, hence, that was quite encouraging. As the Prime Minister said yesterday that was consistent with the kinds of outcomes which the Government expected.

As I have often said in the House, we will not see Australian manufacturing decimated as it was by the coalition, an exchange rate dramatically out of line, a wages policy giving outcomes which no industry can live with, a $39 a week wage increase-which was the case in 1981-82-an inflation rate running to double digits, massive retrenchments and closures in business and yet find that overnight the exchange rate is falling and there is a major reinvestment program. Of course this will always come with a lag, but it will come when business is convinced that the policy settings of the Government are appropriate, when the accord is holding and when all of the other factors affecting Australia's new-found competitiveness will be a permanent feature of the landscape.

The fall in the exchange rate is now over a year old-it started a year ago-and business has had a chance to assess the policy settings, to assess the shape of the 1985-86 Budget and to assess the fact that a discount will operate for the April wage case and that that will secure depreciation benefits. We are now seeing producer goods revealed in the import figures. Those producer goods will underpin a better import competing performance for Australia.

The exchange rate has been labouring to do this job despite a dramatic deterioration in the terms of trade since last August which alone would cost the current account about $750m. That new competitiveness and a slowing in demand which the Government has induced into the economy is forecast to be reflected in trade volumes. I confirm absolutely what the Prime Minister said.

However, it really amuses me that the so-called free marketeers of the Liberal Party of Australia believe that the Australian private sector is so moribund, and Australian entrepreneurship so dead that despite a 30 per cent change in the exchange rate and a massive increase in the profitability of the traded goods sector of the economy there will not be any investment. They think that Australian business is so hopeless and so moribund that this massive price and profit opportunity in the traded goods sector of the economy will not be taken up, that the market system is jammed and that the market will not work. That is where the Liberal Party is in 1986. Is it any wonder that the Business Council of Australia showed it the door on 3 February?

QUESTION.BLOCK.TITLE: ELECTIVE SURGERY IN AUSTRALIAN CAPITAL TERRITORY HOSPITALS

TALK.START.PARA: —Will the Minister for Territories explain some of the difficulties which have been responsible for the increase in the waiting list for elective surgery in Australian Capital Territory hospitals?
—When are you having your operation?
—I can only say to the honourable member for Denison that, if ever he has to have brain surgery, it will have to be done by a carpenter.
—How long have you been working on that one?
—For about as long as the honourable member has been trying to get a credible economic policy together.
—Order! The Minister will ignore the interjections and answer the question.
—Canberra, like all areas of Australia, has a problem with a shortage of nurses.
—Order!

—It is a serious subject but I know that health is a joke to the honourable gentlemen on the opposite side of the House. Canberra, like all areas of Australia, has been experiencing problems in recruiting sufficient nurses in order to provide a full service in its hospitals. As the Minister for Health pointed out yesterday, one of the reasons for this is the manner in which the previous Government completely ignored the needs of Australia in respect of trained nurses and professional nursing care. There are some problems in all the Canberra hospitals in respect of elective surgery. The Australian Capital Territory Health Authority has had discussions with some sections of the medical profession and is planning further discussions in this area in order to work out solutions to these problems. However, I think I should inform the House that one of the solutions that the Government will not be looking at nor accepting is the one which the Opposition is continually putting forward in this House; that is, turning the availability of medicine into a market forces arrangement whereby those people who are not able to pay the exorbitant fees which are being sought by some sections of the medical profession will be denied surgery. That is the solution that honourable members opposite are putting forward for reducing the waiting list. They are pricing medical treatment out of the reach of people and making health a commercial commodity available to the rich but not to the poor.

—The Minister for Employment and Industrial Relations will be aware that a Party colleague, the Premier of Victoria, last Tuesday cast doubt as to whether Victorian public servants would get the 3 per cent national productivity wage rise in the form of superannuation settled in a private deal between the Australian Council of Trade Unions and the Commonwealth. Bearing in mind the impact that this superannuation deal with have on Victoria's finances, will the Minister now admit that it is fundamentally unjust to force this heavy cost on the crisis-ridden rural sector and on embattled small business when they too, clearly, have no capacity to pay it?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Willis The Hon R.

TALK.START.PARA: —I am not aware of the statement by the Premier of Victoria, but, in relation to the thrust of the question, the productivity case is a case which the Government supports. We believe that there is scope for a 3 per cent productivity increase to apply in the way in which the ACTU-Government agreement says it should be applied; that is, over a two-year period. Of course, that is quite different from any other increase that would ever have been awarded by the Australian Conciliation and Arbitration Commission in the history of this country. There has never been an occasion when the Commission has made a decision which has been phased in over a two-year period. The phasing in of that increase will be on a basis which is subject to discussion between the Government, the ACTU and the Commission, assuming that the Commission finds in favour of the ACTU-Government proposal.

ANSWER.PARA: The Leader of the National Party of Australia raised the position of the rural sector. It is, of course, very much in our minds that the rural sector is going through hard times and it would therefore be very appropriate that the rural sector be at the end of that queue; that is, that a productivity increase which applied in the way in which it is being proposed would apply to the rural sector towards the end of that period rather than now or in a few months time when, quite clearly, that sector would still be in difficult times.

This superannuation increase has to be looked at in the light of the level of the wage increases which have been occurring under the accord, what has happened to real labour costs in this country, which have been reduced to levels well below those applying under the previous Government, and the fact that our competitiveness has been greatly increase as a result of the wages policy pursued by this Government, supported further by the devaluation. The situation for the nation is that the 3 per cent increase can be applied in a way which will not impair our competitiveness. It will be unique in the sense that it is to be applied over a two-year period. The concerns of the rural sector can be addressed in the way that I have mentioned; that is, they will most likely not have to face this increase in labour costs until some two years from now.

TALK.START.PARA: —Is the Minister for Primary Industry concerned that lives are in danger as a result of the forestry conflict at Farmhouse Creek in Tasmania? Will the Minister be considering ways and means of resolving the conflict? Why is the Minister not putting in place positive action as a result of this conflict, particularly following the Government's decision of 16 December 1985 on Tasmanian export licences? Can the Minister reassure the Parliament that the Government's decision will be implemented?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Kerin The Hon J.C.

TALK.START.PARA: —All honourable members in this House will be pleased to know that there has been some cooling down of what was a very serious situation late last week and earlier this week. I am sure that all honourable members have been very concerned about the possibility that that conflict would lead to physical injury. I am most concerned that this conflict has the capacity to create a situation where decisions are taken by the Tasmanian Government that do not take full account of the overall community interest. This is particularly so in the forestry area, where a conflict between production and preservation is one on which I am sure every Australian will have a view.

ANSWER.PARA: On 16 December last year the Government took a decision on the Tasmanian woodchips issue that was directed at allowing utilisation of the forests in Tasmania but imposing significant controls to ensure that the community could be satisfied that the operations were as environmentally sensitive as possible. As a preliminary to that decision the Commonwealth had insisted that an environmental impact study be conducted across the breadth of forestry in Tasmania. There was some two years of consideration and even after the draft environmental impact statement came out there were 450 submissions placed in the consideration process.

The Commonwealth's decision, as a result, effectively encompassed the totality of forest operations in Tasmania and sought a mechanism to ensure that Commonwealth objectives on environmental protection as well as employment and industry security were achieved. Since then we have been negotiating an agreement with the State Government to implement that mechanism. The Premier has gone public on the issue, which is yet to be settled between us. The Farmhouse Creek situation is a roads proposal at this stage to get saw logs, which is a domestic operation. It is a roads proposal about which the public has known since 1983. It is not concerned with woodchips at all. The woodchip licences that are in a place at present go through to 31 December 1987. What we are talking about is whether or not the agreement that we are seeking to get in terms of that 16 December decision would have avoided a situation such as that which we have at Farmhouse Creek. I believe that, by and large, if we did have that agreement-the Tasmanian Government should realise this-we could get a much more rational solution to these sorts of conflicts. The Tasmanian Premier has said that I am backtracking on an understanding we had previously reached and that I am now seeking to have the Commonwealth dictate to the State on the management of its domestic logging operations. This is nonsense. Neither of the allegations is correct. However, I am concerned to ensure that the State does take full account of the values of national estate areas whether they are logged for export or domestic purposes. The Commonwealth will not back away from that position.

The honourable member for Franklin has been interjecting to the effect that statements are being made that are not factual. I would join with him on that, because we have heard all sorts of claims. One is that it is world heritage-it is not; that it is wilderness-it is not. The movement put out a statement saying that it is highly sensitive wilderness. It is not. It is not rainforest. This area is State forest going back to 1925 and 1933, but it is also part of the national estate. We have to try to reconcile environmental values with the question of jobs.

The Government and the public have been aware of Tasmania's intention to construct a road as part of the summer roading program across Farmhouse Creek since 1983 when the Forestry Commission publicised this in its management plan for the area. This Government's decision on woodchip licences allowed for those operations to proceed provided a sufficient buffer was left to protect the South West National Park. So it is not about wilderness. The timber is the same on both sides of the creek. It is about a wilderness buffer. The proposed road is consistent with this decision and does not compromise the Commonwealth's position in respect of its decision on the Tasmanian licences.

The conservationist attachment to Farmhouse Creek as a boundary for logging is purely arbitrary. As I said, there is no difference in the quality of the forest between one side of the creek and the other. Both sides are registered national estate areas and as such logging should be managed so as to minimise adverse effects on their registered values. The specific area is not registered for wilderness value, as the conservationists would have the public believe. The Farmhouse Creek general area of national estate values can be summarised as old growth forest habitat, which is not unique, as Dr Bob Brown has conceded, the Mount Picton alpine area, and there are no trees there, and within the viewfield of the Hartz Mountains National Park. One cannot take that one into account otherwise one would wipe out the whole Huon Valley.

More responsible elements in the conservation movement are on record as supporting limited forestry activity in the Farmhouse Creek area, providing that it did not extend too far up the creek catchment nor too far from the Picton River south of Farmhouse Creek. Reports to that effect were put forward by the Tasmanian Conservation Trust in 1980 and the Australian Conservation Foundation in 1983. It is those suggestions that have formed part of the basis of this Government's consideration of what would be an appropriate buffer for the wilderness area in the South West National Park. Finally, I remind all honourable members that national estate status for an area is not identical to national park status. The Act passed by this Parliament imposes an obligation upon Ministers, both Mr Cohen and myself, to ensure that where there is no alternative all measures which can reasonably be taken to minimise the adverse effect will be taken.

TALK.START.PARA: —I raise a point of order, Madam Speaker, I ask the Minister for Primary Industry to table the document from which he has just been reading.
—Was the Minister reading from a public document?
—No.
—Then there is no necessity for it to be tabled.

—Is the Treasurer aware that during January and February 1986 the top 10 Holden dealers in Melbourne suffered a drastic drop of 40 per cent in new car sales when compared to January and February 1985? Is the Treasurer also aware that other major new car dealers in all States have experienced a similar sharp reduction in sales over the past six months, which could result in 25,000 jobs being lost in this industry. In view of these gravely disturbing facts, will the Treasurer now abandon the fringe benefits tax on motor vehicles as originally detailed in his statement of 19 September last year?

—If the honourable member for Bruce is the new chairman of the Liberal Party economic policy committee, he will need to do a lot better in drawing economic conclusions from facts than we saw in that question. It should be well known to the honourable member that in this period unleaded vehicles were brought to the market. They came at a higher price, and of course, not unreasonably, many firms ordered vehicles before the more expensive unleaded vehicles arrived at the market place. Further, discounts are being offered, and a lot of market-sensitive people made investment decisions ahead of the new model.

—I direct my question to the Minister representing the Minister for Community Services. Has his attention been drawn to a report which appeared in the Age on Monday 10 March, which stated that several State youth housing projects have been shelved because of delays to joint grants from the Victorian and Federal governments which were to have been announced on 17 January? Will he inform the House when an announcement will be made and what steps have been taken to ensure that delays like this do not occur again?

—I am aware of the present delay in announcing new approvals under the joint Commonwealth and State funded supported accommodation systems program as reported in the Age newspaper on 10 March. Recommendations for the allocation of some of the new funds were forwarded by the Victorian Minister for Community Services, Mrs Hogg, at the end of January. As the package was incomplete, the original intention was to await the balance of the recommendations before approving the package as a whole. Since the additional recommendations have still not been received, the Commonwealth Department is preparing recommendations for me in my capacity as Acting Minister for Community Services for approval of two new services, one for youth and one for women as recommended by Mrs Hogg. I expect to have this submission later today or early tomorrow and will be advising Mrs Hogg early next week. No commitment to advise approvals by 1 January-I think the honourable member said 17 January-was ever given. Arrangements are being made between offices of the Commonwealth and State community services departments regarding the streamlining of recommendations and the approval process in Victoria. I believe that this action will avoid the present situation recurring.

—I ask the Minister for Employment and Industrial Relations a question and refer him to the answer he gave to the Leader of the National Party of Australia. Is the queuing process for the productivity case, in which he referred to the position of rural industry-that dispensation for rural industry-based on a belief that there has been no productivity gain, or is it based on grounds of hardship? Also, can the Minister say whether a similar dispensation will be given to small businesses which manifestly are unable to pay?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Willis The Hon R.

TALK.START.PARA: —The process by which particular industries take part in the superannuation increase which will come from the productivity case of the Australian Conciliation and Arbitration Commission, if so decided, will be worked out over time. This is something that will come up following any decision and will require the parties to be in a position to be able to put forward a proposition which will mean that an increase can apply. In other words, there has to be a fund; a process must exist whereby superannuation payments can be made. In many industries that simply would not be the case. It will take a long time for a situation to develop where there will be a possibility for any productivity outcome taken by way of superannuation to apply. There can be no clarity on this matter at this stage. Obviously, some industries have a capacity to go ahead as soon as the Commission makes any decision, although, of course, under the accord mark 2 agreement, nothing should start until 1 July. But after that date there will be others that will come on stream at a later time; that is, they will get their superannuation scheme sorted out some time after 1 July, and some will take a considerable time after that. The process by which there is an ordering of awards is one that will have to be sorted out in the next few months.
—Is that based on hardship?
—What I said before was that in the Government's view-
—On hardship?
—Hardship.
—Does the honourable gentleman want me to answer this or not?
—We want a proper answer.
—I will answer it then-in my own words, if the honourable gentleman does not mind.
—Order! The Leader of the Opposition will wait for the answer.
—He ought to stick to the question.

—As I was saying, in the Government's view the rural industries, which are going through hard times, ought to be towards the end of that queue. The reality is, anyway, that because that industry is highly unlikely to be in a position to participate early in the superannuation scheme, because of the factors I mentioned earlier, it would be well towards the end of the process.

ANSWER.PARA: Small business was also mentioned. It is not possible to segment out small or big business from any particular industry. Industries cover small and big business, and it is therefore inappropriate and, I should have thought, impossible to single out small business from larger business. It would be a physical impossibility. However, small business and big business have in general fared very well under this Government. Because of the accord, they have had a growth of the economy which is unparalleled in this nation's history. There has been a strong increase in profitability, which is not confined to large business but which spills over into all sectors of corporate and non-corporate business areas and means that, the rural sector aside-where special factors obviously apply-small business has done very well while this Government has been in office. It is a nonsense to argue that small business as a whole is doing badly while big business is doing well. There is no evidence to that effect, and I defy the Opposition to come up with any that shows that small business generally is faring badly. It is part of a corporate and business sector which is faring very well and which never fared so well under the previous Government.

TALK.START.PARA: —I ask the Minister for Science: Is there any concern about the return of the Nella Dan from the Antarctic to Australia?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Jones The Hon B.O.

TALK.START.PARA: —I thank the honourable member for Brand for her question. I am pleased to report that after the worst season in living memory in the Antarctic, things are going very well. As honourable members will appreciate, it is getting very late in the season. Nella Dan was caught briefly in the ice off Davis after having picked up the summer expeditioners who had been at the new temporary base at Edgeworth-David. They were ultimately relieved by helicopter, picked up from Davis, and then Nella Dan was caught in the ice for a couple of days. The ship is now in open water, I am glad to say, and because the configuration of the ice is different, as honourable members would know, outside the Mawson base, it is expected that they will have no difficulty in getting away from Mawson. The honourable member for Brand, as a member for Western Australia, will be glad to know that we are going to use Albany as a back-up port for our Antarctic operations. Albany is actually due north of the most easterly of our bases, Casey. Most of our bases are more in the Indian Ocean area than they are in the Pacific zone.

ANSWER.PARA: The other piece of information I should gratuitously pass on to the House is that I am glad to say the Icebird has now been repaired. Our expectation was that the Icebird would be leaving at 12 noon Tasmanian time to go down to pick up the remaining expeditioners from the summer period who need to be relieved. We have gone through a long period of potentially high hazard and we have gone through it very well. There have been two losses of life this season, which is appalling, but the situation could have been far worse.

TALK.START.PARA: —My question is directed to the Minister for Local Government and Administrative Services. I refer to the Minister's personal explanation on Tuesday in which he stated that the grants to Tilley Devine's and the Wyuna Co-operative Housing Project were made as a result of recommendations by the Australian Capital Territory Employment Advisory Committee. I ask the Minister: Who were the members of that Committee while he was the Minister for Territories and who appointed them? Will the Minister table all the documentation relating to the appointment of Committee members? Will the Minister table the letter to him of 23 November 1983, which he referred to on Tuesday, recommending approval for the funding of Commonwealth employment projects? Finally, who sponsored or recommended the community employment program grant to the Women's Centre?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Uren The Hon T.

TALK.START.PARA: —I will answer the last part of the question first. The Women's Centre Incorporated sponsored the proposal before the Advisory Committee in Canberra. The Australian Capital Territory Employment Advisory Committee was made up of five women and five men. The Committee was considered to be the most imaginative and, productive community employment program committee in the whole of Australia. Of course, honourable members opposite have never really been too supportive of CEP. It was their Government that created so much unemployment in this country. At least the CEP, which has been well debated in this House, certainly has proved itself a worthy program to support.

ANSWER.PARA: I am asked who made the recommendation of the 10 people on the Australian Capital Territory Employment Advisory Committee. That recommendation was made jointly by myself and the Minister for Employment and Industrial Relations. The two authors of the article, Richard Farmer and Dean Banks, are businessmen here in Canberra. They obtained the letter through public information and if it is made available through public information I am sure the Minister for Territories will make it available to membership in this House. It is not within my authority to do so, but I am quite sure that the Minister will make it available.

TALK.START.PARA: —For the information of the House, I present the annual report of the Australian Manufacturing Council for 1984-85.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Dawkins The Hon J.S.

TALK.START.PARA: —For the information of the House, I present a report by the National Aboriginal Education Committee on the philosophy, aims and policy guidelines for Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander education, together with the text of a statement relating to the report.

SPEECH.PARA: Motion (by Mr Lionel Bowen) proposed:
That the House take note of the papers.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Brown The Hon N.A.

TALK.START.PARA: —I move:

SPEECH.PARA: That the debate be now adjourned.

Perhaps I can have your indulgence, Madam Speaker, to say, as I have unfortunately had to say on other occasions, that there is a statement accompanying this report and we do not know who made this statement or what status it has. We have been given no notice of that statement, and normally statements would have to be made after the Minister has asked for leave. We are becoming a bit exasperated with the practice, which is happening with increasing frequency and about which all honourable members should be concerned, of reports being tabled accompanied by statements but with no explanation being made as to where the statement has come from or the circumstances in which it was made.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Dawkins The Hon J.S.

TALK.START.PARA: —With your indulgence, Madam Speaker: This practice was started by the coalition Government. The fact is that this report relates to a portfolio the Minister of which is in the Senate. The statement was made in the Senate at the time the report was tabled in the Senate. So, it is not as if it is a matter of any great mystery. It is, however, important that the statement made by the Minister in another place also be available to this House, which, of course, it now is.

SPEECH.PARA: Question resolved in the affirmative.

DEBATE.TITLE: COMMONWEALTH ACCOMMODATION AND CATERING SERVICES LTD

TALKER.NAME: Mr UREN
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for Local Government and Administrative Services)

TALK.START.PARA: —For the information of honourable members, I present the annual report of Commonwealth Accommodation and Catering Services Ltd for 1984-85.

DEBATE.TITLE: MANAGEMENT AND INVESTMENT COMPANIES LICENSING BOARD

TALK.START.PARA: —Pursuant to sub-section 46 (3) of the Management and Investment Companies Act 1983, I present the annual report of the Management and Investment Companies Licensing Board for 1984-85.

DEBATE.TITLE: NATIONAL ENERGY RESEARCH, DEVELOPMENT AND DEMONSTRATION COUNCIL

TALK.START.PARA: —For the information of honourable members, I present the annual report of the National Energy Research, Development and Demonstration Council for 1984-85.
—Madam Speaker, I wish to make a personal explanation.
—Does the honourable member claim to have been misrepresented?
—I certainly do, Madam Speaker.
—The honourable member may proceed.

—Today in the Sydney Morning Herald, in a column by Rod Frail entitled `From the Gallery', there is a claim that I have `a curious habit in the Parliamentary dining room of refusing to accept food served on plates bearing the words Australian Parliament'. The present Government's action in replacing crockery marked `Commonwealth Parliament' with that marked `Australian Parliament' clearly indicates Labor's complete contempt for our federal system.
—Order! This is not a personal explanation. The honourable member should get on to where he has been personally misrepresented.
—Unlike many Australian Labor Party members who always frequent expensive restaurants, and Senator Elstob, who considers--
—Order! This is not a personal explanation, either. The honourable member will show the House how he has been personally misrepresented.

—Unlike Senator Elstob, who considers that the meals served in the Parliamentary Dining Room would kill a brown dog, I eat from time to time in the Dining Room. There is absolutely no truth whatsoever in the assertion that I refuse to accept food on plates bearing the words `Australian Parliament'. I therefore wanted to correct the record.
—Order! The honourable member will now resume his seat. I remind the House that personal explanations are made with the indulgence of the Chair. That indulgence is starting to run out.
—Petitions have been lodged for presentation as follows and copies will be referred to the appropriate Ministers:

PETITION.PRESENTERS: BALDWIN; DARLING; HOLLIS; HURFORD; KENT; MAHER; RUDDOCK
PETITION.NAMEIDS: MD4; UD4; DH4; AV4; PH4; GP4; 0J4
PETITION.TITLE: Tamils in Sri Lanka
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the Speaker and Members of the House of Representatives in Parliament assembled.

We the undersigned are deeply concerned that under the guise of ceasefire the Government of Sri Lanka has largely militarised Tamil regions and has now resorted to airship attacks in highly populated areas and indiscriminate killings of civilians which is seen even by the Indian Foreign Minister as having genocidal tendencies.
Your petitioners humbly pray that the House of Representatives in Parliament assembled will call upon the Government to:
1. Intercede with the Government of Sri Lanka to desist from airship attacks and seeking a military solution;
2. To offer refuge under humanitarian and compassionate programmes to Tamils who are fleeing from the violence;
3. Abandon all direct and indirect forms of repatriation of any Tamil who has sought refuge in Australia and grant them meaningful assistance to resettle;
4. As a member of the Commonwealth, persuade the Government of Sri Lanka to pursue a political solution which will allow the Tamils to live in peace and dignity.
Your petitioners, as in duty bound, will ever pray.
PETITION.PRESENTER.BLOCK: by Mr Baldwin,Mrs Darling,Mr Hollis,Mr Hurford,Mr Kent,Mr Maher and Mr Ruddock.

PETITION.PRESENTERS: ANDREW; COBB; FISHER; JULL; HICKS; RUDDOCK
PETITION.TITLE: Fuel Prices
PETITION.PARA: To The Honourable the Speaker and Members of the House of Representatives in Parliament assembled.
The petition of the undersigned shows:
That the Hawke Government should;
pass on the full benefit of lower international oil prices on 1 March 1986;
not increase or extend fuel taxes; and
maintain its tax cut commitments.
Your petitioners humbly pray that the Hawke Government honour its commitment to the Import Parity Pricing policy.
And your petitioners, as in duty bound, will ever pray.
PETITION.PRESENTER.BLOCK: by Mr Andrew,Mr Cobb,Mr Peter Fisher,Mr Jull,Mr Hicks and Mr Ruddock.

PETITION.TITLE: Pensions
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the Speaker and the Members of the House of Representatives in Parliament assembled.
The humble petition of the undersigned citizens respectfully showeth that your petitioners are gravely concerned at the failure of the government to honour its election promises to pensioners.
In particular those promises relate to the following commitments:
1. That within three years of its election to office, a Hawke Labor Government would raise the level of the standard pension to 25 per cent of average weekly earnings;
2. That the lag time between the announcement of the Consumer Price Index figures and the subsequent adjustment of pensions would be reduced to one month, and
3. That the disproportionate tax burden borne by low income earners would be lifted.
None of these promises has been honoured to date.

Your petitioners are extremely angry at the failure of the Government to live up to its commitments and as in duty bound will ever pray that these serious omissions will be given the attention they deserve.
PETITION.PRESENTER.BLOCK: by Mr Blunt,Mr Robert Brown,Mr Cowan,Mr Lee and Mr Allan Morris.

PETITION.TITLE: National Flag
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the Speaker and the honourable members of the House of Representatives in the Parliament assembled. The humble petition of the undersigned citizens of Australia showeth that whereas:
1. They are completely satisfied with the design of the existing Australian National Flag.
2. They are aware it properly reflects immutable characteristics of Australia, namely:
(a) The Union Jack, itself the creation of three Christian Crosses, represents the Nation's historical origin and the source of its language and law;
(b) The Southern Cross on an azure blue background signifying its geographical location;
(c) The large star depicting the advent of Federation.
3. They know the Flag has been a source of inspiration to generations of Australians in peace and war.
4. They recall that millions of native-born Australians and newcomers to these shores from other parts of the world have become united under its proud symbolism.
5. They are certain that any change to the Flag will produce division in the Australian community.

Your petitioners therefore pray that your honourable House will give speedy passage to the Flags Act Amendment Bill which provides that the Australian National Flag can only be changed by a referendum.
PETITION.PRESENTER.BLOCK: by Mr Andrew,Mr Shack and Dr Watson.

PETITION.TITLE: Pornography
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the Speaker and Members of the House of Representatives in Parliament assembled. The petition of the undersigned respectfully showeth:
That your petitioners are greatly concerned at:
(a) The ready availability of X-rated videos including pornographic and violent material; and
(b) The increased tendency to highlight so many forms of sexual activity in the media without regard to the susceptibilities of the general public; and
as a consequence, Your petitioners most humbly pray that the House of Representatives in Parliament assembled should take action to:
1. Prevent the importation and sale of hard core pornography and grossly obscene publications;

2. Require the censorship authority to more appropriately reflect responsible community attitudes in determining classification and suitability of films and videos to be shown to Australian audiences; and
3. Ensure greater propriety in television productions, local and overseas, telecast to Australian audiences.
And your petitioners, as in duty bound, will ever pray.
PETITION.PRESENTER.BLOCK: by Mr Conquest and Mr Webster.

PETITION.TITLE: Nuclear Free Zones
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the Speaker and Members of the House of Representatives in Parliament assembled.
The humble petition of citizens of Australia shows-

That the people of New Zealand and the New Zealand Government have given an example to the world in their efforts to achieve a nuclear free South Pacific, and such decision being endorsed by the people at a general election.

Your petitioners therefore pray that the Australian Government support the principled stand taken by the New Zealand Government and urges it to condemn any efforts by the U.S. Government to impose economic or other sanctions on New Zealand in retaliation for their stand on nuclear vessels.
We further urge the Australian Government to urgently implement its policy to promote the development of zones of peace and nuclear free zones in the Indian and Pacific Oceans.
PETITION.PRESENTER.BLOCK: by Mr Kent and Mr Staples.

PETITION.TITLE: Taxation: Small Business
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the Speaker and members of the House of Representatives assembled in Parliament. The petition of the undersigned respectfully showeth:
Introduction of any additional capital gains taxes, wealth taxes or death duties is opposed on the grounds that:
they adversely affect the small and medium size businesses in Australia, destroying incentive and discouraging investment in this important area of the economy;
the Australian economy, and employment in particular, is heavily reliant on growth in small businesses;

any capital gains that might result when owners of small businesses finally sell the business are not `windfall gains' but the result many hard years of work and sacrifice, with very little being taken out of the business by way of salaries so that the maximum amount money can be ploughed back into the business to create growth and jobs;
the owners of small businesses often depend on a capital gain-which are simply deferred salaries-when they eventually sell their business to sustain them in retirement;

Your Petitioners request that the House of Representatives, in Parliament assembled, will protect the rights of private enterprise and reject any inequitable additional taxes. And your petitioners as in duty bound will ever pray.

PETITION.TITLE: Proposed Australian Government Centre, Mordialloc-Chelsea Area, Victoria
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the Speaker and members of the House of Representatives in Parliament assembled:
The humble Petition of undersigned Citizens of Australia respectfully showeth-
The area between Cheltenham and Frankston is lacking any C.E.S., Social Security or Medicare Offices, despite the clear need for such offices.
Your Petitioners therefore humbly pray that
An Australian Government Centre containing a C.E.S., Social Security, Medicare and other appropriate Government Offices be established in the Mordialloc-Chelsea area as soon as practicable.
And your petitioners as in duty bound will ever pray.

PETITION.TITLE: South Dubbo Post Office
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the Speaker and members of the House of Representatives assembled: The humble petition of the undersigned citizens of Australia respectfully showeth:

That we strenuously object to the proposal that the Post Office Agency at South Dubbo be closed. The Post Office Agency serves a community need and we would be seriously inconvenienced by having to travel to another centre for our postal requirements, or even to collect a registered letter. Many of us are pensioners and even the cost of such travel would be an unnecessary imposition.
Your Petitioners therefore humbly pray that the House should take all possible steps to prevent the closure of this Office.
And your petitioners as in duty bound will ever pray.

PETITION.TITLE: Marine Band Radio Licence Fee
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the Speaker and members of the House of Representatives, Parliament House, Canberra. A.C.T. 2600.
The petition of certain citizens of Australia draws to the attention of the House-

That we, the undersigned, are greatly concerned by, and totally opposed to, paying a licence fee to operate a marine band radio which is carried in any craft, and which may be relied upon to summon assistance in emergency situations.
We wish you to rescind the Regulation under the Wireless Telegraphy Act 1905, which prescribes this fee.
Your petitioners, therefore, humbly pray that the Federal Commonwealth Government of Australia will protect us from payment of this fee, and your petitioners as in duty bound, will ever pray.

PETITION.TITLE: National Flag
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the Speaker and Members of the House of Representatives in Parliament assembled. The petition of the undersigned respectfully showeth:
1. That the overwhelming majority of Australians are completely satisfied with the existing Australian National Flag.

2. That we are totally opposed to any change in the Australian National Flag as provided in Section (3) of the Flags Act, unless such proposed change is first voted on by the people of Australia and passed by a majority of voters in a majority of States.
And your petitioners as in duty bound will ever pray.

PETITION.TITLE: Enterprise Migrant Hostel, Victoria
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the Speaker and Members of the House of Representatives in Parliament assembled. The petition of the undersigned respectfully showeth:

We are concerned that the closure of the Enterprise Migrant Hostel will be detrimental to the long-term settlement prospects of migrants in Victoria as well as detrimental to Ethnic Communities who have settled in the Springvale area. In addition, the long-term development of commerce and industry in the area will be adversely affected.
We urge the Government to reverse this decision.
And your petitioners, as in duty bound, will ever pray.

PETITION.TITLE: Namibia
PETITION.PARA: To the Speaker and Members of the House of Representatives in Parliament assembled. The Petitioners of the undersigned citizens of Australia respectfully showeth: That the humble petitioners respectfully believe that the representatives in Australia of the African National Congress and the South West Africa Peoples Organisation should not have to suffer unending financial problems to the cost of rent, food and clothing, and the maintenance of two small offices run on the most austere basis.
Your Petitioners therefore pray and urge the provision of:
1. Official recognition of A.N.C. and S.W.A.P.O. as the legitimate representatives of the people of South Africa and Namibia.
2. Financial support to the offices and representatives of the African National Congress and the South West Africa Peoples Organisation to promote the anti-Apartheid cause.
3. Additional financial support for the official representatives of the A.N.C. and S.W.A.P.O. to assist the humanitarian needs of Namibian and South African refugees who are victims of Apartheid.
4. Scholarships for South African and Namibian refugees. These to be provided through the A.N.C. and S.W.A.P.O. education departments.
And your petitioners as in duty bound will ever pray.

PETITION.TITLE: Television Services in Illawarra Region
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the Speaker and Members of the House of Representatives assembled. The petition of the undersigned citizens of the Commonwealth of Australia respectfully showeth:

That the Government's decision to force, at the expense of viewers, the transfer of WIN TV (and any future local broadcaster) from VHF to UHF transmission, while excluding Sydney metropolitan T.V. stations from this requirement, has placed in jeopardy the future of the Illawarra and South Coast region's only local commercial T.V. operator.

Your petitioners request the House of Representatives to protect the interests of the hundreds of thousands of television viewers within the area from Wollongong to the Victorian border served by WIN TV, by preventing the government from taking this unwarranted and discriminatory action which disadvantages both viewers and advertisers on the South Coast to the benefit of the metropolitan networks.
And your petitioners as in duty bound will ever pray.

PETITION.TITLE: Proposed Relocation of Army Training Facilities
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the Speaker and Members of the House of Representatives in Parliament assembled. The petition of the undersigned citizens respectfully showeth:

We object to the proposed relocation of the Army Training Facilities to the Central Tablelands of New South Wales where they shall cause interference with the access, environment and resources of the Macquarie River, its tributaries and the catchment of Burrendong Dam. We respectfully request that the Honourable Members of the House of Representatives assembled, will ensure the immediate cessation of all investigations, studies and proposals in the Central Tablelands area which include the Macquarie River, its tributaries and catchment for Military purposes and that the Macquarie river, its environs, recreational resources, historical significance and access along the entire length of the river will be preserved for present and future generations.
And your Petitioners as in duty bound will ever pray.

PETITION.TITLE: Education
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the Speaker and Members of the House of Representatives in Parliament assembled. The humble petition of the undersigned citizens respectfully showeth that:

1 They call on the House of Representatives and the Government of the Commonwealth to reject the recommendations of the Commonwealth Schools Commission contained in `Funding Policies for Australian Schools', concerning proposed increases in State aid to private schools and the proposed community standard for education funding.

2 They call on the House of Representatives and the Government of the Commonwealth to declare a three year moratorium (1985-1987) on increases in State aid to private schools and on grants for new private schools and for increased private school enrolments.

3 They call on the House of Representatives and the Government of the Commonwealth to re-affirm their primary obligation to government schools and to implement all 1983 ALP election promises for increased funding to government schools.
And your Petitioners as in duty bound will ever pray.

PETITION.TITLE: Funding of Children's Services
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable Speaker and Members of the House of Representatives, the Petition of the undersigned respectfully showeth:

that the May expenditure savings which introduced funding cuts to children's services will cause hardship to many low and middle income earners. Families relying on these vital services will suffer, as will workers within the industry. Your petitioners therefore humbly pray that your Honourable House fully restores all Federal Funding to children's services in Australia, and your petitioners as in duty bound will ever pray.

PETITION.TITLE: Identity Cards
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the Speaker, and Members of the House of Representatives assembled in Parliament.
This petition of Australian residents shows that we strongly oppose the introduction of the ``Australia Card'' or any form of compulsory identity cards.

We believe that the introduction of Identity cards will erode civil liberties; will create an increased risk of invasion of privacy; and will not result in any significant increase in Government revenue.
We call on the Parliament to immediately reject any proposals for the introduction of compulsory Identity Cards.

PETITION.TITLE: Koalas
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the Speaker of the House of Representatives in the Parliament assembled.
The petition of concerned people respectfully showeth their desire to have the koala declared an endangered species and given the proper protection of the Commonwealth.

Your petitioners therefore humbly pray that your Honourable House declare that the koala may not be exported from this country and that urgent re-vegetation of their habitats be carried out. Your petitioners also humbly pray that Commonwealth Government funds will be made available for research into the disease Chlamydia Psittaci which is killing the koala.
And your petitioners as in duty bound will every pray.

PETITION.TITLE: Slaughter of Wild Horses
PETITION.PARA: The Honourable the Speaker and Members of the House of Representatives in the Parliament assembled.
The petition of concerned people respectfully showeth their desire to have the wild horses of Queensland and the Northern Territory declared a protected species.

Your petitioners therefore humbly pray that your Honourable House set aside a National Park for these horses and ensure that the killing of feral animals be undertaken in a humane manner with proper legislation and enforcement.
And your petitioners in duty bound ever pray.

PETITION.TITLE: Nuclear Weapons Tests
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the Speaker and Members of the House of Representatives in Parliament assembled;
And, to the Australian Government.
This petition of concerned Australian citizens respectfully points out that a comprehensive ban on all nuclear weapon tests in all environments for all time would be a vital first step towards:
inhibiting the addition of more and more sophisticated and destabilizing nuclear weapons to the world's arsenals;
arresting the extension of the arms race to outer space;
upholding the provisions of existing treaties and agreements.
Your petitioners humbly pray that:

1. The Australian Government-(a) take new initiatives to encourage all member States of the United Nations-especially the Governments of nuclear weapon States-to conclude at an early stage a treaty banning all nuclear weapon tests in all environments for all time, (b) call on all nuclear weapon States to declare an immediate moratorium on all nuclear weapon tests pending conclusion of a CTB.
2. All Federal Members of Parliament and Senators make strong representations to the Australian Government to act towards these goals.
And your petitioners as is duty bound will ever pray.

PETITION.TITLE: Australian Bill of Rights Bill
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the Speaker and Members of the House of Representatives in Parliament assembled: the humble petition of the undersigned citizens of South Australia showeth that: Your petitioners pray that Your Honourable House will reject the proposed Australian Bill of Rights Bill 1985 for the following reasons:

1. We believe as a matter of faith and judgment that the proposed legislation is anti-God and its implementation will result in attacks on the Christian church and the promotion of a State religion based on secular humanism;
2. That there is no need for legislation of this kind since the principles of freedom are already enshrined in Common Law and that it will cause more problems than it seeks to solve;

3. That there is a potential threat to our national security through making treaties of this kind with foreign nations, many of which do not share a common heritage and do not practice many of the principles that they have convenanted to uphold;

4. The methods being used to introduce this legislation are secretive and a blatant misuse of the external affairs powers under Section 51 of the Australian Constitution and that furthermore are contrary to the spirit of the Constitution;

5. That the implementation of the legislation through a process of new educational initiatives will result in the centralised control of education and this will inevitably lead to the destruction of States' rights.
And your petitioners, as in duty bound, will ever pray.
PETITION.PRESENTER.BLOCK: by Mr Andrew and Mr Bilney.

PETITION.TITLE: Australian Bill of Rights Bill
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the Speaker and Members of the House of Representatives in Parliament assembled. The humble petition of the undersigned citizens of Richmond electorate respectfully showeth that:
The Hawke Labor Government's Bill of Rights seeks to make changes in the constitutional balance in Australia by intruding into the affairs of individuals and of State and Local Governments.
Your petitioners humbly pray that the House of Representatives, in Parliament assembled, urge the Government to:

Repeal the Bill of Rights legislation and not restrict the individual freedoms of Australians and its present justice system, nor in any underhand way centralise power in our three tier system of Government.
And your petitioners as in duty bound will ever pray.

PETITION.TITLE: Ayers Rock
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the Speaker and Members of the House of Representatives in Parliament assembled. The humble petition of the undersigned citizens of Richmond electorate respectfully showeth that:

Whereas the present Government of the Commonwealth of Australia has announced its intention to present the Title Deeds to Ayers Rock in Central Australia, currently the joint property of the people of the Commonwealth to an Aboriginal Land Council on 26 October 1985,

Whereas opinion polls and statements of representative groups, Members of Parliament and respected individuals show clearly that the Commonwealth Government has no mandate from the citizens of the Commonwealth to act in this manner,

Whereas the present Government claims to be totally opposed to apartheid (separate development) in South Africa but is handing over Ayers Rock to an Aboriginal Council in support of a policy of apartheid (separate development) which has been shown to be detrimental to the Aboriginal people of Australia,

Whereas it is pursuing this policy making it a crime for most white and many Aboriginals to enter, without permit, large areas of the Commonwealth designated apartheid (i.e., set aside for separate development), contrary to our democratic traditions and experience of freedom of movement for citizens of all racial origins within Australia,
Whereas Australians citizens have no present means available to them to prevent this violation of their natural rights to unfettered common ownership of, and access to, a treasured natural asset.
Your petitioners humbly pray that the House of Representatives, in Parliament assembled, urge the Government to:
Seek means available for the protection of the people's interests to prevent this outrage and preserve the democratic traditions of Australia,
And your petitioners as in duty bound will ever pray

PETITION.TITLE: Fuel Prices
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the Speaker and Members of the House of Representatives in Parliament assembled. The humble petition of the undersigned citizens of Richmond electorate respectfully showeth that:

The Hawke Labor Government's refusal to pass on to motorists, farmers and small businessmen, and the community as a whole, the full effect of the drop in world oil prices will decrease Australia's competitiveness as a trading nation.
Your petitioners humbly pray that the House of Representatives, in Parliament assembled, urge the Government to:
Act immediately to adhere to the oil world parity pricing policy, and give the full flow-on of the drop in world oil prices to the Australian public and the business sector.
And your petitioners as in duty bound will ever pray.

PETITION.TITLE: Australian Bill of Rights Bill
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the Speaker and the Members of the House of Representatives in Parliament assembled:
The humble petition of certain electors of the Division of Cowper respectfully showeth:

That the Bill of Rights Bill, the Human Rights and Equal Opportunity Commission Bill, the Human Rights and Equal Opportunity Commission Amendment Bill and the Human Rights and Equal Opportunity Commission (Transitional Provisions and Consequential Amendments) Bill, if passed by the Parliament, will undermine human and civil rights in Australia; will attack the institution of the family in our country, and will destroy States Rights and the federal nature of our Commonwealth.
Your Petitioners humbly pray that:
The Parliament rejects these Bills; abolishes the Human Rights and Equal Opportunity Commission and moves to withdraw ratification of the International Covenant on Civil and Political Rights.
And your Petitioners, as in duty bound, will ever pray.

PETITION.TITLE: Australian Broadcasting Corporation Radio Studio, Grafton
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the Speaker and Members of the House of Representatives in Parliament assembled.
The humble petition of certain citizens of the North Coast of New South Wales, Australia respectfully showeth:

That the community of Grafton and the Clarence Valley desire the retention of the A.B.C. Radio Studios in Grafton for the Second Regional Radio Network and pledge total support of Grafton City Council's submission on the Green Paper entitled ``Discussion Paper-Second Regional Radio Network for the Australian Broadcasting Corporation''.

Your petitioners therefore humbly pray that your Honourable House will sympathetically look at the problems of all these people in northern New South Wales and that the responsible Minister will take the necessary action to ensure the retention of the A.B.C. Radio Studio in Grafton and heed the submission of Grafton City Council in response to the Green Paper entitled ``Discussion Paper-Second Regional Radio Network for the Australian Broadcasting Corporation''.
And your petitioners as in duty bound will ever pray.

PETITION.TITLE: National Flag
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the Speaker and Members of the House of Representatives in Parliament assembled:
The humble petition of certain citizens of Queensland, Australia, respectfully showeth that we are totally opposed to any change in the Australian National Flag as declared in the Flags Act (1953).
Your petitioners humbly pray that Parliament in its wisdom will take no action to change the Australian National Flag.
And your petitioners, as in duty bound, will ever pray.

DEBATE.SUB1.TITLE: Discussion of Matter of Public Importance

INTERJECT.SPEAKER: Mr DEPUTY SPEAKER

TALK.START.PARA: —Madam Speaker has received a letter from the honourable member for Mackellar (Mr Carlton) proposing that a definite matter of public importance be submitted to the House for discussion, namely:

INTERJECT.PARA: The ever increasing conflict and confusion in the Hawke Government over its economic policies.
I call upon those members who approve of the proposed discussion to rise in their places.
More than the number of members required by the Standing Orders having risen in their places-

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Carlton The Hon J.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —Today's unemployment figures are very bad news for the Australian people. They show that unemployment, seasonally adjusted, has risen once again to 8 per cent. Along with the disastrous slump in the housing and motor manufacturing industries, they signal that the business cycle has peaked, the period of economic recovery is drawing to a close and Australia faces more difficult times ahead. At this critical point in the management of the Australian economy we need a government that is united and determined, well prepared and steady, and able to guide us through the period of difficulty to better times ahead. We need sound policies and effective execution of those policies. Unfortunately for Australia, as the portents of gloom crowd in upon us we have the spectacle of a government that has squandered its opportunities, depleted the national larder and in internal disarray over how to deal with its economic predicament.

SPEECH.PARA: Let us first examine the background to our present difficulties. Since the Government came to office it has had a wonderful opportunity to establish a sound economic base for Australia during a period of economic recovery. It had the good fortune to come to office just as the business cycle was beginning to turn up. In 1982 and 1983 Australia had suffered a severe economic recession brought about by three principal factors: Firstly, a sharp downturn in the economies of the developed world; secondly, a series of disastrous droughts in Australia over a number of years; and thirdly, a massive and unearned rise in real wage costs arising from widespread strikes and other forms of industrial action supported by the Australian Council of Trade Unions and also by the present Prime Minister (Mr Hawke), who was shadow Minister for Industrial Relations at the time. Indeed, we are reminded in that respect of the contribution the same man made as President of the Australian Labor Party and as President of the ACTU to the previous major breakout on wages and costs in the Australian community, 1974-75.

Not long after the Labor Government came to office in 1983 it had the benefit of a world economic recovery, the breaking of the drought and a wage pause initiated by a the coalition Government. Needless to say, the incoming government grossly exaggerated difficulties it was facing. It claimed that the Budget deficit for 1983-84 would be $9.6 billion or more under the Fraser Government's policies, yet after the Hawke Government has increased government spending by an outrageous 7.3 per cent in real terms in that financial year, its deficit came out at only $8 billion. That was after increasing spending by 7.3 per cent in real terms. If the Hawke Government had held its spending increases to the average of the Fraser years, the deficit would have been $2.7 billion less in 1983-84 and there would have been a surplus of $380m this financial year instead of a deficit of over $5 billion. That would have occurred if it had had the same fiscal responsibility on average as the Fraser Government had over seven years, one of which included an economic recession.

The Government has also exaggerated its record on employment. Unemployment was high when it took over in the depths of the economic recession, and not surprisingly. Now, after three years of economic recovery, unemployment is still higher than it was for all but the last four months of the 86 months of the Fraser Government, and even the Government admits that there will be no improvement in the performance this year. Today's figures show that unemployment is at 8 per cent. In other words, after three years of economic recovery, the best this Government can do is to reduce the unemployment figures by just over two percentage points, leaving them at a very high 8 per cent, and youth unemployment is still well over 20 per cent and showing no sign of changing.

TALK.START.PARA: —The period of unemployment has doubled.
—As my colleague the honourable member for McPherson correctly points out, the period during which people are unemployed is increasing disastrously.
—From 39 to 52 weeks.

—From 39 to 52 weeks, as the Deputy Leader of the Opposition points out. That is the increase in the length of unemployment of those unemployed under this Government. I raise these matters in advance as the Treasurer (Mr Keating), if he comes in to reply to my remarks, usually tries to raise false spectres of the past in these debates. But as time moves on, his rewriting of history becomes more transparent and less possible.

SPEECH.PARA: The fact is that this Government had the good fortune to come into office at the beginning of an upswing in the business cycle. It had the opportunity to use that period of economic growth prudently and productively. It had the duty to husband the nation's resources for more difficult times. Yet what has it done? It has squandered its opportunities. It has frittered away the fruits of the economic recovery in irresponsible spending programs. In its first two Budgets it increased government spending by over 30 per cent and taxes by 28 1/2 per cent. Over its three years of office it has run up Budget deficits totalling $19.6 billion, compared with total deficits under the seven years of the Fraser Government of $17.6 billion. So in three years of economic recovery the Government has run up more debt than the Fraser Government did in seven years, which included a period of recession when one would expect a bit more government borrowing.

Instead of putting money aside for a rainy day-maybe in Australian terms I should say for a drought-the Government has been squandering our resources and putting us into hock. The Hawke Government has turned Australia into a major debtor nation. Our total overseas debt now stands at $70 billion, compared with $25 billion three years ago. In the same period, the Government's overseas debt has risen from $9 billion to $26.5 billion. This year we are spending over 40c in each dollar we earn in export income on servicing our overseas debt. It is going to cost us $6.7 billion in interest charges alone on Federal Government debt this financial year-more than we spend as a nation on health, education or, heaven help us, our national defence.

What of the other indicators of economic performance? What of interest rates and inflation? Despite the promises of the Prime Minister and the Treasurer before the 1984 election that interest rates would fall in 1985, they reached the highest real rates since the early 1930s-the Great Depression-and they are still high. They are still putting farmers and small businessmen out of business and they are still putting up the costs on home mortgages. Our inflation rate is now 8.2 per cent and rising. It is twice the rate of our major trading partners, at a time when their inflation rates are falling.

The economy is at a critical point. The housing industry and the motor industry-two leading indicators of economic activity-tell us that we are heading towards a decline. Today's unemployment figures tell us that unemployment has begun to rise again from the high base of 7.8 per cent, which I point out to the House is two percentage points higher than the base rate at the end of the Fraser economic recovery. In other words, when we had had over two years of economic recovery, we finished up with an unemployment rate two percentage points lower than this Government has been able to achieve after a period of three years of economic recovery. When one, hopefully, has built up employment during a rise in the business cycle and a rise in economic activity, one expects the unemployment rate to be considerably lower than it is now.

At this critical turning point in the economy, after the long period of economic growth, do we stand well prepared for leaner times? Of course we do not. We have overspent, over borrowed, over inflated and over charged, but we have under invested. Business investment is at pitifully low rates and the Treasurer's pathetic words today during Question Time, hoping like Macawber for a turn up in business investment, were ridiculous, and certainly will not be met under any current indications. Just when we need a cool head and a steady hand at the tiller, we have total confusion in the ranks of the Government. If ever we needed cohesion and, dare I say it, consensus in the Government, it is now. Yet what do we have? Ministers cannot even agree on the interpretation of the figures.

Let us take the balance of payments, which is a critical indicator of economic performance, as the honourable member for Calwell (Dr Theophanous) pointed out in his statement yesterday. On Tuesday the Treasurer said that he expected the balance of payments deficit for 1985-86 to be about 5 per cent of gross domestic product. That would require a fall of the monthly deficit in coming months to about half the present figure of over a billion dollars a month. In other words, to meet what the Treasurer said on Tuesday, we would have to halve the current account deficit over the next few months. On Wednesday we received the monthly figure and it was over $1 billion, higher than the previous month. We asked the Prime Minister about that in the House yesterday, and what did he say? He thought the figures were good. Yesterday, he said:
We believe that evidence is starting to emerge of the turnaround we have been looking for for some time now.

He said earlier the same thing about the dollar, interest rates and now about the current account deficit. In the Senate, also yesterday, Senator Button was not so sure. Honourable members might recall that he is the Leader of the Government in the Senate and ought to know what he is talking about. He said:
We do not expect any dramatic turnaround in that current account problem this month, next month or the month after.

All I can say is that if the Government cannot even agree on what the balance of payments figures mean, Lord help it and Lord help us. Today the Treasurer was asked about this discrepancy between the various interpretations of the figures and he said that he saw the sign of a clear J effect. He refers to his theory of the J curve which he has been waiting to turn up for the last months.

TALK.START.PARA: —Is not a jay a magpie?

—My friend, the honourable member for Denison (Mr Hodgman), asks whether the jay is a magpie. This particular J is a popinjay. The reference to the magpie is well taken because the theme of the Australian Labor Party's recovery is the tune the Thieving Magpie. It is in its advertisement on television in the mid-term campaign leading into the election-La Guzza Ladra. I hope I have used a reasonable form of Italian to indicate what I mean to those in the audience who might understand that language. It is very clear in English and Italian that this Government is typified and will be labelled as the thieving magpie Government. This Treasurer will be labelled as the thieving magpie Treasurer.

SPEECH.PARA: Let us consider the equally serious matter of the Government's objectives, one of which is the trilogy. Quite simply, the trilogy is this commitment by the Government:

There will be no increase in tax revenue as a proportion of GDP in 1985-86 and over the life of the Parliament; Government expenditure will not increase as a proportion of GDP in 1985-86 and over the life of the Parliament; and the Budget deficit will be reduced in money terms in 1985-86 and reduced as a proportion of GDP over the life of the Parliament.

That is not a very demanding commitment but at least we thought that we had it clear. After all, it is written in black ink on page 382 of the Budget Statement. So last week, when one of the Government Ministers leaked a confidential Cabinet submission on the 1986-87 Budget strategy to the Sydney Morning Herald, we noted that according to the Government's own figures, tax revenues for this financial year will exceed the trilogy figure. That is another broken promise. Naturally, we asked Ministers about this in Question Time. We asked: `Is it true that the trilogy commitment on taxes will not be met?' The Treasurer at least agreed that the leaked document was genuine. Indeed, he threatened, if not to crucify the Minister responsible, at least to expel him from the Labor Party. Senator Walsh in the Senate declined to acknowledge the truth of the document. The Prime Minister said unequivocally in this House on Tuesday:
. . . we will adhere to the terms of the trilogy.

That is well and good, except for the query about the truthfulness of the Treasurer's Cabinet paper. Yesterday I asked the Treasurer about the discrepancy between the Prime Minister's remarks and the Cabinet paper. He replied, inter a lot of alia:

I am not in any position at this stage to be able to say with any precision just precisely where receipts will finish over the course of the year. The fact is that the trilogy is a commitment for the Parliament and the trilogy commitment will be met.

Those opposite do not even understand what are their objectives. They are leaking, disagreeing with each other and the head of their back bench committee on industry questions their industry policy. They are in total disarray. How can they guide us through this extremely difficult period? They ought to give it up. They are hopelessly incompetent and will not be able to get through this period.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Brown Mr R.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —Mr Deputy Speaker--

SPEECH.PARA: Opposition members interjecting--

TALK.START.PARA: —The ovation that I am receiving from the Opposition benches is one of the greatest ovations that I have received at any time in my life. I thank those opposite for it. I do not suppose that it will come as any surprise at all to either the honourable member for Mackellar (Mr Carlton) or the Opposition generally that the Government absolutely rejects this matter of public importance. I thought that it was particularly interesting that in presenting this matter of public importance two of the first matters to which the honourable member referred were that of employment and housing commencements because if we need any evidence to indicate the appalling nature of the economic policies that were pursued by the Fraser-Howard Government and the devastating results of those policies, we need look no further than at those two matters.

SPEECH.PARA: We had an employment situation when those opposite were in government in which unemployment increased from less than 300,000-representing 4.6 per cent of the labour force-to over 730,000-representing 10.4 per cent of the labour force. The honourable member for Mackellar, the shadow Treasurer, referred to employment as one of the grounds upon which he believed he could base the matter of public importance despite the fact that on a similar occasion yesterday I mentioned that prior to March 1983 when the present Government was elected an undertaking was given to the Australian people to pursue the creation of half a million new jobs in the first three years of the Hawke Government.

TALK.START.PARA: —They laughed at us.
—As the honourable member for Calare reminds me, the Opposition laughed at us.
—They said that it could not be done.

—As the sterling member for Stirling indicates, the Opposition said that it could not be done. That response from the Opposition was not surprising. Could it have been surprising from a coalition of political parties which during their last year in government brought about an increase in unemployment of a quarter of a million? The second matter to which the honourable member for Mackellar referred was that of housing commencements. Despite the appalling lack of housing that existed and continues to exist in Australia the number of housing commencements during the Opposition's last year was 105,000. Almost immediately the Hawke Government brought about a situation where the number of housing commencements increased to, and averaged over two years, between 140,000 and 150,000 new homes every year.

SPEECH.PARA: Even this year, when the Opposition is trying to suggest that the situation in the housing industry has reached a crisis the number of housing commencements will be 137,000. That compares with the 105,000 in its last year. Those opposite have suggested that the present Government's economic policy has been confused and inconsistent. One thing I can say about them and their economic policy is that a number of aspects are remarkably consistent; first in the grossly inadequate degree of expertise and concern which they brought to economic management; and secondly, they consistently maintained, as part of their economic strategy, an overvalued Australian dollar as one of the chief devices against inflation. In the process they decimated Australian secondary industry.

During their seven years, as those opposite well know, secondary industry in Australia almost ground to a halt. There were liquidations and bankruptcies and company closures and factories closing their gates and doors became the order of the day. The reason is that those opposite had no answer to the great problems which confronted the Australian people during those years. The aspirations of the Australian people with all the magnificent human and natural resources which provided this nation with the type of potential that should have been harnessed and directed towards the well-being of people and the development of this nation were absolutely dissipated during those seven disastrous years.

They were absolutely dissipated during those seven disastrous years, yet they come in here and suggest that there has been some inconsistency or inadequacy on the part of this Government-a government which, more than any other government in the history of the Commonwealth, has brought about magnificent results. Of course, those results are applauded not only within this nation and on the part of those 600,000 people in Australia who are in employment today as a result of these successes of this Government's policy but also in other countries of a similar kind.

In fact, I remind the House and the Australian people that the Treasurer, on an occasion of great modesty, said that, if Australia's economic revival had been achieved in western Europe, the people of western Europe would have been lighting candles in every cathedral of every country. I am pleased to see that endorsed so positively and so overwhelmingly from all of the people on this side of the chamber.
