(Quorum formed) It is quite apparent that, while Opposition members are happy to raise a matter of public importance, they are not very happy to debate it. They have tried to reduce the amount of time available to me.

The person who raised this matter of public importance today was the honourable member for Mackellar, the shadow Treasurer. I refer the House to a copy of today's Age with a headline `Backbenchers rebuff shadow treasurer'.

TALK.START.PARA: —Who is the shadow Treasurer?

—The honourable member for Dobell asks me to remind the House who is the shadow Treasurer. I will tell the House. The shadow Treasurer is the honourable member for Mackellar. Do honourable members know how he was rebuffed by his back bench? First of all, he got on the phone and tried to solicit support for Dr David Watson, the honourable member for Forde, to become chairman of the back bench treasury committee. What happened was that the Opposition members of that committee repudiated that approach, abandoned the shadow Treasurer and-wait for this; honourable members will not believe this-instead voted in as chairman of their treasury committee no other than the honourable member for Bruce, Mr Ken Aldred.

SPEECH.PARA: Government members-Oh!

TALK.START.PARA: —I know honourable members cannot believe it but that is according to today's Age , and I do not think it has been denied.

SPEECH.PARA: As I have said, Opposition members have expressed concern about the consistency of the Hawke Government's economic policy. I said that, if the Opposition had shown any consistency in its economic policy, it was in a number of directions, First of all, it showed its consistent inadequacy in economic policy. Secondly, as I have said, it maintained an overvalued dollar which decimated Australian manufacturing industry. It also consistently failed to allow room in its budget plans to make it possible for any economic growth to take place in Australia. Every year when it introduced a Budget, it would first of all determine what it expected the level of inflation to be. If it expected the level of inflation to be, for example, 10 per cent, it set its monetary targets at 10 per cent.

What that meant was that, while its monetary growth target allowed capacity to accommodate that inflation, no capacity was allowed for any type of real economic growth. What happened during the last three years of the Fraser Government as a result of its adopting that sort of approach was that in terms of real economic growth, in 1980-81, the figure was 3.3 per cent; in 1981-82, it was 2.8 per cent; and, in 1982-83, it was minus 0.6 per cent. As I have said, as a result of that decline-to the point that economic growth became negative-in the last year of the Fraser Government unemployment was increasing every day by 750 people.

TALK.START.PARA: —Who was the Treasurer?

—The honourable member for Macarthur asks me to remind the House that the Treasurer at that time was none other than the person who leads the Opposition today, the honourable member for Bennelong, Mr John Howard. He was the chief architect of those economic policies which brought this nation to its economic knees. But we have had such a remarkable transformation, such a remarkable turnaround.

SPEECH.PARA: As I said earlier, there are now in Australia 600,000 people who have the dignity associated with employment-people who are now in jobs who would not have been in jobs had it not been for the fact that the Australian people showed their magnificent perception and judgment in March of 1983, and repeated it.

Of course, we have been concerned about the attitude which has been adopted by the Opposition. The Opposition has shown itself, not only in government, to be incompetent and incapable of determining solutions to all of the great issues that confronted the Australian people. It has also shown itself in opposition to be completely incapable of presenting any alternative strategy. Opposition members have learned nothing from their gross, continuing and destructive results while in government. They have been repudiated by us. They have been repudiated by the community, and the Opposition front bench is now in the process of being repudiated by the back bench.

The honourable member for Mackellar also referred to the issue of investment. For three consecutive years while the Opposition was in government, real investment in Australian fell by 15 per cent. This year it is expected to rise by over 20 per cent and next financial year by a further 27 per cent. The great achievements that have been brought about as a result of the enlightened policies of this Government-a government which has shown itself capable of understanding the essential problems this nation faces and devising the sorts of policies that are necessary to overcome those problems-are all attributes of this Government that are showing themselves to be effective. Across this nation, the Australian people have rejoiced in the great achievements of this Government because the Australian people have shared in the fruits of those policies.

TALK.START.PARA: —Order! The honourable member's time has expired.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: McGauran Mr P.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —For the first time in memory the Treasurer (Mr Keating) has failed to attend this chamber to defend his economic record. It is also the first time in memory that a Treasurer has failed to do so during the period of any government. The matter of public importance reads as follows:

SPEECH.PARA: The ever-increasing conflict and confusion in the Hawke Government over its economic policies.

Lucifer glides in here in his patent leather shoes, without a sound, and in his black double-breasted suits, without a crease, when he wants to bucket people. The only time we ever see the Treasurer of this nation become excited or passionate about an issue is when he is directing a well-aimed kick at someone's head. I have never in my three years in this place heard the Treasurer speak strongly about the unemployed, the underprivileged, the farmers, small businessmen or any other disaffected sector of our society. The Treasurer is a shallow, disinterested man who has displayed today an utter contempt for the Parliament. He stands condemned. Every person listening to Parliament this afternoon ought to understand that the Treasurer has not attended the chamber to defend his record or that of his Government. I suggest that he be given leave of absence to sort himself out because there is no doubt at all that under the strain of the impending reckoning day, which so many members of the Government know will occur later this year, he is cracking.

The Treasurer's cracking is symptomatic of what we have been witnessing for the past few weeks. There has been the most extraordinary internal brawling in the Australian Labor Party since the Taxation Summit fiasco, and that is really saying something. The divisions at present within the Government are more deep-rooted and bitter because at stake is not just one aspect of policy-that is, taxation-but the whole economic strategy of the Government. The divisions have left back bench members jumpy and nervous and Ministers distrustful of each other, some of them having shown a propensity to leak confidential Cabinet documents. I refer to the paper of the Minister for Employment and Industrial Relations (Mr Willis) which stated that employment opportunities have stagnated and it is likely that unemployment will worsen, and the Treasurer's paper which argued for a reduction in Government spending.

It is a vicious and personalised dispute within the Government. The punch-up-there is no other word for it-in Caucus last Monday has left many members embittered. As one of them said to me, the dummy spitter let his ego run wild again. There are no prizes at all for guessing who the dummy spitter is-it is the Treasurer. I hasten to add that the Government member who so accurately described the events of last Monday is not one of your garden-type prepackaged left wingers; for that matter, he is not one of your ordinary automation right wing backbenchers. He is a factional leader.

TALK.START.PARA: —Graeme Campbell!

—He is a numbers cruncher. As members of the Government ridicule their own colleagues, I hasten to add that the member I am referring to resides in another place. The immediate cause of the problem last Monday was the debate on whether to have an inquiry into the takeover of Broken Hill Proprietary Co Ltd. The Treasurer carried the day, as we know, even though the Prime Minister (Mr Hawke) has been publicly uncertain and equivocating. The conflict and confusion within the Government ranks over economic management is epidemic. The whole sorry mess which the Government finds itself in is entirely of its own making.

SPEECH.PARA: There are three arms of economic policy-monetary policy, incomes policy and fiscal policy. Of those, only one has the broad support of Caucus-the incomes policy in the shape and form of the prices and incomes accord. All that can be said about monetary and fiscal policies is that confusion and conflict reign supreme. The existing situation is that the Government has a large external constraint, that is, the size of the current account deficit. We know that in February 1986 the current account deficit was $1 billion, ensuring that the predicted $13 billion to $14 billion trading deficit will, sadly, be met at the end of June 1986. It is likely that, on the present course, we will in the near future for the first time ever have a trading deficit with Japan. To correct the deficit the Government should allow the exchange rate to depreciate. However, an exchange rate depreciation will add to the inflation rate and this is where the incomes policy comes into play. Of course the accord indexes wages according to the consumer price index. Any reduction in indexed wages to allow for depreciation is excluded specifically in the accord. In other words, because of the accord the Government cannot bring about a real depreciation.

What can the Government do, since it has locked itself into this position? How will it overcome its subservient relationship with the Australian Council of Trade Unions? The Government must turn to either monetary or fiscal policy, and this is where we have members of the Government tearing at each other's throats as each seeks to protect his specific interests and to ensure, as one of those spending Ministers has said, that his constituency knows that he is in there battling very hard for them. The Government has relied on monetary policy to try to tackle the large current account deficit by tightening the money supply. This policy pushes up interest rates, thereby creating a differential between interest rates in Australia and in other countries. It is true to say that the Government hopes to encourage Australians to borrow off-shore and to encourage foreign investment in Australia. Both these things will keep up the exchange rate, and the Government needs to keep up the exchange rate so that pressure is not placed on the accord. Rises in interest rates, a deliberate policy of this Government, have obvious adverse effects on the domestic economy-on farmers, small businessmen and home owners.

TALK.START.PARA: —All exporters.

—Not to mention, of course, exporters. This high interest policy squeezes the economy, especially private investment. I was interested to see that today's Australian reported that the Treasurer, when addressing the ACTU, advised the union movement of a necessary cut in Government expenditure because of fundamental weakness in the economy caused by a lack of private sector investment. The Treasurer knows that he has gone as far as he can with monetary policy. He cannot squeeze it any further; he must turn to fiscal policy and restrain Government expenditure. Of course there are just too many people within his own Party at both Cabinet and back bench level who will not allow him to do so. All they say is that the deficit should be increased. Not one of them has specified how the deficit can be funded. We on this side of the House know that it will be funded firstly by higher taxes and secondly by higher Government borrowings. That is the only way to satisfy the left wing's demands. I point out that Senator Graham Richardson, a well-known organiser for the right wing in New South Wales has criticised the Treasurer, too; so this conflict crosses factional lines.

SPEECH.PARA: When one reads today's Australian Financial Review the problems of the Government can be seen in a nutshell. On the front page is a story of how exports have performed so poorly but on the second page we have the honourable member for Calwell (Dr Theophanous) calling for higher protection and quotas. The honourable member for Calwell is supposed to be the intellectual guru of the Left, and he has called for higher protection and quotas. As every first year commerce student knows, increases in protection do not increase aggregate employment.

All it does is reshuffle employment. It may assist employment in specific industries but it would be at the expense of employment elsewhere. The honourable member for Calwell is simply reflecting the line of the metal trade industry unions; he is simply doing their bidding. There is conflict and confusion within the Government; there are highly personalised bitter disputes which nobody on this side would lose any sleep about except that all Australians are suffering.

TALK.START.PARA: —Order! The honourable member's time has expired.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Edwards Mr R.F.

TALK.START.PARA: —We have just heard from the anti-privatisation, agrarian socialists of the National Party of Australia who basically want to underwrite publicly everything in this economy. They do not want to hear anything that the Leader of the Opposition (Mr Howard) says about privatisation. They do not want to know about that. They want to make sure that they underwrite everything in the economy, but they have not really worked out what policies they want to pursue, whether it be a wages policy, a fiscal policy or a monetary policy. All we know from the history of the National Party is that it underwrites everything.

SPEECH.PARA: When we turn to other sectors of the Liberal Party of Australia we hear different voices sounding. Some of those voices are sounding a little softer about privatisation because suddenly that issue is off the boil. The Opposition has taken a beating in two State elections because privatisation became the out word. It did not know whether it should put all its election material through the shredder or whether it should put the leaders of the Opposition through the shredder. Clearly, judging from the opinion polls, the Leader of the Opposition in this place has been put through the shredder. We have to understand that the Opposition is divided. The interesting thing is that the community knows it. While we have the cacophony of voices from the pro-South Africa National Party, the agrarian socialists, in one corner, we also have the privatisation group clustered around the honourable member for Mackellar (Mr Carlton). I understand that the honourable member for Bruce (Mr Aldred), who is leading the Opposition's economics committee, is a bit soft on privatisation. So we have another position to which we have to react.

The only thing the Government can say-the honourable member for Charlton (Mr Robert Brown) has expressed it all-is that the Australian public does not have to worry about privatisation because Opposition members are just voices in the wilderness and they will stay there because their record is appalling. The interesting thing is that the community knows their record is appalling. What I find staggering is the fact that suddenly we have a Leader of the Opposition whom the Opposition is trying to make out as new. The thing the Opposition forgets is that the Australian community remembers the Leader of the Opposition's performance when he was Treasurer under big Mal. It was not good. The honourable member for Charlton spelt it out in terms of figures. People felt the impact on their lives. When a quarter of a million people are unemployed in a year people know it, and they rejected the former Government. As the honourable member for Charlton has said, housing commencements fell to 105,000 a year-a 20-year low-and the people knew it. Honourable members opposite even said that people in Australia would have to learn to live without housing. What a disgraceful proposition! What a disgraceful situation! Clearly, as the honourable member for Charlton and Labor Ministers for housing have said, we have got people back into houses in this country and our record has been outstanding. We are looking at an average performance of 140,000 to 150,000 housing commencements over two years, as the honourable member for Charlton has said. Our record is there. We know all about that and the community knows about it.

Let us look at the appalling housing record of the Opposition. Fancy getting to a situation in Australia where we have a group such as honourable members opposite saying: `People will have to learn to live without housing in this country'! What a disgraceful proposition! That is what the Opposition came up with.

TALK.START.PARA: —It is absolutely disgraceful.

—It is absolutely disgraceful, as my colleague says, and the community knows it. The Opposition's record on unemployment is also quite staggering, given the way it put masses of people on the dole. As has been said repeatedly by honourable members on this side, the Opposition's record is appalling. Let us look at the Government's record. Some 600,000 jobs have been created in the three-year period it has been in office. As the honourable member for Charlton said, we thought that a figure of 500,000 new jobs would be difficult to attain. Not only have we attained it but we have gone well beyond it and people recognise that. These days a lot more people are in jobs than there were when the Opposition was in government and people recognise that. The Opposition's record is not good and it cannot remake itself because the cracks would show through. People know that very well.

SPEECH.PARA: The other issue we have to address is economic growth. What the Opposition never really understood and what it never really came to terms with was that if it kept talking down the economy, as it did when it was in government, after a while people, no matter how reluctantly, would begin to believe it and then the economy would begin to go through the floor. That is what happened under the former government. It takes a while for people to come to terms with the fact that the Opposition's economic performance was pretty shonkey but they believed it when it was in government and they paid the price. Businesses collapsed left, right and centre. We had a record number of bankruptcies. We had not seen so many bankruptcies in this country since the Depression.

We have achieved economic growth and recovery and people in business have recognised that. Also, as the Government and the Treasurer (Mr Keating) have pointed out repeatedly, what we have is a situation where the profit share of gross domestic product has recovered. That is matched by the figures for private fixed capital investment. People are prepared to put their money where their mouth is because they recognise that the Australian economy is on the move. Certainly, if one listened to the rhetoric of honourable members opposite one would think that we were in the midst of great doom and gloom. But the Opposition has always been the same. If it cannot get some scare going on the foreign policy front it will try to talk down the economy. Those are the two options. It is the same old strategy of the decrepit conservatives of this country. If they cannot get something going on the foreign affairs front, they will talk down the economy.

Yesterday the honourable member for Fisher (Mr Slipper) tried to get something of a vicious racist kind going about people in the Philippines. That is typical of the strategy of honourable members opposite and it is an absolutely discredited position. Those strategies are old hat and people recognise that. They understand very well that they will not sell any more. The Opposition cannot talk down the economy because people recognise very clearly what is happening, and it cannot beat up some foreign affairs issue. It was probably a source of great discontent to all honourable members opposite that the people of the Philippines managed a peaceful transition. We recognise that and we are supporting them. I am pleased to say that the Leader of the Opposition quickly declared himself on that issue but I wonder where some National Party members stand on that issue. We are never really sure.

Let us now turn to industrial relations. We have been waiting for a wages policy from honourable members opposite but we have not got one. We are not sure whether it is opting out, opting in or going under the waves. We are not sure what strategy the Opposition wants to pursue. What does the Opposition suggest? Would it have an opting out system? Would it have centralised wage fixation? We do not know which voice to listen to. The only thing I can say is that there are plenty of voices of discontent opposite willing to talk to members of the Government on a regular basis and tell us what their real thoughts are. Those thoughts cannot be projected in the Party room because the clique that has control is narrow and unrepresentative of the Australian community. Interestingly, the Australian community understands that. One does not have to be a member of this Parliament to understand that. The Australian community understands that control of the Opposition is in the hands of a narrow, unrepresentative clique which talks about things that are discredited.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Western Australian Liberal Party.

—As my colleague the honourable member for Calare says, the Western Australian Liberal Party was shown to be unrepresentative, as was the South Australian Liberal Party. We have these groups which do not understand what is happening in the community.

SPEECH.PARA: What the Opposition is saying on industrial relations simply is not believed by the people. We have an accord which has worked. A couple of times the Opposition has said: `The accord will not work; it cannot possibly work. How can you have a sensible, mature agreement between unions, employers and government? You cannot do that. You have to treat people in this community as though they are not responsible'. We treat people in this community as though they are responsible. The record is on the board. The number of industrial disputes has dropped to the lowest level since 1969. We are experiencing the lowest amount of working time lost since 1969. If one talks to people in the community one hears that they are happy with the way industrial relations are going.

We do not have the knock-down, drag-out brawls that honourable members opposite seem to want all the time. An industrial dispute is exactly the sort of tune that rings in their ears. What we are talking about is getting the economy going, getting things moving, deregulating the economy, getting people into the economy and bringing in new financial institutions. If one looks at employment growth in the economy on a sector by sector basis one sees that our performance, particularly in the finance area, has been quite outstanding. We have had a regeneration of the economy. The Government has said to people in the finance industry: `We challenge you to perform. We challenge you to show that you are capable of performing as a sophisticated, economic sector'. What was the economy like under the Opposition? The Opposition wanted to keep the lid on everything and close down everything. Again, we had the agrarian socialists of the National Party calling the tune and the then Treasurer, the present Leader of the Opposition, could not bring about changes. The Opposition had a discredited economic policy.

The honourable member for Charlton has said a great deal in support of the Government's position. He said that we would reject the terms of the matter of public importance; of course we do. The Australian community rejects it. There is no need for the Treasurer to deal with the B-graders opposite. The record speaks very loudly and the incredible thing is that the Australian community understands that record. It is there for all to see. In conclusion, if we reflect on the economic growth and the employment performance that we have seen over the last three years we see that the record speaks very loudly indeed and the Australian community well understands that. We on this side of the House reject the Opposition's matter of public importance.

TALK.START.PARA: —Order! The time for the discussion has expired.

PROCTEXT.PARA: Debate resumed.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Blanchard Mr C.A.

TALK.START.PARA: —Before the debate was interrupted I was discussing how there had been this debate in ethnic communities concerning the need to renounce or not to renounce all other allegiances and I was quoting from the report entitled `National Consultations on Multiculturalism and Citizenship', which was published in October 1982.
—And they were comprehensive consultations.
—As my good friend the honourable member for Stirling has indicated, they were comprehensive consultations. The report states:

SPEECH.PARA: It was suggested that it was insulting to ask a person to renounce all former allegiances. The renunciation was also said to give the Oath too negative a character. Speakers testified that it was psychologically impossible to renounce their backgrounds.

On the other hand, it was thought highly repugnant that a person granted Australian citizenship should retain allegiance to another nation or power. This concern appeared to focus on national affiliations and obligations in time of war, whereas opposition to the renunciation seemed, in the main, directed to the denial of cultural heritage or a psychological attachment to a former homeland.
It is probable that a clearer wording would resolve some of the apparent disagreement.

I certainly agree with the comments of the honourable member for Moncrieff (Mrs Sullivan) when she said that there were obvious discussions which led to differing opinions when these consultations took place. Despite the fears of the Opposition I do not think the proposed new wording for the oath and the affirmation will create the same divisions as the present wording does.

I turn to another matter which concerns the position where, at the moment, a person loses Australian citizenship upon acquisition of foreign citizenship. Under the present Act, a child of a parent who loses citizenship will also lose citizenship. Section 23aa of the Act allows a resumption of citizenship if a person can show that he or she would have suffered significant hardship-this has been raised in debate by honourable members on the opposite side of the House-if he or she did not acquire foreign citizenship or did not know that he or she would lose Australian citizenship on acquisition of foreign citizenship. This only applies to acts done after 22 November 1984. The present Bill extends section 23aa to include all persons who have lost citizenship under section 17 at any time. So the time barrier that existed before will be removed by the Australian Citizenship Amendment Bill.

To apply for a resumption of citizenship under the new proposals persons must have been lawfully resident in Australia for at least two years and they must show that they intend to return to Australia to live permanently within three years. I think this is a generous concession. I think it is a realistic concession and one that meets the wishes of many of the ethnic communities to whom I have spoken. It is pleasing to see that the Bill proposes that a child who lost citizenship under sub-section 23 (1) of the Act will be able to resume citizenship upon registration of a declaration lodged by the parents under section 23aa in which the child is included, provided the child is under 18 years of age. There are other elements of the Bill on which I would like to have commented but time prevents this. I would like to say that I fully support the Bill and I hope that it has a speedy passage through the House.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Hodges The Hon J.C.

TALK.START.PARA: —Debate on the Australian Citizenship Amendment Bill has been proceeding now for more than two hours and the Minister for Immigration and Ethnic Affairs (Mr Hurford) has been absent from the chamber for the total time of the debate. I think it is contemptuous of this Parliament that the Minister, who would have responsibility for no more than perhaps two or three Bills a year under his portfolio, should be absent. I recognise that he has other responsibilities as Minister Assisting the Treasurer. It may be that, because the nation is in such dire straits now in terms of its economic condition, that is where the Minister is. But I suggest to the Prime Minister (Mr Hawke) that he ought to ensure that his Ministers are in the chamber when legislation is being debated so that they at least can hear the views not only of the Government members but also of the Opposition. Clause 11 of the Bill deletes the renunciation phrase and the requirement that candidates state their names when taking the oath or making the affirmation of allegiance. I want to direct some comments to this aspect of the Bill. The Minister in his second reading speech stated:

SPEECH.PARA: Renunciation is ambiguous and unnecessary. Some candidates think that it requires them to renounce not only other allegiances but also their cultural background and all other ties with their country of origin.

I respond to that simply by saying that a small percentage of people might have that view but surely, soon after, they will come to realise that this is not the case. I believe that, if explicit written instructions are given to the candidates and if explicit written instructions are given to those persons who are conducting citizenship ceremonies-in the main they are mayors, chairmen of councils around the nation and certain departmental officers-there is no need for any deletion of the renunciation or a deletion of the individual's name. The Minister then went on to say:

In many cases renunciation does not affect the previous nationality or citizenship of candidates because the nationality laws of many countries permit their nationals to have more than one citizenship.

I respond to that simply by saying that what other countries do relevant to citizenship, whether they allow dual citizenship or multi-citizenship, is entirely their position. We, as a nation, cannot change laws of other countries. We do not support the concept of dual citizenship. People who take the oath or make the affirmation of allegiance must, in my view, continue to renounce previous allegiances. If their previous country of citizenship or country of birth continues to bestow certain rights and privileges on them, so be it. We cannot change that. In my view, it is essential that they belong in every sense to this country. Surely they take out citizenship to belong to and to be an integral part of this country.

I point out to the House that citizenship in Australian is not compulsory. There are people who have spent a large part of their lives in this country who have never bothered to take out citizenship. That is their decision; there is no compulsion on them so to do. No doubt in the future some people will continue to do this but I would hope-I am sure that everybody on both sides of this House would hope-that all people who come to make Australia their permanent home would indeed take out citizenship. There are certain advantages in citizenship. People must be Australian citizens in order to be able to register to vote. The Commonwealth Public Service and some State Public Services require individuals to be Australian citizens before they can be employed. One has to be an Australian citizen before one can enlist in the armed services. I say to those people who may commit any serious crimes that there have been many instances in this nation in the past where non-citizens have faced the prospect of being deported, whereas citizens cannot be deported.

I say, in summary, that there were no compelling reasons put forward in the national consultations on the Australian Citizenship Act to delete the renunciation of previous allegiances. Likewise, in my view the Minister has failed to place before this Parliament any compelling reasons for deleting the renunciation of all other allegiances. I mention the consultations because my predecessor in that office, the honourable member for Goldstein (Mr Macphee), as Minister for Immigration and Ethnic Affairs, instituted the consultations that were held in eight capital cities in Australia. I attended all those consultations and one could detect no unanimity of view. Many views were expressed and they were put by very sincere people.

I do not for a moment want to detract from the sincerity of the ethnic affairs task force chairman, Professor Jerzy Zubrzycki, who compiled the report for the Department at that stage, because I believe he did so in good faith. He also attended all those meetings, but I repeat that there was no unanimity of view that one could detect from those eight consultations, which involved about 1,000 people right around the nations. That is not a very large percentage of people in an Australian population of 15.8 million. Finally, on that issue I would point out that there is no compulsion on a government to accept any views, whether they be majority of minority views. The decision is finally up to the government of the day. There is no compulsion on any government to accept them, and I reject this aspect in clause 11 of the Bill.

I would ask the Minister if he were present-and he has been absent for the whole of this debate-why he should meddle with a system that has served us well for years? There has been no overwhelming pressure in the past to make such a change and I know of no such pressure not to do so. The Minister, in his second reading speech, said:
Some Commonwealth citizens find renunciation confusing because the Queen of Australia is also the head of state in their country of origin.

Once again, the person confering citizenship could explain this point in some detail. I do not recall one person from another Commonwealth country raising this matter with me personally. Common sense surely prevails in such a situation. The argument for deletion of renunciation is nonsense and I reject it completely.

I would point out that in the bipartisan approach we in government adopted on matters concerning immigration and ethnic affairs I, as Minister, invited the shadow Minister, now the Special Minister of State (Mr Young), to accompany me on those consultations right around Australia. He did accompany me to a number of those eight meetings. I suggest to the Minister for Immigration and Ethnic Affairs, and indeed to the Government, that if we are to delete the person's name as provided in this Bill we, as members of this place and senators in another place, when taking the oath or affirmation of allegiance in this Parliament should delete our names as we stand around the table at the beginning of each Parliament.

I turn to the question of applications for Australian citizenship received in any one year and granted. An examination of the last report of the Department of Immigration and Ethnic Affairs entitled `Review '85' reveals that 20,031 more applications were received for citizenship than in fact were granted in that year. In the previous year 1983-84 the figure was 5,197; in 1982-83, 12,450; in 1981-82, 17,275; in 1980-81, 1,249; and in 1979-80, 134. That makes it clear to me that in the last financial year 1984-85 there has been something wrong with the system, because the actual number of people who applied was not all that great compared with previous years.

I suggest that the Minister should look within the Department to see whether that backlog can be reduced. Those 20,000 people who applied for citizenship were residentially qualified to apply, having been here for a period of two years. A delay of that sort is a discouragement to people to take out citizenship. I would have thought that we want all the approximately one million people with resident status to take out citizenship and become more a part of this nation. Table 1 on page 128 of the review clearly sets out the number of persons from those countries who at this stage have not taken out citizenship. One sees from that table that 43 per cent of people who are eligible have not taken out citizenship. One also sees from that table that most of the persons from Communist regimes are well down in the 4 to 8 per cent area, whereas person from countries such as Britain and the Republic of Ireland stand at 62 per cent. The figure for Turkey is 77 per cent, Spain 49 per cent, New Zealand 68 per cent, Malta 57 per cent and Canada 61 per cent. I have quoted those figures which are over the average of 43 per cent. I sincerely trust that the Minister and the Government will give every encouragement to those people. The Government must bear in mind the frustration experienced by those people who are applying for citizenship and whose cases are not being brought forward.

I recognise that the mayors and chairmen of shires who are responsible for the final conferring of citizenship may in some cases be responsible for the delays. However, I and, I am sure, other members of this House would want to express our appreciation for the fine job that is done right around the nation by almost 900 elected representatives in their capacity as mayors of cities or chairmen of shires. They do a fine job in conferring Australian citizenship on the vast majority of people who come to this country to live. Once again, I point out that I hoped that the Minister for Immigration and Ethnic Affairs would be present for this debate. I want to raise a matter relating to the migration to this country of persons from Central and South America. I wish to point to the figures from 1979-80 to 1984-85 of permanent settlers, visaed migrants, to this country from central and southern America and to relate them to the total migrant intake. In the year 1979-80 to 1982-83 the total intake was 2.2 per cent, 1.2 per cent, 1.2 per cent and 1.8 per cent. Yet in 1983-84, the first full year of the Hawke Government, that figure as a percentage of total intake rose to 2.9 per cent, and it has risen to a staggering 4.7 per cent of total intake or 3,689 persons in 1984-85.

TALK.START.PARA: —That is as many as from Vietnam.

—Almost as many as from Vietnam, as my colleague the shadow Minister reminds me. To me those figures are quite alarming. When I was Minister for Immigration and Ethnic Affairs, a very senior officer in the Department visited those areas and on his return recommended strongly against the encouragement of migration from Central and South America. He did that for a number of good reasons, some of which I will outline to the House. I am not aware of where this decision has come from-whether from somewhere in the Department or as a result of ministerial direction. As Minister, a deal of pressure was put upon me from left wing members and senators of the Australian Labor Party to allow more people to come in from those areas. The report I got back from that senior officer was that, to start with, most of the people in those areas did not even know where Australia was. They were not even aware of where we were or what sort of a society we had. They related to Central America, if they were in southern America, and they certainly related to northern America if they were in southern America or in Central America. Many of them did not speak English or spoke very little English. Most of them were poor and unskilled. They did not even know-

—Order! I draw the honourable member's attention to relevance. This is a wide ranging debate, but he might relate his comments on migration from Central America and South America to the Australian Citizenship Amendment Bill. It is not a Bill about the immigration program as such.

—In all deference to you, Mr Deputy Speaker, I suggest that the citizenship of this country depends on the people from around the world whom we bring to this country, and I suggest to you that my reference to the immigration program and to the people we bring here-hopefully, to confer citizenship upon them eventually-is very much involved and very much intertwined with the total program of migration and, finally, of resident status and citizenship in this country.

SPEECH.PARA: Let me return to discussing the people who have come from that area. The final and very important point is that their settlement prospects here were not good. That was the assessment and the report that came to me. I suggest to the House that there is something a little unusual about this, something a little fishy about it. I suggest to the Minister that he ought to answer certain questions that I pose to him. I would be the last person to suggest that there is some conspiracy within the Department, because I could not detect such a thing when I was the Minister. I think that there are some very fine officers within the Department of Immigration and Ethnic Affairs, so I am not suggesting for a moment that there is a conspiracy there. However, it is very unusual that we have had this quite massive increase, both in numbers and in percentage terms, in the total intake from Central America and South America. I am highly suspicious that the increase from Central America and southern America has something to do with a political left wing bias.

I would hope that there is a balance in that program, but the Minister ought to answer some of the questions relative to it. Among the questions that I would put to him are: Has immigration from Central America and South America increased as a result of a recommendation from the Minister's Department? Has it increased as a result of a recommendation or, indeed, an approach from the United Nations High Commissioner for Refugees? Has it increased as a result of ministerial direction? From what countries have these people come, and have detailed character checks been carried out on all migrants from the region? This is a very serious matter. Have any of the migrants a known political activist background, and, if so, in what political groups have they been involved?

Those are questions that this Parliament ought to have answered. They are questions on which the Minister should respond to the Parliament or, indeed, to me personally. All of the recommendations to me when I was Minister were against an increase in the intake of people from that area. There may well be a good answer to this and good reasons for it, but I should like to know what they are, because it certainly was not the situation about four or five years ago. I am not in a position to answer the questions; the Minister is in such a position. I suggest that he provide an answer to the Parliament, because, as I say, it is a quite dramatic increase in numbers, and it involves a quite serious aspect in terms of our total immigration program. Numbers from that part of the world have consistently been fairly low over many years, and yet we find this quite dramatic increase in numbers. The least that we can expect from the Minister is a full explanation of where the nation stands.

Frankly, if the same situation arises in any other part of the world and if there are good and sound reasons for the program being increased for a particular part, I believe that the Parliament ought to be told, because certain patterns have been set with our immigration program over many years. There have often been good reasons why a program has been decreased for a particular country. Indeed, in parts of southern Europe over more recent years, because of an increased affluence in some countries, there has been less desire on the part of people from some of those traditional source countries for migration to Australia. But those reasons are stated. I would like to know the reasons for any dramatic increase or decrease in intake from any part of the world. A very important part of our program concerns citizenship.

TALK.START.PARA: —Order! The honourable member's time has expired.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Price Mr L.R.S.

TALK.START.PARA: —Earlier the honourable member for Petrie (Mr Hodges) complained that the Minister for Immigration and Ethnic Affairs (Mr Hurford) had left the chamber or was not in the chamber. I suggest to the honourable member that earlier in the debate the Minister was in the chamber, and that the only complaint the honourable member may have about being left out is about being left out of his shadow Cabinet. The most disappointing contribution of the honourable member was his maligning of those people coming from Central America and South America. I have met some of these people, through my responsibility as a Federal member of Parliament, in my electorate office and I am more than happy to say that they are taking out Australian citizenship. They are a very fine body of people. As to the aspersions cast by the honourable member for Petrie against Central American and South American Australians, if he wants to throw aspersions around about the quality of people coming from particular countries--
—You speak the truth.

—I am speaking the truth. I have quoted the honourable member, who is slurring Central American and South American people coming to Australia, imputing all sorts of motives to their being brought here. Anyway, let us talk about the Australian Citizenship Act, which was introduced in 1948. Its main aims were to set down guidelines for Australian citizenship by birth, adoption or descent and by grant to those who migrate to Australia. It also covers such areas as loss and renunciation of citizenship. The original Act, introduced some years ago, was last amended in 1984. Citizenship is a very important issue as it goes to the heart of democracy. I am pleased to see the Government updating the legislation and making it relevant to the 1980s and 1990s.

SPEECH.PARA: I give my full support to the citizenship by birth amendment. Under the current Act, people born in Australia, excluding children of diplomats, consular representatives and enemy aliens, automatically become Australian citizens. Unfortunately, this was often used as a ploy for visitors and illegal immigrants to achieve residence in Australia. This is totally unacceptable as well as being unfair to those who go about obtaining Australian citizenship in the correct way. The Act is to be amended so that a person born in Australia after the Bill comes into effect will become an Australian citizen only if at the time of birth at least one of the parents was an Australian citizen and a permanent resident. I believe that this is a fair and proper way to deal with the problem, considering the fact that Australia is one of the few remaining countries which have retained that provision.

By the same token, the Government will fulfil its obligation to ensure that children born in Australia do not become stateless. To ensure this, a child born in Australia who is not eligible to acquire Australian citizenship by birth becomes an Australian citizen provided that the child will not be, and has never been, eligible to acquire the citizenship of a foreign country.

Another amendment the Bill introduces concerns loss of Australian citizenship due to the acquisition of citizenship of another country. The Act was previously amended in 1984 and the Minister was thus empowered to approve the resumption of Australian citizenship in certain circumstances. These circumstances were: If former Australians lost citizenship because they acquired citizenship in another country under some form of compulsion, through economic necessity or without realising the consequences of their action, they were able to have it restored. However, this applied only to those who had lost Australian citizenship after 22 November 1984. The major problem with this amendment was that those who had lost citizenship prior to 22 November 1984 were not included and consequently wished to be included.

The amendment is that this provision should apply to any former Australian citizen, subject to certain commonsense recommendations. Such people must show a commitment to Australia by having had two years' lawful residence in Australia at any time and satisfy the Minister that they intend to return to Australia within three years to live permanently and that they have maintained a close and continuing relationship with Australia. The amendment will also permit a child who has lost citizenship to resume it with his or her parents. This amendment brings about no drastic changes to the Act but is merely a commonsense alteration that is more practical and definitely more simplified for former Australian citizens.

I also want to talk about the oaths and affirmations of allegiance amendment. In the Blacktown and Penrith local government areas, which are in my electorate of Chifley, some 2,000 people each year seek to obtain, and are granted, citizenship. I could not discuss citizenship without congratulating Alderman Leo Kelly, the Mayor of Blacktown, and Alderman Brian King, the Mayor of Penrith, on the manner in which they conduct their citizenship ceremonies. Penrith City Council provides a very formal ceremony which often involves only small numbers, whereas the Blacktown ceremony is less formal. However, I enjoy attending both councils' ceremonies equally.

Penrith City Council gives those taking the oath of allegiance a Bible-an act which I highly commend to all councils-for which it pays and which I know the people very much appreciate. Alderman Alsop of Penrith City Council is one of the oldest and most independent aldermen on the Council. He is always the last speaker at citizenship ceremonies and invites the ratepayers of Penrith City Council to accept the Mayor's invitation to enjoy a little refreshment and light supper, advising them that it will be the last free thing they ever receive from Penrith City Council.

I am always pleased to attend citizenship ceremonies. In the Blacktown area we always have a large ceremony at Bowman Hall. On Australia Day we induct some 300 people as Australia's newest citizens. We also have held ceremonies at the Riverstone Senior Citizens Centre in the electorate of my colleague the honourable member for Greenway (Mr Gorman) and the Mount Druitt Senior Citizens Centre. The senior citizens always put on a lovely supper and refreshments after the ceremony.

The Blacktown City Council now provides Bibles to participants in the ceremony and has developed the practice of handing out, during the ceremony, small shrubs and trees to our newest citizens as a memento of their decision to become Australians. Whilst there are no financial implications in the amendments before the House, I believe that other members on both sides of the House would join me in suggesting that local government should receive some form of recompense for the expense they go to in holding citizenship ceremonies. It would be very nice if, when Federal members attended the ceremonies, they were able, on behalf of the Australian Government, to present to people some memento of their becoming new Australians. Hopefully, this can be incorporated in administrative orders and does not require any legislation. I would be most grateful if the Minister would look at that suggestion.

Unfortunately, I was not able to attend the last ceremony held at Mount Druitt. I am pleased to say that my wife represented me. I am sure that many wives represent their husbands at these ceremonies when they cannot attend them themselves.

TALK.START.PARA: —Spouses.

—Spouses, I am sorry, or partners. Anyway, it is my wife. I was a little jealous that, when Sister Anne Hastings from St Aidan's School, Sister Sarah McCabe from Our Lady of Consolation Home and Pat Stewart and her mum and dad became citizens, I was not there to participate in the ceremony. In respect of the changes in the oath and affirmation, having the person making the oath or affirmation repeat the word `I' and then state his or her before making the oath or affirmation is unnecessary and repetitive and serves no important purpose. I can assure you, Mr Deputy Speaker, that at these ceremonies at least 12 or 15 people will say the name of the mayor after they say `I'. It is rather confusing.

SPEECH.PARA: I notice that the honourable member for Petrie (Mr Hodges) and other honourable members have raised the issue of renouncing all other allegiances. I guess that, 10 to 15 years ago, the character of these ceremonies-not that I had the privilege of attending them-would have been very much along the lines of our asking people to be very much Australian to eat meat pies and drive Holden cars. In a monoculture such as Australia was-unfortunately Australian is still very much a monoculture-the renouncing of all other allegiances had very strong connotations about dropping cultural backgrounds, assimilating and becoming very much Australian. The difference today with citizenship ceremonies is that we say: `Certainly you bring to Australia a richness, a heritage. We ask you not to lose that heritage or to drop it. We ask you to preserve your second language'. We have got away from the idea that everyone must conform to a narrow definition of Australian society. We are very much a multicultural society now. Therefore, it is very confusing to ask people to renounce all other allegiances.

I am very pleased to say that after the citizenship ceremonies conducted in the electorate of Chifley the Prime Minister (Mr Hawke) always sends a message of congratulations to our newest Australians. I publicly thank him very much for that because I know that it always goes over particularly well. I suggest to the Minister that the certificates that are issued would be every more meaningful if they had the Minister's signature on them. I understand that there are moves afoot to do that.

TALK.START.PARA: —They should use better quality paper.

—I guess that better quality paper would not be amiss. I thank the honourable member for suggesting it. In cases in which there is a need to get a ceremony performed quickly, with the local council people delegated to do it, there is the mayor of the town clerk. We need to examine the legislation and consider why deputy mayors and deputy town clerks cannot perform this very important function.

SPEECH.PARA: I strongly support the proposed amendments to the legislation. Citizenship and citizenship ceremonies are taken very seriously in the electorate of Chifley. We all have to be grateful for the quality of the new citizens coming forward and congratulate the councils and local government bodies on the manner in which they discharge their citizenship responsibilities on behalf of the Federal Government.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Ruddock Mr P.M.

TALK.START.PARA: —The purpose of the Australian Citizenship Amendment Bill 1986 is to make certain adjustments to the Australian Citizenship Act to exclude children born in Australia to visitors, temporary entrants and prohibited non-citizens from automatically acquiring Australian citizenship by birth; to amend the oath and affirmation of allegiance; to remove the requirements when taking the oath or affirmation to announce one's name and to renounce all other allegiances; to allow the resumption of citizenship for persons who lost it under section 17 of the Act at any time, subject to a continuing commitment to Australia; and to effect, as the explanatory memorandum says, certain other minor and formal amendments.

SPEECH.PARA: I will be discussing one issue, and that is the issue of the resumption of citizenship when it is lost. I will be quite critical of the proposal of the Government, and I think with very good reason. I am disappointed that this matter has to be debated in a contentious way because I would have thought that it would have been possible for the Government and the Opposition to narrow the range of issues in relation to the resumption of citizenship and I would have also hoped it was possible to narrow the range of issues on the one other contentious question, and that is the amendment to the oath and affirmation of allegiance.

Bipartisanship can only be achieved if both parties are willing to participate in meaningful dialogue and discussion, to share their views and to work towards the resolution of differences. It is not always essential that there is bipartisanship for good government or for good policies. A good stoush is sometimes very essential for the workings of democracy, but in the area of immigration, ethnic affairs and citizenship I think for some time it has been desirable to minimise the areas of conflict. Certainly that was the view of former Ministers on this side of the House. I think it ought to be noted that the approach that the Hon. Ian Macphee and the Hon. John Hodges took when they were Ministers for Immigration and Ethnic Affairs was to involve the Opposition spokesman fully in the development of policies in relation to citizenship and in relation to the question of immigration generally.

I have a copy of the `National Consultations on Multiculturalism and Citizenship' report of October 1982. I would like to mention what occurred on that occasion because on page 4 it talks about the process of consultation and in relation to the public forums on multiculturalism and citizenship that were being held it says that Mr Hodges welcomed the participation in the forum of the Opposition spokesman on immigration and ethnic affairs, the Hon. Mick Young. I know the sort of co-operation that ought to take place and I am sorry that in relation to this legislation, about which I had expressed a significant degree of interest over time I was not consulted-I do not suppose there was any special reason why I should have been consulted-but the Opposition spokesman, the honourable member for Mitchell (Mr Cadman), received a copy of the Bill some two hours before it was introduced in this House. That is not the basis upon which to get agreement. It is not the basis upon which these issues can be thrashed out and some measure of co-operation obtained. I think it is important.

I have listened very carefully in this debate to the discussion that has taken place on the question of the resumption of citizenship and I must say that except for the honourable member for Chifley (Mr Price), those who have spoken-it is no reflection upon you, Mr Deputy Speaker, but it includes you because you have spoken in this debate-have not understood clearly what has occurred, how it occurred and why the approach taken by the Opposition ought to be preferred. The honourable member for Chifley at least canvassed the argument. He had a well written brief. I do not know whether he wrote it himself but, from the words he used, he certainly understood the argument. It was a well prepared brief. Of course, he made it quite clear that in relation to certain amendments made in 1984 there was no capacity for those people who had lost their citizenship before that date to be able to resume it under provisions that were implemented for the resumption of citizenship under section 23aa of the Australian Citizenship Act when it was amended. I understand it was intended at that time that the legislation operate retrospectively to ensure that anybody who lost their citizenship prior to that date would be able to resume it and not just those who lost it after the legislation had been implemented, but for some reason or another the Parliamentary Counsel left it out. I assume, having been bitten in relation to taxation matters, the Government thought that retrospective legislation in relation to citizenship was not appropriate. The fact of the matter is that it was left out.

There were also certain changes to section 17 of the Act-the section by which people lose their citizenship. I just want to alert the House to the nature of those changes and also to the nature of the advice given by Australian officials overseas. I intend to mention a particular case which came to my attention. This case is probably the reason that I am very familiar with this issue. A constituent approached me more than two months ago. She lived for a time in Israel and she had, like many young people of Jewish origin, gone to live in Israel as a young person with some commitment as a Jew to assist the state of Israel. She did not intend that she would lose her Australian citizenship. She did not intend that she would never return to Australia. In fact, this lady, being of Jewish origin, and entitled, to do so under the Israeli nationality law which contains certain provisions known as the laws of return, take out permanent residence to enable her to work in Israel. She was unaware at the time that there was also another provision under which, if she had availed herself of it, she might well have been able to maintain her citizenship. However, she did not avail herself of that. That provision in the Jewish nationality law is a provision which enables certain people to conditionally opt out of taking up Israeli citizenship.

All through that time our officials at the Australian post in Israel were not terribly concerned about this matter. The operation of section 17 of the Australian Act, which is very similar to the Canadian provision, had not suggested to our people that there was any basis for concern about which they ought to brief people. In fact, the Australian Council of Jewry and others who were advising people going to Israel were not aware that there was likely to be a problem. People went to Israel, accepted permanent residence and found that, of course, over time they achieved Israeli citizenship, very often without knowing it.

This particular lady believed that she was still an Australian citizen. In fact, she returned to Australia with her husband, having renewed her Australian passport on a number of occasions before 1984. She had children born overseas whom she registered, one in London and one in Tel Aviv, as Australians born overseas-children born to her, presumably as an Australian citizen. This lady ultimately came back to Australia and in due course her husband wanted to go overseas on a trip associated with his work. Under our new passport arrangements, she applied for an Australian passport and had this drawn to her attention: `Did you go through this procedure in Israel at some earlier time? We are terribly sorry; you are no longer an Australian citizen. In fact, you are here illegally. The fact that you have taken up a job with the Australian Public Service as an Australian citizen means that you are really holding that job illegally because you are not an Australian citizen. By the way, those children you registered as Australians born overseas are not Australians either. We will fix it all up. We will allow you migrant entry now and we will register the children. The Minister has a discretion in relation to that but he has no discretion in relation to you because we passed this amendment in 1984 which did not have any retrospective effect'.

That is the nonsense with which we are having to deal. Anyone faced with people who have lost their citizenship-in this case the lady was living in Australia-would understand the nature and the extent of the problem. Of about 7,000 Australians living in Israel, about 2,000, we believe-the number might be greater-may well have not opted out of taking up Israeli citizenship. They will find at some time that they have no right to return to Australia. I will deal with the matter of the interpretation of this legislation. It is rather interesting that Canada had in operation certain provisions, before our amendment in 1984 to section 17 of the Act, that were in like terms to ours. Section 17 of the Australian Citizenship Act which operated in 1984 stated:

An Australian citizen of full age and of full capacity, who, whilst outside Australia and New Guinea, by some voluntary and formal act, other than marriage, acquires the nationality or citizenship of a country other than Australia, shall thereupon cease to be an Australian citizen.
Section 15 (1) of the Canadian Citizenship Act states:

A Canadian citizen, who, when outside of Canada and not under a disability, by any voluntary and formal act other than marriage, acquires the nationality or citizenship of a country other than Canada, thereupon ceases to be a Canadian citizen.
That was a very similar operation to our Act. We amended our Act. When we did so, we provided two new elements. They are:
17 (1) A person, being an Australian citizen who has attained the age of 18 years, who does any act or thing-
. . . the sole or dominant purpose of which; and
. . . the effect of which, is to acquire the nationality or citizenship of a foreign country, shall, upon that acquisition, cease to be an Australian citizen.
The Canadians, in interpreting their provisions, which before 1984 operated similarly to ours, took the view, as stated in a letter from the Canadian Ambassador to Israel:

In the opinion of the Registrar, the automatic or involuntary acquisition of Israeli Nationality by Canadian citizens does not involve loss of Canadian status. Further, the Registrar confirms that failure or omission to make a declaration of refusal under section 2 (a) (2) of the Israeli Nationality Law of April 1 . . . does not constitute formal and voluntary act for purposes of section 15 (1) of the Canadian Citizenship Act. As a result there would be no loss of Canadian citizenship.

I mention that because it is important that honourable members understand that other Commonwealth countries with provisions similar to ours and with a similar attitude to citizenship accept the position in Israel-one of the situations to which these amendments are particularly addressed. Canadians in particular would not forfeit the citizenship of their citizens in similar circumstances to those in which we are saying to Australian citizens: `You have forfeited your Australian citizenship'.

How has the Government gone about dealing with this problem? It has not simply ensured that section 23aa can now be of retrospective effect. By reading statements by the Minister for Immigration and Ethnic Affairs and also the undertaking to Australians in Israel in the form of a letter to the editor of the Jerusalem Post by Dr R. S. Merrillees, the Australian Ambassador, honourable members will appreciate that it was thought that the only step that the Government would take would be to amend section 23aa to give it retrospective effect. But that is not the Government's intention. In the Bill the Government has introduced three additional steps that a person in Israel who was likely to lose citizenship would have to satisfy to resume citizenship. Those new steps have been criticised by Opposition members. An amendment has been circulated by the honourable member for Mitchell. The Minister has already circulated a speech and an explanatory memorandum for certain further amendments that he intends to make to his Bill. But that does not meet the Opposition amendment in every respect.

The substantial difference is that a person who wants to resume citizenship after residing outside Australia will still, under the Minister's proposal, have to undertake to commence residing again in Australia within three years from the date from which that person seeks to apply for the return of his or her citizenship. The Minister says that that is a new element. It was not in section 23aa when amended in 1984. The Minister says that he wants it because he wants people to evidence an ongoing commitment to Australia. I am not sure what is so magic about three years but I know that it creates a very inconsistent position between every Australian who goes to Israel and is sufficiently astute to make the appropriate declaration and therefore not lose Australian citizenship and the person who has accepted the advice given by our officials-a very important matter-and lost citizenship before 1984 and is now being told that the only basis on which he or she can get it back is to indicate that within three years the person will make citizenship application.

It is very important that people understand the degree of sensitivity about this matter in Israel amongst those 7,000 Australians. It arises because there is an element of insecurity, as people said to me when I was there. They are under threat. The security situation is posed in terms of there being a group of people who want to push all the Jews back into the sea. A group of people there, Canadians, Americans, Australians and Britons say: `We are happy to give this time to try to assist in Israel but at some time, if there is a great and overwhelming risk, we may want to be able to go back to our original country'. They see being able to resume their citizenship as a lifeline. It is very important to them. It is a very emotional issue. In my judgment it is appropriate that they should feel that way. Certainly, I would want to meet their wishes.

I am disappointed that the Minister is introducing this new element into Section 23aa. As are my colleagues, I am disappointed that he is not here to hear these comments. I hope that they will be drawn to his attention and he withdraws the proposal. In the spirit of bipartisanship which we all see as being essential in this important area I hope that the Minister accepts the amendment proposed by the honourable member for Mitchell because then it would simply ask that a person residing outside Australia who wants, at some future time, to return be not specific as to the time limit by which that decision ought to take place. I believe that my colleagues have canvassed the other matters well. I attach a great deal to the oath and affirmation. I am disappointed that there could not be a bipartisan approach on that matter as well.

TALK.START.PARA: —Order! The honourable member's time has expired.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Lamb Mr A.H.

TALK.START.PARA: —This Government has introduced several amendments to the 1948 Australian Citizenship Act which covers the bestowal, deprivation and resumption of Australian citizenship. It is right and proper that the Government should constantly review and update its legislation particularly concerning citizenship as there are ebbs and flows of international law and relationships dealing with citizenship between different countries. The honourable member for Dundas (Mr Ruddock) raised the problem of the 1984 amendments which left some people prior to that time who had had dual citizenship or had lost citizenship not stateless but without Australian citizenship. That has been attended to in this Bill; it is a desirable change and a rectification of the problem.

SPEECH.PARA: As I have said, in late 1984 several amendments were legislated to remove discrimination on the basis of sex, marital status or previous nationality and to provide a mechanism to review decisions under the Act through the Administrative Appeals Tribunal. Among other matters, this Bill tackles an area also mentioned by the honourable member for Dundas, that is, the problems associated with dual citizenship. Australia's granting of automatic Australian citizenship to children born in Australian unless to consular or diplomatic parents often results in dual citizenship for the child and there are problems associated with the renunciation of citizenship when other countries will not recognise that renunciation which results in dual citizenship or a continuation of it.

Dual nationality arises through inconsistency between nations applying their domestic laws relating to citizenship. It is internationally accepted that each country is free to determine for itself as a matter of domestic law whom it will regard as its nationals and under what conditions its nationality can be acquired or lost. Australia has for many years tried to avoid the recognition of dual nationality and in fact since 1930 has supported the principle of the Hague Convention which favour a single nationality. Previous governments-for instance, the Opposition when it was in government-also favoured single nationality. I was surprised to hear the honourable member for Dundas advocate that we should adopt the model of Canada which does recognise, he said, dual citizenship. But I note that Canada was a signatory to the Hague Convention of 1930.

It is not that the matter of single nationality is readily accepted by everyone in Australia. As previous speakers have said, the history of modern Australia is virtually of a nation of migrants or the children of migrants, certainly since the acceleration of and the encouragement of migration to Australia over the last 40 years since the Second World War. Migrants from the United Kingdom and the Commonwealth have been reluctant to lose their dual citizenship or their British subject status as there were certain advantages for them in having dual citizenship-for instance, the right to obtain a passport from each country, thus making visiting to their former homelands easier and offering better employment opportunities as nationality is often a prerequisite for employment.

Many British subjects were reluctant to accept the amendments to the Citizenship Act in 1973 when the Whitlam Government required British subjects to become Australian citizens only if they met the same formal requirement of migrants from other countries. Some people thought that they would lose their British citizenship as they were required to renounce it. But Britain is a country that does recognise dual citizenship. Ten years on, I believe that British people who migrated here have now accepted those amendments of 1973 and have come to realise that it was not an anti-British move but simply a move to treat all migrants to Australia as equals.

However, migrants from other countries, particularly the Union of Soviet Socialist Republics and eastern Europe are anxious to divest themselves of their former nationality and to be only Australian citizens. Many were war refugees who fled oppression. These people were sad to lose their former nationality because of the circumstances but determined to renounce their former citizenships. But many are still considered by their former countries to be nationals of those countries. Despite their declaration, some of our Australian citizens retain dual citizenship against their will or in ignorance. Should they return to those former countries, they may find themselves subject to the laws of those countries, such as national service.

I want to bring to the attention of the House an example from my own electorate of a young Frenchman who migrated to Australia as a minor with his mother. His mother died very soon afterwards but he decided to stay in Australia, took out Australian citizenship and accordingly renounced his French nationality. He now wishes to return to France with his Australian fiance for a holiday and to attend his sister's wedding. He has been advised that he will be liable for national service in the army on his return to France, as it is the duty of any 19-year-old Frenchman. I understand that this is also a problem for Greeks who wish to return to their country. We have a very large Greek population, particularly in Melbourne, and I think they should be free to return to their country of origin. But Greek males face possible induction into national service. The Frenchman to whom I referred is afraid that he will lose his Australian citizenship automatically by serving in the army of a foreign power. But section 19 of the Australian Citizenship Act says that he would be deprived of his Australian citizenship only if his former country were at war with Australia. But we are not at war with France or with Greece.

What would be the reaction of the community if an Australian citizen returned to Russia or Vietnam and was forced to do national service there? He would still remain an Australian citizen but I wonder whether there would be clouds over that person when he returned to Australia. Australian diplomats cannot provide protection against induction into a foreign army because of the accepted principle of international law that diplomatic protection may not be given by one State to a dual national when he is in the country of his other nationality.

The issue of dual nationality is a vexed one and was referred in 1975 by the then Prime Minister, Mr E. G. Whitlam, to the Joint Committee on Foreign Affairs and Defence for report to this Parliament. The firm conclusion of that Committee was that its sympathies were entirely with those who suffer hardship by virtue of their dual nationality status and that attention should be give to overcoming their problems. That is what this legislation does. The report confirmed our ratification of the Hague Convention, Australia being one of only 20 nations to do so.

The Council of Europe Convention on Reduction of cases of Multiple Nationality and Military Obligations in cases of Multiple Nationality of 1963 brought about similar arrangements between some 10 European countries in an effort to minimise the causes of dual nationality, especially as they relate to military obligations. I will quote a small section from the report of the Joint Committee that points out the situation faced by my constituent, the former Frenchman. It states:
This-
that is, the Council of Europe Convention-

supports the view that the nations of Europe are anxious to minimise the causes of dual nationality. However, there are countervailing tendencies, even within Europe, which exacerbate the whole problem of dual nationality. An example is the French Nationality Law of January 1973. Under prior French domestic law, a person forfeited his French citizenship if he became naturalised in another country. France therefore appeared to uphold the principle of single nationality. The new Law provides that on naturalisation elsewhere a person does not lose his French nationality unless he makes express declaration to that effect: but a man under 35 may not thus renounce his French nationality until he has satisfied, or been exempted from, his obligations of military service. This Law is expressed to be subject to France's obligations under the European Convention, and the combined effect of the two is: if a French citizen becomes naturalised in one of the other countries which has ratified the European Convention, he loses his French nationality automatically: if, however, the same citizen is naturalised in any other country in the world (including Australia)-
this would include our former Frenchman-

he may continue to retain his French nationality, or may indeed be prevented from losing it. Thus, in relation to all countries outside Europe, France has taken the step of increasing the incidence of dual nationality.

We can see that, should an Australian citizen return to the country of second nationality, the Australian Government has no legal authority to protect him or her against the government of that country, such as in the case of compulsory military service, unless some special agreement concerning military service exists between the two governments.
