In the case that I have outlined of my former French constituent, I made an approach to the French Embassy, and asked it to keep a watchful eye, and also to the Australian Embassy. The co-operation that I have received suggests that my constituent can enjoy his holiday and return to Australia without hindrance. The fact that he did not flee from France in order to avoid conscription, but came with his family, must of course be in his favour. Of course, there is no guarantee; there is only goodwill.

In the reply of the Minister for Immigration and Ethnic Affairs (Mr Hurford) to this debate, I would welcome an indication of any further international efforts being made to bring about bilateral arrangements relating to compulsory national service so that our young former Greeks and former Frenchmen and others can return to those countries on holiday to see their relatives or whatever.

I cite this case to the House because of the provision in clause 11 of the Bill which will delete the renunciation phrase from the citizenship ceremony. On the surface, it would suggest a retreat from our commitment to single nationality. As the Australian Government cannot deprive people from other countries of their nationality, the act of renunciation can be an empty gesture, albeit an important symbolic act. Those countries which acknowledge, along with Australia, single nationality, could accept the adoption of Australian citizenship as an automatic declaration of renunciation of their former citizenship. Moreover, for some countries this renunciation does not remove such a person's citizenship.

I was going to talk about the importance of the citizenship ceremonies in my electorate and how I enjoy attending them, but I have been asked to speak for only 10 minutes and I will do that, except to make one comment about a matter raised by the honourable member for Chifley (Mr Price). He said that those who swear an oath of allegiance are given a Bible and he recommended that they read it. I endorse that for all those Christians who take out Australian citizenship. However, I am disappointed that we do not do at citizenship ceremonies what we do when we enter this Parliament as new members and have those who take the affirmation and the oath stand side by side. Perhaps the same thing could occur at citizenship ceremonies. Maybe it is for administrative ease that people are put into separate groups, but it seems to me that the problem should be overcome because religion should not be prominent in a citizenship ceremony; the ceremony should demonstrate allegiance and respect for the country these people are adopting. I compliment the Shire of Lillydale, which does not allow its new citizens who affirm their allegiance to go home empty-handed. Without a Bible, the distinction is even more obvious. They are given a book of Australiana showing, for example, Australia's coastline, and even the children are given a book of original Australian stories, such as The Magic Pudding. This is a splendid idea. The distinction between those that affirm and those who swear is blurred even more.

I finally say thank you to the people behind the scenes, particularly Mr George Mohren from the Department of Immigration and Ethnic Affairs, who has been at nearly all the citizenship ceremonies in my electorate to make sure that things go smoothly. Without the people behind the scenes, I am sure that the running of these ceremonies would be far more difficult. I am sure that such people could make suggestions for improvements to ceremonies. I support the Government's efforts to eliminate the problems associated with dual nationality, and I support the Bill.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Webster Mr A.P.

TALK.START.PARA: —I heard a definition of parliament the other day which said that it was a place where a person gets up to speak, says nothing and then everybody disagrees. I do not think that the definition applies to this debate on the Australian Citizenship Amendment Bill 1986. We have heard some very wise words spoken and had many positive speeches, and at the end of the debate I think that there will be a considerable amount of agreement. So the definition I have given is not quite right, at least in this case.

SPEECH.PARA: I wish to direct my remarks on the Australian Citizenship Amendment Bill mainly to clause 11. The other objectives of the Bill-such as clause 7, which seeks to redress the loss of citizenship inadvertently brought about by the 1984 amendments to the Australian Citizenship Act; clause 4, which removes automatic citizenship for children born in Australia by granting citizenship only to those with one parent who is a permanent resident or citizen; clause 8, which fulfils Australia's international obligations to prevent the statelessness of a child born in Australia who is not eligible to acquire Australian citizenship by birth; and the remaining clauses, clauses 5, 6, 10 and 12-are considered reasonable amendments to the Act. Not the least reasonable of the amendments proposed is that to be moved by the shadow Minister for Immigration and Ethnic Affairs, the honourable member for Mitchell (Mr Cadman), to section 23AA in clause 7.

I am much more concerned with the implications and unnecessary amendments in clause 11 to Schedule 2. This part of the Act provides the form for the oath or affirmation of allegiance. It describes the various ways in which those two parts of the ceremony should be carried out. The amendment to Schedule 2, in clause 11, removes the requirements for a person taking the oath or the affirmation to announce his or her name and to renounce all other allegiances. It is that removal that causes me a great deal of concern. I feel strongly that the removal of the requirement upon candidates to state their name in full at the commencement of the oath or affirmation is totally unnecessary and has been done far too hastily. It has diminished the great significance of the whole ceremony. By naming themselves in full at the commencement of the oath or affirmation, great emphasis is given to the candidates' psychology of commitment. By naming themselves, people speak to themselves about what they are doing and they give emphasis to their public commitment. I have attended many citizenship ceremonies over the years, both before and especially since my election as the member for Macquarie. Any confusion over the inclusion of a candidate's name in the ceremony has been absolutely minimal. It has never been complained about by any candidates and has never been brought to my attention by any officiating or administrative personnel. In fact, I confidently feel, on the basis of many observations, that the families and friends of candidates enjoy seeing and hearing candidates include their names in the oath or affirmation. It would appear to me that the Minister for Immigration and Ethnic Affairs (Mr Hurford) has introduced this change without full consultation and evaluation. As a point of interest, I might mention that the greatest confusion occurring at the ceremonies is when families, friends and some candidates witness two ceremonies-one for those taking the oath and another for those giving an affirmation.

I turn now to the deletion of the requirement for people to renounce all other allegiances on becoming a new citizen. There exists in this nation today a dangerous imbalance, favouring individual and minority group rights as against shared responsibilities, civic duties and a commitment to self-restraint and self-sacrifice for others. We seem to have forgotten that the social cohesion and the liberal democratic institutions we enjoy and value are human contrivances, the result of conscious decisions. They are part of our natural assets handed down to us. We face the choice of continuing to preserve and develop these assets or letting them be devalued and subverted by apathy, unbounded self-interests or misguided hostility to patriotism. Only last year we saw evidence of dangerous tensions arising out of our neglect to foster patriotism and allegiance to this great country of ours. Honourable members will recall that a few members of one ethnic community threatened to take political action against the Australian Government when it became clear that joint surveillance facilities in this country were being used to monitor political developments in their former country, developments which were detrimental to our national interests. Shocked by these threats, Mr B. A. Santamaria responded publicly in these terms:
As a first generation Australian of Italian racial origin, my cultural and emotional links with Italy run too deep to be either betrayed or the subject of apology.

Nevertheless, if I am born an Australian, or accept Australian citizenship, the strategic interests of Australia must take precedence over the strategic interests of Italy, Greece-or any other country of origin-and the political viewpoint of that country's government, however much I may happen to sympathise with it.

Nor is it in accord with citizen responsibilities for any ethnic group to threaten electoral disadvantage to any political party, in the political interests of their country of origin, at the expense of the decisions of their country of choice.

Mr Santamaria was quite correct. That attitude to former allegiance and loyalty to this country should be impressed upon all those who would seek to share in the freedom, wealth and security which we enjoy in this beautiful country of ours. Let us be clear that what I am talking about is not some fanatical nationalism but a mature, patriotic spirit. I believe that it is only as individuals learn to appreciate and serve their own country that they can develop a sense of their place and responsibilities in the global community.

I speak of the kind of patriotism which, as Bertrand Russell wrote, emphasises a willingness to die rather than to kill for one's country. I speak of a patriotism which recognises its own limitations, the patriotism of Edith Cavell who, as she was shot in World War I, spoke of a patriotism without hatred or bitterness towards anyone. I speak of patriotism and the need for each of us as citizens to affirm our sole allegiance to this nation, its institutions and its welfare. I speak out of a fear that we are witnessing the dissolution of this country from a united nation, which is bound together by shared values and obligations, into what might be called a group of tribes and self seeking individuals. I appreciate that the renunciation requirement needs clarification and sensitive explanation. I should stress that a legal renunciation does not deny the person's private cultural heritage. Rather, it is a positive step in recognition of the legal requirements and character of Australian identity. The Government was given the choice between clarification and deletion; it chose the easy path of deletion. I believe it was wrong to do so.

The citizenship ceremony is, and should be, a solemn and happy occasion. I am very glad to say that throughout my electorate and in the City of Blue Mountains we have very fine ceremonies. I would like to commend the mayor, Alderman Peter Quirk, for the excellence of the citizenship ceremonies that are conducted in the City of Blue Mountains. Likewise, I commend the Shire President of Hawkesbury, Councillor Geoff Michael, and the President of Oberon Shire, Councillor Armstrong, for the excellence of the ceremonies they conduct. They are of great significance to the people concerned. Also jutting into my electorate is the Shire of Baulkham Hills. I congratulate Councillor Les Shore on the excellent ceremony I attended recently in his council area with the shadow Minister for Immigration and Ethnic Affairs, the honourable member for Mitchell. Also jutting into my electorate is the local council area of Penrith. Again the ceremony conducted by the Mayor, Alderman Brian King, was a very creditable one and I would like to place that on record.

However, I raise one further concern about which I feel greatly perturbed. It would concern me greatly if the Minister were ever to allow citizenship procedures to be delegated to administrative staff to allow citizenship over the counter. I finish by requesting the Minister to clarify his intentions in this regard and urge, as did my colleague the honourable member for Cook (Mr Dobie) last year, that the solemnity and significance of the ceremony be preserved in full as it is at present.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: O'Neil Mr L.R.T.

TALK.START.PARA: —I speak in full support of the Australian Citizenship Amendment Bill 1986. This is an important piece of legislation and it is an important matter. I congratulate those, particularly on this side of the House, who have put such constructive input into this important piece of legislation. It is very important to me because in my electorate of Grey there is great racial diversity within the population and yet it would be the success story of immigration as all races live harmoniously together, working as one to improve the lot of the communities in which they reside. In my home city of Whyalla there are some 64 different nationalities, whilst the city of Port Pirie, which is some 40 kilometres across the Gulf is based on a large Greek and Italian population. They do some very positive work within the community, particularly on a voluntary basis. It is with this background that I feel I can suitably discuss the Australian Citizenship Amendment Bill 1986.

SPEECH.PARA: Australia is a nation of immigrants. We are a multicultural society. We have greatly benefited from the people who have migrated to Australia and who have brought with them a multitude of educational and vocational skills. I feel confident in saying that on the whole the Australian nation lives in peace and harmony. Perhaps this is due to our attitude of mateship. Of course we have not been without our problems along the way. I like to think that our use of derogatory terms has been mainly a result of good natured jest rather than bitterness. Within our society we have many ethnic communities which are willing to share their cultural background with us. The many cultural festivities which are held throughout Australia and in my home State of South Australia-the festival State-are fine examples of this.

Within my electorate of Grey I am proud to be associated with the ethnic communities through the international food and wine fair in Whyalla and the blessing of the fleet at Port Pirie. I have celebrated the Vietnamese New Year, Hogmanay with the Scots and been a guest at various Latin-American evenings and an Indian banquet. I have also experienced many other cultural activities, too numerous to mention, which I have enjoyed immensely including the superb hospitality of the Greek community at Coober Pedy.

The goal of the citizenship program run by the Department of Immigration and Ethnic Affairs is to provide an opportunity for, and to encourage those who are eligible to become Australian citizens, thus enabling them to be fully participating members of the community. Citizenship is the step which makes the settler a full and equal member of the Australian community. It confirms each person's earlier decision to make Australia his or her homeland.

The benefits of citizenship are numerous. Australian citizenship enables one to take part in the affairs of the nation. As an Australian citizen one is entitled, under Australian law, to the same rights bestowed by citizenship that are enjoyed by people born in Australia. One has the right to apply for appointment to any public office or to stand for election as a member of parliament. On this side of the House of Representatives we have many fine examples of people who have obtained that right through citizenship. I will name just a few. We have the honourable member for Hotham (Mr Kent) who is from Yugoslavia, the honourable member for Fowler (Mr Grace) who was originally from Ireland, the honourable member for Calwell (Dr Theophanuos) who migrated from Greece, the honourable member for Hindmarsh (Mr Scott) who is from Scotland and of course you, Mr Deputy Speaker, are from England.

TALK.START.PARA: —And I am from Scotland.

—I think that they are very fine examples. One has the right, as a voter, to help elect Australia's governments as well as the right to apply for an Australian passport and to leave and re-enter Australia without applying for a return endorsement. While overseas one has the right to have protection by Australian diplomatic representatives and eligibility to apply to enlist in the defence forces and for those government jobs for which Australian citizenship is required. These are just some of the benefits that I have had occasion to discuss with many of my constituents. In my electorate of Grey I have weekly inquiries concerning procedures for obtaining citizenship. The procedure is relatively simple once a person has fulfilled the residential criteria. It would be remiss of me if I did not give some praise to the Good Neighbour Council in my electorate as it does a magnificent job in organising people to obtain citizenship.

SPEECH.PARA: The amendments introduced in this Bill will most definitely assist in the simplification of the whole process and the concluding ceremony. I see the amendments as positive evidence that this Hawke Labor Government is progressive in its actions. The Australian Citizenship Amendment Bill 1986 will bring the Australian Citizenship Act of 1948 well into the 1980s by amending some of the sections presently contained in the legislation. The removal of sex-specific language from the Act is a progressive move and shows that this Government is prepared to keep pace with the changing times.

The Australian Citizenship Act 1948, which came into force on 26 January 1949, provides the legal basis for Australian citizenship. The Act governs the ways in which citizenship can be acquired or lost. This Bill makes amendments to section 23aa of the Act concerning the resumption of citizenship. Previous amendments to the Act empowered the Minister to approve resumption of Australian citizenship in certain circumstances. Former Australians who lost their citizenship after 22 November 1984, were able to have it restored in some instances. Following representations to the Minister for Immigration and Ethnic Affairs (Mr Hurford), that the resumption provisions be made retrospective, the Government has agreed that the provisions of section 23aa should be applicable to any former Australian citizen, subject to conditions of a commitment in the form of residential criteria.

These proposed amendments are to be effected by clause 7 of this Bill. Over the past few years an increased number of people have been applying for citizenship. In 1984-85, 107,744 applied. This was a marginal fall from record applications in 1983-84 of 113,810. The fall was due in part to industrial bans in several regional offices in mid-1984-85. During the remainder of that year, the underlying upward trend of recent years continued. I believe the amendments to this Act in 1984, have contributed significantly to increases in the application rate. Those amendments to the Australian Citizenship Act have made it easier for many eligible people to become citizens. Likewise, I believe that the proposed changes we are debating today will further enhance the reasons for applying for Australian citizenship.

Despite the growing awareness of the value of citizenship, the 1981 census showed that over one million residentially eligible permanent residents were not Australian citizens. Although precise figures are not available, the Department estimates that the number of eligible people who have not applied for citizenship has fallen to one million. This is still high. In the past, some eligible candidates have not made application because they did not wish to renounce all other allegiances. Many have been under the impression that, in renouncing all other allegiances, they would have to cut all ties with their former homeland and their cultural background. The amendments to this section of the Act will definitely assist the increase in the number of applications for citizenship by those people who are eligible. Of course, the nationality laws of many countries permit their nationals to have dual citizenship, a fact that many eligible residents are not familiar with.

Clause 11 of the Bill will amend Schedule 2 of the Act to remove the requirement to renounce all other allegiances and the requirement that candidates state their names when taking the oath or making the affirmation of allegiance. A fundamental amendment to section 10 of the Act will limit citizenship by birth only to those persons who, at the time of birth, have at least one parent who is either an Australian citizen or a permanent resident. The effect of this is that children of visitors, temporary entrants and prohibited non-citizens will no longer automatically acquire Australian citizenship simply by reason of their birth in Australia. As we all know, there are good and bad people in all communities in all countries and there are many people who dishonestly play the system.

The amendments to this section of the Act will combat the problem of visitors and illegal immigrants exploiting our generous laws, by having children born in Australia in order to seek to achieve residence. The acceptance of this recommendation by the Human Rights Commission, in accordance with the amendment to this section of the Act to ensure that a child of an illegal immigrant has Australian citizenship, if it would otherwise be stateless, shows the compassionate and generous nature of the progressive Hawke Government. Clause 8 of the Bill will fulfil Australia's international obligations to prevent statelessness.

During the period that I have been the Federal member for Grey, I have had the immense privilege of attending countless citizenship ceremonies throughout the electorate. At each ceremony I have experienced an enormous pride in our great nation. Too often we take this great country and all its grandeur for granted. We truly are the lucky country and all that it takes to remind us of that is to look at the vast number of people who are so earnest to acquire Australian citizenship. We in Australia take democracy for granted but those who have been fortunate to witness the moving ceremony of citizenship can truly start to appreciate the freedom we in Australia so easily enjoy. The joys these new citizens find in their sense of new found freedom are immense. For many the decision to leave their homeland and their extended families to settle in a country that offers them freedom is a truly heart-rending situation. Those emotions often flow freely during citizenship ceremonies, the climax of their journey.

At this juncture I think it is correct to pay tribute to the Mayor of Whyalla, Mrs Aileen Ekblom, for the magnificent way in which she conducts the citizenship ceremonies in that city. She does a magnificent job. I also pay tribute to the Port Lincoln City Council which certainly gives the ceremony the status that it deserves. It gives me great pleasure to support the Bill and I commend it to the House.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Dobie The Hon J.D.M.

TALK.START.PARA: —I enjoyed the remarks made by the honourable member for Macquarie (Mr Webster), a new member in this House, who is doing a great job in representing that area of Sydney. I was pleased to hear him refer to a speech I made in the House last year where I spoke strongly against the information I had received that the Department of Immigration and Ethnic Affairs was recommending that the citizenship ceremonies be taken away from local government. Although I have not had any direct response from the Minister for Immigration and Ethnic Affairs (Mr Hurford) I am aware that he has written to members of his Party saying that this would not be so. As I have listened to this debate and I have heard glowing reports from honourable members on both sides of the House on the standards of citizenship ceremonies throughout the country, I am pleased to see that this furphy has been laid to rest firmly by this debate.

SPEECH.PARA: It is not my intention to talk on all aspects of the Australian Citizenship Amendment Bill which is before the House. This has been a long debate and previous speakers, especially those on my side of the House, have given a good coverage of the issues and have put forward the need for amendments to the Bill before us.

As I am one of a small number of members in this House who were not born in Australia, my recent personal experiences reveal the need for legislation in the area of citizenship to be precise, carefully considered and drafted. I believe that parts of the Bill dealing with the removal of the renunciation of former allegiances have not been properly considered. Certainly the Minister has not made a sufficient case in his second reading speech to warrant the exclusion of the renunciation clause. I shall address myself to this question later in my speech.

Following the 1984 amendments to the Australian Citizenship Act and the issuing of passports, I point out to the House an anomaly in that Act which I had to overcome and which I will be relating to this Bill. Having arrived in Australia at the age of seven months in 1928-honourable members can do their mathematics afterwards-I was not required to go through any citizenship ceremony when I was issued with my first passport in 1953, nor was I required to do so when I was issued with my first official passport as a member of this Parliament in 1966. Nor was I required to do so when I was issued with my diplomatic passport as a member of the Executive Council in 1971.

An ordinary passport was issued in 1973 which was surrendered when, once more, I was issued with an official passport in 1976. However, upon the passing of the 1984 Act, despite some 32 years of holding an Australian passport, it was not possible for me to have my current official passport renewed, nor could I be issued with a new official passport unless I produced a declaratory statement of citizenship which had to be signed by someone who had known me to have been a resident of Australia between 1944 and 1949. This was duly done and the official passport duly issued.

The point I make is not whether or not one should have made a declaratory statement of citizenship. The point I make is that when this Bill came to the House no mention or suggestion of this requirement was made by the former Labor Minister for Immigration and Ethnic Affairs. I will not take that up the House's time with further details, but I have made these remarks to emphasise strongly my concern for the amending Bill now before us, when the Minister talks quite superficially about the removal of the renunciation clause in the oath or affirmation of allegiance. I regret to say that I cannot accept the glib assertion he makes in his second reading speech that renunciation is `ambiguous and unnecessary'. In going on further, the Minister says:
In many cases renunciation does not affect the previous nationality or citizenship of candidates because the nationality laws of many countries-
many countries, not all countries-
permit their nationals to have more than one citizenship.

The Minister should have spelt out quite clearly to the House which countries do and which countries do not permit dual citizenship. More importantly, he should have informed the Parliament of countries which require a legal renunciation of the previous citizenship.

We have had a lot of talk today about the rights and wrongs of dual citizenship, but nowhere have we heard from the Government side any mention of the countries from which we have citizens coming to Australia that require a legal renunciation. This is an amazing gap in this Bill. For example, until January 1985 the Netherlands Government required an adult renunciation of Netherlands citizenship. Until that time, although Dutch-born Australian citizens received Australian citizenship as children on the citizenship certificates of their parents, they were still recognised as being subject to the requirements of the laws of the Netherlands. In this situation, we had the Australian law changed some 15 years ago so that such disadvantaged Australian citizens of Dutch birth, as adults, could renounce and instantly renew their Australian citizenship to conform to the laws of the country of their birth. Again, I have taken the time of the House to illustrate how complex this seemingly simple amendment to the oath of allegiance is. I look forward to the Minister's comment on these vital matters when he makes his speech or whoever makes the speech on his behalf at the end of this debate.

Of course, the whole area of dual citizenship and particularly Australia's situation against an international backdrop needs to be investigated. I must say I was pleased to read in a news magazine recently that the Minister had asked his Department to prepare a study on the general question of dual citizenship. I hope this is the case and that the matter is being considered with due care and attention to detail as it affects each and every country whose former citizens are seeking Australian citizenship.

The Government's proposal to again play around with the oath or affirmation of allegiance is a nonsense. I would have hoped that the Government would have learned following its experience in 1984 when, without any public mandate and I believe against the wishes of the vast majority of Australians, the Government attempted to withdraw from the oath and affirmation the declaration of allegiance to Her Majesty Queen Elizabeth, Queen of Australia. The Government was soundly defeated by the Opposition and public reaction on that occasion. I am sure the Australian public has not yet forgiven or forgotten that surreptitious attempt by the Labor Government to lead this country down a path to republicanism.

While on the oath or affirmation of allegiance I have some doubts on the claims being made by the Minister about the need to simplify the procedure by removing the need to declare one's name. On a personal basis and on balance I do not object to this amendment. I might say there are many colleagues on this side of the House who do not share my view. But, I and all my colleagues on this side of the House remain very concerned about the proposed move to do away with the renunciation of all other allegiances from the oath or affirmation and the repercussions that such a move would have.

I had planned to talk on the recent deliberations in the High Court on a Tongan couple whose daughter was born in Australia while they had overstayed their temporary entry permits. However, time does not permit me to have such a discussion. Suffice it for me to say that it is pleasing to note that there is bipartisan support for those sections of the amendment Bill before us, having regard to the Tongan case before the High Court, which deals with what has been a vexed deportation procedure.

However, I am a little concerned by some other areas of this amendment Bill which are too non-specific and open to interpretation, and thus need some clarification. I refer, for example, to clause 5 of this Bill suggesting amendment to section 13 of the principal Act by inclusion of sub-section (1A), which reads:
The Minister shall not grant a certificate of Australian citizenship to a person under sub-section (1) at a time when the person is not present in Australia unless-
(a) the person is a permanent resident; and
(b) the Minister considers that the person is engaged in activities outside Australia that are beneficial to the interests of Australia.

I wonder what the Minister considers to be activities `beneficial to the interests of Australia'. Perhaps the Minister, even if not at the end of this debate, would care to advise Opposition members as to what he means by this. Perhaps he could sum up and expand the matter later. It certainly needs clarification.

Likewise in clause 7 of the Bill, which repeals existing section 23AA and replaces it with a new 23AA, it is proposed that a person who has inadvertently lost his Australian citizenship must make a written submission to the Minister for consideration to have his citizenship restored. In that written statement the person must show that he or she `has maintained a close and continuing association with Australia'. Again, I ask the absent Minister: What constitutes `a close and continuing association with Australia'? Does this mean a person must have active business and property interests here, or is it simply good enough to show proof that he or she has written home to mum every three months? I think it is important to state plainly how the proposed legislative changes will be applied and what criteria the Minister would use to judge individual cases. We members of this House, on both sides, must have this information so that we may more effectively advise our constituents when they come in to see us, irrespective of party. At this stage I had planned to turn to clause 7 and the proposed changes to section 23AA. However, in view of time I shall leave that discussion to the Committee stage.

Contrary to several comments made by back benchers in the Government who have spoken on this Bill, the Opposition does want a bipartisan approach to matters relating to immigration and subsequent citizenship. Cheap points of debate that have been made by them through this debate do not encourage bipartisanship. Certainly all of us in this House have similar problems placed before us by our constituents who seek reunion with members of their family and family friends. All of us here must face the future with bipartisan goodwill towards migration from what will become a greatly changed geographical source of migration to Australia. Our proximity to Asia, Africa and South America demands a bipartisan sensitivity of approach to a change which could well match the dramatic change in the source of permanent residents to Australia following World War II. Already such a change is taking place, but all members of this Parliament, and our constituents, will need to realise that traditional sources of migration will be down numerically and that new sources will become more significant. It means that debate in this House on migration and citizenship will have to be held without some of the smart-Alick comments that some members of the Government have resorted to in this debate.

In conclusion, I would like to pay my tribute to the Minister, who has shown a real compassion on those matters I have placed before him when all other administrative appeals have been fruitless. I would also pay a tribute to the many departmental officers, both in Sydney and in Canberra, who, over the past 19 years, have been as professional and considerate as the Act has allowed them to be in all matters put before them. It should be noted that in my experience, however, not all overseas posts have shown the same objectivity when asked to reconsider unfavourable decisions they have made. Perhaps then the next series of amendments, brought forward after further consideration, will bring about a change in the capacity of members of this Parliament to take a far stronger role when applications for permanent residency have been declined by officers based overseas.

I was going to talk at length about some of the anomalies that still exist in our Citizenship Act. The 1984 amendments changed the Act with regard to the requirements in respect of people who serve in this Parliament. Up to 1984 one did not have to be an Australian citizen to be a member of this Parliament. But even in the 1984 amendment Act still no mention was made of this fact in the Parliament. So talking this through with the nonsense I had to go through last year in making a statutory declaration of citizenship to get a renewal of an official passport I had held for 19 years, one wonders what should really have happened with regard to my membership of this House, having served here since 1966.

TALK.START.PARA: —Refund the money!

—That was an inane interjection. I mention these things not for any sense of recording details in the Parliament, but to emphasise to the Minister and to his advisers who sit in the House that an amendment Bill such as they have brought forward on this occasion with regard to permanent residency and citizenship cannot be allowed to be as inexact and as carelessly worded as this amending Bill has been. It is far too significant for the people who are taking citizenship to have such broad and bland comments made about things such as renunciation. I suspect that in some of the other sections of the Bill upon which I have decided not to talk tonight, there was an equal problem when it comes down to the likes of all of us in this House, on both sides, trying to interpret for our constituents what the changes really mean.

SPEECH.PARA: I wish the Minister well. I wish I knew where he was. I hope he is made aware of what has been said in the House today. I know that it would have to be something serious to keep him away, but I am still disappointed that he has not been present to hear the individual debate, because, with all the goodwill in the world, the departmental officers who have been following this and the Ministers who have been sitting at the table have not got the capacity, because of their other interests, to fully relate this to the Minister. So, I think, in all, the bringing in of this amendment Bill has not been a crowing success for this Government.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Fitzgibbon Mr E.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —Anyone who has served in local government and then progressed to be a mayor or a shire president is well aware that the Australian Citizenship Act needs amending. We are talking about a bipartisan approach here, and the speakers have all said `Yes, sure enough, we all know that the Act needs amending and we will take a bipartisan approach'. For years the very amendments included in the Australian Citizenship Amendment Bill have been discussed throughout Australia by reputable committees which have examined all the anomalies in the existing Act. It was some years ago, as a mayor, that I attended a meeting in Sydney on citizenship and multiculturalism. That was in the days of the Fraser Government. So we all know that the Act needs amending. We have improvements in this Bill. We all accept that they are improvements, and yet there are some of us who are prepared to nit-pick about some of the details contained in this Bill.

SPEECH.PARA: As outlined in the second reading speech of the Minister for Immigration and Ethnic Affairs (Mr Hurford), Australia is one of the few remaining countries which confer citizenship automatically upon a child born in the country. There are a couple of exceptions, of course. There is no doubt that this fact has been exploited in the past by visitors and illegal immigrants. In fact, the 1985 report of the House of Representatives Standing Committee on Expenditure entitled `Who calls Australia Home?' stated that during its review the Committee became aware of the way that Australian citizenship provisions were being used by some prohibited non-citizens. Cases have arisen of prohibited non-citizens giving birth to a child while they were in Australia and, as a result of the operation of the Australian Citizenship Act 1948, that child has become an Australian citizen.

When these cases come to light, always in a blaze of emotive publicity, the parents argue that they should not be deported because their deportation would infringe the human rights of their Australian-born child. The Committee stated that a legislative measure which it considered would provide that any child born to a person entering Australia on a temporary basis or who was here illegally would not become an Australian citizen unless the child would otherwise be stateless. The Committee went on to say that, by removing the automatic right to citizenship which currently exists for residents and prohibited non-citizens, another incentive for people to queue-jump would be removed. The Committee recommended that children born in Australia to temporary residents, to the proposed tourist-visitor category and to prohibited non-citizens, should not become Australian citizens unless they would otherwise be stateless.

The Human Rights Commission reported on two cases where the parents challenged deportation orders on the basis that their children were Australian-born. In the first case, a Mr and Mrs Au Yeung came to Australia on 15 August 1982 on tourist visas and Mrs Au Yeung gave birth to a son, whose birth was notified to the Registrar of Births, Deaths and Marriages in Sydney. As a result of the operation of section 10 of the Australian Citizenship Act 1948, the child became an Australian citizen by birth. When the Department of Immigration and Ethnic Affairs eventually caught up with the Au Yeungs because they had stayed in Australia after their visas had expired, they became illegal immigrants and deportation orders were issued. Mr and Mrs Au Yeung took legal advice and complained, under the Human Rights Commission Act 1981, that their threatened deportation was inconsistent with, or contrary to, human rights.

The Au Yeung family left Australia in September 1984 and, in its findings and recommendations, the Human Rights Commission, among other things, recommended that consideration be given to the question whether Australia's international obligations in the field of human rights require it automatically to grant citizenship to children of non-citizens born in Australia. Whilst it said that the human rights of Australian citizens must invariably be observed, it questioned the necessity for the children of prohibited non-citizens to become Australian citizens merely because they are born in Australia. The Commission further stated that it may be fairer in the long run to change the rule that birth in Australia automatically results in Australian citizenship, provided that otherwise stateless children born in Australia are granted Australian citizenship.

The second case reviewed by the Human Rights Commission concerned the Yilmaz family, who came to Australia on 24 March 1981 on temporary entry permits. They overstayed and became prohibited non-citizens under section 7 of the Migration Act 1958. Mr Yilmaz obtained employment, paid taxes and clearly had the intention of staying in Australia. Two children were born to the Yilmazes and, again, both births were registered with appropriate State registration authorities. As a result of the operation of section 10 of the Australian Citizenship Act 1948, both children became Australian citizens as a result of their birth in Australia. When the Department of Immigration and Ethnic Affairs issued deportation orders against the Yilmaz family, an appeal was made to the Human Rights Commission on the ground that their threatened deportation was contrary to and inconsistent with human rights. However, they eventually left Australia on 22 December 1984 to avoid deportation.

Again, the findings and recommendations of the Human Rights Commission stated that, whilst the human rights of Australian citizens must invariably be observed, nothing in the International Covenant on Civil and Political Rights or the Declaration of the Rights of the Child requires the children of prohibited non-citizens to become Australian citizens merely because they are born in Australia. As in the case of the Au Yeung family, the Commission said that it may be fairer in the long run to change the rule that birth in Australia automatically results in Australian citizenship for the children of prohibited non-citizens. These are only two particular cases. There have been many, and there can be no doubt that the parents of such children see this as a way of staying in Australia.

Despite the fact that we have in place an excellent immigration program, Australia is faced with ever-increasing numbers of illegal immigrants. These illegal immigrants are threatening the integrity of our migration program. They are occupying jobs needed by unemployed Australians and taxing government resources. Almost half of all detected illegal immigrants and visitors have drawn on health, social security, education and other government services. I was concerned to read in the Department of Immigration and Ethnic Affairs review of activities to 30 June 1985 that the nature of the Department's enforcement work against illegal immigration has changed dramatically, as has the management task facing the Department.

In the past, few illegal immigrants challenged deportation orders or directions that they leave Australia. Now, however, some form of challenge-often a series of sequential or simultaneous actions-is usual. The Au Yeung and Yilmaz cases are classic examples. Not infrequently, this action must proceed under the glare of media attention to which the Department cannot respond without running the risk of breaching personal privacy or being in contempt of court. These processes are expensive for the Department, in terms of both the staff time they tie up and the overall legal costs to the Commonwealth. The proposed amendment to exclude children of temporary visitors and illegal immigrants, except where they would otherwise be stateless, will remove a big incentive for those people. They will be deterred from jumping the queue ahead of immigrants who go through the regular channels and come to our shores legally.

The second significant amendment relates to the oath or affirmation of allegiance and removes the requirements for persons taking such oath or affirmation to announce their name and renounce all other allegiances. The requirement to state one's name created confusion and is unnecessary because candidates have already been identified and will be identified again when called to receive their Australian citizenship certificates.

The requirement for candidates for Australian citizenship to renounce all other allegiances is ambiguous and unnecessary. It leads some candidates to believe that they are required to renounce not only other allegiances but also their cultural background and all other ties with their country of origin. Anybody who knows anything about immigration and who speaks to some of the wonderful people who have come to this country will realise that that is a heartrending exercise. Other Commonwealth candidates find it confusing to renounce allegiance to the Queen, as the Queen of Australia is also the head of state in their country of origin. If this is not a farcical situation, perhaps the honourable member for Denison (Mr Hodgman) can try to come up with one that is.

The other significant change proposed by this Bill relates to the resumption of Australian citizenship under the provisions of section 23AA of the Act. As outlined in the Minister's second reading speech, when the Act was last amended it empowered the Minister to approve resumption of Australian citizenship in certain circumstances. Former Australians who lost their citizenship after 22 November 1984 by acquiring the citizenship of another country under some form of compulsion, economic necessity or without realising the consequences of their actions were able to have it restored.

Because of representations made to the Minister by former Australian citizens who lost their citizenship prior to 22 November 1984 and requested that the resumption provisions be made retrospective the Government has agreed that the provisions of section 23AA should be applicable to any former Australian citizen, subject to the condition that the person concerned should demonstrate a commitment to Australia. That commitment would be based on the applicant having had two years lawful residence in Australia, at any time, and satisfying the Minister that he or she intends to return to Australia within three years to live permanently. The proposed amendment will also allow a child who had lost its citizenship to resume it with its parent. This amendment will have an impact, especially on Australian citizens who, for example, may have gone to Israel, automatically acquired Israeli citizenship and lost their Australian citizenship. They will now be able to resume their Australian citizenship.

The amendments in this Bill have been well thought out. I am glad that some Opposition members are prepared to adopt a bipartisan approach towards them. I hope that we have less nitpicking from the following speakers in this debate. I congratulate the Minister for Immigration and Ethnic Affairs and commend the Bill to the House.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Hodgman The Hon W.M.

TALK.START.PARA: —Some 2,000 years ago the proudest boast in the civilised world was `Civis Romanus sum'-`I am a citizen of Rome'. Twenty-five years ago, the then President of the United States of America, J. F. Kennedy, summed up the thoughts and aspirations of millions in the West committed to the cause of freedom by standing in front of a mass of people and uttering the words: `Ich bin ein Berliner', thereby associating millions and millions of fellow human beings with the cause of a people and of a city besieged-a city which was a bastion for the cause of justice and peace. I put it to members of this House today and to thousands of my fellow Australians listening to this broadcast while driving home to ask themselves whether there is a prouder boast any of us could make than to say: `I am an Australian citizen'.

SPEECH.PARA: This is the greatest country in the world. It is a country of potential without limit. There is nothing that Australia cannot achieve if only we Australians make up our minds that we will achieve it. I take pride and pleasure in attending, on many occasions, citizenship ceremonies. I did this as a Minister in the former Government. I did it as shadow Minister for Immigration. I have done it as the member for Denison. I point out the fundamental truth that all citizens of Australia are equal, whether they were born here, whether they are fifth or sixth generation Australians or whether they came to this country as their chosen home. Citizenship is universal, it is equal and it is fundamental that we are one equal with the other. There can be no prouder boast than `I am an Australian citizen'.

My colleague and friend, the honourable member for Mitchell (Mr Cadman), the shadow Minister for Immigration and Ethnic Affairs in Her Majesty's loyal Opposition, commenced his speech on this Bill with words which I dare to repeat because he put it so well. He said: `Any change to the Australian Citizenship Act immediately arouses interest within the Parliament and within the community because citizenship deals with the character, identity, political and legal status of all Australians'. I add one further word. When I see changes to the Australian Citizenship Act brought into this Parliament by the Hawke socialist Government, it not only arouses my interest, it arouses my suspicion. I am saddened to say that once again my suspicions and worst fears have come to light because it is in one area above all that we see once again the nibbling of the republican mice on the oath of allegiance and the affirmation of allegiance. It is like cheese to the mice or cheese to the rats-they cannot keep away from it. What appals me-I note that we have the presence of two distinguished Ministers of the Hawke socialist Government in the chamber right now-is that the thing was got right, if I can put it that way, by former Prime Minister Whitlam back in 1974 to the satisfaction of all Australians when the oath of allegiance was settled, encompassing, as it did, in this fundamental oath the views of people as diverse as great Australians like Curtin, Chifley, Menzies, Holt and Fraser. Whitlam got it right in 1974 but since the Hawke socialist Government got into power in 1983 we have seen attempt after attempt to nibble away at the oath of allegiance.

What is this oath of allegiance? What does it mean? What does it represent? The oath of allegiance is set out in the Australian citizenship Act 1974, brought in when Mr Whitlam was Prime Minister and supported then by Her Majesty's loyal Opposition. In both Houses of Parliament there was unanimous support. The oath states: `I'-then you add your name-`William Michael Hodgman, renouncing all other allegiance, swear by Almighty God that I will be faithful and bear true allegiance to Her Majesty, Elizabeth the Second, Queen of Australia, Her heirs and successors according to law, and that I will faithfully observe the laws of Australia and fulfil my duties as an Australian citizen'. It is a beautiful oath-an oath which has been taken by thousands upon thousands of persons who have come to this country and sought the richest thing this country could give them-Australian citizenship. What did we find in 1983? The Hawke socialist republican Government, without the consent of the people of Australia, moved surreptitiously to slip through this Parliament an amendment to the oath of allegiance to remove all reference to Her Majesty the Queen and to take it out of the affirmation of allegiance.

There were some in the Government who were bitterly disappointed that they could not also remove God from the oath of allegiance. I kid honourable members not when I say that that was a proposal which was seriously considered by the Hawke socialist Government. It thought: `We are going to take out the Queen, we might as well remove God as well'. An ever vigilant Opposition in this Parliament took up the fight and the people of Australia rallied to the cause in numbers I have never seen in 20 years in politics. We came into this Parliament and, although the Hawke socialist Government had the numbers, we had the courage and the commitment, and we moved an amendment which the House should have passed-that is not a reflection on you, Mr Deputy Speaker-which condemned the Hawke socialist Government. We condemned it for; firstly, its shameful and disgraceful action in seeking to remove Her Majesty the Queen from the oath of allegiance and the affirmation of allegiance, against the wishes of the overwhelming majority of Australians, without having first put such an important amendment to the people of Australia at a referendum; secondly, its deliberate devaluation of the importance of the honour of Australian citizenship; and thirdly, its overall failure to consult properly with the people of Australia before bringing into this Parliament such radical republican legislative proposals.

Has history repeated itself? I need only refer the Parliament and the people to the speech of the shadow Minister. What have we got here? Has there been consultation with the wider community? No. The Government does not seem to learn. Is it moving to devalue the importance of Australian citizenship? Sadly, it is. Mr Deputy Speaker, you are one of the most respected members of this House and it is my honour to sit with you on one of the committees of this Parliament. Have you ever heard such nonsense as that it is confusing and difficult for someone to state his or her name at the commencement of an oath? Have you ever heard such poppycock?

I suppose it has come about because in some less advanced parts of the country at citizenship ceremonies some genius gets everybody to state their names all at once before they administer the oath of allegiance. I would have thought that on a matter as important as the oath of allegiance that the rest of Australia would follow the lead of the Right Hon. the Lord Mayor of Hobart and his Worship the Mayor of Glenorchy because when they conduct citizenship ceremonies-I have attended many-those about to receive citizenship are lined up and, as the Lord Mayor looks at each one, they give their names. They do not all do it at once. It is very simple. They say `John Brown' or `Angelo Mariani'-they all give their names, they all identify themselves and then the oath is administered in unison. It is a simple procedure.

The Minister for Immigration and Ethnic Affairs (Mr Hurford), however, against whom I have no malice-he is quite a pleasant, jovial and nice person-has come in here and said that it is unnecessary for people to identify themselves. How would one get on in a prosecution for perjury or when making a false statutory declar- ation if the person has not said who he is. It could be Santa Claus. This is the sort of gobbledegook that has been put in front of us. I ask honourable members to listen to this: Candidates for the grant of citizenship are required to repeat the word `I' and then state their name before renouncing their former allegiance and taking the oath or making the affirmation of allegiance. This is unnecessary, says the Minister, because the candidates have already been identified and will be identified again when called on to receive their certificates. Neither of those procedures amounts to the taking of an oath. One can fill in 150 forms in the Department of Immigration and Ethnic Affairs but that does not amount to the taking of an oath. People should say who they are.

I have never seen a more pathetic argument put forward as to why people should not say what their name is when they take an oath. My word, I would like to see the fun and games we would have-Mr Deputy Speaker, I have often thought you are very judicial by nature-if you were sitting on the bench in the Supreme Court in Queensland saying to somebody: `All right, come along, we will hear your evidence but you do not have to tell us your name'. This is a public declaration that a person is going to become an Australian citizen. I have to say quite bluntly that the arguments put up are fatuous. This is not a fatuous government; it is a cunning, deceitful and, I might say, untrustworthy government. It does not do things by accident. Once the name is taken out of the oath of allegiance, the oath is devalued, and I am dead against the removal of it, with all due respect to another honourable colleague who spoke a moment ago and who said that it did not matter very much to him.

Now we come to the gravamen. The Government is going to take away the renunciation of all other allegiance. If one goes back to the statute of Edward III one will find that it is part of the tradition of the common law, part of the tradition of the constitutional monarchy and parliamentary democracy, which is what Australia is, that a person can have allegiance to only one country. There are problems with dual nationality. Every time those words are mentioned I think of our Baltic friends and what they go through. The plain fact is that allegiance is part of the tradition of our heritage. Mr Deputy Speaker, do you know that it was treason centuries ago-one did not have to act-to think or compass a treasonable intent? It was a heinous crime punishable by death.

Renunciation is a renunciation of former allegiance. It has never been argued by anybody to whom I have spoken that it means that one renounces one's heritage, background and memories. The situation has never been what the Minister and the honourable member for Hunter (Mr Fitzgibbon), who has just resumed his seat, said, that is, that there was confusion amongst Commonwealth citizens that they might be renouncing allegiance to one queen and then to another. This is sheer, unadulterated poppycock. I have a suspicious mind about the republican commitment of this Government. We have a Prime Minister who is a self-confessed republican. He backs from it now but when he delivered the Boyer lectures on Australian Broadcasting Corporation radio he set down clearly and squarely that Australia would move towards a republic.

TALK.START.PARA: —What about the flag?

—Of course, the flag. How proud we are of my colleague. If everybody in the National Party were as good as the honourable member for Gippsland this country would really be getting on its feet. Why will the Prime Minister (Mr Hawke) not tell the Parliament the truth and say: `There will be no change to the Australian flag except following a referendum'? Yesterday he said in a wishy-washy way that it was not high on his list of priorities.
—At this point I remind the honourable member for Denison that the legislation before the House does not relate to the Australian flag. He may like to come back to the Bill.

—Mr Deputy Speaker, your counsel is wise. I readily heed it. It is just that every time I think of citizenship I think of how those opposite want to tear up the flag and turn this country into a republic. I think of every mean, miserable little thought in their minuscule socialist republican minds as evidenced by the sort of claptrap in this Bill.

SPEECH.PARA: I come back to the matter of renunciation. The Government did not come clean on that and tell us exactly what the people said when they were asked. The impression we got from Government speakers was that there is general consensus-that foul word, the lowest common denominator of everything is consensus. There is no excellence, no achievement, no pursuit of the best. A line is just drawn and the lowest common denominator is taken. That is why this country drops back when it should be striding forward. We have a suggestion of consensus. The suggestion that came out of national consultation on a bipartisan basis in the time that we were in office was that it needed clarification. I agree. It is clarified by explaining that it does not involve renouncing one's heritage, cultural background and memories. I have still to find one person who said he thought that that was what he was giving up.

In the extraordinary situation of bipartisan co-operation to get through the second reading stage I will bring my remarks to a conclusion. I bear the Minister no malice. In passing, I simply say that he is doing a better job. I stand before this House as a shadow Minister for Immigration who was vilified in 1984 and vindicated in 1986. I believe in this country, its citizenship, its traditions, its rights and privileges. This Government would serve better the Australian people if it stopped coming back like a rat to the cheese, nibbling away at the oath of allegiance. The Government, tragically, has the numbers to get the legislation through this place but I trust in the judgment of the majority of members of another place to ensure that for the second time its attempts to nibble at, alter and devalue the oath of allegiance will be thrown out. The majority of Australians will be delighted to see those opposite get it in the neck once more.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Staples Mr P.R.

TALK.START.PARA: —How does one follow an act like that? That is what it was. It was just an act. Parliament has often been described as the theatre of the absurd. We have just seen a fantastic example of absurdity here. The amendments to the Australian Citizenship Act presented by the Australian Citizenship Amendment Bill 1986 are further illustrations of this Hawke Labor Government's commitment to the understanding of Australia as the world's most multicultural nation. Our approaching bicentenary of European settlement should make us more aware than ever before of the role played by immigration in our development; whether they be immigrants who came in the First Fleet, Asians, the many Chinese and others who came to our goldfields, Pacific Islanders whom we brought here virtually as slaves for our canefields, the arrivals from Europe or the refugees from wars and persecutions around the world over the last 200 years.

SPEECH.PARA: Australia has developed into what it is today largely because people from other lands have brought themselves, their families, language, food, customs, skills and culture to this continent. Last year, people from approximately 120 nations took up Australian citizenship. Many of us would be hard-pressed to write a list of 120 nations, yet people from these diverse cultures live, work and play peacefully side by side in this country. Probably the greatest sadness is that the original inhabitants, our Aboriginal people, have been the least well-treated Australian citizens. It should be a sobering reflection for the rednecks and the red faces in this House and in our community to reflect upon the high esteem, place and privilege in which Aboriginal people should be held in this society, as its original inhabitants. It should also be a sobering reflection to note that, without their culture, language and links with this land which were forged and welded over unimaginable thousands of years, our culture and our image as Australians and Australia would be a thin veneer of crass suburban amorphism.

Therefore, because of our background before European settlement and the events of the last 200 years, Australia's citizenship laws should reflect the widest possible allowances and openness within practice and reason. The amendments to this legislation develop this direction, started under the Whitlam Government and now further carried on under this Hawke Labor Government. It is valuable within the context of this debate to reflect that, under this Government, the residential eligibility period has been reduced from three to two years after a reduction from five to three years under the Whitlam Government. Furthermore, the new basic English language requirement has had an immediate impact upon the number of people applying and being granted Australian citizenship. Annually about 3,800 applications were refused citizenship in latter years on language grounds. With the relaxation to a basic English language requirement, this number has fallen to about 200. That is very welcome.

I make these points because it is in the full context of the Australian Citizenship Act and its more recent amendments under this Government that these amendments proposed today should be judged, although they are quite capable of standing alone. Because of the large number of people who want to migrate to Australia, there are always those who seek citizenship by bending the spirit, if not letter of the law, quite often to the detriment of those who do the right thing all the way through the process of gaining permanent residency and citizenship.

In order to give everyone a fair go, the Government now feels it is necessary to remove the provision for people to be able to claim permanent residency and citizenship on the basis of the birth of their child in Australia. Australia is one of only seven countries in the world, where children born in those countries automatically acquire citizenship of the country even though the parents are only temporary residents. The other countries are the United States of America, New Zealand, Argentina, Fiji, Malaysia and Canada. This technique which has been employed by many people over the years to gain Australian residency and citizenship is, unfortunately, now becoming quite a common lurk. In earlier years, the average was approximately 3,000 cases per annum. In 1982-83, this had risen dramatically to 5,025. In 1983-84, it had further increased to 7,422 people who were seeking to gain Australian citizenship in this back-door way. Obviously this loophole cannot be allowed to continue. It only results in costly administrative processes often accompanied by litigation and sensationalist media attention.

In fact it is interesting to note that the Human Rights Commission in its reports Nos 10 and 15 recommend that the Act be amended to make sure that such children should not acquire citizenship by birth unless this would render them stateless. Other members, principally the honourable member for Moore (Mr Blanchard) and the honourable member for Perth (Dr Charlesworth), have, as usual, very competently addressed this point. So I will not linger any longer on this.

I turn now to the clause relating to the requirement for citizenship candidates to state their name at the beginning of the oath or affirmation, which is the case at present. Anyone who has attended citizenship ceremonies-everyone in this House certainly will have done so on many occasions-will have noted the confusion that often surfaces in these ceremonies. It is to be expected. There is a high degree of nervousness among the people who are taking out Australian citizenship. It is a very significant event. It is often difficult for people to understand the proceedings. It is not the sort of thing that one takes part in every second day of one's life. A citizenship ceremony is a very moving occasion and should be enjoyed by all. It should be meaningful to all and its great significance should not be demeaned by problems that surface in the way in which people have to state their name in full within that oath or affirmation.

It is okay for people who understand well the English language, our culture and the way that we do things-for example, if one is of Anglo-Saxon background and comes as a migrant from the British Isles or another English speaking country. For many, that is not the case. How many people in this House have been to a citizenship ceremony and effectively heard the people being sworn in as citizens with the name of `State your name in full'? What happens is that the Town Clerk asks them to say `I' and then says: `State your name in full'. In the confusion and rush and so on, the people often just say the words `State your name in full'. It is very sad.

The national consultations in 1982 and the report of the Human Rights Commission supported either the clarification of the phrase or its deletion altogether. This Government, for very good reason, believes that it should be deleted. It adds no great significance to the ceremony to leave it there; in fact, it demeans it. Obviously, there is no confusion about who is the new citizen; that has been covered. But the removal of this requirement dignifies the ceremony and enhances it for all concerned. I have spoken to many local government officers and elected councillors and they agree with what the Government is doing. I believe that those opposite should also agree and seek to remove it.

At this stage I commend the Preston City Council, the Heidelberg City Council and the shires of Diamond Valley and Whittlesea for the way in which they conduct their ceremonies in trying to make them as meaningful and significant as possible within the confines of the present ceremony. I am sure that with these changes ceremonies will be enhanced. Except for those opposite, who wish to make Australian citizenship as difficult to attain as possible, most reasonable people will certainly welcome this amendment.

Related to this amendment in clause 11 is another alteration to the oath or affirmation of allegiance. The present form of the oath or affirmation requires a candidate to renounce all other allegiances. As has been pointed out very well by speakers before me on the Government side, especially the honourable member for Grey (Mr O'Neil) and the honourable member for La Trobe (Mr Milton), this requirement is confusing and distressing for a prospective citizen. It has no basis of protection from his former allegiance or citizenship in most cases and it cannot be enforced or directed simply by the uttering of those words within our citizenship oath or affirmation.
In fact a booklet put out by the Australian Department of Foreign Affairs entitled `Hints for Australian travellers' at page 10 gives Australian citizens the following warning:

Each country is free to determine who it will regard as its citizens and under what conditions its citizenship can be acquired or lost. These laws are often complex and they can be quite different from Australian laws.

In many countries, for example, citizenship is not considered to be lost simply because a person has acquired Australian citizenship. The laws of some countries require people who wish to renounce their citizenship to make formal written applications to do so.

Such laws mean that citizenship cannot just be renounced in a ceremony in a form of words, but that people have to make written application to do so. The consequences if they do not do that can be quite severe. But the people opposite do not worry about that. They think that it can be done just by a form of words and that that will protect those people. But it does not. The booklet also states:
Because of such laws many Australian citizens are also citizens of other countries and, therefore, possess what is internationally referred to as `dual nationality'.
It continues:

It is wise to check whether you are a dual national before leaving Australia and if so whether you are subject to particular laws or regulations when in the country of your other citizenship, such as liability for military service and for offences under its law committed outside that country. You could also be required to obtain an exit permit before being allowed to leave that country.
Even if you do not accept the claim of another country that you are its citizen, the authorities there may treat you as one.

If you possess the nationality of an Eastern European country you should know that some of those countries have mutual extradition agreements under which a visitor may be arrested in one country and transported to another (of which he or she is considered a citizen) to face outstanding charges (such as an earlier unauthorised departure from that country).

That is what those opposite will expose our new citizens to by their pedantic insistence on these words in the current oath or affirmation. That basically sums it up. If one is born in Australia, like most of us here, or even Britain, it is generally not a problem. But for others it is not as easy. It can dramatically affect the lives of people who are Australia citizens. The inclusion of the renunciation of all other allegiance leaves some people with the impression that perhaps they must give up their culture, language and all that they have brought with them in their natural identity and the spirit of their birth land. Obviously, this is reprehensible in a multicultural society such as ours.

But those citizens who leave Australia on a trip or whatever can be lulled into a potentially dangerous situation because the renunciation provision in our oath is not recognised. For anyone to oppose these amendments is pure cultural arrogance, but we see that continually in this House from honourable members opposite. We have seen it on the issues of land rights and of Aborigines in general. We have seen the orchestrated racist attacks of the Opposition during that black time in Australia's history of the Blainey Asian immigration debate. Today we have seen it especially from the honourable member for Petrie (Mr Hodges) with his low assertions against the credentials and rights of Central and South American migrants. The honourable member for Petrie exposed today his own political prejudices and those of his Party. His lack of bipartisanship on migration policy in his labelling of people from one particular area as left wing and undesirable is quite disgusting. By statements such as his today, and reflected by others in this House in other ways, he has exposed why his Administration limited migration from these countries. Just because people from those countries were suffering under right wing dictatorships and civil turmoil, they have been discriminated against under the former Liberal-National Party Administration. We might ask on what basis he set immigration policy from countries such as Poland, Vietnam or Kampuchea. Was it because he thought that they would be anti-communist people or because they were genuine immigrants and refugees being treated-

TALK.START.PARA: —I take a point of order, Mr Deputy Speaker. I have been in the chamber the whole afternoon. The honourable member for Petrie did not use the words being expressed by the honourable member for Jagajaga. I think he ought to be made to withdraw them because in fact he completely misrepresents what was said by the honourable member for Petrie.
— Order! There is no point of order.

—I have in my electorate the example of a person from Colombia who is trying to migrate to Australia. The family has been affected by the volcanic eruption and the mud slide there. I do not care whether they come out here as potential Labor voters or Liberal voters.

SPEECH.PARA: The fact is that people who seek to migrate to Australia should be able to do so without fear of being treated unequally. This is a sad day for the bipartisanship that we have seen over the years on immigration and ethnic affairs in the Parliament and that those on this side of the House and many others have sought to engender. I refer not only to the comments of the honourable member for Petrie, but also to the whole thrust of the debate on this citizenship legislation. The Leader of the Opposition (Mr Howard) and the Leader of the National Party of Australia (Mr Sinclair), if they have the backing of their parties or the intent to do so, should clean up their migration policy and direct their members accordingly.
Sitting suspended from 6.30 to 8 p.m.

TALK.START.PARA: —Madam Speaker, this is the first opportunity I have had to address the Chair while you have been the occupant, so I congratulate you on your elevation to that high office. It is a great joy to us all. As I was saying before the dinner break, I felt that in this debate we had a great opportunity to restore balance, equanimity, reason and the broad bipartisanship that has characterised so much of the debate and action on citizenship and immigration matters. (Quorum formed) As I was saying before the foolish and pedantic tactics of the Opposition were again exposed, I thought that this debate would give us the opportunity to restore some of the broad bipartisanship lost after the disgraceful action in which members opposite played such a large part. It is sad today that we have again stepped backwards. Nonetheless, this legislation will proceed with the blessing and approval of the majority of the people of Australia, who are so well represented in this chamber tonight by so many members of the Government. Their presence highlights further the total irrelevance of the Liberal and National parties to Australians, whether they be born Australians or people who have taken Australian citizenship. As a member of Parliament who was born in Australia, and who obviously had no choice in his nationality, I feel great humility and also pride when attending citizenship ceremonies to see the choice that so many new settlers make.

SPEECH.PARA: This legislation both enhances the citizenship ceremony and protects our new Australian citizens; indeed, all Australian citizens. The Minister for Immigration and Ethnic Affairs (Mr Hurford), government members and this legislation are to be applauded. People are getting tired of the attitudes and partisan approach of the Opposition. We need say no more about those opposite than that they stand disgraced again today as a result of their immigration policy.

TALK.START.PARA: —Order! The honourable member's time has expired.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Wilson The Hon I.B.C.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Australian Citizenship Amendment Bill is designed to make some alterations to the legislation which governs Australian citizenship. One aspect of this Bill prompts me to debate this issue in the broader context of Australia's international relations, the significant changes that have occurred to this country over the last 30 years, the changes in the world environment and the concerns of the people who make their permanent homes in Australia.
