Australia's citizenship law has for a long time been in need of reform. One clause in this legislation is designed to protect Australian citizens who move to live in another country for a short time but whose residence in that country may result in their having imposed upon them the citizenship of that country. When that occurs, under Australian law those people forfeit their Australian citizenship. This legislation is designed to assist those who find themselves in the situation, somewhat later, of deciding to return to the country that they believe is the country of their citizenship only to discover that their citizenship has been forfeited.

SPEECH.PARA: That is a small step in the right direction, but only a small one. I put it to the Minister that he should have put in this legislation an imaginative proposal that took account of the fact that well over a million Australians have dual citizenship and yet we, under our citizenship law, live out a sham. We pretend that our citizens have only one citizenship. It is a nonsense at citizenship ceremonies to ask people, who know that notwithstanding their application for Australian citizenship they will retain the citizenship of the country of their birth, to deny the allegiance and loyalty to and affection for the country of their birth because we have an anachronistic approach in Australia to single citizenship. I am pleased that consideration is being given to the sensitivity of people when they make their oaths or affirmations but we should not just try to change the words in a way which tries to fit in with that single citizenship attitude. We should move to a more modern approach and recognise dual citizenship.

I am aware that this matter has been the subject of parliamentary inquiry and has been examined at the departmental level but I urge the Minister to give it urgent and high priority for his department's consideration because in an increasingly mobile world in which people want to live in one country for a while but desire to maintain the love and affection for and loyalty to the country of their birth they should be able, in this sophisticated and modern world, to have that dual sense of love and affection for and loyalty to two countries. I find it offensive that if I, as an Australian, wished to go to another country, whether it be New Zealand or the United Kingdom or a non-English speaking country such as Italy or Greece, and were under certain circumstances to find that I would like to take out the citizenship of another country, I would forfeit my Australian citizenship. Yet I can have living next door to me people who have come here from the United Kingdom, from New Zealand, from Italy or Greece, who have gone through a formal act acknowledging allegiance to Australia, who have assumed Australian citizenship, but who through the domestic laws of the countries of their birth retain the citizenship of those countries. If that can occur why should we pretend it does not happen? Yet our laws and this legislation are based upon that premise. We shelter behind a treaty, a convention.

In 1930 it might have been appropriate for countries to say: `We want to try to get an international regime whereby people have one citizenship only'. However, in 1930 the world was not nearly as mobile as it is today. The opportunities of international travel, not merely as tourists but in terms of life style and career opportunities, are vastly different now from what they were 55 years ago. In any event the 1930 Hague convention was signed by only 20 countries. In signing that convention the countries said that they believed in moving towards single citizenship. Some of the countries that signed that convention recognise dual citizenship, for example, the United Kingdom. When a United Kingdom citizen comes here and takes out Australian citizenship through a citizenship ceremony he or she does not lose United Kingdom citizenship. Why should an Australian lose citizenship when he moves to the United Kingdom or to some other country?

I know that difficulties can arise as a consequence of obtaining dual citizenship and that there are some advantages in being a dual national. They include the right to unrestricted entry into either country, the right to engage in employment in either country, the right to own land or property in either country, the right to inherit assets in either country, the right to confer citizenship of one or both countries on off-spring and, in some instances, the right to receive special concessions while visiting other countries. They also give a choice, in times of international conflict, as to the citizenship of which the dual national's rights, duties and obligations may be based and the right to the social security benefits of both countries. Those are the advantages that very often flow to people who have dual citizenship. Why should a million and a half Australians have those benefits if their birthplace is outside Australia whilst we deny those benefits to Australians who get their citizenship by virtue of birth in this country? We do it because we base our attitude on that old-fashioned convention which time has passed and is still passing by.

I will list the disadvantages of being a dual national. They may be real for well over one million Australians. What difference would it make if we added a few more thousand-10,000, 100,000-Australian born who wish to take out the citizenship of another country? For the purposes of the debate let me draw to the attention of the House those disadvantages that are commonly advances. They are: On the return to the country of origin there is sometimes exposure to penalties such as a restriction in the freedom of movement; on return to the country of origin there is sometimes exposure to severe penalties such as imprisonment for illegality of the original departure from the country; difficulties sometimes arise from conflicting laws affecting divorce and custody; there are sometimes obligations towards both countries in respect of military service; there are sometimes difficulties in claiming inheritances or compensation for loss of property; in time of war there is the problem of being regarded as an enemy alien in either or both countries; there is sometimes loss of consulare protection in one country when visiting the country of the other citizenship and there is sometimes the possibility of having to pay taxation in both countries.

That list is often included in the official presentation in justification of our antiquated approach to citizenship. I get the feeling that people are searching for reasons why we should not change. They are clutching at straws because a large number of those disadvantages apply to Australians who take out Australian citizenship and retain their dual nationality because they were born in another country. We already have a million and a half person-problem and yet we say: `We cannot let our citizens get the advantages of dual citizenship if they choose to take out the citizenship of another country'.

I hope that the Minister will pursue the inquiries which I understand he has made to see whether we can lay down new laws for citizenship of this country that recognise that all Australians-not only those who happen to have been born overseas-live in a very mobile world. We want Australians to retain the citizenship of their birth so that they, like Italian Australians, Greek Australians, United Kingdom Australians and New Zealand Australians, can be vigorous Australian citizens while they are here and vigorous supportive Australian citizens when they return to the country of their birth. However, at the same time, we should allow those rights to the Australian born who happen to take up, or wish to take up, citizenship of other countries.

I express my disappointment in this legislation. It really makes only a very small change. It does not preserve Australian citizenship to someone who goes to a country that imposes its citizenship upon people and says: `You have lost your citizenship. We will let you resume it on a very narrow basis'. For many it is so narrow that resumption of citizenship is denied. This problem affects Australians today. I am aware of Australians who were born in Australia and to my way of thinking they remain Australians for the rest of their lives. I am sure that Australians who now have the citizenship of other countries have the same affinity with Australia-the place of their birth-that so many of our migrants have with their place of birth. In fact I find it a paradox that we go to a citizenship ceremony and hear those taking on citizenship say: `I renounce loyalty to and citizenship of the country of my birth'-that is, in effect, what the oath says. We then make a speech and say: `You were born in Italy and Greece and you will bring your culture here. We hope that you will maintain ties with your country of birth'. Yet the very ceremony we put people through denies the reality of their new relationship to Australia and their birth relationship to their country of origin. I urge the Government to give serious consideration to making this change. I believe that a large number of Australians would recognise the value of those changes.

It is a matter for Australian law because the citizenship of any individual is determined by the domestic law of the country that confers citizenship. I recognise that fact. It is our domestic law that forfeits the citizenship of an Australian who takes the citizenship of another country. I believe that we should remove that forfeiture provision. I would like to see an amendment to this legislation. I propose to read the amendment that I would like to see made to the Bill so that the Minister can give it consideration. I think a clause 6A should be inserted which reads:
Section 17 of the principal Act is repealed and the following section is substituted:
Loss of citizenship on acquisition of another nationality.
Section 17 of the principal Act should read:
17 (1) Subject to sub-section (2), a person, being an Australian citizen who has attained the age of 18 years, who does any act or thing-
(a) the sole or dominant purpose of which; and
(b) the effect of which,
is to acquire the nationality or citizenship of a foreign country, shall, upon that acquisition, cease to be an Australian citizen.

That is as the law stands at present. My amendment goes on to state in sub-section (2) that sub-section (1) does not apply in relation to an act of marriage. That relates to an Australian marrying in another country who, by virtue of that marriage, has the citizenship of that country imposed upon her. I say `her' because most countries that do that do not impose the citizenship upon a spouse who is a man. That is for the domestic law of Italy, Greece or wherever it may be. If it were our domestic law, I suppose we would have made changes to it by now. The act of marriage that imposes upon the woman the citizenship of a husband does not forfeit that woman's Australian citizenship. I would like to see added a further sub-paragraph, sub-paragraph (b), that reads:
the acquisition of the nationality of citizenship of a prescribed foreign country.
In other words, proposed section 17, sub-section (2), would read:
Sub-section (1)-
the forfeiture provision-
does not apply in relation to-
(b) the acquisition of the nationality or citizenship of a prescribed foreign country.

That would enable us, by regulation, to determine with which countries we would have some bilateral arrangements whereby we would acknowledge that dual citizenship. We may want to do it upon the basis of those countries conferring upon Australian citizens born in those countries rights that we think are appropriate to dual nationals when they return to their countries of birth, as we would presumably wish to confer similar rights upon their nationals by birth when they acquire Australian citizenship. In that way we may be able to overcome some of the difficulties that confront dual nationals in respect of military service. We might also be able to overcome some of the difficulties that confront dual nationals when they go to countries basically in eastern Europe. I believe that our negotiating leverage for those people who came here in many instances because they were political refugees is very limited because we deny the existence of the possibility of dual nationality in a domestic law sense. Those countries say: `Once a Czech always a Czech and once a Hungarian always a Hungarian'. We deny the dual nationality and therefore it limits our negotiating capacity.

I urge the Minister to look at this matter from two points of view. Firstly, if we confer dual nationality it would put Australian-born Australians on the same footing as well over one million people who became Australians by an act of citizenship. Secondly, it would give the Minister and the Government greater negotiating power for the time being in sorting out by bilateral agreement sensible arrangements to protect the rights of dual nationals when they happen to be in a country of one of their citizenship, so that when an Australian citizen goes to Hungary the Hungarian Government acknowledges that he has some rights as an Australian citizen notwithstanding the fact that he was born in Hungary and, vice versa, a Hungarian born person coming to Australia or an Australian going to Hungary if that were the case. For those two reasons and the others that I have mentioned during my address to the House this evening, I urge the Government to seek to lift itself out of the straightjacket of the 1930s and move into the 1980s and 1990s with regard to our citizenship laws.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Hurford The Hon C.J.

TALKER.NAME: Mr HURFORD
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for Immigration and Ethnic Affairs)

TALK.START.PARA: —in reply-I would like to thank all honourable members who have taken part in this long and wide-ranging debate. Some strange concepts have been articulated in the House during the debate but, where that has happened, honourable members on the other side of the House have, no doubt, responded adequately. I regret that I have not been able to be present throughout the debate but those honourable members who are understanding will know that there is a large administrative role in my portfolio. Indeed, I have been seeing one colleague after another today, which is one of the jobs of a Minister for Immigration and Ethnic Affairs, while the House has been sitting. I have been listening to as much of the debate as I possibly could and I have had officers, both in my private office and in my Department, monitoring what has been going on. I know that on one or two occasions some kind things were said about me as Minister for Immigration and Ethnic Affairs which, when they came from the other side of the House, were a shock to the system but, nevertheless, much appreciated and I thank those honourable members who recognised the difficulties and expressed those thoughts.

SPEECH.PARA: Generally speaking, the debate has convinced me of the wisdom of the Government's decision in the three main areas which are the subject of the Australian Citizenship Amendment Bill. I would like to respond now to some of the contributions. The honourable member for Mitchell (Mr Cadman) led for the Opposition. I was disappointed to hear him say-I did hear the whole of his speech-that he felt I was not consulting sufficiently. I reject and resent the claim that there has been a lack of consultation on these matters. We have let his office know of whatever is in the pipeline. I was reminded, by the honourable member for Sturt (Mr Wilson) in the final contribution to this debate of the subject of dual citizenship. The honourable member for Mitchell will know that, because there had been some expressions of interest in dual citizenship by honourable members on both sides of the House, I had work done in my Department. It is not an easy subject. There are all sorts of consular difficulties in dual citizenship. There is also the conventional wisdom-whatever that may be-in our society at a particular time on the value of single citizenship, and the Government would not want to move until there was a consensus for movement in this area. But as soon as we have the papers finalised and as soon as I am able to get more details of what is going on in Canada at present-it has moved to dual citizenship-and how it has dealt with some of the problems, I shall be sharing those experiences and that knowledge with members of the Opposition to see whether there is any consensus for change.

In the case of changes to the Act that relate to the resumption of citizenship where it is inadvertently lost, there was correspondence with the honourable member for Mitchell's predecessor, the honourable member for Dundas (Mr Ruddock). In the case of changes to the oath and the affirmation, I felt I was entitled to rely on what was said in this place in debates when this subject was last before the Parliament. Admittedly, the focus of that debate was on removing the reference to the Queen from the oath. I have not so far been able to look to the length that I would have liked at the debate in this House but certainly some members of the Liberal Party of Australia in the other chamber expressed a wish for removing the renunciation of all other allegiances. Just how much can one consult? This commitment on the part of a lot of Opposition members is there in black and white.

Then the honourable member for Moncrieff (Mrs Sullivan) made a contribution which I respect. She commented on the proposal to restrict the acquisition of Australian citizenship to those children born in Australia of parents who were either Australian citizens or permanent residents of this country. The report of the National Consultations on Multiculturalism and Citizenship in October 1982 considered a proposal that children born in Australia whose parents were either prohibited non-citizens or temporary residents would acquire Australian citizenship at birth, but would lose that status if they left Australian within five years of birth and did not return to this country within five years of departure. The amendments to the Act in 1984 did not include any reference to this topic. The introduction of such a provision would not overcome the problem of queue jumping or the administration problems envisaged for the proposed amendment. The child would be an Australian citizen by birth and its parents would still be using the fact that the child was a citizen as a lever to prevent their having to leave Australia. That was the subject of the Human Rights Commission's advice to us. If I have misunderstood the point made by the honourable member, I will certainly go back over Hansard and reply in writing to her. But I would point out that, administratively, if my assumptions are correct and I have understood her point correctly, it would still have been necessary for such children to have obtained evidence that, if they left Australia within five years of their birth, they had returned to Australia for residence during the five years immediately following the departure.

The honourable member for Moncrieff also stated in the debate that if the Bill is passed in its present form the birth certificate of a person born in Australia could no longer be used as prima facie evidence of the person's Australian citizenship. I recognise that, but in fact this is already the case as the birth of some children in Australia does not automatically result in their acquisition of Australian citizenship. The honourable member will know that this applies, for instance, to diplomats and consular officers in Australia. She might rightly say that that is a very small group. The point is that when one has a small group, one has to look on the birth certificate in new light. Every birth certificate has to be checked because of the possibility that it might apply to a diplomat or consular officer.

Often my Department is required to check the status of the parents of persons born in Australia. Some expansion of these difficulties will arise from the further reduction in the reliability of a birth certificate as evidence of an Australian citizenship in such fields as passport issue. Consultations have already been arranged with the States with a view to ascertaining whether a means exists by which a birth certificate of a person who is not a citizen would be distinguishable. We will be reporting later on these consultation to anybody who is in touch with us on this matter. I would point out that the proposal for an Australia Card is also interesting in this field. It, too, would give evidence where evidence is not otherwise available.

The honourable member for Macquarie (Mr Webster) stated that he did not wish to see citizenship reduced to a pure administrative procedure whereby it was acquired over the counter. Nor do I. It was an absolute furphy of the honourable member for Cook (Mr Dobie) earlier in the term of this Parliament when it was suggested that that might be in the pipeline. It never was, it never has been to my knowledge, and I wish to assure all honourable members that I do not intend to abolish the ceremonies that are conducted by local governments. The honourable member for Cook made a contribution to this debate. I send a message to him-I shall not be so rude as to say who is present in the chamber and who is not, as it was said about me earlier in the day on a number of occasions-that I will be sending the honourable member a list of those countries which recognise dual nationality. Indeed, that list may also be of interest to the honourable member for Sturt.

The honourable member for Dundas applied some of his time to the question of resumption of citizenship, and asked why there were differences in relation to Canada. The obvious answer to his rhetorical question is that the words of the particular Acts are different. This Bill seeks to rectify the situation so that those who have been wronged by losing their citizenship, admittedly by no fault of the Australian law but in this case, it seems through the fault of the Israeli law, have, just by seeking permanent residence in Israeli, automatically obtained Israeli citizenship and by that act have in so many cases lost citizenship. I come back to the point I am making that this Bill seeks to correct the wrongs that have been done to people where they did not intend to lose their Australian citizenship. I promised in my second reading speech that because new material had been brought to my attention I would be looking again at this matter. The House now knows, because I have already circulated the amendments, that there are some further amendments to be dealt with at the committee stage which will give us an opportunity to debate that question. I shall not delay the House on that matter.

The honourable member for Denison (Mr Hodgman) expressed concern about the oath. He stated-more for rhetorical reasons, which is a characteristic of his than for any other reason-that the oath was defective legally because the person swearing the oath did not recite their name. I am amazed that a Queen's counsel could have come to that conclusion, which is built on sand. There is no substance in it whatever. It is not necessary for the person swearing or affirming to recite their name. All that is required is that the person be identified. As was said in my second reading speech, candidates are identified both before and after swearing the oath.

TALK.START.PARA: —How?

—When they come into the room and when they are ticked off by the clerks. There is no way in the world that when they repeat their names anyone can understand the name in so many of the cases. Let us be reasonable about it. Of course they are identified. They are identified also by the town clerks knowing them. It is most disruptive to the ceremonies when people stop in the way they do at present and do not know what is expected of them; they do not know whether they are saying their names or not. It is an absurdity for anyone to resist this change.

SPEECH.PARA: The honourable member for Denison also said nobody had told him that the renunciation in the oath was a renunciation of heritage. It is time he got out among the ethnic communities a little more and learnt about their feelings. I suspected that he had been isolated from those who are familiar with these issues, and what he said confirmed my view. As everyone who has taken part in this debate knows, the Government is not automatically conferring citizenship upon a child born here. I think I have addressed the only questions that arose on that and they were from the honourable member for Moncrieff. On the resumption of Australian citizenship when it has been lost, we shall be talking about that matter in the committee stage, so I shall not detain the House now. When it comes to the oath or affirmation, I gather that more will be said in the committee stage about that, too. So be it, let us address that matter when the time comes.

For my part now, there is just one other duty I have and that is to draw to the attention of the House that a small change is required to the Migration Act in relation to that part of this Bill that is non-controversial. I refer to Australian born children who are not citizens. Amendment will be necessary to reflect the position that there will be persons born in Australia who are not Australian citizens. The Migration Act provides that persons who enter Australia without entry permits or remain in Australia after the expiry of entry permits are here illegally-termed prohibited non-citizens. The Migration Act will be changed to provide that children born in Australia to non-citizens or to persons who are not permanent residents will be taken to be included in the temporary entry permit of the parent whose permit last expired or, if only one parent holds a temporary entry permit, the child will be taken to be included in that parent's permit. A child where both parents are prohibited non-citizens will be deemed to be a prohibited non-citizen. This amendment reflects the policy position as expressed in the citizenship amendments which are before the House now, and I foreshadow that those changes will be made to the Migration Act.

I would be very pleased indeed, as we have already had a wide ranging debate on this issue, if we could include that particular amendment, by agreement with the Opposition, in the Statute Law (Miscellaneous Provisions) Bill, the Omnibus Bill. We will give Opposition members a copy of that part of the instructions to the Parliamentary Draftsman, because we certainly do not want a wide ranging debate again with such a heavy timetable in this Parliament. I commend the Bill to the House.
Question resolved in the affirmative.
Bill read a second time.

PROCTEXT.PARA: Clauses 1 to 6-by leave-taken together.

TALK.START.PARA: —I just wish to raise a matter to seek clarification in respect of clause 3. I have received representations from a group called the Inter-Agency Migration Group, of Marrickville which points out that clause 3 covers abandoned children but does not cover orphaned children. It could well be that the Minister may consider that an additional change could be made here. It is possible that a child travelling with its parents who has no relatives overseas could suffer the loss of its parents through their being killed in a car accident. The child is orphaned in Australia and has no near relative to make a claim on that child. This may be worth consideration. I believe that the Inter-Agency Migration Group has acted in good faith and that this matter should be considered.

TALKER.NAME: Mr HURFORD
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for Immigration and Ethnic Affairs)

TALK.START.PARA: —I would be very disappointed if the group has not written to me, too, but I have to tell the House that this was not brought to my attention. If `abandoned' does not already cover the particular class mentioned, we will have to look at that next time the Bill is before the House.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Sullivan Mrs K.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —I take the opportunity to clarify something that I said in my speech in relation to section 4 and I ask the Minister to readdress himself to the subject. I indicated while the Minister was speaking that he had misunderstood something I said. In fact, the notes with which he was provided by his Department or his staff had kaleidoscoped two things that I referred to. One related to the report from the Australian Council on Population and Ethnic Affairs on the National Consultations on Multiculturalism and Citizenship, and he said that I had put a view which I had ascribed to that Council. In fact, the view that I was putting at that stage was from the speech of the former Minister for Immigration and Ethnic Affairs, the honourable member for Goldstein (Mr Macphee), when he made a statement to the House on 6 May 1982 which initiated the review of the Citizenship Act. It is the report on this review that has been central to the debate here. I make that point by way of clarification.

SPEECH.PARA: I have to say that I am disappointed that in the Minister's response on the subject of changes to the section on citizenship by birth, it is clear that he apparently has no knowledge of the suggestion made by the former Minister for Immigration and Ethnic Affairs on this subject, a suggestion made to make more humane the operation of this part of the Act. I found the Minister's comments on this subject altogether too cursory in that they skated over what the possibilities were. Obviously, the Minister is not going to accept that, but I ask him, since there will obviously be further reviews of this Act in the future on the basis of what he said this evening, to look at that suggestion again, because I feel that his amendment goes too far.

On the subject of birth certificates, I am a little disappointed to be told that consultations have commenced on what will be the implications for the recording of births in Australia, given that it is State governments that are responsible for the recording of births. I accept that it is probable that the Minister felt that he could not wait for those consultations to finish in order to settle this issue of whether people who are illegal immigrants or have overstayed their visas and have children here, attempt to use the device of their Australian-born children as a way of stopping their deportation from this country. However, I simply suggest that it might have been better to wait until those bureaucratic difficulties-mentioned in the House of Representatives Standing Committee on Expenditure report to which I referred this afternoon-were further down the track.

The Minister mentioned that there are presently categories of people who are excluded from claiming Australian citizenship because they were born here, categories of a very limited nature. I would be interested to know how those children are identified-I would think that those cases are extremely limited-and how their birth certificates are handled. I doubt that there is much use in those procedures for the situation that the Minister will face after this amendment. Under these circumstances, this amendment is premature, and we should have been better advised as to how this will operate, given that it has the potential to affect everyone born in Australia, including those born to Australian citizens.

A birth certificate is important to people in respect of such things as obtaining a passport. If the situation arises in which a substantial number of children born in Australia are not entitled to Australian citizenship, a question mark will arise over the usefulness of a birth certificate showing a birth in Australia for those purposes. It may well be that the Minister has something very specific in mind. He did not give it to us in his second reading speech, and I, therefore, have to assume that it has not all been worked out and that this clause is therefore deficient. It is being introduced in advance of the Government's having worked out all its implications. Under those circumstances I do not believe that the Government should proceed.

Perhaps the Minister would say that the amendment is necessary now to stop these applications for residence from illegal immigrants. I do not think that it is beyond the realm of the Government's power to announce that it will legislate to this effect in the future, and the legislation will be made retrospective to the date of the announcement-that is quite a common device in our laws, particularly in financial matters. Therefore, anybody now in Australia illegally or who has overstayed his or her visa and who has a thought of using that device to stay in Australia would be warned that a law would be passed by this Parliament which would render that device useless. I think that that was a possibility. It might also have given time for the sort of consultation that should have been undertaken on other aspects of the Bill; I am sure this will be debated further in the Committee stage.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Hurford The Hon C.J.

TALKER.NAME: Mr HURFORD
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for Immigration and Ethnic Affairs)

TALK.START.PARA: —The honourable member for Moncrieff (Mrs Sullivan) has been building a lot of straw men in the course of her remarks. Of course before we brought such a measure as this to the House we looked at any administrative arrangements that are necessary in order to put into effect what is being put into the law. I have not resiled from the fact that it will be far better administered when we have entered into successful negotiations with the States so that the birth certificates themselves will show whether people are born of Australian citizenship, and, in time, that will be done. But the necessary tests can be now carried out by those who are issuing passports to ensure that people are Australian citizens before they are issued with passports. The honourable member need not concern herself with a lot of the worries that she has. These have been addressed in the administrative arrangements that we are putting in place.

SPEECH.PARA: Clauses agreed to.
Clause 7 (Persons may resume citizenship lost in certain circumstances).

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Hurford The Hon C.J.

TALKER.NAME: Mr HURFORD
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for Immigration and Ethnic Affairs)

TALK.START.PARA: —I move:

SPEECH.PARA: (1) Clause 7, page 4, line 7, omit ``did not do'', insert ``had not done''
This is a technical amendment picked up by the Parliamentary Draftsman.
Amendment agreed to.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Cadman Mr A.G.

TALK.START.PARA: —by leave-I move:

SPEECH.PARA: (1) Clause 7, page 4, proposed sub-sub-paragraph 23aa (1) (b) (iv) (a), omit ``permanently'' (twice occurring).
(2) Clause 7, page 4, lines 21-30, omit proposed sub-sub-paragraphs 23aa (1) (b) (B) and (C), substitute the following word and sub-sub-paragraph:
``; or
(B) in a case where the person is not residing in Australia-to return to Australia; and''.

The Opposition and the Government are not far apart in regard to the amendments each is proposing to clause 7. The only area of disagreement in regard to the amendments-one from the Government and two from the Opposition-relates to the amount of time that an Australian, who has lost his citizenship and who has then regained it under the provisions of this Bill, has to remain outside Australia before returning to Australia. The Minister is prescriptive in his approach and says that such people must return to Australia within a period of three years from the day on which their statements were first made.

The Opposition does not consider this to be a reasonable approach. We have considered the matter carefully and consulted widely. We feel that citizens who inadvertently lost their citizenship by dint of the 1984 Act should not be treated differently from any other citizens of Australia who are overseas. It was through no fault, intent or action of their own that they lost their Australian citizenship. These people are mostly Australian citizens living in Israel who, under the law of return, Aliyah, had to apply within a period of three months to disclaim any wish to become citizens of Israel.

TALK.START.PARA: —There are about 2,000 of them.
—As the honourable member says, about 2,000 of them were stuck in the position of having lost their Australian citizenship, but of having had no intention of doing so.

SPEECH.PARA: There are some sad and distressing stories of individuals who lost their citizenship in this way. There have been many newspaper accounts of people who feel that they were badly treated and deserve better treatment from their own country. These people were born in Australia. They were natural Australian citizens. I quote from a report in the Age of 20 December concerning Mrs Waysman, who was born in Australia. When she found out that she had inadvertently lost here Australian citizenship she said:
I still feel very . . . Australian. I felt like I'd had a limb amputated when I found out I had to have a visitor's visa to go back to Australia where my family's roots go so deep.
That would be the typical reaction of any person who felt that he or she had been poorly treated by an inadvertent effect of changes to the law in Australia.

The amendments the Minister is now proposing to the Bill make some sort of sense out of it. There was no way in which the Opposition could have agreed with the Bill as it was originally presented. However, on examining the amendments the Minister now wants to make, it is our feeling that a limitation of time should not be placed on individuals who regain their citizenship by applying and making a statement to the Minister and the Minister then exercising his discretion. How are those people who have inadvertently lost their citizenship and are to have it restored by this Bill, when it becomes an Act of the Parliament, different from citizens who have not returned to Australia at all? It was not their intent to lose citizenship. It was not as a result of their action. They were not involved in any positive steps to lose it. We restore their citizenship by this Bill, properly and rightly, and then the Minister says that, unlike anybody else, these people ought to return to Australia within three years. It is not fair. It is not proper.

The Minister has not explained, either in the explanatory notes or in the speech that he has circulated, why there is a need for this three-year limitation. There is no reason for it. We are talking about Aussies who have lost their citizenship under the 1984 Act. We are restoring that citizenship and now the Minister wants to apply to them a condition of time within which they have to return to Australia. I do not believe that we can tolerate this. We are talking about Australians. They have not taken steps to deny that they are Aussies. They have not taken steps in any way which would move them away from the mainstream of Australian life, or acted any differently from other Australians living overseas. I do not believe that the House should accept the Minister's proposal.

The Opposition and the Government are close together in intent. The Government has seen the error of the original Bill. It has moved to correct that error in a sensible way. Not only has the Government moved to correct it formally, but it has moved informally to give the assurances that are necessary for the administration of the Bill to be carried out cleanly. It has moved to define areas that are left uncertain by the Bill, such as what `retaining appropriate contact with Australia' should be. I appreciate that. The Opposition appreciates it. I know that all the citizens who have been affected appreciate it. However, a small matter still rankles-the condition the Government is setting that these Australians have to return to Australia within three years. It is no good saying that they must only give an intention that they will return to Australia. What is the Government trying to do? Is it trying to encourage them to make false statements? Is it trying to say to them: `Wink wink, nod nod, sign this and you do not have to come back to Australia':

Let us put it up front. Let us be honest about it and say: `If you are going to sign for a three-year limitation in the country where you are living and then requirement to return to Australia, we will apply that provision'. On the other hand, we should say: `We do not really think that condition is tenable. It was a thought that we had that would put some obligation on those individuals to show their real regard for Australia, to show their intention of continuing an association'. There is no need to do that. The Government has available to it other techniques which it has enunciated. It has enunciated with care and detail the way in which it wants these people to show a continuing contact, with regard for and intent towards Australia. It has clearly stated that. All that needs to be done at this point is to remove the three-year condition. It is a small thing and a proper thing to do for Australian citizens.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Ruddock Mr P.M.

TALK.START.PARA: —I am not sure whether the Minister for Immigration and Ethnic Affairs heard my speech at the second reading stage. I would not like to have to go through it and cover the whole ground again, but I do wish to reinforce briefly some of the points I made in that speech because I think it is important that we all understand that the nature of the Nationality Act in Israel-I understand there are one or two other places in which there are similar provisions; South Africa may be another place where provisions have a similar impact-is such that people lose their Australian citizenship in circumstances where they simply take up permanent residence in Israel to enable them to work. That is familiar to us because it happens with many people who come to Australia. They have no intention of giving up their citizenship of another country and we do not ask them to give up their citizenship. We say that they can come to Australia as a permanent resident but they are not Australian citizens.

SPEECH.PARA: People do the same thing in Israel-they go there to work and have no intention of giving up their Australian citizenship-but the operation of the Nationality Act in Israel is such as to give them automatically Israeli citizenship unless, within a certain period of time, they disavow the intention of taking up Israeli citizenship; in other words, they opt to retain their Australian citizenship. That is a positive act that is required on their part. It is that positive act, the failure to take that additional step, which has meant that many people who were affected prior to the operation of this legislation and who believed that they would not lose their Australian citizenship have in fact lost their Australian citizenship. It is a result of inadvertence. It is a result of poor advice.

The fact is that officers at our posts abroad believed that before 1984 people in those circumstances would not lose their Australian citizenship. The evidence for that is contained in the specific case study I mentioned in which our posts at Australia House and Tel Aviv registered as born to an Australian the children of a lady who it was determined later was not an Australian. The children of that lady were registered as Australians born overseas. They could only have been registered if the officers in the post-those people who are responsible for the administration of the law-looked at the information which was provided to them honestly and in a bona fide manner and accepted that this woman was an Australian citizen.

Certainly in terms of the advice I have been given following talks with officials, it is generally recognised that before 1984 people were not thought to have lost their citizenship in those circumstances. We now know that there are a large number of people-the estimates are that there are as many as 2,000 people-who have not made a declaration in accordance with the Israeli Nationality Act. In many cases they would have believed that they were still entitled to keep and retain their Australian citizenship. There have been meetings in Israel of many hundreds of people concerned at the impact of the changes made to the Act in 1984. Those people sought, which is the approach that I thought the Minister would take, provisions by way of amendment to the Australian Citizenship Act that would simply provide that section 23aa would have retrospective effect to cover those people who thought they retained Australian citizenship and who have now found that it is lost to them. The Government has produced an amendment which contained a number of provisions but which, after being further amended, will simply impose one new condition. That new condition is that a person who applies overseas to have his citizenship restored will have to evidence an intention to return to Australia within three years.

Of the 5,000 people in Israel amongst the 7,000 residents who were formerly Australian citizens there is a group of people who are entitled at any time to return to Australia but who do not have to return within a particular time. Their citizenship is not at risk unless they take some further action which brings them into conflict with the relevant parts of section 17 of the Australian Citizenship Act. Provided they do nothing of that sort, they will retain their Australian citizenship. They might never return, but they will still be Australian citizens. That is one class of people. Those people who have lost their citizenship through poor advice or inadvertence and who we believe ought to have the capacity to have their citizenship restored have to satisfy another condition. That condition is that they will return within three years.

I submit that the Minister is creating two classes of Australian citizens-those people who have taken up permanent residence in Israel and who have taken the further step of reciting that they do not wish to lose their Australian citizenship and the people who failed to do so and who will have to satisfy this additional provision. It not only imposes a very considerable hardship but also creates classes of citizenship, which I think is undesirable in that sense. It also means something for the people I described this afternoon as seeking to have a basis upon which they could return to Australia in the event of significant and changed circumstances in Israel. There would be a group of people who were born in Australia and who would be able to return and there would be a group of people who were born in Australia or who had taken out Australian citizenship previously and who would not be able to return. I do not think that is fair in any sense whatever.

While I do not believe it is appropriate that we should be guided by what other countries are doing except by way of analogy-I do not think we have necessarily to adopt their laws-I think it is important for the Minister to note that other countries which have a similar legal background to our own and which disavow the concept of dual citizenship, countries such as Canada and Britain-

TALK.START.PARA: —Canada does not disavow dual citizenship.

—As I understand it and as I recited this afternoon, it has a similar provision-section 15(1) of its code-which provides in similar terms to section 17 as it operated before 1984 for citizenship to be forfeited where people take a particular step.
—I responded to you in my reply to the second reading debate. You should have heard that.

—I apologise if that was the case. I was in a Party meeting, as the Minister might know. I would not normally miss the opportunity of hearing the Minister's contributions, particularly when they are responding to mine. I will read those comments with interest because if they do not in any way answer mine, perhaps I will be given an opportunity to make them again and we can have a further tete a tete. The fact is that the Canadian provision was a very similar operation to our own before 1984. As I understand it, in terms of the interpretation given by the Canadian Registrar, Canada does not revoke the citizenship of a Canadian in the circumstances where we revoke the citizenship of an Australian. I think that is another reason why we ought to have an element of consistency in the approach we take and why we ought to ensure that there are no double standards in relation to these matters.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Hurford The Hon C.J.

TALKER.NAME: Mr HURFORD
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for Immigration and Ethnic Affairs)

TALK.START.PARA: —The Government cannot accept this amendment but it accepts the objective that is sought to be achieved by the honourable member for Mitchell (Mr Cadman). In my second reading speech over two weeks ago I indicated that the Government was giving further study to the contention that the requirement that a person should intend to return to live permanently in Australia may be unduly onerous as it is drawn in the Bill that was first brought to this Parliament. Therefore, on behalf of the Government, I have taken wide counsel on this matter. I have had discussions with leaders of the Jewish community. The Committee will know, because I have given ample evidence, that I intend to move shortly a Government amendment. It will make redundant the amendment moved by the honourable member for Mitchell because it removes certain words that are removed in that wider amendment. To be fair to the Committee I should anticipate my amendment and explain why I will seek the support of the Committee for that amendment.
—The Minister is stretching the line by anticipating this. But I imagine that in the terms of the debate the Committee is interested.
—It would be useful to have some explanation.
—I would be disappointed, Mr Chairman, if I could not ask you to review your interpretation.
—I said that I think in the interests of the debate that the matter is in order.

—Thank you, Mr Chairman. The fact is that when I move the amendment I will do so because on the examination that I promised I would make I have concluded that the provisions of clause 7 would operate against some former Australians who, as we all know, wish to resume their citizenship, for example, those who will return but expect to again depart to live or work overseas for brief periods. To this extent, we are at one because we all want to make sure that those people are not penalised. To overcome this consistency in application the amendment that I propose to clause 7 will delete the requirement that a person must provide evidence of intention that he or she will either continue to live permanently in Australia or will return to live permanently in Australia. We are at one there, too. In summary, the Bill as amended will provide that persons who have lost their Australian citizenship-here is the important part because I believe that this extra part is what the House would want to hear-can apply to resume it provided they are able to show that they would have suffered significant hardship if they did not acquire the foreign citizenship.

SPEECH.PARA: Indeed, I explain that many people who go to Israel, and apply for permanent residence in Israel, thereby getting citizenship in Israel, lose their Australian citizenship accordingly. They are doing this not only because that is the law in Israel but also because they need Israeli citizenship in order to carry out a lot of the vocations in Israel. As I understand it Israeli nationality is required for a person to work in an Israeli hospital. Doctors who decide to leave Australia and give some of their working life to Israel would require Israeli citizenship to carry out that calling. I will go back over the various elements. They would suffer significant hardship if they did not acquire the foreign Citizenship. That point would apply to them. Significant hardship would be suffered by those who did not know when acquiring that citizenship that they would lose their Australian citizenship. That situation applies to many people, as we know, including those in these categories: Those who (a), have resided lawfully in Australia for at least two years; (b), intend to continue to reside in Australia or to return to Australia within three years to reside here-I will come back to the point of why I think that time limit is necessary in a moment-or, (c), they have maintained a close and continuing association with Australia. In relation to the last of these requirements, it is envisaged-it is very important that this is in the public record-that the `close and continuing association' requirement will be interpreted liberally so as not to pose an obstacle to resumption of citizenship in cases where individuals have maintained any form of close association with Australia. It is of course impossible to define all the circumstances in which an individual will satisfy the test of having `maintained a close and continuing association with Australia'. I believe that the test will generally be satisfied where the individual (a) has family or relatives living in Australia and is able to demonstrate that he or she has maintained contacts with them by correspondence, telephone or by visits to them in Australia or visits to him or her; or, (b), is able to demonstrate that he or she maintains significant economic, financial or business interests within Australia; or, (c), maintains friendships with residents in Australia and visits them in Australia from time to time.

I believe, particularly after the discussions I have had with leaders of the Jewish community, that the proposed amendment which I will move shortly will operate without discrimination to former Australians and should therefore receive the support of the Committee. It is not sufficient that I should just say that but I should also respond to the points made by the honourable member for Mitchell and the honourable member for Dundas (Mr Ruddock). My advice is that a time limit is necessary; otherwise the requirement means nothing. To make a commitment to return in say 20 years, leave alone an unlimited return time as is proposed in the amendment moved by the honourable member for Mitchell, in reality is no commitment at all. Three years has been chosen as a reasonable period. In addition, that period coincides with the three-year period within which a permanent resident who leaves Australia with a return endorsement must return to Australia. I will go over that again.

TALK.START.PARA: —A permanent resident, not a citizen?

—Yes, a permanent resident. Of course, a citizen can come back-there must be some consistency-whereas a permanent resident in this country can have a return endorsement for only three years. There has to be balance in this matter as well. Honourable members should remember that we are talking about people who are often giving virtually the best years of their lives to another country. They require some consideration which we are giving but too many cases have come to my notice, and I am sure will have come to the notice of previous Ministers for immigration, in which Australian passports are being abused, where people have no commitment to this country whatsoever and are using those passports around the world for their own benefit.

SPEECH.PARA: I hope honourable members realise that fact and that anything we put into the law applies not only to the Israelis, for whom we have sympathy and whose leaders we have been in contact with in arriving at this solution, but to everyone. I urge the Committee to see reason and to recognise-this is no great criticism of the honourable member for Mitchell; he does not have the resources that I have in matters such as this-that we really have come to a sensible balance. To save later debate in Committee, because I will only formally move my amendments-if we get that far-I will read into the public record the letter that I have written to the President of the State Zionist Council of Victoria which gives even further commitments from the Government regarding unfortunate circumstances of these Israelis. I have referred to discussions with Mr Mark Leibler. I stated:
. . . concerning the question of Australian Jews in Israel who were advised, or understood, prior to 29 July 1981-

I will come back to that point. I make the point in passing that this administrative arrangement was messed up in this way in the years when those in opposition were in government. There is a reason why 29 July 1981 is an important date. But I continue:

. . . that they had not lost their Australian citizenship when they acquired an Israeli resident visa. I wish to confirm that I would be prepared to exercise my discretion under section 32 of the Australian Citizenship Act to grant them certificates of citizenship so as to remove any doubt as to whether they are in fact Australian citizens.
It continues:

Because of the advice provided, I do not believe it to be clear that the act which they did at that time was `voluntary'; that is, with correct advice they may have been unwilling to undertake the act. In order to avail themselves of that discretion, it would only be necessary to apply formally to the Department for the necessary certificate. It would not be necessary to comply with the conditions specified in section 23AA.

Australian-born children of these people and children born overseas prior to 29 July 1981 may be included in the section 32 certificate provided, in the case of those born overseas, their parents registered their birth with the relevant post to acquire citizenship by descent. Children born subsequent to 29 July 1981 would have not been registered and would therefore not have acquired Australian citizenship. The resumption provisions of section 23AA could not apply. So as not to penalise these children I would be prepared in appropriate cases to exercise my discretion under section 13 (9) of the Act to grant them citizenship in their own right upon application to my Department.

Finally, let me say that, consistent with the Government's objectives and policy as outlined in the Australian Citizenship Amendment Bill 1986, my associated statements to Parliament, and this letter, I shall give sympathetic consideration to anomalous individual cases, if any arise.

In summary, we are now talking only about people who lost their citizenship after 29 July 1981. It is a fact that that date is applicable because that is the date on which our Embassy in Tel Aviv learned unequivocally from the then Administration of the parties of honourable members opposite that the Israelis who gained Israeli citizenship lost Australian citizenship. However, in these amendments, we are facilitating their regaining their Australian citizenship provided that they have a commitment to this country. I have not been able to explain that in detail to all honourable members who are interested in this subject but I hope, now that I have done that, and explained why I will move my amendments in the form in which I will move them, that these amendments will be withdrawn or, if not, just allowed to be disagreed with on the voices, so that we can move to the Government amendments which are well thought through.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Macphee The Hon I.M.

TALK.START.PARA: —I appreciate what the Minister for Immigration and Ethnic Affairs (Mr Hurford) has just said. There are a couple of points that I would like to make in response. First of all, he is correct in trying not to confine this particular part of the debate to Israel. It just happens that the law of Israel has impacted upon the law of Australia in a way that has affected some 7,000 Australians who happen to be Jewish and who happen, therefore, to be caught under the law of Israel. I do not think anyone listening to this debate ought to think that, therefore, we are making a judgment to assist Australian Jews. It just happens that they are the ones immediately affected. There are a number of aspects about these amendments with which I agree, especially those relating to marriage.

SPEECH.PARA: When I was the Minister for Immigration and Ethnic Affairs I had to exercise judgments often about the way in which Australians through no voluntary act, really, but just by the act of marriage to a male of another nationality, had by the law of that country surrendered their Australian citizenship, or at least had become citizens of the other country and as such had lost, under our laws, their Australian citizenship. One was then faced with the issue whether to allow them to migrate back to Australia in the event that they became widowed or separated. I am pleased that that state of affairs has been improved.

I am also delighted that the Minister has now placed on record the letter that he is writing to Mr Leibler. I commend the Minister for doing that. It will probably put at rest the unease now in the minds of a number of Australians of Jewish faith who happen to enjoy being Australian but who feel a commitment to and manifest that commitment by going to live in Israel for lengthy periods and have, therefore, been caught up with the law and the administrative arrangements to which the Minister has referred. I must say that the period to which he referred was my period as Minister and I must say that I was not aware of these administrative arrangements that were then apparently made.

I take the Minister up on one point. He speaks of liberalising the term `close and continuing association'. He says that he will interpret it liberally so as not to pose an obstacle to resumption of citizenship in cases where individuals have maintained any form of close association with Australia. He said: `It is of course impossible to define all the circumstances in which an individual will satisfy the test of having maintained a close and continuing association with Australia'. Of course, I agree entirely with the Minister's observation. He then went on to outline a general test. I suggest to him that he must have some sort of general test and guideline to look at when he is exercising his discretion. Knowing the Minister reasonably well but speaking from experience, I suspect that what he has now set out will not be a sufficient test or guideline in many of the cases before him. Frankly, that is the reason why I, speaking from experience, still support the amendment moved by my colleague the honourable member for Mitchell (Mr Cadman) to remove the time limit. Mr Chairman, you used to come to me with representations on behalf of your constituents and I do not doubt that you go to the present Minister. One has to make judgments. We and the officers of the Department become skilled in assessing the bona fides of people. But I think this test is too tight.

I am bound to observe that this has not been the most splendid piece of draftsmanship. First of all, we had the amendments put through by the Minister's predecessor, the honourable member for Cunningham (Mr West). Secondly, I must say that when I picked up the Bill now before us I found all sorts of things that I thought were wrong. I then found that several of my colleagues had picked up those things, and so had the Minister. The Minister then came in with further amendments. As the honourable member for Mitchell has rightly said, there is not much difference between the views of the Minister and the shadow Minister. The only point of difference appears to be in the need to set a time limit for determining the bona fides of somebody who is Australian but who happens to have gone abroad and the country in which that person has settled has a law which somehow or other conscripts that person into changing his nationality involuntarily and, I am bound to say, informally.

The clause before us refers to a formal act. The mere fact of being, in this case, in Israel is voluntary, yes, but it is not a formal act. We are putting a number of unnecessary complications in our own way by this kind of amendment to the Act. Therefore, I support the amendment to the Bill moved by the honourable member for Mitchell because I think it is also a challenge to our maturity as a nation. Having been to Israel-this happens to be the case that has come before us, but I stress that it is not the only case-I can say that I met many Australians, including many from my own electorate, who were working in various ways. Some were on kibbutzes; that is true. Some were working for medical research foundations and other scientific and technical research institutions. Some were working in national security activities. As the Minister observed, some were working in hospitals and were obliged under Israeli law to be Israeli citizens. It is terribly important that we recognise the country to which they have a religious and cultural commitment but of which they do not intend to become permanent residents or citizens in the strict sense; their affinity with that country is far more of a cultural and religious nature. They are Australians who happen to have that commitment over and above that which most of us have to the country of our antecedents or the antecedents of our parents or grandparents. These people are doing something that they think is important, and it is important. They are acquiring knowledge in a country which is surrounded by enemies and which therefore adopts security laws which impact upon the citizenship of Australians who may actually be resident there.

We have to be part of the world, in more ways than one, and be very mature in the way we look at that matter. Imposing a three-year time limit is not the way to go. Let me give one example from another country. Sir William Heseltine is now Private Secretary to Her Majesty the Queen. Whether she be the Queen of Australia, the Queen of England, the Queen of Granada or the Queen of all the other countries of the Commonwealth that bestow that title upon her, it just happens that her Private Secretary is an Australian. He comes here when Her Majesty comes here. He may come over and above that; for his annual holidays to see his family and friends. He has on every basis a close and continuing association with Australia; he is proud to have his Australian passport. He may well have some sort of UK passport-I have no idea-because the UK does allow that. I do not know what his entitlement to a UK passport would be. The important point is that he is an Australian and he feels himself to be Australian. The test ultimately is what people feel themselves to be. The Australians I met in Israel were no less Australian for having committed themselves for a period of time in their lives to work in Israel. Whether it was three years, six years or thirty years really does not matter. They are no less Australian in the end; they feel that they are Australian. We know of so many people who have migrated to this country and who now, at the age of 65 or 70 years, go to citizenship ceremonies because their children and grandchildren are here and at last they feel they will never return to the country of their origin. It is how people feel that matters.

We get to know when there are subterfuges, when there is deceit, and we get to know when people are genuine. While our officials in the Department of Immigration and Ethnic Affairs are not always right, because they are human beings, they are right more often than they are generally given credit for and I think that their capacity to work with their Minister in a liberal interpretation of this close and continuing association test will be a great one. On the basis of their judgment and their capacity and the problems which I know to exist in Israel but which will exist also from time to time in other countries in which Australians feel some commitment, I support the amendment moved by my colleague which effectively deletes the time limit. I put it to the Minister very seriously that he is achieving nothing by imposing a three-year time limit. He is doing nothing other than obliging people to spend an air fare to come back here for a short period and then go back to the country whence they have come. I have had five continuous years away from this country but I was no less Australian for that. It just happened that the two countries in which I resided during that five years did not have laws that obliged me to become a citizen. What an incredible situation one would have been in if one had had to go through the rigmarole-with due respect to the Minister, liberalised as it might be compared to the original legislation-in the Bill which he now puts before us.

TALK.START.PARA: —I support the amendments put forward by the honourable member for Mitchell (Mr Cadman) but as the debate on these amendments has ranged beyond the amendments to this clause I hope to have the indulgence of the Chair to engage in like remarks.

—To keep the debate on the clause in context the Minister was allowed to anticipate. I hope that the honourable member for Sturt might keep to the amendments moved by the honourable member for Mitchell, and if he wishes to debate the amendment that the Minister is to put forward he might address it when the Minister does so. Under those general guidelines he may continue.

—I understood that people were addressing themselves to the clause but if that is not the case I will wait until the Minister's amendment. However, I support very much the amendment moved by the honourable member for Mitchell. This time limit should be removed. I support the arguments he has advanced.

—Mr Chairman, I do not in any way wish to canvass your ruling because I want to address my remarks to the amendment of the honourable member for Mitchell (Mr Cadman). In doing so I will by analogy draw some inferences from the comments that the Minister himself made because I think that they were also made in the context of the debate on the amendment of the honourable member for Mitchell.
—Would it help the Committee and the honourable member for Dundas if that were dealt with when the Minister moves his amendment?
—It is very difficult because I want to relate to the Minister's argument when discussing why the honourable member for Mitchell's amendment should be preferred.
—I realise that but I also have to be fair to the honourable member for Sturt.
—Yes; my view would be that we ought to treat the whole matter as a cognate debate.
—Mr Chairman, it may please the Committee if we have such a debate now but may not debate the Minister's amendment when we come to it.

—There are five amendments to clause 7-three moved by the honourable member for Mitchell and two to be moved by the Minister. If it suits the Committee we could have a wider debate and both the honourable member for Mitchell and the Minister could come back into that debate.
—One of my amendments is not really related to the matter currently under discussion.
—We are talking about the first two Opposition amendments and the first Government amendment. Would the honourable member for Dundas mind if I recalled the honourable member for Sturt?
—I am happy with that.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Wilson The Hon I.B.C.

TALK.START.PARA: —I want to take part in this element of the debate because the legislation brought before us by the Government is very narrow and inadequate and although it could be made somewhat wider by the proposal of the honourable member for Mitchell, which I support, it is, nevertheless, a band-aid approach to the problem. It does not in any way anticipate the sorts of circumstances that could arise. For example, I refer to a former German citizen who takes up Australian citizenship. German law is somewhat similar to ours, but even if it is not let us consider the hypothetical case that Germany passes legislation not in relation to Australia but generally that says that when a former German national born in Germany returns to that country that act of returning regains him his German citizenship. That would then re-confer upon that former national pensions which are forfeited as a consequence of losing German citizenship. How then would this apply? We would say that those people who have lived in Australia a long time would have within three years to go through a technical and formal procedure in order to regain Australian citizenship. This would apply even though their family and home were here and their return to Germany was for a long working holiday or even just a retirement holiday. In that regard the Minister's legislation is far too narrow in trying to achieve its particular objective but also it is totally inadequate in addressing the problems of the type I have instanced.

SPEECH.PARA: As I mentioned earlier, in the second reading debate, the nationality laws of countries are based upon their domestic law, and the rules governing nationality generally range from an automatic loss of former nationality on the acquisition of another to making it impossible to surrender a former nationality. We adopt the view-wrongly I believe-of automatic forfeiture however that other nationality is acquired. Some countries make it impossible for their citizens to lose their nationality and there is a large group of countries in the middle that make their citizens go through a formal act under the domestic law of the country whose citizenship they are giving up, so that the appearance of giving up citizenship at one of our citizenship ceremonies, not being an active law under the country of birth, is not regarded as the giving up of citizenship. As a consequence of that and our being a migrant receiving country, well over 60 per cent of overseas-born Australians who have taken up Australian citizenship have dual nationality. Thus those Australian citizens have a whole range of choices. I will not go through the advantages that they have because I outlined them in an earlier debate.

However, I want to emphasise the fact that someone with dual nationality who, for example, is going on a holiday to the United Kingdom, someone born in the United Kingdom or with United Kingdom citizenship because of some patriality arrangement, can leave Australia on an Australian passport, enter the United Kingdom on a United Kingdom passport, leave the United Kingdom on a United Kingdom passport and return to Australia on an Australian passport. Why should not that be so for someone who was born in Australia and who, in appropriate circumstances, applies for citizenship in another country? Earlier I instanced the sort of amendment that I would like to see made to the Australian Citizenship Amendment Bill, probably as clause 6A, to amend section 17 of the principal Act for the purpose of following the present procedure of having the act of acquiring the nationality or citizenship of a foreign country to cause the cessation of Australian citizenship but then to expand the area of exceptions.

The present exception is an act of marriage. A person does not forfeit Australian citizenship if that person acquires another citizenship as a consequence of an act of marriage. I would like to see added to that a further exception and that would be the acquisition of the nationality or citizenship of a prescribed foreign country. If we had prescribed Israel or Germany-I gave an hypothetical illustration-that problem would not arise. If the Australian Citizenship Act were amended in that way it would be necessary to the extent that it would continue to be desirable to have resumption of citizenship proceedings to cover those countries that had not been prescribed under our legislation. It would then be necessary for the changes to this section of the Act to be amended in a consequential way for sub-paragraphs (i) and (ii) of proposed paragraph 23AA (1) (a) to read:

(i) has done a voluntary and formal act, other than marriage, by virtue of which the person acquired the nationality or citizenship of a country other than a prescribed country or other than Australia; or
(ii) has done any act or thing-
(A) the sole or dominant purpose of which; and

(B) the effect of which, was or is to acquire the nationality or citizenship of a foreign country other than a prescribed country, being an act or thing that resulted in the person ceasing to be an Australian citizen;

I have urged the Minister to look at that matter. He touched on it very lightly in his response in an earlier debate. I conclude by quoting an article entitled `A note on the problem of dual nationality' by Anthony Bergin, a lecturer in politics at the Royal Australian Naval College. He stated:
Similarly the International Law Commission has not pursued the question and in 1954 decided to `defer any further consideration of multiple nationality and other questions relating to nationality'.
He continued:

One need not adopt too cynical a view of the effectiveness of international negotiations to suggest that the chances of any international conference abolishing dual nationality by adopting a single principle for the conferring of nationality at birth are fairly remote. Indeed it is for precisely this reason that it would appear far easier to obtain an agreement between two states that acknowledges the existence of dual nationality . . .

I urge that we should acknowledge the existence of dual nationality in a de jure way, not in a de facto way, so that we are able to seek to regulate the resulting difficulties rather than to discover some international formula which would radically restrict State powers to legislate in this area. I recognise, as did the author I have just quoted, that bilateral agreements may not be easy to negotiate with those major countries from which Australia takes migrants because very few of them are parties to the Hague convention in which there was a declaration of belief in single citizenship or nationality. Many of the countries which signed that convention have denied their commitment to that principle by having legislation that recognises dual nationality by virtue of the fact that citizenship of their countries is not forfeited automatically if a person takes up citizenship of another country.

I would have liked to see this band-aid measure replaced by a full-blooded change in our approach to the problems that affect a small number of people who have returned to Israel and who, by working in an Israeli hospital or living in an Israeli kibbutz, have had Israeli citizenship conferred upon them in circumstances where, but for that, they would have suffered detriment or where citizenship was conferred on them without their knowledge. People should not forfeit their citizenship in those circumstances. Because the amendment of the honourable member for Mitchell (Mr Cadman) is much wider and addresses the problem in a more comprehensive fashion than the Government's proposal, I strongly support the honourable member for Mitchell. However, I urge the Government on some future appropriate occasion to make some comprehensive amendments to this law so that Australians who are born here can have the same opportunities and benefits from dual citizenship.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Ruddock Mr P.M.

TALK.START.PARA: —I welcome very much the contribution of the Minister for Immigration and Ethnic Affairs (Mr Hurford) to the debate because it advanced the discussion somewhat. He provided information of which I was not previously aware and which has some influence, but not complete influence, on my thinking in relation to this matter. The Minister made it clear in his speech that he will exercise certain discretions that he has under section 32 of the Australian Citizenship Act and also under section 13 (9) relating to minors.
