He indicated in the letter he read into Hansard that he had written to Mr Mark Leibler that he will exercise that discretion in relation to those who lost their citizenship before 29 July 1981, that being the date upon which the Department of Immigration and Ethnic Affairs became aware that it was giving incorrect advice and presumably formed the view that the operation of the Nationality Act in Israel was such that it would put at risk the citizenship of Australians who had gone through the processes that I described earlier.

SPEECH.PARA: I do not believe that 29 July is such a magic date. It may well be that if somebody had gone to the Department after that date and asked for some advice he would have been given different advice. People do not overcome their ignorance of the law merely because departments, at a particular date, start giving correct advice. Very often they get advice from friends, people who have made inquiries at an earlier date, and organisations. It takes a while before the correct approach starts to become known. Certainly this question did not become a cause celebre amongst Australians in Israel until fairly recently.

If we are going to exercise a discretion under section 32 and section 13 (9) the operative date ought not to be 29 July 1981 because that is when the Department got its house in order. The operative date ought to be the date upon which people could reasonably be expected to know that their citizenship was at risk. I am also disappointed in the sense that we have come to this decision late in the day. The Minister knows that I have been raising this question for approximately 12 months. This was not an approach that the Minister was prepared to exercise in relation to the constituent who would not be affected by the provisions that we are proposing to implement in this case because she was resident again in Australia. However, she has had to take out permanent residence again. I would like to know whether or not her difficulty, as it was, might be addressed now by giving to her the same opportunity that the Minister is intending to give to others.

Amongst those people whom I met recently in Israel-one of the reasons I have an interest in this matter is because of the recent opportunity I have had to discuss the question in Israel-were representatives of the National Council of the Hitahtud Olei Australia. I know that they were more keen not to have their citizenship restored, as it were, by a fresh application but rather that the Minister operate as he is proposing by way of a declaratory statement. It would seem to me that it would go a long way towards overcoming the problems if the Minister were prepared to make the undertaking that he has given Mr Leibler, one that would be of wider operation than the amendments in 1984 or perhaps the amendments that are operating now. I hasten the Minister, if he is mindful, to look at a further compromise to raise with my colleague the honourable member for Mitchell (Mr Cadman), and that is the question of the undertaking he has given to Mr Leibler and as to whether a further undertaking can be given to extend the operation because I think that would address the immediate problem. It does not overcome the question of principle which I addressed in my first speech; that is, the problem that we have of two classes of citizen. Nevertheless, in terms of the large numbers of people involved-2,000 odd in Israel in particular-the Minister's willingness to extend the undertaking that he has given to Mr Leibler to 1984 or to these amendments in particular would address the problems of the large number of people that we have identified.

TALK.START.PARA: —I move:

SPEECH.PARA: Clause 7, page 4, lines 40 and 41, omit ``hardship or detriment of an economic nature'', substitute ``significant hardship or detriment''.

I shall be brief. I need to point out to the Minister for Immigration and Ethnic Affairs (Mr Hurford) and to place on record the concern I have raised with departmental officers regarding consistency between two aspects of the Bill. The Minister will be aware that people seeking to have their citizenship re-instated need to make a statement concerning the state of their finances. The Opposition feels that this is an improper and inconsistent approach and has moved this amendment to that effect.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Hurford The Hon C.J.

The threat might be in the form of a threat of physical injury or death or loss of liberty. As the honourable member for Mitchell (Mr Cadman) has had explained to him, there are good reasons, because of implications of consistency, as to why we are obliged to oppose the amendment. I am now in receipt of a letter from the Office of the Parliamentary Counsel about this issue, and I am prepared to make a copy available to the honourable member rather than to detain the Committee by reading it now.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Cadman Mr A.G.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Opposition opposes this clause on two grounds. The first ground is the Government's contention that to prevent confusion persons need not repeat their names when they make an oath or affirmation. The second ground on which we oppose the clause is that the Bill removes the need to renounce all other allegiances. Many aspects of this proposal have been debated in the House today. Despite what has been said, there has been no consultation with any section of the community. The only consultation that has taken place in regard to this proposal to remove the need for a person to say their name and the removal of the renunciation of all other allegiance was done in 1982 at the instigation of the honourable member for Goldstein (Mr Macphee).

SPEECH.PARA: The Government has not chosen to follow the recommendations of those consultations, which made clear that clarification of the oath was all that was needed rather than a removal of any words. Perhaps there could have been a reordering of the words, but certainly clarification was the most desirable resolution of the matter. Instead, the Government has chosen to follow the Human Rights Commission whose reports, beginning in 1982, consistently recommended that the renunciation of all other allegiance be removed from the Australian oath. There are many suggestions as to the way in which these provisions could be improved. The Minister is aware of those suggestions. The Minister has not seen fit to consult the coalition parties or the community, and that is deplorable. The Government is fully aware of the resistance of the Australian community when previously proposals were put forward by the Australian Labor Party to change the terms of the oath and the affirmation.

Why is there a need for secrecy on a matter such as this? Two weeks ago we were made aware of this legislation and we were made aware that there was going to be a change to the oath. I do not think that that is proper consultation, and I do not think that it is the way we should deal with an important matter such as the stating of a person's name in regard to Australian citizenship. It seems to me that this Government, on the one hand, is run by the Australian Council of Trade Unions and, in this instance, by the Human Rights Commission. It is a critical factor that a name must be stated. I reiterate it. It was not some flippant remark that was made by the Queen's Counsel from Tasmania, the honourable member for Denison (Mr Hodgman); it was a factual comment that he made. There is need for a personal identification by the candidate so that he is making a conscious act to link himself or herself with the substance of the solemn promise which follows his or her name. That is the purpose of any oath-so that there can be no doubt that that person is the person committing himself. It will not stand up that the removal of the name does not weaken the oath or affirmation. It certainly does so.

The alternatives that the Government could have looked for are so simple and so easy. There is no denial of cultural tradition by the renunciation of allegiance. I quote the first few words of the American oath:
. . . to support the Constitution of the United States and to renounce and abjure absolutely and entirely all allegiance and fidelity to a foreign place.

That is a positive statement followed by the renunciation. That is what the Opposition feels is by far the best approach to this matter. The Opposition has examined the matter closely and feels that alternative words, such as those laid down in the consultation report, could easily be developed with care and consideration. If it is possible, Mr Chairman, I wish to have printed in Hansard three alternative forms of oath. They are short, they are in type, and they should be easily reproduced.

TALK.START.PARA: —Unfortunately, the rules as laid down by the Speaker are that only tabulated matter can be incorporated.
—I will read them, and thus delay the House.
—Those are the rules. The honourable member may read them if he wishes.
—Mr Chairman, I think that this is an absurd ruling of the Speaker, and I wish that you would take it up with the Speaker.

—Order! The honourable member shall not reflect on rulings by the Speaker. He has been a member of this House for a long while and is aware of the rules laid down by the Chair in relation to incorporation of matter into Hansard.
—Mr Chairman, I do not reflect on the Speaker; I reflect on the ruling.
—Order! The honourable member for Mitchell will withdraw. It is not possible to separate the two. The honourable member will withdraw, and then he may read into Hansard what he wishes to illustrate.

—I withdraw. There are three possible forms of oath or affirmation which would resolve the problems that the Minister has raised-spuriously, I believe-about the need to reject the current form of words. It is a simple matter and yet some charging, innovative crusader on the Labor Party benches is going to change the whole concept of the Australian oath and affirmation. It is not good enough. We have a legal entity, and we have a character. We are proud of them. We cannot, as a nation, put ourselves in a position in which all of the disparate forces that have, from an external point, an influence on an Australian individual can be accommodated in our oath.

SPEECH.PARA: The simple fact is that I have commitments, other members have commitments, and other citizens have commitments. We understand that some of our citizens feel an obligation or commitment to a country of birth. We cannot allow that sense of an individual personal commitment to be reflected in our national life. We cannot, by the processes of citizenship, allow the continuation of circumstances in which an individual does not commit himself first of all to Australia.

The oath can be easily fixed. I am so disappointed with the Minister, and I am disappointed with the Speaker's ruling, Mr Chairman, because I think it would be of benefit to the Parliament to compare various forms of oath. Honourable members would then see that any problems can be easily resolved.

TALK.START.PARA: —The honourable member may table the documents.
—But they will not be printed.
—No.
—That is what I should like to see. The Opposition opposes this measure and will vote against it.
—Order! It being past 10.15 p.m., I shall report progress.

TALK.START.PARA: —Order! Did the honourable member for Mitchell intend to read those forms of oath into Hansard?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Sullivan Mrs K.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —I rise to draw attention to some statements that have been made in debate relevant to the subject of the changing of the wording of the oath and affirmation of allegiance. I do not intend to reiterate all the points I made in my speech on the second reading motion, but the reply that the Minister gave was quite unsatisfactory. The Minister's argument seems to revolve largely around the report from the National Consultations on Multiculturalism and Citizenship. I address my comments to the subject that the proposed oath and affirmation will remove the requirement of a candidate to renounce all other allegiances. I referred at the second reading stage to sections of the report on National Consultations, which I shall not now repeat. However, I want to extend some quotations from the report to point out how incorrect the Minister is when he indicates that this report is in any way responsible for this changing of the oath and affirmation. The report suggested two alternative forms of the oath of allegiance, and I quote them. The first suggestion is:

SPEECH.PARA: I pledge allegiance to and swear to uphold the laws of the Commonwealth of Australia and I renounce all other national legal obligations.
The second suggestion is:
I renounce and abandon all allegiances, if any, to any foreign state and swear-

And it continues. This suggested rewording, covers other points such as removal from the oath and the affirmation of reference to the Queen. Nevertheless, these national consultations did not support removal of that requirement to renounce other allegiances. The point is made in the body of the report that there was a suggestion that it was not good that the renunciation be as negative as it is in the present oath or affirmation.

If that were the sort of change that was being proposed I, for one, would not object to it. But that is not what is being proposed. It is being proposed that this renunciation be removed altogether; not that it be clarified, as recommended in the report; not that it be reworded so that it overcomes the objections-which I do not believe are there, but some people think are there-relating to renouncing cultural heritage. I do not know where this revision came from. For all I know it came out of the Minister's head. Or maybe it came from someone in his office, or somebody in his Department. But to my knowledge, this suggestion in this Bill does not appear in any public document dealing with this subject. Its origins are unknown to this House. The Minister in his second reading speech attempted to imply that the national consultations were in some way responsible for it. That is quite false.

TALK.START.PARA: —Misleading.

—It is misleading, as the honourable member for Petrie says. These national consultations were wide-ranging and thorough. One takes them as being a reflection of views expressed by people who had an interest and a concern in the matter. Their summary view is contrary to the view the Minister is putting. I think the Minister owes this Committee an explanation as to why he is putting forward an important change in the wording of the oath and affirmation of allegiance which is not supported by the national consultations or, so far as I know, by any general public wish. The origins of the change are, at this moment, anonymous. We deserve a better explanation than we have had as to why we should take this significant step.

SPEECH.PARA: I think it is important that there be either a statement pledging allegiance in positive terms or a rewording of the renunciation so as to remove any ambiguity. I believe that most people would argee. Very clearly, those in our migrant communities who were interested enough to involve themselves in changes to the Citizenship Act agree with me and not with the Minister.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Macphee The Hon I.M.

TALK.START.PARA: —I support entirely what my friend the honourable member for Moncrieff (Mrs Sullivan) has just said. The issue is quite simple. Two concepts are involved. One concept is the renunciation of other allegiances of a political character-allegiances to a sovereign other than the Australian sovereign. The second concept is a commitment to Australia. As a matter of logic, the law as it now stands asks people to renounce their other political allegiance and to accept and affirm their commitment to Australia as Australian nationals. It is true, as the Minister has said, that many people misunderstand the current wording. The current wording is `renounce all other allegiances'. As the Minister rightly says, many people whose first language is not English interpret `all other allegiances'-even when it is explained to them-to mean their entire cultural heritage. I have heard that and I accept that that is the perception people have. There is no question about that.

SPEECH.PARA: The advice that I was given by the forerunner of the committee from whose report the honourable member for Moncrieff has quoted was to reverse the order of the oath or affirmation. At some point or other, Cabinet records will reveal that that proposal had some attraction. That is all the Minister needs to do. One does not have to follow literal logic. One can simply reverse the order of the oath or affirmation and say the positive thing, which is the commitment to Australia, and then the negative thing, which is the renunciation of political allegiance to another country. We make a positive commitment to the Government of Australia, that is, to the Constitution. We commit ourselves under the Constitution to the sovereign of Australia and to the Constitution and the laws made pursuant to the Constitution of Australia. Having committed themselves to that, people understand that what they are then renouncing is something similar in relation to another country. They are not renouncing their culture. They are renouncing their political and national allegiance.

TALK.START.PARA: —And they know it.

—They do know it. There is no question. They have made a commitment to Australia in a political sense. They are in no way disowning their former cultural heritage. They know that when they make a renunciation it is as specific as the commitment they make to Australia. We all know that when they become Australians they enrich Australia so much with their cultural heritage. They would also know that they were not denying that heritage when they made a renunciation if we simply reversed the order.

SPEECH.PARA: I put it to the Minister that the honourable member for Moncrieff is right. No advice that this Government or the previous Government has received from the Australian community has been in support of what the Minister is now putting to this House. On the contrary, the advice is that if we reversed the order of the two concepts we would essentially achieve what is fair and acceptable to those who are asked to take the oath or make the affirmation to become citizens of this country. For that reason I urge the Minister not to force this matter to a vote tonight but to go away, do a bit of homework on the matter-it will not take long-and come back to us tomorrow with an amendment which reverses the order. We will be pleased to accept that amendment.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Hurford The Hon C.J.

TALKER.NAME: Mr HURFORD
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for Immigration and Ethnic Affairs)

TALK.START.PARA: —I thank the honourable member for Denison (Mr Hodgman) for not repeating the speech he made in the second reading debate. I know that he was anxious to speak, but the hour is late and we have been over this ground during the second reading debate. Perhaps I will now be allowed to close the debate on what I concede to be a very important subject, namely, the oath and affirmation taken and made at citizenship ceremonies.

SPEECH.PARA: The honourable member for Goldstein (Mr Macphee) admitted clearly that there was no question that there is confusion. I respect him. He put forward something constructive, which has not been done too often. However, it was done by the honourable member for Mitchell (Mr Cadman). In many ways I was sorry that he did not get the opportunity to read his three alternatives into the record because I can assure him, the honourable member for Goldstein and all other honourable members that I have given long and careful consideration, as has the Government, to what are the alternatives to what we are putting forward-the simple oath and affirmation which I will remind the House about in its new form before I resume my seat tonight. We have given a lot of attention to turning it around; but, with all the attention we have given it, we believe that we have not come up with something as dignified, simple and positive towards Australian citizenship as what will result after, I hope, this Bill goes through the House tonight.

Let me return to the honourable member for Moncrieff (Mrs Sullivan), who suggested that this wording might have come out of the top of my head. It has not. I draw to her attention that the first report of the Human Rights Commission, in August 1982, included much discussion on this matter. I do not know of anybody who took more soundings around the community about this matter at that time. My advice is that the feelings that were expressed to the Human Rights Commission on this subject at that time are still widely held in the community. The report of the Human Rights Commission ended with these words:
Accordingly the renunciation clause could with advantage be omitted from the oath.
Anything that turned the oath around would take away from its simplicity.

TALK.START.PARA: —You are not correctly referring to the report.

—I have mentioned the report on National Consultations on Multiculturalism and Citizenship of October 1982. That is what the honourable member is referring to. I am not suggesting that that report recommended taking out the renunciation altogether. It presented alternatives. The honourable member should listen to what I say. I have referred to the August 1982 Human Rights Commission report. The States were consulted about changes to the oath or affirmation in 1983-84. The only objection came from Queensland and Tasmania and was to the proposed removal of the reference to the Queen. There was nothing about the removal of the requirement to renounce all other allegiances. The significance of the renunciation phrase is that it draws the attention of new citizens to an underlying principle of Australian law that, as far as possible, Australian citizens should not be dual citizens. The phrase is ambiguous and unnecessary. Some people believe that it requires them to renounce their cultural background, which is what the honourable member for Goldstein has drawn to our attention.

SPEECH.PARA: Some Commonwealth citizens find renunciation confusing, as the Queen is also the head of state in their country of origin. How many members of this House-certainly members on this side of the chamber-who are sensitive enough to understand what I am saying, have gone to citizenship ceremonies and found an increasing number of British people renouncing, at the beginning of their oath or affirmation, the Queen of England. That is an absurd suggestion and that is what the Opposition is putting forward. The phrase is essentially symbolic. Whether or not new citizens lose their former citizenship does not depend upon Australian laws but upon the laws of their former country. Why does the Opposition want that renouncing elsewhere? It is not going to make any difference to them. How many British people, having renounced their Queen of England, have kept their United Kingdom passports? That does not only apply to the Brits, it applies to Italians, Americans and many others.

Over a million Australian citizens who migrated here from countries as diverse as Britain, Canada, New Zealand, France, Hungary, Greece and Poland still retain their former citizenship under the laws of those countries even though they renounced their former allegiance when they became Australian citizens. One person who I hope will not join with the Opposition in voting against this particular change is the honourable member for Sturt (Mr Wilson) who has-I respect him for doing so-raised the whole question of dual citizenship. Canada has been through it. I will be studying how Canada has accepted it and how it has overcome the particular consular problems. Certainly if one has any inkling of a thought that perhaps dual citizenship in a country like this would be appropriate, one would not want to write that in in any way-turning it upside down or in any form-and if I might address the honourable member for Goldstein, one would not want the words renouncing any other form of allegiance to anything. General support from the ethnic community is there and those countries with which we feel so close-the 75 per cent from Anglo-Saxon and Celt backgrounds such as the United Kingdom, Canada and New Zealand-contain no renunciation phrase in their oath of allegiance.

I have looked at the options. I have also taken counsel from previous debates. In conclusion I draw the attention of the Committee to what went on in the Senate the last time the oath was before it. Senator Crichton-Browne, a Liberal, who is not exactly a raving socialist, said: `Why does the renunciation of all other allegiances remain?'. Going across the spectrum, Senator Chipp said: `The present renunciation of allegiance is ambiguous. People are being asked to renounce their previous nationality, their previous language or their culture.' All of these people are important when it comes to getting the numbers. Finally, Senator Harradine said: `I think citizenship is a two-way thing. Firstly, Australia should have regard to the sensibilities of those who wish to become Australian citizens. Thus at some stage there is a need for the words to be amended. I think that is generally agreed around the chamber.' He said, and I thought it was true because I thought honourable members opposite had more sense than they are showing tonight: `I believe that the Opposition also has the view that a tidying up of the actual words would be appropriate'. I conclude by reading to the Committee how simple and dignified will be the oath, as will be the affirmation:

I swear by almighty God that I will be faithful and bear true allegiance to Her Majesty Elizabeth the Second, Queen of Australia, Her heirs and successors according to law, and that I will faithfully observe the laws of Australia and fulfil my duties as an Australian citizen.
What could be better than that, more positive than that and more sensible than that? I trust that the Committee will support that sensible oath.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Sullivan Mrs K.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —I know that there are certain arrangements about time tonight and I therefore rise not to be vexatious but to put the Minister for Immigration and Ethnic Affairs (Mr Hurford) straight. I do not even rise in indignation because he has insulted my intelligence, but because the speech he has just made contains misstatements. He took it upon himself to suggest that I might look at the August 1982 report of the Human Rights Commission on the Australian Citizenship Act 1948. I refer the Minister to Hansard tomorrow where he might see that I quoted from that report in my speech today. The quote was this:

SPEECH.PARA: The Commission notes the Minister's announcement-
that is the former Minister for Immigration and Ethnic Affairs, the honourable member for Goldstein (Mr Macphee)-

that the wording of the oath will be changed to stress that persons are not re-nouncing all cultural ties with their former country. Depending on its precise formulation, this could substantially meet the points made by the Commission.

In other words, the Commission said that, if a wording was found that made it clear that the renunciation did not mean a renunciation of cultural heritage, it would accept that as being adequate. I suggest that the Minister should read the report himself instead of telling me to read the report. He did not know I had read the report because he did not listen to my speech and he was not properly briefed on it.

As a final postscript, on the subject of including names in the oath and affirmation, I want to know when this Government is going to suggest a constitutional referendum in respect of our oath and affirmation when we are sworn in as members of the House so that we do not have to say our names all together either, because of the so-called cacophony it creates.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Macphee The Hon I.M.

TALK.START.PARA: —I will be brief. I agree again with what the honourable member for Moncrieff (Mrs Sullivan) has said. I point out to the Minister for Immigration and Ethnic Affairs (Mr Hurford) that the three senators whom he quoted were all finding fault with the current form of renunciation, which is our concern as well. To pander to those people who happen to have come from another country which has a concept of sovereignty and which happens to have the same sovereign, as is the case with Australia, is again adding to the confusion rather than trying to resolve it. It is terribly important when we word the oath or affirmation that we point out that the sovereign of Australia is an utterly different concept, even if it is the same person, as the sovereign of another country.
—Hear, hear! That is fundamental.

—That really is a fundamental point. We all know that if perchance under the laws of the United Kingdom Her Majesty ceased to be sovereign that would have no impact whatever on the laws of Australia and her utterly different role as the Queen of Australia. That was dramatically illustrated when the Americans invaded Granada and the British Prime Minister was alleged to have been put out by the fact that Her Majesty did not inform the British Prime Minister of the Americans' decision. Her Majesty's position, as we understood it, was that she was informed by her Governor-General of Granada. It was as Queen of Granada that she was being advised by her Governor-General of Granada and it had absolutely nothing to do with the United Kingdom. It is terribly important that we understand that that is the concept of sovereignty which we are talking about.
—Gough Whitlam understood it.
—He gave attention to detail which I am bound to say, with respect to the Minister, has not distinguished his performance on this point.
—Absolute rubbish.

—It is not. There is this whole body of advice which the Minister has not taken notice of. He has not given us one reason why he has not now adopted a simple formula of words. I could draft it for him in five minutes. He should not say it is complicated because it is not. That simple form of words would renounce the political allegiance that other people have. The question of dual citizenship can and should be debated by this Parliament. We look forward to a document on that in the future. We cannot now take it by the backdoor in a measure of this nature. The Minister is saying, and he is correct, that there is almost a de facto dual citizenship because of the laws of other countries, and in the case of many of them that is so. The Minister said in his second reading speech that there are some 20 or 30 countries like us which say that we deny that. Let us have a proper debate about dual citizenship by all means, but this particular amendment should not be the avenue for creating what amounts to a legal dual citizenship.

That the clause be agreed to.

DEBATE.SUB1.TITLE: ANZUS Treaty-Member for O'Connor-Dumping of Hazardous and Dangerous Goods

PROCTEXT.PARA: Motion (by Mr Hurford) proposed:
That the House do now adjourn.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Hodgman The Hon W.M.

TALK.START.PARA: —I recently had the honour to visit the United States of America which, as all honourable members will know, is party to the ANZUS Treaty which is the fundamental defence treaty for our nation. It is protocol when one is outside Australia not to criticise the Government or the Ministers of one's home country for, I believe, the very simple and proper reason that, first, they do not have the opportunity to make an immediate reply and, secondly, it is divisive to the national interest of Australia to have internal political matters discussed outside the country. I took the opportunity in the United States where I was indeed grateful for the assistance provided, firstly, by the United States Ambassador to Australia, Ambassador Lane of the United States Embassy, secondly, our own Department of Foreign Affairs which I found extraordinarily helpful and co-operative and, thirdly, those involved in the United States Administration who gave me the opportunity to meet and speak with people far higher in station than one in my position would normally have the opportunity of speaking with in Australia.

SPEECH.PARA: I say in passing that it is about time that a few home truths came back to this Parliament about what the United States really thinks about this Government and Australia in 1986 in view of what has occurred over the last three years. The ANZUS Treaty is fundamental and critical to the defence of this country. Over the last three years, we have seen the ANZUS Treaty white-anted and dishonoured by the Hawke socialist Government. In Moscow corner opposite, there are members who would be delighted to see the ANZUS Treaty torn up, delighted to see United States bases in Australia terminated and delighted to do anything they could which weakens the stand of the United States and strengthens the hand of the Soviet Union.

Before my remarks are written off by those fellow travellers-it is about time that term came back into the Australian political dictionary-and fifth columnists who care nothing for the national security of this country, I wish to place on record my gratitude for the fact that I was able to meet people of the calibre of Colonel Samuel J. Watson III, Deputy Assistant to the Vice-President of the United States for National Security Affairs, Mr Paul Wolfowitz, who has just been appointed United States Ambassador to Indonesia, Mr Richard Armitage, Assistant Secretary of Defense, and people such as Dr Craig Dunkerley, Dr Bruce Burton and others including Mr Surber, Director of Pacific Islands Affairs, who will shortly be visiting Australia. I was able to talk to people who were free to talk to me in a way that, sadly, they are no longer free to talk to the Hawke socialist Government.

Let me put these facts on record and let there be no misunderstanding about them. The credibility of this country as a true and faithful ally of the United States is still in tatters following the MX missile decision of Prime Minister Hawke. Those people just do not know where to turn.

TALK.START.PARA: —A disaster.

—It is a disaster. They do not know where to turn. I remind honourable members of reports in the New York Times with headlines such as `Australia reneges on treaty commitment' and `Premier blames split in party', with a photo of the Prime Minister of Australia. Those were headlines read by over 50 million Americans in journals syndicated right throughout the nation.

SPEECH.PARA: Secondly, the Americans are not certain what they can tell Australia that will not filter through to New Zealand. I have to say quite bluntly that Australia's greatest foreign affairs mistake in decades, and a tragedy at that, was to treat the New Zealand fiasco as simply a matter between New Zealand and the United States.

TALK.START.PARA: —You make Joe McCarthy look like a progressive.

—It is all right, comrade; we will deal with you later. The fact is that it is not a bipartisan dispute between the United States and New Zealand. This was a tripartite defence treaty, like a three-fold cord. If one takes away one of the three-fold cord strands, great strain is placed on the remaining two. The Minister at the table is an apologist for the Soviet and an opponent of the United States.
—Order! The honourable member's time has expired.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Campbell Mr G.

TALK.START.PARA: —My receiving the call, colleagues, is a demonstration of faction power. Last night in this House I was giving a dissertation on the hypocrisy-I guess that is unparliamentary; I will say machinations-of the honourable member for O'Connor (Mr Tuckey). I was caught short by the expiry of time on that occasion. The reason why I became involved in this matter was that many of the local government areas that he now represents have been writing to me very concerned about the amendments to the Interstate Road Transport Act. They have been so thoroughly misinformed by his mischievous antics that they are genuinely concerned. I have been able to write to them to tell them that the Bill was not opposed in this House by the Liberal Party of Australia and that it was supported in principle by every State in Australia.

SPEECH.PARA: I reached the stage last night at which I had pointed out that the honourable member for O'Connor had gone to Esperance to try the same sort of trick that he had tried everywhere else, that is, to convene a meeting at which he was the only authority present. But, this time, as I said last night, he failed because of the straight shooting of the State Minister for Transport, Julian Grill. This time when the honourable member for O'Connor got to the meeting he found out that everybody wanted to hear all of the speakers, which was an unusual situation for him to be in. This time the honourable member for O'Connor entered the meeting quivering with rage because he lost the debate. He lost the debate because he so heckled Mr Grill and other speakers that the truckies present began to move out. They just did not want to listen to that sort of diatribe. He lost the debate because he is not familiar with free speech. He likes the one-sided forum; that is what he is familiar with.

He lost the debate because the independent chairman, local Primary Industry Association official, Mr Tony Overheu, a former key member of the then Country Party-summed up the evening by comparing the track record of achievements of the Western Australian Transport Minister, Julian Grill, with the negativity of the honourable member for O'Connor. Mr Overheu declared, more in sorrow than in anger, I should add, that the issue really became one of credibility. He further declared that, while Mr Grill on his past record was very credible, the honourable member for O'Connor was not. This was the considered opinion of the leader of the PIA in the Esperance area, a one time candidate for the National Party of Australia, a man very well regarded, who certainly has my respect.

The honourable member for O'Connor congratulated the ladies of the Goulburn Valley Wives Trucking Support Group for their efforts on behalf of their husbands and the industry. I have no wish to detract from those congratulatory comments. I simply choose to congratulate those people at the Esperance meeting who listened to both the Federal Liberal member for O'Connor and the State Labor Minister and who clearly acknowledged who had won that debate. There is no doubt that it will be a long time before the honourable member for O'Connor goes back to the Esperance area, an area which he used to represent in this Parliament.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Tickner Mr R.E.

TALK.START.PARA: —I wish to speak tonight about a very disturbing world-wide trend which has involved the dumping of hazardous and dangerous goods on the world market and which has caused massive suffering and death to people in many Third World countries. One of the very welcome developments that have occurred to combat this very disturbing trend is the development of Consumer Interpol. Of course, what happened, particularly in the 1970s, was that there was growing evidence of the dumping of these hazardous products and the export of dangerous technologies and toxic wastes on these Third World countries.

SPEECH.PARA: As a result of the internationalisation of product marketing, consumer organisations in the form of people power, have been organised on a world-wide basis. This organisation has taken the form of the International Organisation of Consumer Unions which now has 115 members in 55 countries. The International Organisation of Consumer Unions has three main goals. The first is to support members with information and training. The second is to expand the consumer movement around the world. The third is to represent consumers' interests at the United Nations and other international bodies. The overriding concern of the International Organisation of Consumer Unions has been to promote fair practices and social justice in the world market-place.

As I mentioned, the practice of dumping has been, on commercial and on any reasonable moral, ethical grounds, a most reprehensible one which has caused massive death and suffering in so many countries. One example of this dumping has been the result to the survey in 1979 in several ASEAN countries which showed that a number of trans-national food companies were marketing sweetened condensed milk products as instant food, although the use of such products had been banned in Britain as long ago as 1911.

A second very disturbing example was the revelation in 1972 that 400 Iraqis had died and 5,000 more had been hospitalised after eating wheat and barley imported from the United State of America. A further example was the 1,000 water buffalo that suddenly died in Egypt after exposure to agricultural chemicals manufactured in the United States and which had been exported despite a United States prohibition. ANSWER.TO.QON.TITLE: World Bank and International Monetary Fund: Australian Labor Party Policy

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Peacock The Hon A.S.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Treasurer, upon notice, on 19 September 1985:

QUESTION.PARA: (1) What actions has the Government taken in the World Bank and the International Monetary Fund in accordance with Labor Party policy to support (a) strengthened representation of Third World countries and (b) policies designed to assist access to official credit for developing countries.

(2) At what times, in accordance with that policy, has the Government opposed imposition by these bodies of contractionary fiscal and monetary policies on third World countries experiencing severe economic difficulties.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Keating The Hon P.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —The answer to the honourable member's question is as follows:

ANSWER.PARA: (1) (a) The Government endorses the expansion of World Bank and International Monetary Fund membership where the countries in question meet the requirements of those institutions.

(b) Australia is supportive of continued expansion in the activities of the World Bank and has indicated that it would support a general capital increase for the Bank. Australia is also a strong supporter of the Bank's concessional lending arm, the International Development Association (IDA), which provides funds to the world's poorest countries. This year Australia made a voluntary contribution to IDA of $A60m. We consider that the Bank's primary aim should continue to be the provision of long-term project-oriented finance for developing countries. We have also supported the established role of the IMF as basically a revolving short-term fund. Within that framework Australia has supported the continuation of the temporary enlargement of its financial resources to meet the abnormally large and widespread payments imbalances being experienced.

(2) As its primary concern is the provision of long term project-oriented development finance, the World Bank is not ordinarily associated with the conditionality applying to the broad settings of fiscal, monetary and foreign exchange policies. The basic nature of IMF programs is that they are designed to support and facilitate adjustment. Such adjustments are made necessary by the circumstances of the country concerned, not by the Fund. What the Fund can do is advise on the appropriate adjustment and give financial support to the country so as to minimise the burdens involved in adjustment. The aim of Fund programs is to lessen imbalances and thereby foster sustainable growth in the medium and long term; programs have increasingly focused on structural adjustment as well as on demand management. This Government has supported the evolution of Fund programs consistent with its basic charter and operations which provide that the Fund shall respect the domestic, social and political policies of members and the particular circumstances of members.

ANSWER.TO.QON.TITLE: Consumer Products: Death Statistics

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Tickner Mr R.E.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Attorney-General, upon notice, on 29 November 1985:

QUESTION.PARA: (1) Are statistics kept by the Commonwealth relating to deaths and injuries associated with individual consumer products.
(2) Is he able to say whether statistics are kept by each State and Territory.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Bowen The Hon L.F.

TALK.START.PARA: —The answer to the honourable member's question is as follows:

ANSWER.PARA: (1) It has been recognised that Australia lacks comprehensive statistical data on consumer product-related deaths and injuries at both the National and State and Territory levels. Some data is collected in a number of jurisdictions but is not closely co-ordinated nor slanted towards product identification or the specific prevention of deaths and injuries resulting from use of consumer products.

A major initiative has been commenced involving the Child Accident Prevention Foundation of Australia (CAPFA), the Commonwealth Government and the States and Territories to rectify this lack of co-ordinated and comprehensive data in relation to injury surveillance and prevention. The substantial contribution made by the CAPFA must be acknowledged in this regard.

The first step is to undertake a pilot study to demonstrate the perceived benefits of such a system and this proposal received strong support from all Consumer Affairs Ministers at recent meeting of their Standing Committee. My colleague, the Minister for Health, Dr Blewett, has been given the responsibility to co-ordinate the Commonwealth's interest. I am advised that preliminary work to establish the pilot national injury surveillance and prevention system commenced in late 1985.

ANSWER.TO.QON.TITLE: Consumer Product Standards

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Tickner Mr R.E.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Attorney-General, upon notice, on 29 November 1985:

QUESTION.PARA: Do uniform codes and standards exist throughout Australia for (a) production packaging, (b) labelling, (c) unit price marketing and (d) advertising for (i) food, (ii) drugs and (iii) other products and services supplied to consumers; if not, what Commonwealth initiatives are underway to bring about this uniformity.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Bowen The Hon L.F.

TALK.START.PARA: —The answer to the honourable member's question is as follows:

ANSWER.PARA: Production packaging codes and standards for food and drugs are mainly prescribed in Commonwealth, State and Territory legislation dealing with health and weights and measures matters.

In respect of food products, I am advised that the Model Food Act and Regulations provide, inter alia, for standards of hygiene for the preparation, processing and packaging of food. All State and Territory governments are committed to the rapid introduction of the provisions of the model. In addition, State and Territory Weights and Measures legislation generally controls the production packaging of consumer goods, including food. This legislation is based on model legislation developed by the Standing Committee on Packaging. Packaging is therefore now essentially uniform in respect of packing in prescribed quantities, quantity statements, marking of unit price (price per kilogram) and size of letters and figures in marking on packages.

In respect of drug packaging, I am advised that an appropriate level of safety and uniformity is achieved through the forum of the Australian Drug Evaluation Committee. The package of all new drugs intended for over-the-counter sales is evaluated as part of the drug evaluation process. Packages are tested against accepted pharmacopoeial standards.

Model legislation which deals with deception in packaging, e.g. the free space permitted within a package, has been developed by the Standing Committee on Packaging. This model has been fully adopted by NSW only.

A recent initiative has been taken by Commonwealth/State/Territory Ministers in establishing a Working Party to examine all weights and measures legislation, including deceptive packaging, with a view to identifying and eliminating any remaining differences in legislation and administration.

The Model Food Act and Regulations contain extensive food labelling requirements and this model legislation has been or is being adopted by all States and Territories. The Commonwealth is presently co-ordinating arrangements to finalise the introduction of the model.

In respect of therapeutic goods, including drugs, I understand that the Therapeutic Goods Advisory Committee has developed, in close consultation with industry, governments and user groups, a final draft of the Therapeutic Goods Order for the general requirements for labels for therapeutic goods. This Order is expected to be considered for adoption under the Therapeutic Goods Act in the near future. The individual States and Territories have agreed, in principle, to draft complementary legislation to ensure the requirements are uniformally applied throughout Australia.
The labelling of general consumer goods is also substantially uniform resulting from the adoption by the States and Territories of model legislation for weights and measures.
Advertising standards for food, drugs and other consumer products and services are controlled by legislative requirements and self-regulatory codes.

At the Commonwealth level, the main sources of legislative controls on advertising standards are the Broadcasting and Television Act and the Trade Practices Act. The Australian Broadcasting Tribunal administers advertising standards which cover a range of matters including alcoholic liquor, personal products and advertisements directed at children. Bans on the advertising of cigarettes and tobacco products on radio and television and control over the advertising of therapeutic goods are monitored by the Tribunal.
The Trade Practices Act provides a standard for advertisements by prohibiting misleading and deceptive conduct generally as well as certain unfair practices.

The Media Council of Australia is responsible for the advertising industry's system of self regulation which comprises codes of conduct i.e. code of ethics, therapeutic goods code, cigarette code, alcoholic beverages code, code for slimming preparations, treatments, appliances, and a domestic insecticide code.

The Trade Practices Commission, under Section 88 (1) of the Trade Practices Act, authorises voluntary advertising codes submitted by the Media Council of Australia provided the Commission is satisfied that such codes are likely to result in net public benefit.

ANSWER.TO.QON.TITLE: Australian Law Reform Commission

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Tickner Mr R.E.

TALK.START.PARA: —The answer to the honourable member's question is as follows:

ANSWER.PARA: The powers of the Law Reform Commission, which are provided in the Law Reform Commission Act 1973, have not been significantly altered since 1983. However on 21 February 1984 the Attorney-General gave the Commission a Community Law Reform Reference for the Australian Capital Territory which provided that the Commission could work on small projects relating to ACT laws without the need for a further separate Reference. The program also provides for the Commission to request specific References on more significant matters.

Since March 1983 the Attorney-General has given the Commission five References, in addition to the Community Law Reform Program. ANSWER.TO.QON.TITLE: State Police Forces: Intelligence Gathering

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Tickner Mr R.E.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Attorney-General, upon notice, on 29 November 1985:

QUESTION.PARA: (1) Is he able to say whether State police forces engage in security intelligence information gathering activities; if so, which section of each State police force are engaged in such activities.
(2) Is any information gained passed on to the Australian Security Intelligence Organisation.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Bowen The Hon L.F.

TALK.START.PARA: —The answer to the honourable member's question is as follows:

ANSWER.PARA: ASIO co-operates with State police forces in accordance with section 19 of the Australian Security Intelligence Organisation Act 1979.

The matter was discussed in the 1984 Report of the Royal Commission on Australia's Security and Intelligence Agencies, in particular in Chapters 5 (`Politically Motivated Violence') and 8 (`Assessment and Communication of Intelligence'). The Report observed that agreements regulating the relationship between ASIO and State police forces are in force between the Commonwealth and most States and the Northern Territory, and that these agreements provide a desirable mantle of authority for and clarify the extent of ASIO/police relations (paragraph 8.66). The form of the agreements is at page 379 of the Report.

The Report stated that where agreements exist, communication of intelligence by ASIO and by police is in accordance with those agreements, and that where agreements do not exist the communication of intelligence is within the limits of the terms of the agreements (paragraph 8.61). To a large degree, dealings between ASIO and police relate to terrorism and the protection of holders of high office (paragraph 8.59).
The Report found that co-operation between ASIO and the various police forces is mutually advantageous (paragraph 8.66) and that relations appear to be generally satisfactory (paragraph 8.62).

ANSWER.TO.QON.TITLE: Special Taxation Problems: Performing and Creative Arts Workers

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Tickner Mr R.E.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Treasurer, upon notice, on 29 November 1985:

QUESTION.PARA: (1) Do performing and creative arts workers experience special taxation problems arising from fluctuations in incomes.
(2) If so, what action has he taken to resolve these special problems.
(3) What other occupations experience special taxation problems arising from fluctuations in incomes.
(4) What problems would arise if tax averaging were available to all taxpayers.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Keating The Hon P.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —The answer to the honourable member's question is as follows:

ANSWER.PARA: In answering the honourable member's questions I recall that the Government has been engaged for some time in undertaking a major review of the Australian tax system. This unfortunately, has restricted the resources available to tackle particular income tax issues confronting occupational groups such as performing and creative arts people. The Government has received representations from such people in the past concerning their income tax liability in the face of fluctuating incomes and requesting tax relief along the lines of tax averaging afforded to primary producers, or through the abnormal income provisions of the Income Tax Assessment Act, which apply to authors, artists and inventors. In this regard, I would point out that there already exists a tax deduction schedule designed specifically for use by actors, variety artists and other entertainers. This schedule recognizes that such people can have periods of unemployment between engagements and that they also incur expenses which are allowable deductions.

The Government has given an undertaking to extend averaging to sportspersons whose incomes fluctuate during relatively short careers and to artists in the performing and visual arts. This will be considered further in the forthcoming budgetary processes.
Tax averaging entails a considerable revenue cost and can give rise to some undesirable effects. The Government believes that these reasons require the scope of tax averaging to be confined.

ANSWER.TO.QON.TITLE: Integrated Pest Management and Biological Control

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Tickner Mr R.E.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister for Science, upon notice, on 29 November 1985:

QUESTION.PARA: (1) What research is being carried out into integrated pest management and what biological control is being carried out by (a) the Commonwealth and (b) the State governments.
(2) What was the level of funding allocated to such programs in 1985-86.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Jones The Hon B.O.

TALK.START.PARA: —The answer to the honourable member's question is as follows:

ANSWER.PARA: (1a) The following research programs of CSIRO are concerned with integrated pest management and biological control, either directly or through background research of relevance in developing improved strategies:

Aim: To study the interactions between disease-causing micro-organisms (including nematodes) and insects in order to develop environmentally acceptable means of pest control; to provide a quarantine service for screening imported insects for pathogens; and to advice on the rearing of disease-free insects.

Pathogenic nematodes have been used to control sirex wood wasp in pine plantations, blackcurrant borer, and black vine weevil. Studies are now focused on pathogenic fungi for the control of aphids, wingless grasshopper, sugar can grub, banana weevil borer, and rice stem borer.

Aim: To study the behaviour of insects with a view to obtaining biological and chemical information, basic to the development of specific and environmentally acceptable pest-control methods and an understanding of the biology of insects.

Targets of current research include cabbage white butterfly, sheep blowfly, lightbrown apple moth, oriental fruit moth, codling moth, Heliothis species, a number of armyworms, and Queensland fruit fly.
Ecology and Control of Insect Pests of Stored Grain

Aim: To search for new or better methods of controlling stored grain pests. Nations that import Australian grain have come to demand complete freedom from insect infestation. As all the important grain pests have now developed varying degrees of resistance to all pesticides that are fully acceptable internationally for use with stored grain, the need for new control methods is critical.

This program, as well as studying insecticides, is investigating a number of non-insecticidal approaches to grain-pest control. These include high-temperature disinfestation, fumigation, and storage under controlled atmospheres, and the integration of the various control strategies into programs for managing the major pest species.
Ecology and Control of Insect Pests of Crops and Pastures

Aim: To study insects in crop and pasture ecosystems to gain an improved understanding of insect biology, ecology and dispersal, evaluate their pest status, and devise effective and environmentally acceptable measures for their control.
The pests under study include the cotton boll weevil, armyworms, phylloxera of grapes, fruit flies, scale insects, and lucerne aphids.
Biological Control of Aquatic and Terrestrial Weeds
Aim: To study and assess overseas, and subsequently establish in Australia, effective agents for biological control of introduced weeds of economic importance.

Current programs are concerned with weeds of European, South African and American origin. They include skeleton weed, heliotrope, St John's wort, ragwort, thistles, spiny emex, mimosa, silver leaf nightshade, salvinia, water hyacinth, water lettuce and alligator weed.
Ecology and Control of Dung and Dung-breeding Flies
Aim: To determine the major factors influencing the abundance of buffalo fly and bush fly, both of which breed in cattle dung, and to study the ecology of arthropod fauna of dung.

The major objective of the program is to bring about reductions in populations of these flies through biological and other means. A second aim is reduction of dung accumulation in pastures through the introduction of dung-burying beetles.
Ecology and Control of Arthropods Breeding on Livestock

Aim: To study the biology, ecology, behaviour and genetics of flies and other arthropods breeding on livestock with the broad objective of developing management strategies to obtain regional control or eradication of the pest species. The pests under study are the sheep blowfly, screw-worm fly, and ticks of cattle and other animals.
Aim: To contribute to the biology control of weeds by studying the ecological relationships of major weeds. The weeds at present under study are skeleton weed and some of the thistles.

(1b) The State Governments are involved in varying degrees with integrated pest management and biological control, sometimes in association with CSIRO. Comprehensive information and funding levels are not available.
(2) The level of funding allocated in 1985-86 to the programs described in part (1a) of the answer is $8,600,000.

ANSWER.TO.QON.TITLE: Qantas International Flight Landing at Tullamarine Airport

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Burr Mr M.A.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister for Aviation, upon notice, on 11 February 1986:

QUESTION.PARA: (1) Is it fact that on 17 September 1985 a Qantas international flight was given permission to land at Tullamarine Airport while, at the same time, an Ansett domestic flight was given permission to take-off on a bisecting runway.
(2) Did the pilot of the Qantas flight take evasive action to avoid what he considered a dangerous situation.

(3) Was the landing by the Qantas flight and the take-off by the Ansett flight authorised by air traffic controllers working under the new provisions for simultaneous aircraft movements on intersecting runways announced by him in June 1983.
(4) Did the air traffic controllers involved say there was no danger in the operation.
(5) Will his Department conduct an inquiry into the event; if not, why not.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Morris The Hon P.F.

TALK.START.PARA: —The answer to the honourable member's question is as follows:

ANSWER.PARA: (1) No-the Qantas flight approaching Tullamarine had not been given permission to land. The Ansett aircraft, a Fokker Friendship, was given permission to take-off from Runway 34. The Air Traffic Controller intended to wait until this aircraft had passed the intersection with Runway 27 before issuing a landing clearance to the Qantas flight approaching that runway.

(2) No. The pilot of the Qantas aircraft elected to carry out a go around because he considered that there may have been insufficient separation between the two aircraft. The go around is not regarded as an evasive manoeuvre and it does not involve any abrupt changes to the aircraft flight path.
(3) No. These procedures were not being used at the time of the occurrence.

(4) The report provided by the Air Traffic Controller did not make reference to any danger in the operation. However I am informed by my department that in fact no danger to the aircraft or their occupants existed.
(5) An inquiry was commenced by my Bureau of Air Safety Investigation on the day of the occurrence. The inquiry found that the safety of operations had not been jeopardised.

ANSWER.TO.QON.TITLE: Joint Military Exercises

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Coleman Mr W.P.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister for Defence, upon notice, on 12 February 1986:

QUESTION.PARA: What is the additional cost to the Department of Defence of conducting separate joint military exercises with the armed forces of New Zealand as distinct from conducting combined ANZUS military exercises.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Beazley The Hon K.C.

TALK.START.PARA: —The answer to the honourable member's question is as follows:

ANSWER.PARA: The first ANZUS exercise to be affected by the US policy not to continue exercising with NZ was SEA EAGLE 85-1. As host, Australia cancelled the exercise and rescheduled a new exercise FLYING FISH 85-1, to which NZ was not invited. As an alternative, NZ was invited to participate in the Australian exercise INTREPID GUNNER. This invitation was accepted, and the exercise was subsequently renamed TASMAN LINK. There was no additional cost to Australia.

The additional cost of converting Exercise K85 into the maritime exercise CORAL SEA with the US and the field exercise TASMAN WARRIOR with New Zealand is difficult to assess. The two exercises cost a total of $19m, $0.3m more than estimated for K85, and that increase may be partly attributed to splitting the original exercise.

The increased New Zealand participation in Australian exercises does add to the cost of those exercises. However, the Australian and New Zealand Defence Forces have an offset arrangement whereby costs of collective training are balanced at a biennial reconciliation.

ANSWER.TO.QON.TITLE: Article in the Age Concerning a Department of Defence Courier

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Price Mr L.R.S.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister of Defence, upon notice, on 18 February 1986:

QUESTION.PARA: (1) Has his attention been drawn to an article in the Age by Kate Legge concerning a courier employed by his Department.
(2) Does his Department have standards of dress to which employees must conform; if so, what are they.
(3) Has there been any breach of standards by the employee mentioned in the article; if so, what action has been taken.

(4) Did the employee disclose publicly that he was responsible for carrying classified and other security documents; if so, (a) does this constitute a breach of security and (b) what action is being taken.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Beazley The Hon K.C.

TALK.START.PARA: —The answer to the honourable member's question is as follows:

ANSWER.PARA: (2) No. The Department has, however, issued the following guidelines on standards of dress for its civilian staff:
Standards of dress for defence civilian staff

There are no statutory requirements concerning the dress and appearance of officers while on duty. Subject to the need to wear uniforms or to wear clothing for safety reasons, dress and appearance is a matter for the judgment of the individual officer.
In coming to this judgment, staff should bear in mind the following factors:
a. the geographic location and climatic conditions of their workplace;
b. the degree and type of interface with the public;
c. community standards in similar work environments; and

d. the extent to which staff are employed in an integrated Service/civilian environment; for example, civilians employed at a Service base should take into account the standards of dress observed by Service personnel undertaking comparable functions.
Advice should be sought from other officers or supervisors where doubt exists.
(4) (a) and (b) No. If the employee had disclosed such information this in itself would not have constituted a breach of security.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Bowen The Hon L.F.

TALK.START.PARA: —On 29 November 1985 (Hansard, page 4021), Mr Ian Cameron asked the following question, without notice:

ANSWER.PARA: Is it a fact, as reported in the Press, that the Government intends to amend the Bill of Rights Bill in the Senate and infringe on States rights to attempt to enforce Federal laws on State redistributions? If so, will the Senate be included in the Government's desire for one vote one value, as a senator in New South Wales requires 281,000 votes, in Queensland 176,000 votes and in Tasmania only 20,000 votes?
The answer to the honourable member's question is as follows:

As the honourable member is aware, the Australian Bill of Rights Bill, as read a third time by this House on 15 November 1985, does not override State laws. As I noted in my second reading speech, this was in order to achieve if possible a co-operative approach to human rights protection.

It is true that the very large discrepancies which exist between the sizes of electorates in certain States represent the gravest imposition on the most basic political rights of the citizen, and are to be deplored. But even in respect of those matters, I am firmly of the view that to override State legislation without first allowing the States the opportunity to participate in a truly co-operative arrangement would be unnecessarily heavy-handed. However, as I pointed out in my second reading speech:

. . . the Commonwealth expects the States and the Northern Territory to take action to amend or repeal legislation which offends human rights . . . The Government wishes to make it clear that if such action on the part of the States is not forthcoming, the Commonwealth reserves the right to enact specific overriding Commonwealth legislation and to extend the operation of the Bill of Rights to the States.

As to the honourable member's question about the number of votes required for the election of senators, he should be aware of the Constitutional requirement that each State have the same number of senators.
